HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Making Workfare Work: It Doesn't Come Cheap

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
IF the Giuliani administration is serious about putting able-bodied welfare recipients to work, the Mayor might want to take a close look at his neighbor downtown, the Port Authority. It has, in cooperation with the city and the state, employed people on welfare for about two years and by all reports, it has done so successfully.
But it takes time, money and effort. 
 At least 15 staff people at the authority devote some of their time to training and supervising the part-time employees -- 56 men and women at any given time who work on alternate weeks in about 30 clerical jobs. Participants -- 180 so far -- must pass two special screenings, first by the city's Human Resources Administration, then by the authority.
Those selected tend to be highly motivated -- people like Julio Blanco, an unemployed accounting graduate of Lehman College, who sees his clerical job as a route to permanent employment. "I think everybody who is able to work should work," says the 36-year-old Mr. Blanco, sounding like an advertisement for what is popularly called workfare -- working part time while receiving public assistance.
But even when dealing with a carefully chosen work force -- a luxury the city will not have -- the Port Authority has found that the program requires a major commitment. "It's a continual process," said Mario Argote, supervisor of employment programs. "They need constant feedback."
IT takes time and effort to teach computer skills or to convey the importance of reporting for work on time or to figure out how to give a needy worker a warm jacket without wounding the worker's pride.
"People have this simplistic notion: send 100,000 people into jobs, as if you can wake up some morning and do it," said Michael J. Dowling, the State Social Services Commissioner and originator of the New York State program. "The reality of what it takes to do this has to be appreciated. Otherwise it's going to confuse the public even more, and they're already confused."
Indeed, they are. Who would not be, with all the promises and plans heard over the years? The public even seems confused about basics. For instance, nobody is talking about putting the bulk of the welfare population to work -- those who receive Aid to Families With Dependent Children. In New York City, that numbers 846,000 people -- 545,000 children and 301,000 adults.
The Giuliani program would, by the end of next year, employ about 60,000 of the 244,000 men and women who receive Home Relief, a state program for poor people without children. They would work part time at jobs like cleaning parks. The city already employs 12,000 to 15,000 Home Relief recipients in workfare, and the idea is to expand on that.
Why isn't the number larger? One reason is opposition from unions, which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has already overcome in other matters. But difficulties with workfare go deeper; if they didn't, more welfare recipients would already be at work. The state said two years ago that every county should have half of all Home Relief recipients in work programs by now -- few do. Mayor Edward I. Koch had a workfare program. It didn't go very far.
"We floundered mainly because of the high cost of supervision," said Mr. Koch's former first deputy mayor, Stanley Brezenoff, now executive director of the Port Authority and the driving force behind the authority's modest program. "It is expensive."
THE Home Relief population runs the gamut from people who have lost their jobs to people with spotty employment records. Some abuse drugs or alcohol, some have never worked in a permanent job. Putting that population to work takes work, and money.
So far, the Giuliani administration has focused on saving money by reducing the welfare rolls. By assigning 270 people to do more intensive screening of applicants, City Hall hopes to weed out people ineligible for Home Relief because, for instance, they are secretly employed.
Such screening will help. It did in Westchester County, which runs a workfare program that Mayor Giuliani often cites as his model. But Westchester -- with about 8,000 people on Home Relief, or 3 percent of New York City's caseload -- does a lot more than screen. It refers people to drug and alcohol rehabilitation programs and provides training and education, which can lead to permanent jobs, that elusive goal of workfare.
Richard J. Schwartz, a senior adviser to the Mayor, says the city "would like" to provide the programs available in Westchester but has yet to devise them. "We have to see what kind of success we have, what kind of savings we can generate," he said. And the cost of supervision? That will be the responsibility of the city agencies to which the workers are assigned, Mr. Schwartz explained.
In other words, City Hall is not yet prepared to pay the price of the project it proposes.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Despite a Resurgence in Advertising, Newspaper Stocks Are Languishing

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
With advertising returning to newspapers in most parts of the country, much of the financial news for the American newspaper industry is good.
But the stock market does not seem to have noticed. The share prices of most big newspaper companies have remained listless recently. 
 Newspaper securities analysts say they are pleased by improved earnings at many of the companies, based partly on cost reductions and on the healthy volume of advertising that has returned to most large dailies because of the improving economy.
But those better financial results have not lifted stock prices. "You look at these numbers," said Kenneth T. Berents, director of research at Wheat, First, Butcher & Singer, "and you hit yourself in the head and say, 'Why aren't these stocks moving?' "
The answer, several analysts said, is that the languishing stock prices reflect long-term concerns about the future of the newspaper industry that are returning to the spotlight now that the advertising crisis of the last few years is receding.
Newspapers across the country are contending with sharp increases in the cost of newsprint, which represents a large portion of expenses at all newspapers. Those price increases are expected to eat into profits for several years.
Several analysts said the weak performance of newspaper stocks also probably reflected worries about the strength of the economy and the kinds of lasting concerns about the future that have haunted the newspaper industry for years. Those worries include increasing competition for advertising dollars from direct-mail companies and other new competitors, large-scale changes in the retailing business, declining readership and the uncertain place of the newspaper industry in the emerging world of electronic communications.
"The stock market is making a judgment that as an industry it may be very healthy in October of '94, but December '94, December '95 and December '96 are more important," said Lanny Baker, a newspaper securities analyst at Salomon Brothers. "And the belief is that while the companies are currently healthy that health may prove fleeting."
Newspaper stocks in recent years have not performed as well as the stock market over all, Mr. Baker said, and the shares of many big newspaper companies have been trading at prices far below their highs during the last year.
On Friday, for example, the stock of Knight-Ridder Inc. closed at $51.875 on the New York Stock Exchange, well under its 52-week high of $61.75. The Gannett Company closed at $49.75, down from a 52-week high of $59. On the American Stock Exchange, the stock of The New York Times Company closed at $22.25, compared with a 52-week high of $29.50.
Several analysts said the extremely rapid loss of newspaper advertising during the recession served to highlight newspapers' long-term vulnerabilities. In a sense, some of the analysts said, the velocity of the advertising plunge introduced a new sense of uncertainty in a business that has traditionally been known for stability and high profits.
Mr. Baker says the newspaper industry itself is not quite sure what the risks will be when advertising weakens the next time. That uncertainty, he said, is particularly unsettling because the cycles in the newspaper industry are occurring in the context of a mature business facing long-term downward trends.
Last week, Mr. Baker released an analysis of the share price performance of nine of the country's largest publicly owned newspaper companies. He compared their performance, adjusted for stock splits, with the Standard & Poor's Midcap 400 since just before the stock market collapse of 1987, when most newspapers were carrying more advertising than they ever had before.
Mr. Baker's analysis showed that as of last week the stock prices of four of the companies were lower than than they were on Oct. 16, 1987, just before the market collapse: Pulitzer Publishing was down 12 percent from 1987, Dow Jones & Company was 19 percent lower, Times Mirror was down 20 percent and The New York Times Company was 38 percent lower.
Even those newspaper companies that have seen their share prices climb back beyond 1987 levels have not kept pace with gains in other industries, according to Mr. Baker's analysis. The value of the Standard & Poor's 400 has risen 67 percent since 1987. Mr. Baker's figures showed that the average increase for the group of nine newspaper stocks since 1987 was 2 percent.
As of last week, the stock of Knight-Ridder was up 5 percent since 1987, the Washington Post Company up 8 percent, Gannett up 10 percent, the Tribune Company up 27 percent and A. H. Belo up 55 percent.
Some companies, like Tribune and A. H. Belo, that have had the best stock price performance over the last seven years, have decreased their reliance on the newspaper business through heavy investments in television stations and other businesses.
Analysts said some of the companies that have performed less well in the market were struggling with particular problems. The Times Mirror Company, for example, was affected especially strongly for several years by the weakness of the economy in Southern California, the base of its flagship paper, The Los Angeles Times. And analysts say The New York Times Company has been affected because newspaper advertising in New York City has not recovered as quickly as it has in other areas of the country where the Times Company also owns newspapers.
The highly localized nature of the newspaper business, some of the analysts said, makes the prospects different for each company depending on where its publications are situated. But one nationwide problem that is cooling newspaper stocks is the sharp increase in newsprint costs.
When the size of newspapers was smaller during the recession, paper mills took large losses because of the lower demand. Now that many mills are producing less and newspaper demand is rising sharply because newspapers are selling more advertising, the paper companies are making large price increases stick.
The average price of newsprint in February was $420 a metric ton, according to Pulp & Paper Week, atrade journal. That price was up to $510 by Oct. 1 and is expected to rise to $560 by December.
Larry Ross, an analyst of paper company securities at Paine Webber Group Inc., said he expected newsprint prices to continue to rise and remain high well into 1997. "Prices are just getting going," he said.
The paper mills, which took big losses for the last three or four years, have succeeded in imposing three price rises since the spring, said William J. Hee Jr., the director of purchasing for the Gannett Supply Corporation. "It is very hard to absorb three price rises in six months," Mr. Hee said. "You can't pass it on to your ad rates or your circulation that quickly."
Many newspaper companies own stakes in paper mills as a hedge against rising prices. When newsprint prices are low the companies take some losses from those operations, as they have for the last few years, but when newsprint prices rise they take some of the increased profits from the mills to offset the higher prices their newspapers must pay for newsprint.
But even for newspaper companies that have ownership interests in paper mills, the sharply rising newsprint prices are financially damaging. Tod A. Jacobs, the newspaper analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said that was because newsprint typically accounts for about 20 percent of all newspaper costs.
In 1993, for example, 301,000 metric tons of newsprint were required to produce the daily and Sunday New York Times, according to the company's spokeswoman, Nancy Nielsen.
The current poor performance of newspaper stocks, Mr. Jacobs said, is partly explained by the direct effect of high newsprint prices on profits. "This problem is out there," Mr. Jacobs said, "and it has a better chance of getting worse than getting better. Everybody is saying earnings estimates have a better chance of getting worse than getting better."
But perhaps the real significance of the rapidly rising cost of newsprint, Mr. Jacobs said, is that it shifts the focus of attention from a somewhat rosy present for newspapers back to the nagging concerns that have worried some analysts for a long time.
Projections concerning the health of the newspaper industry beyond the current recovery ultimately lead back to all the familiar issues that have hung over the industry for years.
"The farther you look out of the recovery," Mr. Jacobs said, "the closer you are to the real problems."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Some short- and long-term marriages are ending for companies and their agencies.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THREE advertisers are ending relationships with their agencies that ranged from almost two years to almost six decades on accounts with total billings estimated at $90 million to $110 million.
Trans World Airlines and Bates Worldwide in New York, which had worked together since January 1993, said they had mutually agreed not to renew their global advertising contract that expires at the end of December. Estimates of billings on the account of the beleaguered airline, which will change agencies for the third time in five years, ranged from $45 million to $60 million. 
 Mark Coleman, senior vice president for marketing at T.W.A., said in a statement Friday that the airline's recent relocation to St. Louis from Mount Kisco, N.Y., was the primary reason for parting with Bates.
"We feel strongly that where world-class service is available in our hometown, we should take advantage of it," he said, adding that an agency in St. Louis, which he did not identify, would be hired effective in January.
Last month, reports in trade publications identified that agency as the St. Louis office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, which has had negotiations with T.W.A. for more than a year.
Michael Draznin, a spokesman at the New York headquarters of D.M.B.& B., said Friday, "We have to go with 'no comment' right now."
Frank Assumma, president and chief executive of Bates USA, the United States agency of Bates Worldwide in New York, said in a memo to employees, "We should all be very proud of the outstanding work we did for the airline under some very difficult circumstances." His allusion was to T.W.A.'s severe financial problems that predated the agency's hiring and have continued. T.W.A. executives have presented creditors a restructuring proposal, warning that it would be replaced with a prepackaged bankruptcy filing if the creditors rejected it.
Bates was awarded T.W.A.'s account 19 months ago after a review that also included the incumbents, Avrett, Free & Ginsberg in New York and Groupe FCA in London. They succeeded Young & Rubicam New York on the account in 1990.
Bates's work for T.W.A. included a theme, "The most comfortable way to fly," and the introduction of Comfort Class service, which offered passengers more legroom after seats were removed from aircraft. Comfort Class helped T.W.A. win a designation as the best airline for flights longer than 500 miles in the J. D. Power & Associates 1994 domestic airline business traveler satisfaction study. But T.W.A. has retrenched on Comfort Class promotion as some seats were restored to planes to increase passenger counts and revenue.
In a second change, Cotter & Company in Chicago has named two agencies to share its True Value hardware stores account, which had been handled by McConnaughy Stein Schmidt Brown in Chicago for the last two years. Billings were estimated at $35 million to $40 million.
Leo Burnett U.S.A. in Chicago will handle True Value's national and international advertising, as well as media planning and buying. And Italia/Gal in Los Angeles will handle regional and local retail advertising, serving the account by opening an office in Chicago headed by Carmen Italia, president and creative director.
Chuck L. Kremers, Cotter's marketing director, said Friday that Burnett and Italia/Gal were awarded the account after a two-month review that was narrowed to them and one other finalist, the New York and Dallas offices of Publicis/Bloom with the Publicis/Bloom promotional shop, Frankel & Company in Chicago. A campaign is expected to begin early next year, he added.
In the ending of the longest relationship, Burnett and the Unocal Corporation said they had reached what they described as a "mutual and amicable" decision to part company after 56 years. As a result, Unocal has placed in review its account, with billings estimated at $8 million to $10 million.
"We've restructured our consumer operations to focus primarily on the West Coast," Cindy Hearn, marketing manager for Unocal in Los Angeles, said in a statement Friday, "and we feel it makes good business sense to shift to an agency that offers a similar geographic and market focus." Unocal operates more than 1,400 service stations in 5 Western states; it was at one time in 45 states.
James M. Jenness, group president for Leo Burnett North America, echoed Ms. Hearn. "Both companies agree Unocal's needs will be better served by a different agency," he said.
The relationship dates to 1938, when the agency was awarded the Pure Oil account and created a long-running campaign carrying the theme "Be sure with Pure." Unocal, which acquired Pure, consolidated the account at Burnett in 1969; four years later, Burnett introduced a popular "Spirit of 76" campaign tied to Unocal's Union 76 brand (renamed Unocal 76 in 1983).
Ms. Hearn said Unocal's review would include "a select group of California advertising agencies," but declined to identify them.

HEADLINE: STATISTICS REVEAL BULK OF NEW JOBS PAY OVER AVERAGE

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
The notion that Americans are working more for less pay is firmly embedded in public rhetoric. And it is practically gospel that the growing American economy cannot deliver the higher pay that American workers want.
No doubt many Americans are losing ground economically. But in fact most of the 5.5 million jobs the economy has added in the last two and a half years are in occupations that pay more, not less, than the average, which is now about $15.50 an hour. 
 This year alone, 72 percent of the 2.5 million new jobs have been for managers, from the chief executive to the branch sales manager, and for professionals, from surgeons and nurses to software programmers, accountants and high school teachers. And despite its reputation for low wages, the service sector is adding most of the higher-wage jobs.
As a result, average hourly pay for all employees, adjusted for inflation, is slowly rising, Government data show, not falling as so many politicians and commentators have been saying. Average hourly compensation, which includes health benefits, paid vacations, pensions and other benefits, is also rising, adjusted for inflation.
Indeed, average hourly pay has risen 2.5 percent in the early 1990's, about as much as it did throughout the entire 1980's.
"What's driving the average wage up is not so much an improvement for each individual worker but that the mix of jobs is improving," said David Wyss, an economist at DRI/ McGraw-Hill, a forecasting firm in Lexington, Mass. That is, the number of higher-paying new jobs is rising faster than the number of lower-paying ones.
Other factors -- bigger bonuses for executives and record amounts of time-and-a-half overtime pay for factory workers -- are also helping to push up pay.
To be sure, progress on the pay front has been extremely modest compared with that of the palmy 1960's or even the troubled 1970's. Another recession could wipe out some of the gains, at least temporarily. And the increase in average pay conceals a decline in the pay of many workers, especially those with little education or experience.
Indeed, even as average hourly pay and average family income have been edging higher lately, there is evidence that hourly pay of at least the bottom half of the work force -- those at the midpoint or below -- continues to slip. That may be one reason that median household income, as reported by the Census Bureau last week, has continued to stagnate after several years of economic recovery.
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, who is 4 feet 10 inches tall, likes to say by way of illustration that averaging his height with the 7 feet 1 inch height of the basketball star Shaquille O'Neal produces an average height of 6 feet. That, he argues, shows the limitations of using an average number at a time when the gap between high- and low-paid workers is widening sharply.
But the rising average shows that the economic pie for workers as a group is growing and that there are more good jobs to go around. And it suggests that millions of men and women -- in particular those with education and specialized skills -- are beginning to see benefits from the efficiency-minded reorganizations that have roiled Corporate America in the last few years.
This painful revamping, which spread from the factory floor to the service sectors in the last recession, continues to disrupt the lives of millions of workers and provoke anxiety for many more. But one result is that the average worker now produces about 6 percent more an hour than at the beginning of the decade. Many economists are optimistic that productivity, which ultimately determines how fast wages can grow in real terms, will grow somewhat faster in the 1990's than in the 80's.
And the group that is reaping the immediate benefits, while hardly a majority of workers, is nonetheless a fairly big one. Managers and professionals now count for one in four workers. Their ranks are double, 34 million against 17 million, that of the factory workers who are often cited as the typical American workers.
The data that show the turnaround in average hourly pay are the ones that the Government uses to construct its National Income and Product Accounts, which measure the economy's output. They come from the Labor Department and are more comprehensive than other, oft-cited measures. At least one of those measures -- the average pay for production and nonsupervisory workers -- suggests that average hourly pay has been falling more or less steadily for 20 years.
The broader national income measure is based on records supplied by companies. It captures all forms of pay, including fringe benefits and employee savings plans, which have become increasingly important, and covers the entire work force, not just part of it.
On the national income measure, average hourly pay for all workers climbed to $15.43 by mid-1994 from $13.44 in 1990. That is 2.5 percent more, after inflation. Over the same period, total hourly compensation, including fringes, edged up to $17.63 an hour from $15.09. That is a post-inflation gain of about 3.5 percent.
That might sound unimpressive. After all, in the golden 1960's hourly compensation rose by nearly 30 percent and in the troubled 1970's by almost 15 percent.
Still, the early 1990's compare favorably with the entire decade of the 1980's, which began with a steep recession and ended in an economic slowdown, when the average hourly wage rose just 3.2 percent after inflation and average hourly compensation rose 2.9 percent.
This trend does not support the impression that average hourly pay is sinking, emphasized in President Clinton's first State of the Union Message, in which he said, "For 20 years the wages of working people have been stagnant or declining."
The source of much of the improvement is the service sector, which is supposed to have been producing only low-wage jobs like hamburger flipping and baby-sitting.
Service companies -- from McDonald's to J. P. Morgan -- have dominated job creation in the economic expansion of the last three years, just as they did during the Reagan Administration years. But in an information-age economy that values skills, experience and education ever more highly, these companies have not been hiring just fast-food cooks, nurse's aides or cleaners.
More than two-thirds of the new jobs in the last several years have been in managerial and professional ranks, according to the Labor Department. Much of this new hiring is coming from health care, education, business services, banking, retailing and telecommunications.
Take Northfield Bank, a new community bank in a Chicago suburb that created 16 jobs -- including that of its chairman and president -- last year. Most of the jobs are for professionals, like lending officers, personal bankers and trainees. "So much of the check-processing and back-office operation is electronic now," said Eugene White, the chairman. "Fifteen years ago we would have needed 45 or 50 employees, many of them back-office people."
But now the 16 workers have a higher average pay than the 50 would have had a decade ago. Blair K. Robinson, the bank's president and chief executive, said, "We'd rather pay fewer people more money."
Outplacement counselors confirm that the demand is for people to fill higher-paying jobs. Lee Hecht Harrison, an outplacement firm in New York, says it is placing many of its clients in insurance, health care, entertainment and a host of professional firms from advertising agencies to accounting firms.
The new management jobs tend to be in high-growth fields, frequently at smaller firms where managers actually run businesses and develop new accounts rather than churning out reports for the next layer of bosses to read. "Nobody is adding layers of bureaucracy anymore," said Stephen Roach, an expert on the service economy at Morgan Stanley. "That's not changing."
It is the growing presence of managers and professionals in service companies, labor economists agree, that appears to be most responsible for pushing up the pay averages. Managers include everybody from the chief executive making seven figures to the former checkout clerk who oversees the local grocery store. They push up the average for all workers because they earn 60 percent more than the median wage for all private workers -- $635 a week against $394 -- and three times what people in low-paid fields like cafeteria work or cleaning earn. Professionals fare almost as well as managers.
The trend toward better jobs is hardly new -- the mix of jobs was improving in the 1980's, too -- but a recent Labor Department study suggests that the shift from lower-paying to higher-paying jobs may have accelerated. While managers and professionals accounted for three-fourths of the job growth in the last four years, they accounted for less than half over the 10 years from 1983 to 1993.
Even some leading economists seem a bit surprised by the recent trend. But they agree that it is happening.
"If you believe average productivity is growing," said Lawrence Katz, an economist at Harvard University and until recently the Labor Department's chief economist, "you have to believe that average compensation per hour has gone up."
If workers on average are producing more an hour, the extra income can go to only three groups: owners and investors, foreigners or American workers. Contrary to popular perception, stockholders' and other owners' share of national income has not budged in recent years and neither has foreigners'.
"Workers as a group are fully sharing in the economic gains," said Paul R. Krugman, an economist at Stanford University and author of "The Age of Diminished Expectations," a dour appraisal of the American economy since 1973. "That means there's something funny about numbers that suggest that the average real wage is declining."

HEADLINE: Ex-Soviet States Need All-Purpose Union;
Justified Fear of Russia

 BODY:
To the Editor:
How noble that Grigory A. Yavlinsky proposes a voluntary integration of Russia's neighbors as a counterweight to Russia's own neo-imperialist extremists like Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky (Op-Ed, Oct. 9). 
 By ignoring or certainly undermining the sovereignty of Ukraine, Moldova and others, Mr. Yavlinsky's "harmonized economic legislation" suggests a reformulation of a tortured past. To allay fears of neo-imperialism, Russia must stop defining itself along purely ethnic lines, falsely championing 25 million Russians in the "near abroad," and start acting like a civilized nation.
While Ukraine-Russia trade is natural, Mr. Yavlinsky's attempt to extract economic subservience for a "small price" hardly dispels the justified fear of neo-imperialism.
Ukraine's new President, for example, may finally be proceeding with much-needed reforms. His true course, and indeed Russia's, would be integration with the West.
Ukraine must proceed with prompt reforms, stabilization of currency, privatization, reasonable tax codes and a social safety net to fulfill the promise to its people, more than 90 percent of whom voted for independence from Moscow in 1991.
Mr. Yavlinsky and Mr. Zhirinovsky, though on opposite sides of the Russian political spectrum, would have Ukraine and others recolonized in one fashion or another. It is time for Russia to dispel its good-guy, bad-guy routine with the rest of the world.
 
JOSEPH MAZURYK
Danville, Calif., Oct. 12, 1994

HEADLINE: Restart the Rights Clock in Indonesia

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is having a hard time deciding whether to impose modest trade sanctions against Indonesia for denying workers their basic rights. First it demanded changes by February 1994. Then it let that deadline pass and dropped formal scrutiny of Indonesia's performance for six months. Now it seems ready to delay any action until after President Clinton visits Jakarta next month for the Asia-Pacific summit meeting.
Such protracted delay helps no one. The Administration should tell Indonesia now what it still needs to do and set a firm deadline for doing it. 
 As a low-income developing country, Indonesia is eligible for reduced tariffs on certain products through a program called the General System of Preferences, or G.S.P. About $900 million in Indonesian exports entered the U.S. under this program last year. But by U.S. law, countries benefiting from G.S.P. are required to take steps to accord their citizens internationally recognized labor rights.
In Indonesia's case that means getting the army out of labor disputes and letting workers form independent unions. As the February deadline approached, Indonesia promised Washington it would take meaningful steps in both areas. It has had eight months to put those promises into effect.
A U.S. investigative team recently visited Indonesia to assess compliance. Its findings are not yet available. Human rights groups report some progress, but say the military still interferes in labor matters and the Government is still trying to crush the main independent union. Last month, 28 members of Congress urged the Administration to revoke Indonesia's G.S.P. benefits.
But the G.S.P. debate is now taking place in a radically changed context. In May, the Clinton Administration dropped all human rights conditions on trade with China. As repressive as Indonesia's labor policies are, they are less harsh than Beijing's. In recent weeks, Commerce Secretary Ron Brown has called for expanding trade with China and Indonesia, ignoring human rights concerns.
The message is clear: Washington's human rights talk need not be taken seriously. If President Clinton wants to salvage any credibility on rights, he needs to modify that cynical message at once.
Withholding trade benefits is an appropriate tool for punishing labor abuses. Such abuses offend human rights and confer unfair trade advantages to the violator. In the case of G.S.P., upholding labor standards is required by law. But if the Administration sincerely believes that trade and development are the best ways to advance human rights, other forms of pressure are available.
These include outspoken diplomacy, votes in the U.N. human rights commission and restrictions on military training and sales for countries whose armed forces are involved in human rights abuse. The latest foreign aid bill specifically instructs U.S. representatives in multilateral development banks like the World Bank to take worker rights into account when they cast their votes.
Right now, the Clinton Administration seems at a loss over human rights policy. Renewing the pressure on Indonesia over labor rights could help it find its way again.

HEADLINE: Will Workfare Work?

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's plan to put able-bodied, childless New York City welfare recipients to work rings with optimism. The plan, his senior advisers say, will place idle enrollees in useful jobs, like cleaning parks and other public spaces, saving taxpayers $80 million a year.
Maybe so. But the record of "workfare" around the country has been uneven. Most workfare programs have been expensive to run and have rarely cut welfare rolls or eased recipients into private jobs. Mr. Giuliani points to a successful workfare program in Westchester County as the model for his proposal. Westchester's program is certainly worth looking at. Whether it can be replicated in New York City remains to be seen. 
 The notion of workfare is as old as welfare itself. The idea is to require able-bodied recipients to do something useful for taxpayers in return for cash assistance. Workfare programs can be expensive to run because it is always a lot cheaper to mail out checks than to supervise work. Moreover, studies by the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, reviewing experiments across the nation, conclude that workfare has not consistently cut welfare payments or led to employment and earning gains.
Even so, it is possible for taxpayers to come out ahead -- largely because enrollees are performing useful public work.
Westchester County's system suggests the necessary ingredients of a successful effort. Begun in 1989, it involves only the state welfare program known as Home Relief, which primarily caters to childless adults; Federal welfare recipients, who are usually mothers, would be far more difficult to place in jobs. The Westchester program has saved the county money because it emphasizes early detection and ongoing monitoring -- weeding out enrollees who are ineligible.
Further, by requiring enrollees to show up for public jobs, it drives away applicants who had been collecting welfare while holding jobs on the side. Together, careful surveillance and fraud detection have kept Westchester's welfare rolls from rising more than 1 percent in five years -- a remarkable statistic. Finally, the program's administrators have tried hard to identify specific projects for workfare enrollees to tackle, like cleaning out an abandoned school, and have supplied a steady stream of enrollees for supervisors to direct.
Some of New York City's Home Relief recipients are already in workfare. Mr. Giuliani's plan would eventually cover all able-bodied recipients and, like the Westchester program, emphasize early detection. But can it match Westchester's success? Westchester's economy is in better shape than New York City's, meaning a smaller welfare burden. The job skills of the city's Home Relief population are probably not as good. Westchester has had little trouble in quickly terminating enrollees who do not show up for work without an acceptable excuse. It is unlikely that New York City could so easily enforce its work rules.
But overwhelmingly, the biggest hurdle is size. Westchester handles about 2,500 enrollees a year; Mr. Giuliani talks about a universe of 80,000, with only 270 additional administrators. No state or local government in the country has figured out how to run a successful program on that scale.
The Giuliani administration is to be applauded for setting out an ambitious program to put Home Relief recipients to useful work, improving city services and saving money. It is well worth a vigorous effort. But it will not be easy.

HEADLINE: PULSE;
Teacher Salaries

 BODY:
Public-school teacher salaries in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have leveled off after rising faster than the rate of inflation earlier in the decade. Salaries rose as efforts to improve education focused attention on the problems of the nation's public schools. Teachers in the region are still among the best paid in the nation but tightening state budgets and contentious collective bargaining have held down pay raises. The region still devotes a greater share of its school budgets to teacher salaries compared with other parts of the country. Nationally, the share of school budgets that went for salaries was 52 percent in 1964; this year it was down to 39 percent.

HEADLINE: ISRAEL AND JORDAN SIGN DRAFT OF WIDE-RANGING PEACE TREATY

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan , Oct. 17

 BODY:
Israel and Jordan initialed a draft peace treaty today clearing the way for regular diplomatic relations, enhanced commerce and easier travel after 46 years of veering between warfare and uneasy coexistence.
The agreement, reached after torturous overnight negotiations, was the first major addition to the patchwork of Middle East peace since the agreement between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization last year. It was also the first peace agreement between Israel and an Arab nation since the treaty with Egypt in 1979. 
 While for more than 20 years Jordan and Israel had not fought openly and had sometimes seemed secretly cooperating neighbors, the agreement today maintained the momentum of peace efforts and shifted the diplomatic focus to Syria as the next neighboring country that could end its state of war with Israel.
The White House announced tonight that President Clinton had accepted an invitation to attend the formal signing ceremony for the treaty, scheduled for Oct. 26 in the border area between Eilat and Aqaba. King Hussein of Jordan and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel formally ended the state of war between Jordan and Israel in a ceremony at the White House in July, and Mr. Clinton praised the treaty today as "an extraordinary achievement."
Neither Israel nor Jordan released details of the treaty, and officials said annexes to a final agreement still had to be worked out.
But the Israeli radio reported that the deal involved an agreement by Israel to divert some 50 million cubic meters of water, or 13.2 billion gallons, a year to arid Jordan, where, as elsewhere in this region, water is almost as valuable a commodity as oil in maintaining economic viability. In addition, the two sides reportedly agreed to build dams on the Yarmuk and Jordan rivers later stage to increase water supplies to both countries.
The Israeli radio said the two sides had also reached a complex deal that would allow Jordan to reassert its sovereignty on a pocket of Israeli-occupied territory of 135 square miles along its southern border, but to lease about 11 square miles of it back to Israel.
The unusual arrangement could become a precedent for Israel's negotiations with Syria over the far more extensive and explosive issue of control over the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights, the central point of contention between Israel and President Hafez el-Assad of Syria.
In Amman today, though, both Israeli and Jordanian leaders -- beaming at each other from adjacent podiums -- seemed intent on underscoring the virtues of their agreement and the warmth of a relationship that is widely thought to have grown in secrecy when the two sides were not officially speaking.
"No one lost, no one won, we all won," Mr. Rabin said.
King Hussein said, "Between us, hopefully, it's a fresh beginning, a fresh start." The two leaders spoke at the ceremony in the Royal Guest Palace, where the treaty was initialed by Mr. Rabin and his Jordanian counterpart, Abdul-Salam al-Majali, with much mutual praise by the King and Mr. Rabin.
Israel's Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, later surprised many Jordanians by embracing the King and kissing him on both cheeks, a traditional form of Arab greeting.
Negotiated efforts to sign a peace treaty have been carried out steadily since Jordan signed its agreement with Israel in July to end a formal state of war that had endured for 46 years.
Until Sunday, however, there had been little indication that the negotiations, which started with the Madrid peace conference in 1991 after the end of the Persian Gulf war, were close to overcoming unresolved differences over water, territory and security issues.
Then, on Sunday night, Israelis learned that Mr. Rabin and Mr. Peres had flown to Amman, the Jordanian capital, after a week dominated in Israel by the abduction and killing of an Israeli soldier by Islamic militants.
The episode seemed to highlight the pressures on Israel's agreement with the P.L.O. from Palestinian militants. The urgency of the visit to Amman left the impression that Mr. Rabin was desperate to maintain the momentum of his overtures to Jordan as his agreement with the P.L.O. seemed to be running into challenges.
The initialing, however, did not represent the end of negotiations.
On Tuesday, officials from the two sides are to begin detailed talks on annexes to the treaty in the Jordanian Red Sea port of Aqaba. After that, the agreement needs approval by both Parliaments, which is regarded as a formality.
Of the outstanding issues, water was the most far-reaching.
According to Jordanian accounts, both Israel and Syria have progressively restricted Jordan's access to the water of the Jordan and Yarmuk Rivers, so that of an annual allotment of 477 million cubic meters a year foreseen in American-sponsored proposals in 1953, Jordan is now receiving none from the Jordan River and only about 100 million from the Yarmuk.
Israel's reported agreement to divert 50 million cubic meters a year to Jordan, presumably from the Sea of Galilee area, is thus a major economic boost for a country whose underground water supples are rapidly becoming exhausted. Jordan already rations water.
For Israel, the agreement involved a concession because it has long argued that there is too little water in the region to be shared, and that the only way to overcome the shortage in the long term is to tap new water sources.
The agreement on territory was less dramatic, though it seemed a novel approach to what has long been the central problem of the Middle East.
"Israel will return all occupied Jordanian territories with minor border ratifications carried out on a reciprocal basis," Prime Minister Majali said. The territorial arrangement does not affect the Israeli-occupied West Bank, once ruled by Jordan, because King Hussein relinquished legislative and administrative links to the territory in favor of the P.L.O. in 1988.
Jordan and Israel said they had agreed that the international boundary between their countries should follow, with small modifications, a British demarcation line between Jordan and British-mandated Palestine drawn up in 1922.
The Israeli radio said that Jordan had won back all the territory it had demanded, but that some would be "leased to Israel due to its importance" to farmers. Israeli officials said the amount was no more than about 11.5 square miles.
The agreement did not, however, please everyone.
Jordan's Islamic fundamentalists, following the example of those in Gaza and the occupied West Bank, vowed to oppose the agreement, saying it was against "everything Muslims and Arabs stand for and believe in." The Islamic opposition controls 16 of the 80 seats in the lower house of the Jordanian Parliament and cannot alone block its ratification.
In Israel, Likud opposition officials questioned the haste with which the agreement had been reached. "Always there are concerns, especially when I see the hurry," said former Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.
A further source of opposition could be the P.L.O., which has historically vied with King Hussein to represent Palestinians and, in recent years, has competed with Jordan to secure advantage from peace efforts with Israel.
 
Clinton Hails Peace Accord
 WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (Special to The New York Times) -- President Clinton hailed the peace accord between Israel and Jordan today, and the White House said Mr. Clinton would fly to the Middle East next week to witness a signing ceremony on the two countries' border.
The journey will require Mr. Clinton to cancel or reschedule several appearances intended to shore up his party's prospects for the midterm elections. But aides to the President said he had concluded that his attendance would send a strong message about the importance of the peace effort to the United States, and some of them also suggested that it would call Americans' attention to a foreign policy success.
Before flying from Washington to New Mexico for a daylong trip, , Mr. Clinton offered effusive praise to Prime Minister Rabin and King Hussein. "The United States has stood by them and worked with them, and we will stand by them every step of the way," the President said.
Aboard Air Force One, Mr. Clinton then took a long-distance telephone call from the two leaders, who invited him to attend the signing of the accord. A senior Administration official said the President had decided to accept by the time he climbed back aboard his plane for the trip back to Washington tonight.
The decision, which officials said followed a sharp debate among his advisers, means that Mr. Clinton will interrupt a heavy schedule of campaigning for Democratic candidates to fly to Israel, Jordan and perhaps also to Kuwait, where he would visit American soldiers.

Map/Diagram: "WATER RESOURCES: Reducing a Tug of War Over a Precious Resource"
 
Sources
 Israel, the occupied territories, Jordan, Lebanon and Syria rely variously on water from rivers and their tributaies and wells that draw on underground aquifers, as well as desalted water from the Mediterranean and other seas.
 
Yesterday's agreement
 Israel and Jordan initialed a peace agreement yesterday that ended years of conflict and provided for changes in water alotment in the region.
 
History
 The Eisenhower Administration negotiated an agreement in 1953 among Israel, Jordan, Lebanon and Syria on allocation of water from the Jordan and Yarmuk Rivers, but it was never ratified. Israel captured the Golan Heights and West Bank in 1967, gaining control of most of the Jordan River basin.
 
Consumption
 Water consumption varies sharply in the region. The agreement yesterday provides for Israel to divert some 50 million cubic meters, or 13.2 billion gallons, of water a year to arid Jordan. (One cubic meter equals 264 gallons.)

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE PRESIDENT;
A Sermon on Child Neglect and Crime

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 17

 BODY:
President Clinton flew west today to give a speech to police chiefs about crime. But by its end, he had instead spun an angry sermon on the nation's duty to a generation of children whose hearts, he said, were being "turned to stone" by violence and neglect.
Asked if the President had strayed from his prepared text, the White House press secretary, Dee Dee Myers, replied, "He sure did." 
 But hardly anyone seemed displeased by the digression, which showcased Mr. Clinton in the role he plays best: a preacher, speaking with undisguised passion on an issue that engages him.
After concluding a speech devoted largely to recent Federal anti-crime legislation, Mr. Clinton finally said the words, "I'd like to end today." But he did not. Instead, expanding on a theme he had made early in his speech, that "random violence among young people, people under the age of 18, is going up dramatically in sickening ways," the President spoke without notes for perhaps 10 minutes more.
"You now have the tools to deal with this problem," he said to the chiefs, referring to the anti-crime bill, "but you've got a whole country out there full of people who have to help. Parents have to recognize that the real war on crime begins at home. If the first responsibility of government is to provide law and order, the first responsibility of parents is to teach right from wrong."
Recalling recent news accounts of a 5-year-old boy in Chicago who was pushed to his death by two 10-year-olds because he had refused to steal candy for them, the President wondered aloud how young children could become so cold-hearted, and then he answered his own question.
"Kids are going to look up to somebody, and it's up to the adults in this country to decide who they're going to look up to," he said. The 5-year-old looked up to parents who had taught him the difference between right and wrong, Mr. Clinton said, but "who did the other two kids look up to? Who did they come in contact with who could have taught them right from wrong, and didn't?"
"What about that little kid who was set on fire?" he asked, referring to a report that two children, ages 10 and 11, had been convicted of dousing a toddler with gasoline and setting him afire. "Who taught those children right from wrong?"
The President said children learned such horrific behavior from adults.
"These kids are looking up to somebody," he said. "Who are they going to look up to? How are they going to learn this? We can hire five million police officers. And if we keep losing the battle for what these kids think is right and wrong, we're going to be in a lot of trouble."
The nation need not worry, Mr. Clinton said, if it rolls up its sleeves and sets about saving its young people.
"But what we must be worried about is wave upon wave upon wave of these little children, who don't have somebody both good and strong to look up to, who are so vulnerable that their hearts can be turned to stone by the time they're 10 or 11 years old. And when there is a good one -- a 5- or 10-year-old kid in difficult circumstances, blooming like a flower in the desert, knowing that it's wrong to steal candy -- he actually has his life at risk."
The White House says that the issue of adults' responsibility to children is a favorite of the President, and he has touched on it from time to time, most recently in speeches to black ministers in New Orleans last month and at a black church outside Washington this summer.
But Mr. Clinton has been looking for a chance to emphasize that the issue is not confined to one slice of the population, and today he found it.
Although crime is the top domestic issue in this campaign season, the White House officially called Mr. Clinton's appearance at the annual meeting of the International Association of Chiefs of Police nonpolitical. In his prepared remarks, the President talked about the $30 billion anticrime legislation's provisions to help finance the hiring of 100,000 new officers and the construction of 100,000 prison cells in the next six years; about its "three strikes" provision that imprisons some violent offenders for life after a third conviction, and about its bevy of new death-penalty offenses and prevention programs for young people at risk of becoming criminals.
He also mentioned that "in this election season there are many who are campaigning on a 'Contract with America,' " and they, he said, could "indirectly" derail his efforts against crime by rendering the Government too broke to pay for it. The many are about 300 Republican candidates for Congress whose self-described contract effectively pledges to return the nation to the economic policies of the Reagan Administration, like tax cuts, increased military spending and the balancing of the Federal budget.
Mr. Clinton also restated several points he had made in campaign speeches this fall, reminding the police chiefs that he had cut the Federal work force, streamlined Federal purchasing rules, helped bring peace to Haiti, Northern Ireland, the Middle East and Eastern Europe and had persuaded the Russians to point their nuclear missiles somewhere other than the United States.
Mr. Clinton's extemporaneous remarks were met with applause from the police chiefs, who, as he has noted, support many of the programs in the crime legislation that intended to keep youngsters out of trouble.
Mr. Clinton also brought the chiefs a present, a new $226 million program that would help large departments start recruiting and hiring new officers before the bulk of the Federal grants under the crime bill begin flowing to them.
A related initiative announced today would allow small police departments to seek grants for new officers by way of a short form that asks only the most basic information about the department, like its size and the starting salary of an officer.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "The first responsibility of government is to provide law and order," President Clinton said in extemporaneous remarks yesterday, but "the first responsibility of parents is to teach right from wrong." Mr. Clinton spoke in Albuquerque, N.M., at a meeting of the International Association of Chiefs of Police. (Eliza Wells Smith for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE ECONOMY;
Democrats Getting No Lift From a Rising Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, Oct. 13

 BODY:
The politics in Tennessee epitomizes one of the paradoxes of this unusual election year: The economy is thriving, but President Clinton and the Democrats who support his economic program are getting no credit for it.
The economy here is the strongest in the state's history. The unemployment rate, 4.7 percent in August, is well below the national rate. More than 80,000 new jobs were created last year alone, and the economic research center at the University of Tennessee is forecasting 130,000 more by the end of next year. 
 An analysis last month in The Memphis Business Journal began this way: "As the state enters the middle 1990's, it finds itself riding a wave of economic success that is the envy of much of the nation."
But although Mr. Clinton and his Tennessee running mate, Al Gore, carried the state in 1992, in large measure because of hopes that Mr. Clinton could invigorate the economy, nearly two-thirds of Tennesseans questioned in a recent poll said they disapproved of his performance in office.
Of more immediate significance, Senator Jim Sasser, who as chairman of the Budget Committee was instrumental in getting the Clinton program enacted last year, is running about even with a Republican challenger who has never before run for public office.
The Republican, William Frist, is a wealthy 42-year-old heart and lung surgeon whose family started the Hospital Corporation of America and who first registered to vote six years ago.
Mr. Sasser, who is trying for his fourth term and stands a good chance of becoming the Senate Democratic leader if he is re-elected, does not even mention the economy in his television advertisements or campaign speeches. He concentrates instead on his advocacy of tough measures against crime and illegal immigration, his support for prayer in public schools and his potential to use his seniority to bring Federal projects into the state.
The situation in Tennessee -- and in the rest of the country -- runs counter to one of the conventional tenets of American politics: that a healthy economy is good for incumbents.
"If two years ago, you had said the '94 election would take place in a time of widespread recovery and declining unemployment, I would have predicted great times for Clinton and the Democrats," said Geoffrey Garin, a veteran pollster who is working for the Sasser campaign. "And that is especially true in Tennessee, because the economy is so very strong."
But for the President, Senator Sasser and their allies, these are anything but great times. "The President's held in very low regard around here," Mr. Sasser said. Asked why he does not talk more about the economy, the Senator replied, "We don't feel that resonates."
There are many explanations for why Tennessee's prosperity is not helping the Democrats, but one seems overriding. When voters feel secure in their jobs, they are free to fret about other matters -- like Mr. Clinton's character and Mr. Sasser's longevity in Washington.
No one seriously argues that the Clinton policies are largely responsible for the strength of the Tennessee economy. Many other factors, including the state's central geographic position, its low taxes and its low labor costs, have been much more important.
But the prevailing view of economists and other authorities here is that the Clinton Administration's policies have worked very much to the state's economic advantage, particularly the President's deficit-reduction program, his willingness to waive Federal regulations so the state can adopt a new health insurance system that promises to lower the cost to businesses, and his advocacy of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
In part because of the promise of Nafta, for example, exports to Mexico from Tennessee increased almost 150 percent from 1991 to 1993.
"Everybody should be proud of Clinton's economic program," said Gov. Ned McWherter, a popular Democrat who is retiring this year after two terms in which he concentrated on improving the state's business climate. "There is no question it's helping our economy."
But across the state, Tennesseans who themselves are doing very well hardly express such pride.
Mike Kitzmiller, a Cadillac dealer in Nashville who said his own business was the best it had ever been, expressed what seemed to be the public consensus. "The Federal Government," he said, "doesn't have a damn thing to do with the economy of Tennessee."
Dr. Frist, a tireless campaigner who seems prepared to spend a sizable amount of his own money on the race, is basing his campaign on his belief that most Tennesseans agree.
Speaking of Mr. Clinton and Mr. Sasser, Dr. Frist said, "The economy has gotten better on their watch; I'll grant them that." But much more important, he said, was this: "People are mad at the present direction of the country. People are mad at welfare. They see help-wanted signs up all over Tennessee. And they are mad that people can make more money on public assistance."
Senator Sasser's problem, Dr. Frist said in an interview, is that he has been in Washington so long that he has lost touch with Tennessee.
A poll taken over the Columbus Day weekend by Mason-Dixon Opinion Research for several of the state's newspapers and television stations showed Mr. Sasser leading Dr. Frist 43 percent to 40 percent, with 6 percent favoring an independent candidate and 11 percent undecided. The difference was within the poll's four-point margin of sampling error.
In the race for the other Senate seat, the one vacated by Mr. Gore when he became Vice President, the poll showed that the Republican candidate, Fred Dalton Thompson, had opened a slight lead. Mr. Thompson, a lawyer, lobbyist and part-time actor, regularly criticizes his Democratic opponent, Representative Jim Cooper, for having voted last year for the Clinton deficit-reduction bill.
Mr. Cooper is doing everything he can to distance himself from the President. He emphasizes that he was one of only six Democrats to vote for a Republican alternative to the Clinton budget that supposedly would have reduced the deficit somewhat less but without raising taxes. Mr. Cooper voted for the Clinton plan, he said, only as a last resort after the Republican measure failed.
"The public has a good reason to be upset with the direction our country is headed in over all," Mr. Cooper said in an interview. "The prosperity may not last."
That is not the view of economists who follow what is happening in Tennessee. "The way I see it, we are settling in for a period of moderate, sustainable growth," said Andrew Krikelas, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, who pays close attention to Tennessee.
But voters in this state, as in most of the rest of the country, seem inclined this year to focus on what is wrong rather than what is right.
"When the economy is bad, then people worry about their jobs," said Jeff Clark, a professor at Middle Tennessee State University who keeps track of public opinion polls in the state. "But when everybody has a job, then the economy is not their main concern."
National polls underscore that view. In January 1993, the month Mr. Clinton took office, the national unemployment rate was 7.1 percent. A New York Times/CBS News Poll found that 44 percent of those questioned said the economy was the country's most serious problem.
By last month, with the national unemployment rate standing at 5.9 percent, a four-year low, only 15 percent said the economy was the most serious problem, well behind crime.
Nowhere is this phenomenon more apparent than in Nashville, one of the nation's boom cities. The unemployment rate here is only 3.2 percent, and those out of work are mostly unemployed briefly between jobs. "Anyone who wants a job here can have one," said Marguerite Sallee, chairwoman of the Nashville Chamber of Commerce.
But when people in business here talk about politics, they do not think of the economy but about "their disappointment in Clinton's leadership," Ms. Sallee said.
Howard H. Baker Jr., the former Senate Republican leader who now practices law in Knoxville, put the situation more in terms of the politics of a midterm election. "The Clinton drag is substantial," he said. Expressing a view held by politicians here from both parties, Mr. Baker added: "The drag is based on character, not issues. People decided they didn't trust him, and that seems to override the economy, world peace, everything."
As for Senator Sasser, he had a set of charts emphasizing the strength of the economy that he used in speeches around the state early this year. But he abandoned the charts and the speeches about the economy several months ago. "There just wasn't much energy in that approach," he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Payments to Haiti Will Help Ex-Military Find New Jobs

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
The United States will give Haiti $216 million during the coming year, some of which will be used to provide jobs for members of the widely hated armed forces, a Clinton Administration official said today.
The Clinton Administration has agreed to President Jean-Bertrand Aristide's request to pay the salaries of soldiers not chosen for a new, 1,500-member Haitian military, and ultimately to provide them with other jobs, said Brian Atwood, administrator of the United States Agency for International Development. 
 Under Father Aristide's economic reconstruction program, jobs will be guaranteed to members of the armed forces, many of whom are reviled by the population.
Mr. Atwood called the support for individual soldiers "a very delicate program" that was controversial but preferable to letting them go without compensation. "We don't want them to go back and pick up arms and go into the hills," he said. "We have to pull the teeth from this dragon."
The $216 million in United States assistance also includes $32 million for development of local police forces to replace the combined 7,000-member military police force that is to be dismantled.
The American program is the largest share of the $550 million that the World Bank estimated Haiti would need this year. The rest will come from international lending institutions and other donor nations.
The United States is providing $42.2 million to feed 1.3 million people and to provide health care. Other American aid will go to: helping prepare for elections, $11.3 million; reforming the justice system, $7.5 million; local governance and other social and democratic assistance, $15.7 million; helping protect the currency against instability caused by a trade deficit, $45 million; contributing to Haiti's international debt payment, $25 million, and providing emergency economic recovery aid, $17.3 million.
Mr. Atwood said the American funds would also provide 900,000 textbooks and other school supplies, pay for a large-scale child immunization program and go toward reversing soil erosion and deforestation that has left much of Haiti's land in too poor a condition to farm.
The financial infusion is designed to make the biggest impact in the next four months. American aid to Haiti is expected to drop off to $90 million in the second year, Mr. Atwood said.
Under the military program, for which $5 million has been allocated, the records of the current Haitian armed forces will be reviewed to see which members are acceptable for the new military, Mr. Atwood said. During the time the review takes, the United States will pay the salaries of the current force. Members who are not accepted into the new military will be helped by United States-funded jobs programs, which are expected to employ 50,000 Haitians overall, Mr. Atwood said.

HEADLINE: THREATS IN THE GULF: IN MOSCOW;
Russians Make Their Voice Heard

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Inevitably, there were handshakes and smiles all around today in New York as the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, met his American counterpart, Warren M. Christopher.
But after a week of not-so-private squabbling over Mr. Kozyrev's trip to Baghdad and his possible deal with the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, the Americans are being polite through clenched teeth. They are trying to insure that Russia's intervention, and its efforts to get the United Nations oil embargo on Iraq lifted after a six-month "trial period," do not get in the way of Washington's policy. 
 But Mr. Kozyrev has already achieved a goal as important to Moscow as any Iraqi deal. He has got the world's attention, insuring once more, as in Bosnia, that Russia's voice and views get the hearing Moscow thinks it deserves as a nuclear superpower with global interests.
Part of the American difficulty is the desire not to offend Russia and President Boris N. Yeltsin, whose authority can seem shaky from time to time and whose main challenge comes from ultranationalists eager to see slights to Russia. American officials understand that displays of independence by the Russians do Mr. Yeltsin good, but the Americans rarely pretend to like it.
In a similar way, the Bush Administration tried to be polite as Mikhail S. Gorbachev, already teetering, made last-minute efforts to avoid the 1991 Persian Gulf War, the last time Moscow tried high-profile Mideast diplomacy.
The difficulty for Washington today is that in Iraq, as in Bosnia, the Russians do not really stand alone. Their position is not very far from that of other Security Council members, in this case, France, China, and to some degree, Britain, all of which want to restore economic, energy and trade ties to Iraq and avoid an American attack.
The United States has come to a grudging appreciation for Russian efforts in the former Yugoslavia, but Russian officials say privately that Washington regards the Iraq-Kuwait problem as an "American show," despite efforts at preserving a "United Nations umbrella."
Saturday night provided a good example of the tensions. The Americans forced a Security Council vote on a resolution demanding that Iraq pull its troops back from the Kuwaiti border and not threaten its neighbors again. The Russians vainly asked for a delay, so Mr. Kozyrev could report in person on his Middle East trip, but then voted for the resolution anyway.
Russia has been calling for a relaxation of the United Nations embargo on Iraq for some time, in part because it is short of cash and is owed some $10 billion by Baghdad for equipment, arms and old loans. Moscow is also eager to to sell new oil-drilling equipment to Iraq, to help rebuild the country and to resupply Baghdad's mostly Soviet-equipped military.
But Moscow's commercial ambitions are shared by other countries, including France, Britain, China, Turkey, Japan and Germany, which was Iraq's largest source of imports before sanctions were imposed in 1990.
In fact, as Mr. Hussein was sending troops to the Kuwaiti border, the Iraqi Oil Minister was in Moscow to discuss a potential $2.5 billion in contracts with Russia's two largest oil companies, Lukoil and Rosneft. The pro-Yeltsin newspaper Izvestia cautioned Russian officials not to be hasty, given that Mr. Hussein's fate is unclear and that his successors might not appreciate Moscow's zeal, and then Russia would not get its money back anyway.
But the newspaper Kuranty saw clear gains for Russia and its interests in trying to gingerly take Baghdad's point of view. "We have room for maneuver," the paper wrote. "Given the right approach, Russia, a 'regional power,' may make its way through an opening too narrow for the broad-shouldered diplomats of a superpower."
Last week in Baghdad, Mr. Kozyrev declared a breakthrough, saying Iraq had agreed to recognize Kuwait and its borders. Mr. Kozyrev said there were no conditions, but promised renewed efforts by Moscow to convince the United Nations to lift sanctions after a six-month test. Mr. Kozyrev has said that to prolong the embargoes when Iraq is in compliance is not justice but a form of "revenge."
Kuwaiti officials were cool, bluntly demanding concrete assurances that their sovereignty and borders would be recognized and protected. And Washington rejected the idea, wanting to separate Iraqi troop withdrawals entirely from the issue of sanctions.
But there has been growing pressure, not only from Russia, to ease the embargoes on Iraq. Russian officials admit that differences between Washington and its other Western allies give Moscow more room for diplomacy.
Similarly, in the former Yugoslavia, Russia's efforts to drag its putative allies and Slavic brothers, the Serbs, into some kind of peace agreement found support from France and Britain, whose troops are on the ground with the United Nations and could be the first to suffer in a renewed, full-scale conflict.
After much annoyance in Washington, including a series of Russian complaints about not being fully consulted or informed, the Clinton Administration decided that on balance Moscow's intervention in the former Yugoslavia was beneficial, even crucial. The two countries have tried, with mixed success, to talk tough to the two sides but in tandem.
Whenever President Clinton has come close to a unilateral lifting of the arms embargo against the Bosnian Muslims, as Congress wants but the rest of the Security Council does not, Russia has helped to dissuade him, or at least to provide him a justification for not lifting it. And for that Moscow has already earned the gratitude of London and Paris.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices Accept Case Testing the Reach of a Racketeering Law

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
The Government's effort to convict a former Federal prosecutor for using drug trafficking proceeds to mine gold in Alaska presented the Supreme Court today with an important legal question: when does an activity have a sufficient connection with interstate commerce to justify prosecution under the Federal racketeering law?
A Federal appeals court earlier this year threw out the former Government lawyer's conviction under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act on the ground that the gold produced by the mine was not sold outside Alaska and that the Government had not proved that the operation had more than a minimal or incidental effect on interstate commerce. 
 The Justices agreed today to hear the prosecution's appeal, in which the Government argued that the appeals court had set so stringent a definition of interstate commerce as to cast doubt on the usefulness of other Federal laws ranging from consumer protection to civil rights, as well as other criminal laws. Like the racketeering law, usually known as RICO, numerous other laws limit Federal jurisdiction to activities that affect interstate commerce.
Most courts have interpreted this requirement in a way that is easy for the Government to satisfy; a company whose executives travel, or that orders supplies and equipment from another state, easily meets the test.
For instance, in a RICO case five years ago, involving the theft of police department examinations, Justice Stephen G. Breyer, then a judge on the Federal appeals court in Boston, ruled that jurisdiction could be based on factors like the use of out-of-state consultants and the replacement of locks on doors with new locks shipped to Massachusetts from Pennsylvania.
But in the gold-mining case, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, refused to accept as a basis for jurisdiction the fact that the defendant hired employees and bought supplies from other states and flew in and out of Alaska in a plane he bought for that purpose. "Given that Alaska is fairly isolated," the appeals court said, businesses there obtain many supplies from elsewhere but should not for that reason alone be seen as operating in interstate commerce.
In its appeal, U.S. v. Robertson, No. 94-251, the Government told the Supreme Court that the Ninth Circuit was alone among the Federal appeals courts in refusing to accept the movement of people or supplies across state lines as adequate for jurisdiction in a RICO prosecution.
The defendant in this case, Juan Paul Robertson, became a criminal defense lawyer after serving as an Assistant United States Attorney in Los Angeles. He became a drug dealer, and his conviction for cocaine dealing was upheld in an aspect of the case that did not involve the racketeering law. He stole a client's car after the client told him that there were two kilograms of cocaine and $980,000 in cash in the trunk. Mr. Robertson used this and other drug money to finance his gold-mining operation.
Since the days of the New Deal, courts have generally defined interstate commerce broadly enough to validate the Federal Government's regulatory or prosecutorial efforts, and it is unusual for the Government to lose a case on this basis. This is the second interstate commerce case the Court has accepted for review this term.
The other case is a Government appeal from a ruling that struck down a 1990 law that prohibits the possession of a gun within 1,000 feet of a school. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, found that the law was beyond the power of Congress to enact because there was no requirement that the gun had traveled in interstate commerce. That case, U.S. v. Lopez, will be argued next month.
There were also these developments at the Court today.
 
Randall Terry's Appeal
 Without comment, the Court turned down an appeal by Randall Terry, the leader of the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue, from a conviction for criminal contempt of court. During the 1992 Democratic National Convention in New York, Mr. Terry defied a Federal court injunction and arranged for a follower to confront Bill Clinton, then the Governor of Arkansas, and thrust at him a plastic container holding a human fetus.
Mr. Terry, who took credit for the incident and received a five-month jail term, challenged his conviction on the ground that Robert Abrams, then the New York State Attorney General, should not have been permitted to prosecute the case in Federal court. Mr. Abrams was appointed to handle the case after the Federal prosecutor in New York, Otto G. Obermaier, asked to be excused on the basis of the Bush Administration's view that Federal courts lacked authority to issue injunctions against anti-abortion protests. The case was Terry v. U.S., No.94-141.
 
Airport Limits
 The Court also turned down an appeal by Kansas that challenged the Wright Amendment, a Federal law limiting airline service at Love Field, an airport in Dallas. The law, enacted in 1979 to steer passengers to the more distant Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport, prohibits direct service into Love Field from any place beyond Texas and its four immediate neighbors -- Louisiana, Arkansas, Oklahoma and New Mexico.
Passengers from beyond those four states who want to fly into Love Field must change planes at an airport in one of the contiguous states, buy separate tickets for each leg of the trip, and may not check their baggage through to their final destination. In addition, airlines and travel agents may not advertise connections through Love Field.
The law was challenged by a group of Kansas passengers and by the State, which argued that the law amounted to an "air blockade" of Kansas that shut the state out of "an airport of tremendous economic importance" to the region. The State's arguments, based on the constitutional right to travel, the First Amendment and other grounds, failed in the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. The case was Kansas v. U.S., No. 93-2018.
