HEADLINE: Markets Opened By Mexico

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Taking a final step to open Mexico's financial markets to the world, the Government announced tonight that it would allow 46 foreign banks, securities firms and insurance companies to begin operations here.
The Minister of Finance, Pedro Aspe Armella, said the foreign companies that gained places in the growing Mexican financial-services market were expected to start doing business here by next June. 
 Though the Government did not act on 50 pending applications to set up mutual funds and other kinds of financial enterprises, it sanctioned nearly all the banks, brokerage firms and insurance companies that applied. It also approved the creation of five financial groups and a leasing company.
The welcoming to banks like J. P. Morgan, Citibank and Chemical Banking represents a milestone in the economic restructuring begun in 1985 and expanded under the six-year Administration of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who is to leave office on Dec. 1.
Only a dozen years ago, having defaulted on its foreign debt, the Government nationalized 18 of the country's 20 banks, helping to plunge the economy into six years of inflationary chaos. The opening of Mexico's financial industry was considered a big victory for the United States in negotiations for the North American Free Trade Agreement.
What would have been unthinkable not so long ago, however, is unlikely to have striking effects now. Because foreign bankers and brokers are expected to focus their business somewhat narrowly and will be limited in the market share they can gain, many analysts believe competition will increase only gradually.
"This is certainly going to have an impact," the deputy Finance Secretary in charge of banking, Guillermo Ortiz Martinez, said tonight. "I don't think it is going to have a dramatic impact or one that happens overnight. But it will certainly contribute to greater competition and lower margins."
Mr. Aspe said the foreign financial companies would bring Mexico $1.2 billion in direct foreign investment. Despite the trade agreement's implementation in January, new foreign investment in Mexico this year had totaled a somewhat disappointing $8.9 billion as of the end of August, compared with $15.6 billion for all of 1993.
"It's a vote of confidence for the Government that all these companies are willing to put up the money to come and start an office," said Stefano Natella, the director of Latin American research at CS First Boston in New York.
"But from a business point of view, I'm not so sure," he added. "Is there a lot of business that these companies are going to be able to do now that they were not able to do before? In some sectors, competition is already extremely brisk."
Under the terms of the trade accord, American and Canadian banks and brokerages are to receive the same treatment from the Government as their local competitors. To attract more investors, the Salinas Administration extended that protection to other foreign applicants.
The significant catch is that each foreign bank will be restricted in the amount of risk assets that they may bring to Mexico; none can gain more than a 1.5 percent share of the market. As a whole, foreign brokerages are limited to a 10 percent market share. Foreign banks may have only 8 percent of the market this year, with the figure rising to 15 percent by 2000. Thereafter, the Government can restrain their business if the figure rises above 25 percent.
The 18 commercial banks that were approved from an initial list of 20 foreign applicants are expected to concentrate on sophisticated, high-return products like corporate lending, advisory services, securitizations and derivatives contracts.
Their prospective clients are Mexico's biggest industrial and service companies, some of which are already borrowing money in the United States. And they are hardly catching the strongest Mexican banks off-guard: For instance, Grupo Financiero Banamex-Accival, the owner of the country's largest bank, Banco Nacional de Mexico, has already entered into one strategic alliance with Swiss Bank for derivatives products, and another with Bank One of Columbus, Ohio, for credit cards.
Government officials argue that the advent of so many new participants will help to lower Mexico's high interest rates. But some analysts said they were not so sure.
"These banks are mainly going to be competing with the handful of Mexican banks that do investment banking and have an international presence," said Laura Z. Berdeja, senior banking analyst at the Mexico City branch of Baring Securities. "There is not much more that rates can come down on the corporate side. There, we are already very close to international standards."
Similarly, business is unlikely to undergo radical change at the 16 approved securities firms, which include American companies like Merrill Lynch, Lehman Brothers and Goldman, Sachs, as well as Europeans like James Capel and Baring.
"For the U.S. houses that already have significant trading activity in Mexican stocks in New York, most of what there will be is a moving of that activity to Mexico," said Justin Manson, who will open a brokerage for Morgan Stanley. "You will have a physical presence. You're much closer to what's going on." Other United States financial companies that received permission to operate in Mexico include American Express, Chase Manhattan, Bankers Trust, Bank of America, Bear Stearns, Reliance National Insurance, American Bankers Insurance and Windsor Insurance.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
TRAVELERS INC. (TRV,N)

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Travelers Inc. said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 28 percent as increased revenue from its consumer-lending and insurance businesses offset declines at Smith Barney, its brokerage firm.
Net income rose to $331.3 million, or 97 cents a share, compared with $258.7 million, or $1.03 a share, in 1993, which was a third-quarter record. However, earnings per share fell because the number of shares increased 31 percent. 
 The results were below analysts' expectations of $1.01 a share, according to Zacks Investment Research. "It's not that bad," a Salomon Brothers analyst, Thomas Facciola, said.
The results at Travelers, one of the largest financial-services companies, reflect the national economy to a degree. As the economy improves, Americans are borrowing and spending more often. That increased activity has hurt securities firms by prompting the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to slow inflation or to ward off perceptions of future inflation.
The 1993 results include only the former Primerica Corporation, which merged with the Travelers Corporation at the end of last year and renamed itself Travelers Inc.
Travelers' consumer-finance division made $59.4 million, up 10 percent. Life insurance operations almost tripled to $148.3 million. And the property- and casualty-insurance division's earnings rose 62 percent, to $381.2 million.
But earnings at Smith Barney fell 39 percent, to $72.9 million, Travelers said, reflecting the difficult securities markets and increased expenses related to the addition of Shearson on July 31, 1993.
In recent months, Smith Barney has cut expenses by paring about 75 members of its capital-market group, which includes traders and investment bankers.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 13.46 in a Blue-Chip-Only Rally

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks continued their gains yesterday, the sixth advance out of seven sessions, but most of the leading stock indexes dropped slightly. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 13.46 points, to 3,923.93, putting it about 1 percent away from its peak for the year.
The wider market was almost equally balanced between winners and losers. On the New York Stock Exchange, 11 stocks declined for every 10 that advanced. 
 The Dow's rise was concentrated in just four stocks, International Paper, Bethlehem Steel, Philip Morris and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing. Eighteen of 30 Dow component stocks rose yesterday.
"Except for the Dow, it was basically a boring, flat day," said Dirk van Dijk, equity strategist for C. H. Dean & Associates in Dayton, Ohio. One possible reason for the wider stock slide was a sharp decline in the value of the dollar, which discourages foreigners from buying American stocks because assets bought in dollars decline in value when converted to their native currency. Stock traders will thus have a new focus for worry when the August trade deficit figures are released tomorrow.
The trade figures matter because the dollars paid by Americans for Japanese, German and other foreign goods are often converted to yen, marks and other currencies. The resulting glut of unwanted dollars has led to record lows against major currencies.
The dollar fell against most major currencies yesterday, but especially so against the German mark. In the German elections Sunday, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government coalition barely held onto a parliamentary majority.
The narrowness of the Kohl victory ought to have pulled down the value of the mark, but instead put downward pressure on the dollar, which fell to a two-year low against the mark. Currency traders have apparently come to the conclusion that Germany, at least for now, will continue to offer higher interest rates than the United States, making Germany a more attractive place to invest. Since Feb. 8, when the dollar hit its peak for the year against the mark, the dollar has lost almost 15 percent of its value. Still, the Dow was almost back to its recent peak of 3,953.88, set on Sept. 15, and only 1.36 percent away from the peak for the year of 3,978.36 on Jan. 31. Hitting or even exceeding the peak of Jan. 31 is possible this week, but it is likely to be a short-lived stay at the top unless the wider market follows.
The other leading stock indexes fell yesterday. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 dropped 0.14 point, to 468.96. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 1.3 point, to 765.78. The S.& P. 500's high is 482, on Feb. 2, and the Nasdaq's peak is 803.93, on March 18.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was below normal with 238.5 million shares changing hands, about 17 percent below this year's average of 287 million shares. For unknown reasons, Mondays tend to be low-volume days on which stock prices sometimes, but not always, fall.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.03 point, to 257.96, with advancing stocks lagging declining stocks by 1057 to 1129. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.26 point to 458.76.
Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 259 stocks fell, led by Wal-Mart, which dropped 3/8, to 23 3/4.
The most-active stock, at 7.1 million shares, was Intel, which fell 5/16 , in advance of its announcement of higher third-quarter earnings.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Hits a 2-Year Low vs. the Mark

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Buoyed by Sunday's parliamentary election results, the mark rallied today, sending the dollar to a two-year low against the German currency. German bond prices also soared in response to the narrow election victory of Chancellor Helmut Kohl and his coalition Government.
The dollar fell below 1.50 marks, considered a key psychological barrier, to close at 1.495 in late afternoon trading here. In New York it ended at 1.4987, down 1.4 percent from Friday. 
 Stock prices also fell because of profit taking and concern that an overvalued mark would make German industries, which rely heavily on exports, less competitive. Last week, the market had risen in anticipation of a Kohl victory
"The bond market was euphoric today," said Ulrich Ramm, chief economist for the Commerzbank. "Investors welcomed the Kohl victory."
Mr. Kohl's Christian Democratic-led coalition won only a 10-seat majority in the 672-seat Parliament, the narrowest victory in almost four decades of German parliamentary politics.
When early election results indicated his margin was barely two or three seats, bond prices fell sharply because of fear that Mr. Kohl would be unable to implement his policies. Once it became clear that his Government was assured at least a 10-seat majority, investors decided that Mr. Kohl would be able to continue with his economic and fiscal policies, and bond prices soared.
"Clearly, the German election says that the German people want political continuity, steady progress on reducing the budget, experienced hands at the helm," said Richard Reid, chief economist at the Frankfurt office of the Union Bank of Switzerland.
By the end of the day, more than 350,000 bond futures contracts for the 10-year Government bond had changed hands on the Frankfurt and London exchanges. Prices on the futures contract rose sharply and interest rates fell.
Currency traders reported that many investors had bought Swiss francs and Dutch guilders in the weeks before the election and that there was a rush back into German marks today. That, plus a surprisingly steep drop in the dollar, sent the American currency to its lowest level in more than two years.
Analysts said many investors had deep reservations about the dollar and the commitment by the Federal Reserve Board, as well as the political establishment in Washington, to adhere to a strict anti-inflation policy. By contrast, the Bundesbank has not wavered in its policy.
"You have a central bank that is absolutely against inflation, realistic plans by the Government to bring down its budget deficit and more years of Kohl," said an economist for a major European bank who insisted on anonymity.
Among the worries about the dollar, analysts said, is that Republicans could win in Congressional elections in the United States next month. "That would generate wide tax cuts, higher budget deficits and more inflation, all weakening the dollar," said another analyst who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"In a sense the dollar has been on a long-term decline against the mark," he said. "Inflation is lower in Germany; real interest rates in Germany are very attractive. Why buy dollars?"
Indeed, fears before the election were that Mr. Kohl's opposition, the Social Democratic Party, would win and usher into Germany the kinds of problems that investors have with ballooning budget deficits and higher inflation in the United States.
However, once polls last week predicted a narrow Kohl victory, investors began buying stocks, pushing up prices as much as 8 percent.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Dollar Slips Widely
 (By Bloomberg Business News) -- The dollar was weaker against most leading currencies in trading in New York yesterday.
"The dollar isn't going north any time soon," said Karl Halligan, vice president for strategic trading at CF-CIC Bank New York. "No one wants to buy it. Everyone wants to sell."
The dollar, which fell to a two-year low against the German mark, also fell to a two-year low of 1.2437 Swiss francs and a two-year low of 5.127 French francs. The British pound jumped as high as $1.6140 today, its highest level since Oct. 26, 1992. It was last quoted at $1.6100, up from $1.5943 on Friday.
Japan's central bank bought dollars to try to stem the dollar's slide against the yen, traders in Tokyo said. The Bank of Japan has spent trillions of yen trying to support the dollar this year. A weak dollar hobbles the Japanese economy by making the country's exports more expensive.
The dollar fell to 97.25 yen in Tokyo trading. In New York yesterday, it was last quoted at 97.65 yen, down from 98.10 on Friday.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rally To Recoup Early Losses

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury bonds pared early losses that were prompted by a fall in the dollar and ended little changed yesterday.
Bonds began their slide in Asian and European trading yesterday, as the dollar tumbled against the German mark after the narrow victory of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government coalition in a national election. A weaker dollar makes dollar-denominated assets like Treasury securities less attractive. 
 Bond prices, however, firmed in afternoon trading in New York, as the dollar steadied somewhat against the mark. The afternoon buying reflected moves by some traders to cover short sales, which occur when traders sell borrowed securities in the hope of buying them back at a lower price and profiting on the difference.
"Guys got short at the low end of the range," said Ed Harvey, a trader for First Chicago Capital Markets. "Then the dollar got a little bit of strength and people started covering."
The price of the 30-year Treasury ended up 2/32 , to 9610/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 7.82 percent, from 7.83 percent on Friday.
At yesterday's regular weekly Treasury auction of three- and six-month bills, the rates were unchanged. The Treasury sold $13.143 billion of three-month bills at an average rate of 4.92 percent, the same as in the previous two weeks. The Government also sold $13.067 billion of six-month bills at an average rate of 5.43 percent, the same as in the last week.
The mixed performance yesterday came after two sessions of gains. After reports on producer and consumer prices last week, traders have been increasingly confident that the Federal Reserve will not move again on interest rates until its policy-making committee meets on Nov. 15. The Fed has raised short-term interest rates fives times this year in an effort to slow the pace of inflation.
Bonds could rally by Nov. 15 if economic reports prove to be "surprisingly on the weak side," said Joseph Bench, who manages $400 million for New Castle Advisers in White Plains. The yields on two-year notes could fall as low as 6.25 percent, and the yields on 30-year bonds could fall as low as 7.50 percent, he said.
The optimism that inflation will not accelerate has been "somewhat negated by the weakness in the dollar," said Bernard Jensen, the head United States Government bond trader for Fuji Securities.
The weakness of the dollar, however, could be "a 24-hour wonder," said Charles Quigley, a trader at Chemical Securities in London. United States bonds "will quickly revert to a domestic focus, which probably means a trading range," he said.
The bond market will turn its attention tomorrow to the Government's report on the nation's merchandise trade deficit, which is also an important component of the gross domestic product.
The following are the results of yesterday's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Inventories in August Increased 1%, U.S. Says

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Businesses built up their inventories at a rapid pace in August despite the fastest sales in seven and a half years, the Commerce Department reported today.
Inventories rose 1 percent, the fifth consecutive advance and the biggest since 1.2 percent in May, while sales rose 3 percent, as auto dealers restocked after a July shutdown to retool for 1995 models. 
 The inventory-to-sales ratio was 1.39, equaling an all-time low. That means it would take 1.39 months to exhaust stockpiles at the August sales rate. The ratio was 1.42 in July.
Analysts said the figures were fresh evidence of economic strength, increasing the chances that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates next month. It has already raised rates five times this year.
The Government's first estimate of gross domestic product for the third quarter is due on Oct. 28, and today's report suggests there could be a 3 percent expansion, analysts and others said. The inventory accumulation "is stronger than expected," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York. "The economy continues to push along."
Analysts had generally predicted that inventories would increase four-tenths of 1 percent in August, less than half the actual rise.
The Commerce Department said inventories totaled a seasonally adjusted $903.6 billion in August, up from $894.7 billion. They had risen six-tenths of 1 percent in July and four-tenths of 1 percent in June. Stockpiles have risen throughout 1994, except in March, when they slipped by two-tenths of 1 percent.
The 3 percent increase in sales was the largest since a gain of 4 percent in February 1987. They rose to a seasonally adjusted $649.6 billion from $630.6 billion.
Inventories have been accumulating at a rapid pace for much of the year, but analysts disagree over how much of the buildup is intended. If stockpiles increase too quickly, it could mean slower growth ahead if consumer buying slows.
"There are 67 shopping days till Christmas," remarked Ron Schreibman of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors. "As long as consumers and businesses keep spending, inventory accumulation will take care of itself."
Retail inventories in August were up to $288 billion, a gain of 2.4 percent and the biggest jump since October 1986, when they rose at the same rate. Stockpiles at the wholesale level rose to $228.5 billion from $226.6 billion, or eight-tenths of 1 percent. Manufacturers' inventories increased to $387.1 billion from $386.6 billion -- a little more than one-tenth of 1 percent.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Inventories-Sales Ratio" shows total month-end business inventories divided by the total monthly business sales from March 1993 to Aug. 1994. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: For 13, Change Brings A Chill

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
The announcement last week that the "MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour" intended to abandon WNET, the station where the program began 20 years ago, has set off the latest round of doomsaying at Channel 13, New York's long-suffering public television station.
The management of Channel 13 has been through the cycle before: bad financial news, followed by sinking morale among employees, concerns among producers about forthcoming projects and serious questions about the station's long-term future. 
 The response from WNET's management is that the station is a mature institution trying to deal with changes imposed by declining revenues and rising costs. But critics of the station, who include current and former employees and independent program producers, say the current crisis is different because it arises not just from Channel 13's near-chronic lack of funds but also from a lack of vision.
Specifically, they say Channel 13 has ceded its position as the leading provider of the signature programs of public television -- like Ken Burns's "Baseball" and the documentary series "Frontline" -- to other stations, like WETA in Washington and especially WGBH in Boston.
William F. Baker, the president of WNET, has presided over two waves of layoffs at the station in three years, reducing the staff from about 550 to just over 400. The station was forced to cancel locally produced programs and to shut down for 12 hours on the weekends.
The "MacNeil/Lehrer" decision was precipitated by a plan floated by the station in July to shut down its production studio. The same plan compelled another of WNET's signature programs, "Charlie Rose," to seek a new location. Mr. Rose found it, along with what he called more technically advanced yet cheaper facilities, across town in the studios of Bloomberg Financial News.
Mr. Baker acknowledged that the "MacNeil" news was bound to send tremors under his staff's feet again. "When jobs are at risk," he said, "people understandably worry and get angry."
But he added: "We're not falling off the edge of the earth. When you try and turn a mature institution hard aport, it just doesn't turn too easily."
The economic picture for the station is actually reasonably bright, Mr. Baker asserted. The reason for all the recent cost-cutting, he said, has been management's refusal to allow Channel 13 to fall into the red, a problem that afflicts many public television stations.
George Miles, who was the executive vice president of WNET until he took over the leadership of WQED in Pittsburgh this year, said: "If you look at WNET's financial statements, they're sound. I'm in debt over my head. You can only spend what you have."
Mr. Miles said Mr. Baker, who came to WNET in 1987 after a career in commercial broadcasting with Group W, was taking a "businesslike approach" to running Channel 13, characterized by his refusal to allow the station to run deficits. "WNET has not had a deficit in a decade," Mr. Baker said.
But the station has also had no margin for discretionary spending. After raising $104 million last year, Mr. Baker said that all he had as a working margin after expenses was $100,000. He has set out to counter that problem by starting a campaign to build an endowment for WNET, which will provide a yearly financial buffer, based on the interest on the endowment. The station has raised $14 million toward its goal of $40 million.
Mr. Baker also pointed out that Channel 13 was caught up in many problems endemic to public television. Several have to do with money: corporate financing, for example, is down for a second year in a row; Federal financing is flat and probably will not grow significantly, and individual contributions are growing only slightly.
Other problems are institutional, beginning with the almost ludicrous amount of duplication in the system. As Mr. Baker observed, each of the major broadcast networks has about 200 affiliated stations. But there are more than 350 PBS member stations.
In the New York area, Mr. Baker added, "there are six overlapping public television stations." They are WNET, which is actually licensed in Newark; WNYC and WNYE in New York City; the New Jersey Network; the Connecticut Network, and WLIW on Long Island.
Robert Ottendorf, the executive vice president of PBS, said that while some public stations were beginning to share facilities, there was still far too much duplication. "In 1994 we shouldn't be operating like it's still 1970," Mr. Ottendorf said.
The duplication is terribly costly, one former WNET executive said. "There are probably 10,000 employees working in public television," he said. "Compare that to one of our competitors, like the A&E channel." That channel, Arts & Entertainment, has fewer than 350 employees.
"Even when you try to fix the problem, you run into impossible political situations," this executive said. Indeed, Channel 13 previously tried to forge a cost-saving alliance with the New Jersey Network, only to see it fall apart. The executive said station managers had little incentive to cooperate because they saw their own jobs threatened.
Mr. Baker said most of Channel 13's financial problems would be solved if it did not have to compete with so many other public television stations. Although the station continues to pursue alliances with other public television outlets, Mr. Baker is looking more toward the endowment as a long-term solution.
The endowment is an excellent idea, one producer associated with the station said, but it does not make up for what the station is missing. "There's just not a lot of energy there," said the producer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "I don't see much of a vision."
Mr. Baker conceded that the station needed to "focus on programs, not on the physical plant," which is one reason he played down the news that WNET might close its production studio. He pointed out that A&E and the Discovery Channel, often perceived as the chief competitors of PBS, did not have studios. "Neither does Channel 4 in England," Mr. Baker said, "which is known as the best public broadcaster in the world."
Partly to address what might be called Channel 13's "vision thing," Mr. Baker has brought in Ward Chamberlin, the former president of WETA in Washington, to direct Channel 13's local and national programming. Mr. Chamberlin said yesterday that the loss of "MacNeil/ Lehrer" was bound to feed the perception of a station in trouble, one that is no longer the chief provider of significant new programs to public television.
"We have to attract talent to the station," he said. "That's exactly what I came here to do."
Mr. Chamberlin said WNET was developing two series, one on human sexuality and the other on space and design in America. They would not be broadcast until two years from now.
"We have to restore this place to status as the station that gives PBS the hit series," Mr. Chamberlin said.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Of Winchell and the Power of Gossip

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:
WINCHELL
Gossip, Power and the Culture of Celebrity
By Neal Gabler
681 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.
At the height of Walter Winchell's power in the late 1930's, some 50 million Americans -- roughly two-thirds of the adult population -- either listened to his weekly radio broadcast or read his daily newspaper column. Songs and movies were written about him. Presidents courted him. And politicians, actors and socialites alike all feared him. Although he would die a defeated and largely reviled man, Winchell presided over American mass culture for several decades, a self-appointed arbiter of power and taste, and an eerie harbinger of the culture of celebrity and gossip that would take hold in the country in the years to come. 
 In Neal Gabler's enthralling new biography, Winchell emerges as a strangely emblematic figure -- an avatar of "a cultural revolution in which control of the American agenda shifted from the mandarins of high culture to the new masters of mass culture." In the 20's, Mr. Gabler observes, Winchell's gossip column -- with its irreverent debunking of the rich and famous -- spoke to a society seething with new egalitarian impulses and discontents. During the Depression, his hectic descriptions of Broadway openings and Hollywood shenanigans provided a glamorous escape from the cruel realities of the Depression, while his New Deal populism buttressed his pose as a champion of the people. And in the years before and during World War II, his impassioned denunciations of Hitler and his calls to arms galvanized and echoed the nation's commitment to war.
In the course of his career, Mr. Gabler argues, Winchell helped redefine the media's role in American society, introducing concepts all too familiar today: journalism as entertainment, celebrity gossip as news, opinion-making as reportage. As a leader in "the tabloid revolution," Mr. Gabler adds, Winchell not only provided his readers with sensationalistic stories, but also "purveyed a cosmology, an attitude toward the world which was every bit as rich as the cosmology of the traditional press. In place of cool reason, heated passion. In place of the primacy of world and national events that presumably determined the readers' own destinies, trivial and salacious events, a 'drama of life,' as one called it, that reflected a world gone mad. In place of faith in the objective and verifiable, the subjective and provisional that ceded no higher truth."
Writing that Winchell was "arguably one of the principal architects" of modern American culture, Mr. Gabler turns the columnist's life into the springboard for a fascinating social history. At the same time, he uses a novelistic approach to give the reader a vivid, psychologically acute portrait of Winchell himself. This is the same narrative technique Mr. Gabler employed in his last book, "An Empire of Their Own: How the Jews Invented Hollywood," and he makes the reader aware of the many parallels between Winchell and the Hollywood moguls depicted in that earlier volume -- namely, a "patrimony of failure," a desperate, driving need for attention and security, and a willingness to sacrifice familial happiness to a career.
Winchell's sensibility, Mr. Gabler tells us, was indelibly shaped by his impoverished childhood in Harlem and by his early, scrambling years as a performer in vaudeville. The latter would endow him with a compulsive desire to entertain and a nihilistic sense of the precariousness of attachments. The former would leave him with a lasting sense of insecurity and a free-floating need for revenge. "I'm not a fighter," Winchell wrote in his autobiography, "I'm a 'waiter.' I wait until I can catch an ingrate with his fly open, and then I take a picture of it."
From vaudeville, Winchell slipped into writing theatrical newsletters, and from there into the fledgling world of tabloid journalism, where his ear for the slangy patois of cafe society and his mastery of gossip quickly earned him an avid following. Fame on a national level followed in the early 30's with the success of Winchell's radio broadcasts, broadcasts that brought distracting news of celebrity marriages and divorces to a country reeling from unemployment and unpaid bills.
It was only a matter of time before Winchell tried to translate his oracular authority in the world of celebrity gossip to the broader stage of politics. And for a time, he was remarkably successful. Roosevelt paid him tribute, and Winchell repaid the compliment with fervor, rallying support for the President's policies both at home and abroad. After the war and Roosevelt's death, Winchell's liberalism began to sour. Truman disappointed him and so did Dewey and Henry Wallace. By the early 50's, he had become an ardent supporter of Joseph McCarthy, not solely out of anti-Communist fervor, Mr. Gabler suggests, but also out of a willingness to employ similar tactics of finger-pointing and innuendo.
By then, Mr. Gabler observes, Winchell's columns and broadcasts had grown increasingly vituperative and vindictive. All pretense of populist sentiment had vanished, as he used his power to settle purely personal scores and reward a dwindling number of friends.
In fact, Winchell's private life had grown empty and acrimonious as well. He rarely saw his wife, June. His son, Walt, committed suicide. And Winchell broke up his daughter Walda's romance with a producer named Billy Cahn by questioning her sanity and defaming Cahn's reputation, acts that would help sully Winchell's own reputation, when they were incorporated into the portrait of a vindictive gossip columnist in the 1957 movie "The Sweet Smell of Success."
By the early 60's, Mr. Gabler reports, Winchell had already become an anachronism, forced out of radio by the advent of television and diminished as a columnist by his own self-destructive rants. Having celebrated the cult of the ephemeral celebrity, he would die in 1972 by the very unforgiving rules of fame he had helped to invent, alone and forgotten.

HEADLINE: THREATS IN THE GULF: IN BAGHDAD;
Iraq Fails to Act on Security Council Proposal to Recognize Kuwait's Borders

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 17

 BODY:
The Iraqi Parliament held a closed session today that had been expected to yield formal recognition of Kuwait's sovereignty, but the meeting broke up without any acknowledgement that the lawmakers had even discussed the issue.
A vague statement issued later by the official Iraqi news agency said the 250-member assembly had discussed "situations in the Arab and international arena" and "the attitude toward the Security Council and recent Russian-Iraq talks." It was not clear when the Parliament would meet again. 
 Supporting a proposal by Russia, President Saddam Hussein indicated last week that Iraq was ready to accept Kuwait's sovereignty and borders as demanded by the United Nations Security Council in exchange for the eventual lifting of economic sanctions.
Despite the blandness of the news agency's announcement, some lawmakers and several Government officials said that Iraq was ready to recognize Kuwait's borders and end the state of war between the two countries. But the extent to which Baghdad would meet the United Nations criteria for granting such recognition was unclear.
"We are in a difficult situation and our aim is to get the sanctions lifted," said Mohammad Mozafar al-Hamadi, a university professor who is a member of Parliament. "We have said before that we are ready to accept the United Nations resolutions. We should have peace and we should have dialogue."
Other members of Parliament said they believed they had been summoned to ratify a decision already made by the ruling Revolutionary Command Council, headed by President Hussein, to recognize Kuwait.
The economic sanctions were imposed by the Security Council in the months after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990 and declared it to be an Iraqi province. The Council requires that Iraq's recognition of Kuwait come through official channels, including a formal measure of the Parliament, which is considered a rubber-stamp assembly.
Iraq had called the parliamentary session on a day's notice, describing it as an emergency meeting on its latest confrontation with the United States. Reporters were ushered into the opening session but then abruptly asked to leave when it was declared a closed session.
A member of the Parliament who declined to be identified said he was convinced that recognition of Kuwait would come soon. "I think the matter is over," he said. "We will have to coexist as two independent states."
The parliamentary session was preceded by numerous Government statements and gestures paving the way for such recognition. They made it clear that after four years, this country of 18 million is no longer able to withstand the most severe regime of economic sanctions ever imposed on an international level.
Tonight the country's Trade Minister said during a news conference that Iraq was reeling under an annual inflation rate of 2,500 percent as its currency continued to decline and its reserves of foreign currency dwindle. Oil exports, its main source of foreign exchange, were shut down by the United Nations in 1990.
In another sign of Iraq's eagerness to get the sanctions lifted, the officially controlled news organizations have reported international criticism of Iraq's military moves toward the Kuwaiti border. The reports have repeatedly emphasized the insistence of several countries that Iraq must drop its claim to Kuwaiti territory if it wants relief from the sanctions.
On Sunday, Iraqi newspapers reported criticism from a previously close ally, King Hussein of Jordan, who said he would side against Baghdad if it ever moved militarily against Kuwait.
Tonight, Iraqi television, a prime instrument of the Government's propaganda, showed parts of the speeches by members of the United Nations Security Council, including accusations by the United States and Britain that Iraq provoked the crisis and should refrain from military threats to its neighbors in the future.

HEADLINE: Japan Plans to Conquer Sea's Depths

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
NO part of Japan is more than 75 miles from the sea. With its fish catch three times that of the United States, its shipyards some of the world's most innovative and its Emperor a marine biologist, the land of nearly 7,000 isles in the past few years has quietly honed its technological skills to become a global leader in probing the depths of the world's seas and working hard to unlock their secrets.
It is an effort of no small moment, as the deep encompasses more than half the earth. 
 The deepest diving manned submersible in the world is now one from Japan. The craft recently set a depth record in the Atlantic, carrying three people down nearly four miles to scrutinize the sea floor. Earlier this year in the Pacific, a Japanese robot set a depth record for exploration by advanced machines.
Japan is making discoveries, setting up international deep-sea collaborations and launching waves of new equipment meant to illuminate the sea's dark frontiers. Smaller than California and bereft of many natural resources, the archipelago nation sees the deep as a repository of biological and mineral riches and is making preparations to mine them both.
It is also probing the abyss to fathom its own geophysical fate, which is tied to nearby oceanic plates that grind past one another to produce swarms of earthquakes, volcanoes and tsunamis. The hope is to learn how to warn of danger.
"Increased knowledge of the ocean is indispensable to making our way into the future," said Mitsugu Ishizuka, president of the Japan Marine Science and Technology Center, located on Tokyo Bay, the nation's top group for the development of deep gear, speaking recently to an American audience.
Japan over the years has sunk large sums into industrial sectors it deems important, at times with mixed results. It won big on memory chips but stumbled on futuristic computers and some types of advanced television. Its space program is ambitious but seemingly confused over whether it wants a leading world role.
American experts say Japan's inner-space program is as serious as any they have analyzed, even if small compared with some of that country's giant projects. Its steady growth is reportedly based on annual investments that have now risen to around $100 million.
The effort seems more ambitious than that of the United States, where Federal development of deep-sea vehicles has slowed in favor of operating some the Government already owns.
"They're making a big push, putting a lot of money into it, and exceeding us in some ways," said Dr. Richard Von Herzen, a senior scientist at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution on Cape Cod who recently dived in the Japanese deep submersible. "It's not competitive. They're complementing our work in the oceans, and doing it rather quickly and well."
J. Bradford Mooney Jr., a retired Navy Rear Admiral who studies global trends in deep-sea research, said America's style was piecemeal while Japan's was comprehensive. "Clearly, the whole nation is marching to the same drum," he said in an interview. "They have a national strategy."
Much of Japan's undersea push arises from its wrestling with harsh geographic facts of life. The island nation is mountainous, short on farmland and resources and highly dependent on the ocean. Its annual per capita consumption of fish is the highest in the world.
The sea, often celebrated in national festivals, is also feared. The type of earthquake that shook Japan on Oct. 4 is common in the Western Pacific, where the intermittent shifting of deep oceanic plates begets earthquakes, volcanoes and the big waves known as tsunamis. The quake's epicenter was in the maze of deep fissures in the ocean floor that runs parallel to Japan and regularly erupts in tectonic upheavals.
Justin L. Bloom, the United States science attache in Tokyo from 1975 to 1981 and now a consultant on international science, said Japan's drive to fathom the deep was as much spiritual and intellectual as practical and economic.
"Historically, as a nation, as a people, the Japanese have had a huge involvement with the ocean," he said in an interview. "Their culture is largely based on their relationship to the sea. I don't think the program was ever justified on the basis of some great economic plan. It was something they wanted to do well simply because the ocean is such a big part of their lives."
In the early 1970's, the Japanese founded the Japan Marine Science and Technology Center and immediately turned to the West for aid in learning how to probe the deep. In particular, they turned to Woods Hole on Cape Cod, which in concert with the Navy had invented deep maneuvering submersibles. Its pride was Alvin, which could carry three people to a depth of 2.5 miles.
Japanese engineers visited Woods Hole in 1973 and inspected Alvin closely. In 1975, Emperor Hirohito paid a visit as well. After much experimentation, in 1981 the Japanese launched the Shinkai ("deep sea") 2000, which could carry people down 2,000 meters, or 1.25 miles.
Alvin and its support ship visited Tokyo in 1987, fresh from making headlines by investigating the sunken hulk of the Titanic. The American submersible was toured by Crown Prince Akihito, who is now Japan's Emperor. He is a marine biologist, as was his father, and specializes in gobies, a type of small carnivorous fish.
In 1990 the Japanese completed the Shinkai 6500, which cost about $60 million to build and can carry three people down 6,500 meters, or more than 4 miles. It can dive deeper than any other manned vehicle in the world and is quite well equipped. For instance, it has more electrical power for lights, cameras and science experiments than Alvin.
The 31-foot-long submersible and its 345-foot-long support ship stopped at Woods Hole in late July as part of a Japanese-American effort to probe the Atlantic. The sub had just set an Atlantic depth record by diving down 3.74 miles to hunt for insights into how the Earth's crust is formed. Both vehicles appeared to be engineering jewels, the ship made by Kawasaki and the submersible by Mitsubishi.
Masahiko Ida, formerly Japan's top submersible pilot and now head of the Shinkai 6500 team, gave a reporter a tour of the tiny submarine. Asked the secret of its powers, he said there was no secret. All the "cutting and welding," he said, all the innumerable parts and the personnel sphere, which is made of titanium, a super-strong metal, had simply been done with great care and precision.
He led the way up a flight of stairs near the gleaming white machine and then down a ladder into its heart. The interior was cramped but not claustrophobic. Three small windows looked forward. Banks of switches were arrayed in neat rows, many underlaid by Japanese script. Most of the gear, including tape recorders for deep-sea cameras, was made in Japan. An exception was the underwater telephone system, made by Ametek, a California company recently acquired by one in Utah.
American scientists say the Japanese are learning rapidly and loosing a tendency to be overly cautious in their deep explorations. For instance, the Shinkai 6500 now dives almost every day. At the program's start, it went down every other day, with the off days devoted to painstaking rounds of maintenance.
"The big surprise was how far they've come," said one American oceanographer, who recently dove on the Shinkai 6500 and who spoke on condition of anonymity to avoid the possibility of offending his hosts. "This sub clearly has substantial abilities and very good imaging systems."
Another American scientist echoed that view. "We were all impressed," he said, fresh from a Shinkai 6500 dive. "They babied the system. They didn't work it the way we would. But we got all the samples we wanted. After all was said and done, it seems to be a very good system."
The Japanese rush into the deep has occasionally led to stumbles that Tokyo apparently views as unavoidable missteps on the road to leadership.
A particularly painful episode centered on the device known as Kaiko, or "trench" in Japanese. Built by Mitsui, the $50 million machine is the world's deepest-diving robot, designed to plunge on a tether to depths of 11,000 meters, or nearly seven miles. It has television cameras, still cameras, sonars, sensors and crab-like claws. One of Japan's goals is to use it to map cracks in the ocean floor as an aid to finding and monitoring active geological faults.
On a test dive early this year, Kaiko was nearing the ocean floor nearly seven miles into the Mariana Trench -- the deepest spot in the ocean -- when video screens watched by Japanese engineers suddenly went blank. The dive was aborted and the 10-foot-long robot hauled back to the surface for lengthy repairs. The setback came just feet short of breaking the depth record set in 1960 by the American bathyscaph Trieste, which carried two people. Still, Kaiko's dive was the deepest to date by a robot and succeeded in gathering valuable data with a suite of modern sensors.
Despite such stumbles, the Japanese are pressing ahead to perfect Kaiko and develop other gear, including prototype machines for deep mining. Sumitomo has built an experimental device that can be towed to depths of 5,000 meters, or 3.1 miles, to gather manganese nodules. Scattered like cobblestones on parts of the sea floor, the nodules are rich in copper, cobalt and nickel, which is important for making stainless steel.
Experts say ocean mining, though perhaps decades off in general, might be done sooner by the Japanese as a way to achieving greater resource independence.
So too, Japanese biologists have begun a major effort to retrieve microbes from the deep, and perhaps to make new drugs and tools for genetic engineering. The $43 million Deepstar project, as it is known, involves building a plant that can reproduce on land the extreme pressures and temperatures found in the sea's depths. The aim is to have a repository for breeding unique bacteria and organisms brought back to land by Kaiko, Shinkai 6500 and other deep-diving vehicles.
A tentative project on the horizon for Tokyo is a large new ship that would be used to drill deep into the ocean's rocky crust to study global geology. That job is now done by the Joides Resolution, a 470-foot-long ship based in the United States that sails the world for an international consortium of geologists.
As Japan develops a wealth of deep-sea gear, Western experts wonder to what extent the rush will advance the hardest aspects of science and discovery, noting that creative flexibility can be as important to such work as solid financing.
Another question is whether the Japanese drive into the deep is just a temporary plunge created by the fiscal surpluses of 1980's or is the beginning of a long-term expansion. Experts are divided on the topic. Among the riddles is a proposed new Japanese submersible, informally known as Shinkai 11,000, that would carry scientists into the deepest parts of the abyss.
"They don't like to talk about things before they happen," said Don Walsh, a former Navy captain who was on Trieste's pioneering dive and has advised the Japanese. He said he expects the new submersible to materialize "by the end of the century."
Other experts say the Japanese are changing focus now that key tools are in hand or nearly finished, spending money as much on exploration as new vehicles. Japan, they add, is pouring new funds into coastal development, marine construction and oceanic power generation, even as the nation becomes more serious about seabed mining.
"They're starting to explore a lot of things," said Dr. Joseph R. Vadus, an expert on Japanese sea endeavors at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in Silver Spring, Md. "Over all, what Japan is doing with the ocean is mind-boggling."


GRAPHIC: Japan is pioneering deep-sea exploration to learn how to warn of devastating earthquakes and tsunamis, to mine the sea's biological and mineral riches and generally to gain a better understanding of the waters that so dominate Japanese life. New fleets of manned submersibles and unmanned robots focus particularly on the tectonic intersections near Japan whose shakes and rumbles have caused recurring tragedies over the centuries. HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
After 40 Days and 40 Nights, Players and Owners Will Meet in Capital

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Five years to the day after the World Series earthquake, there were slight rumblings yesterday in the long dormant negotiations in baseball's labor dispute. Forty days after they last held a bargaining session, representatives of the players and the owners will meet in Washington tomorrow with Bill Usery Jr., the mediator who will try to help them resolve their differences.
Neither side would comment publicly on the meeting, but one person involved in the talks called the gathering a "ground rules meeting." 
 Last Friday, the day he was brought into the dispute, Usery met separately with Donald Fehr, the union chief, and two of his aides, and then with Bud Selig, the acting commissioner. Selig isn't expected to attend tomorrow's session, but it will be the first time since Sept. 9 that the two negotiating teams get together.
Besides union staff members, a large contingent of players will accompany Fehr. Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, was not in Washington last Friday but is expected to be there tomorrow. Some owners and other club executives also will be at the meeting. The group most likely will include John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox, Jerry McMorris of the Colorado Rockies and Wendy Selig-Prieb of Milwaukee.
The last time the negotiating teams met, Selig joined the talks for the first time, and the owners rejected the players' new proposal. The next day, union lawyers met with Harrington and Stan Kasten of the Atlanta Braves, but the informal session produced nothing to bring the negotiating teams back to the table.
Four days later, the clubs voted to cancel the rest of the season, the playoffs and the World Series, and negotiators embarked on a long hiatus.
As they agreed to return to the table, the two sides continued to have their differences. Seventeen more players filed for free agency yesterday, but just as it did last Saturday, the first day of the 15-day filing period, the owners' Player Relations Committee rejected four names.
The P.R.C. said that Gregg Olson of Atlanta, Tom Gordon of Kansas City, Greg Harris of Colorado and Chris Gwynn of Los Angeles do not have the required six years of major league service to be eligible for free agency.
Those players would have enough service if the days of the strike were counted, but the clubs' lawyers say those days don't count. The Players Association says they do and eventually will file a grievance to resolve the dispute within a dispute.
Even without the strike days, Gwynn, Tony's brother, who is a reserve outfielder for the Dodgers, is only one day short of six years.
Last Saturday, the P.R.C. rejected filings for Jim Abbott of the Yankees, Jack McDowell of the Chicago White Sox, Kenny Rogers of Texas and Erik Hanson of Cincinnati. Four other players, including Randy Velarde of the Yankees, are in the same category.
Players who filed successfully were Terry Mulholland and Scott Bankhead of the Yankees, Dave Winfield of Cleveland, Orel Hershiser of Los Angeles, Bob Tewksbury of St. Louis, Danny Jackson and Ricky Jordan of Philadelphia, Mike Macfarlane of Kansas City, Mike Jackson of San Francisco, Dave Gallagher of Atlanta, Jeff Brantley of Cincinnati, Tom Foley of Pittsburgh and Luis Aquino of Florida.
They raised the number of undisputed free agents to 22.
Another eligible player, Mark Parent, reached agreement with the Pirates on a one-year contract for $300,000. The Pirates claimed the catcher on waiver from the Chicago Cubs.
In another economic development, the Players Association sent out checks for $5,000 from its $200 million strike fund. That brings to $25,000 the amount of money players who qualify for the maximum have received from the fund. No more checks will be disbursed until the union's executive board votes to release more funds.

HEADLINE: City's Advice on Central Park: Take a Friend

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
As he moved into the pale wash of a lantern alongside the Central Park Reservoir at 8:30 last night, Sammy Busby had the long straightaway on the western side of the reservoir jogging track to himself.
Despite the eerie solitude, despite the much-publicized rape on Saturday of a woman who was jogging on the same track, Mr. Busby, an actor, said he did not feel threatened. "I'm a pretty big fellow," he said, adding: "The women seem to be the victims." 
 Central Park last night was a place for the die-hard runners, cyclists and skaters, or for those who simply do not believe they are vulnerable. Those who did their laps in the park after dark said there were perhaps one-fifth as many people as usual there, out for their exercise.
At 9 P.M., perhaps a dozen people could be seen circling the reservoir, only one a woman and she was with a man. A few more people ran, skated or rode the East and West Drives. Though most knew about the recent spate of rapes in the park, and conceded that they were in the minority in not being scared off by the events, they insisted that they felt safe.
"It's too nice a night to be worried about that," said Paul Heffner, a banker, who said he ran around the reservoir two or three times a week.
"I have to run," said Susan Feitelberg, a banker, who ran the West Drive with her friend, Michael Wootton. "I go every night. I try to go with someone, but not always."
While the police continued to search for the man who committed the most recent rape, city officials and Central Park boosters yesterday struggled to explain the increase in the number of rapes. They insisted that the park was a relatively safe place, but counseled caution at night.
Central Park, which is one of the city's 75 police precincts, has far less crime than the average precinct. But other precincts have about 100,000 residents each, as against just a few in Central Park, making a comparison difficult.
"Central Park is a relatively safe place to be if it's used appropriately," said Henry J. Stern, the city Parks and Recreation Commissioner. "It's much safer by day than by night, and it's safer with a buddy."
Recent attacks in the park would not have drawn as much attention if they had happened elsewhere, Mr. Stern said. "Central Park is like a metaphor for New York," he said. "It's like Macy's window. Whatever happens there is magnified."
The most recent victim, a 39-year-old unemployed secretary, was attacked by a knife-wielding man while jogging around the reservoir at 9:30, the police said. The police offered no new information about the investigation yesterday.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the park is not unique when it comes to danger, and he urged people who run there after dark not to go alone. "That's good advice for almost all parts of the city," he said. "That would be good advice given by the mayor of almost any American city."
The police say there have been 11 rapes in the park this year, up from 9 last year and 4 in 1992. Yet crime in the park has dropped in the same period.
"I think the rapes are an anomaly," said Elizabeth Barlow Rogers, administrator of the Central Park Conservancy, a nonprofit environmental organization that helps care for the park. "Over all, the park is becoming, I think, a more benign place."
In the last few years, the police have begun patrolling the park on scooters and bicycles, giving them access to more of its hidden and potentially dangerous places.

HEADLINE: Police Move Street Vendors In Harlem

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Hundreds of police officers descended on 125th Street in Harlem yesterday to carry out the Giuliani administration's order to clear the busy thoroughfare of street vendors, and 22 people were arrested as scuffles broke out between the illegal merchants and officers.
Although the sweep went relatively smoothly -- the police had been anticipating trouble -- many store owners, fearful of reprisals from vendors, kept their doors shut for much of the day. 
 Among those arrested was Morris Powell, the president of an association of vendors on 125th Street. He was charged with disorderly conduct for using a bull horn without a permit during a march by about 150 people demonstrating against the sweep.
Under the administration's plan, the vendors are to move to an open-air market site about eight blocks away, at Lenox Avenue and 116th Street. But by late afternoon, only two vendors had opened for business at the new site.
There were several minor scuffles in the morning between officers and vendors trying to set up shop. But with each wave of arrests, the ranks of protesters along 125th Street grew thinner.
By late afternoon, the street had largely returned to normal, and a few store owners who had kept their businesses closed decided to reopen for the rest of the day.
The major difference from most days was the complete absence of the once-ubiquitous vendors, whose presence on 125th Street had become a major attraction for shoppers from other parts of New York City and beyond.
While the vendors drew shoppers to the area, they also drew the ire of merchants and civic groups, who contended that the thousand or more illegal merchants were clogging sidewalks and leaving debris strewn about while often peddling counterfeit goods at bargain-basement prices.
In place of the vendors yesterday were police officers standing along the street in clusters of three, with metal barricades on the sidewalks, giving 125th Street an air of an area under siege.
On the western edge of 125th Street, police officials set up a command post where they oversaw a battery of officers, some in patrol cars, vans, tow trucks and buses and even some mounted on horses. They were joined by officials from 14 other city agencies, ranging from Sanitation to the Department of Transportation. Police officials declined to say how many officers were assigned to the area yesterday, but some officers estimated their numbers at more than 500.
And while many Harlem residents found the scene disquieting, some praised how the Giuliani administration was dealing with what many had considered a perennial severe problem whose solution had eluded previous mayors.
"For the first time, I could walk down 125th Street unencumbered," said Keith L. T. Wright, a State Assemblyman from Harlem who has supported the Mayor's initiative and whose office is in the Adam Clayton Powell Jr. State Office Building on 125th Street. "The experience of seeing the scene is not completely pleasing, but the end result -- moving the vendors off of 125th Street -- is pleasing."
Barbara Askins, executive director of the 125th Street Business Improvement District, which has supported the sweep, said that while she was pleased with the action, it was still too early to assess its long-term effectiveness.
"I don't get the sense that it's over yet," Ms. Askins said. "I don't know how long the police will be there or what the enforcement will be. It's too early to say what will happen beyond the next few days."
Many displaced vendors and some residents angrily questioned why the Giuliani administration had used so many police officers to relocate people merely trying to make a living.
"You never see this kind of police force used to raid a crack house," said Gregory Lucas, a book vendor standing along 125th Street. "You would think that Saddam Hussein was invading Harlem. All we want to do is make a living. Does Giuliani want us to go on welfare?"
The first to set up shop at the newly established open-air market was a vendor selling video tapes, Lance Shabaaz. Mr. Shabaaz said that he understood that a mosque would be built on the site of the open-air market.
"So this is just a temporary arrangement," he said. "When the new mosque is built, what's going to happen to the vendors then? I don't think the city has considered any of this."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, speaking at a press conference in City Hall, said the sweep would ultimately benefit the economy of Harlem.
"Virtually all the vendors we're talking about here are illegal vendors," he said. Citing the failures of his predecessor, Mayor David N. Dinkins, to deal with the illegal vendors, Mr. Giuliani said "This time we have to make it work."
Legal vendors, he said, pay taxes. "There has been a feeling for some time that if you're concerned about the economic vitality of Harlem, this has to be dealt with," he said.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE GOVERNOR;
Cuomo, for One, Seeks to Hitch His Star To Clinton's

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FREEPORT, L.I., Oct. 17

 BODY:
In a year in which Democratic politicians are fleeing from the outstretched arms of President Clinton, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, ever the loyalist Democrat, made it clear today that he longs for the Administration's embrace and does not mind returning it. Indeed, he made a repeated point of describing the President as great but misunderstood, a heroic figure whose struggle for popularity sounded very much like his own.
"He has the most extraordinary record for achieving things that has not been appreciated," the Governor said of President Clinton while campaigning on Long Island today, calling Mr. Clinton not just a good President but a great President. "I think I know why: when you get something done, you don't let it sink in and exploit it. Let the people know what you've done." 
 Asked if he identified with the President, Mr. Cuomo suddenly turned coy, saying he would never make such a comparison.
But as if following his own prescription, the Governor throughout the day was lavish in his praise of President Clinton's accomplishments, and the Administration returned the favor by sending its second-highest emissary to demonstrate its solidarity with one of the few Democrats who seem to want it. Vice President Al Gore, joining the Governor at a converted defense plant here, called him one of the greatest governors in American history, and closed the circle of identification by saying that Mr. Cuomo is being challenged by the same conservative forces that daily besiege the White House.
"Let us be clear about the fact that America and New York face a choice," Mr. Gore said. "We've made a good start. We're moving in the right direction. Are we going to continue moving forward, or call a halt to the progress and take a radical right-wing U-turn back to the trickle-down Reaganomics approach that almost bankrupted this country and caused those two deep recessions, the worst since the Great Depression?"
Mr. Gore didn't say whether he was referring to right-wing Republicans in general, or to Mr. Cuomo's Republican opponent, State Senator George E. Pataki, who is generally considered more moderate than the party's most conservative wing. His point, in fact, seemed to be that there is no difference between them, a message that Mr. Cuomo has recently taken pains to assert in his speeches and advertisements.
Linking himself to the Administration holds a number of strategic advantages for Mr. Cuomo, the most important of which is that the President is more popular in New York State than the Governor is. The most recent New York Times-WCBS-TV poll, in fact, found that 55 percent of New Yorkers approve of the President's performance, while only 45 percent approve of the job Mr. Cuomo has done.
The Governor acknowledged such a calculation yesterday, saying that New York State "probably appreciates the President better than others."
"The truth, the God's honest truth is, if he weren't a plus I'd want him here," Mr. Cuomo told reporters. "He is my President, and I'm with him. But he is a plus, there's no question in my mind."
Standing shoulder-to-shoulder with Mr. Gore and, at a fund-raiser Wednesday night, with Mr. Clinton himself, also appeals directly to the traditional Democratic base that Mr. Cuomo is so desperately trying to energize and send to the polls next month.
His stops yesterday seemed to reinforce that point, reading like something out of a yellowing Democratic playbook from 30 years ago: a vigorously pro-union speech before the Communications Workers of America; a groundbreaking at a city-subsidized laboratory in the South Bronx; the appearance with Mr. Gore at a defense plant converting to civilian use, and finally a fund-raising dinner sponsored by the Democrats of Suffolk County.
The defense plant, Frisby Airborne Hydraulics Inc., is a small manufacturer of aircraft hydraulic systems that its chief executive, Greg Frisby, said was on the verge of closing as a result of the defense downturn that has ravaged Long Island's aerospace industry. Through a Federal and state loan guarantee plan for defense conversion, the company is joining forces with a Queens defense contractor, the Edo Corporation, to make similar systems for civilian aircraft.
Inside the stifling plant, filled with cheering Frisby employees and their families, the two perspiring Democrats took turns admiring each other's vision and exchanging credit for promoting such conversion plans.
Throughout the day, Mr. Cuomo had only one critical word about the Clinton Administration, noting that he had differed with the President's support of the North American Free Trade Agreement. But he included it as part of Mr. Clinton's "stunning" record of legislative accomplishment, one that he said is not fully appreciated by the public or media.
Ask 15 people in the street whether they know the President had increased the earned-income tax credit, he said, and not one will have heard about the important program for lower-income working families.
"That's not your fault and it's not mine," he told reporters. "They just didn't tell the story." Later, in the same vein, he said he is running the most substantive campaign ever, but that it has not received enough coverage.
 
IN THEIR OWN WORDS
 
GOV. MARIO M. CUOMO
As Governor Cuomo campaigns, he often laments what he describes as a mood of negativism he says he sees, adding that one of the reasons he wants a fourth term is to combat that mood. He repeated the message yesterday at a ground-breaking ceremony in the Bronx.
"This is one of the most negative periods in our history that I can recall. Over the last 10 or 12 years, this whole country seems to have turned sour, especially in recent years after the second recession. I'm trying to figure out why. Now we older people, you know, have a better span of vision; you younger people were born in the middle of negativism, and you had nothing else but negativism for 10, 12, 15 years. I don't know exactly where it came from."
 
STATE SENATOR GEORGE E. PATAKI
Speaking of the negativism, Senator Pataki was asked by reporters yesterday for his reaction to negative campaign ads being broadcast by the Cuomo campaign. Here is how Mr. Pataki, whose campaign is running its share of negative commercials, responded.
"I think it's just sad and unfortunate that instead of painting a picture of what the Governor wants to do in the future, he has lowered himself to trying to distort my record. . . . It's simply a sad attempt to frighten people about me."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: CONNECTICUT;
Groark Stays the Course As Campaign Sinks

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 17

 BODY:
An early surprise in Connecticut's race for governor is the fall in the polls of Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s chosen successor, who is favored by fewer than 10 percent of those surveyed, dangerously near the race's fringe candidates.
Analysts say the collapse from 1990, when Mr. Weicker won as an independent with 40 percent of the vote, is very much a result of traditional politics: voters don't like Mrs. Groark's defense of the Weicker record and her pledge to carry on his policies. 
 As more people have heard her call to stay the course set by Mr. Weicker, including making the state more competitive by continuing to use the personal income tax to cut business taxes, her unfavorable ratings have doubled and her standing in some polls has fallen by nearly half.
Some experts say that to voters unnerved by continuing upheaval among major employers like insurers, hospitals and military contractors, Mrs. Groark's assurances that she and Mr. Weicker have put Connecticut on the road to recovery contradict personal experience.
"Even the people who think Lowell has done a decent job don't believe the state is headed in the right direction," said Jonathan Pelto, a former political director of the State Democratic Party. "So, when Eunice Groark based her campaign on staying the course, she doomed it to failure."
But Mrs. Groark, a 56-year-old lawyer who also served two terms on the Hartford City Council, is proving as stubborn as Mr. Weicker as she promotes the administration's record along with the virtues of not being beholden to a political party.
Descended from Hartford's founder, Thomas Hooker, she campaigns with the erect posture and good-humored smile of a Yankee aunt. Her opponents, she says, are bad boys, "tough guys" making "macho" promises of tax cuts that they can't keep. She and Mr. Weicker have done what's best for Connecticut, she says, and she will continue the strict fiscal regimen that started the state to recovery.
"My job here," Mrs. Groark said in an interview in her Capitol office, "is to say: 'You may not have liked this, but we're way down the line here. Do you want to go backward or do you want to go forward?' "
While John G. Rowland, the Republican, who is leading in the polls, is promising to repeal the income tax, and William E. Curry Jr., the Democrat, is saying he will slash local property taxes, Mrs. Groark has hardened her no-nonsense theme.
In a television ad that was first broadcast today, she says: "You probably don't know much about me because I'm not really great at tooting my own horn. But I am good at governing, and I talk straight."
She then holds up papers representing the tax-cut plans of Mr. Rowland, Mr. Curry and another independent candidate, Tom Scott, and says, "These are the promises of the party politicians, and here's what they're worth." And she drops them into a trash can.
She also issued a biting attack on the Rowland and Curry tax-cut plans, saying both would force the state to raise taxes on business. "These guys think they can sell the public a bill of goods that is based only on their political ambition, not reality," she said.
Mrs. Groark, a former Republican, says she will cut taxes if money is available, but she will not touch the income tax. Instead, she wants to cut business taxes further, and perhaps lower the state's 6 percent sales tax.
She also pledges to recruit new companies to move to Connecticut, and says that to do so she will offer corporate tax credits like those that helped persuade Swiss Bank to move to Stamford from Manhattan.
In her appearances, Mrs. Groark makes honesty the foundation of her campaign. At a forum on the arts in Hartford, she told a questioner, yes, she supported more state aid for the arts, but she didn't know if the state could afford more.
Moving on to a radio talk show, she said, "I'm telling the truth," when asked what set her apart from the other candidates.
"Eunice has adopted a policy of being very honest, but I'm not sure it's winning her any votes," said Betsey P. Todt, director of the Quinnipiac College Poll, who added that she was surprised when Mrs. Groark lost ground after the Democratic and Republican primaries in September. "She is basing her campaign on the fact that she can't guarantee to do what she wants to do, that spending caps have to be observed. She's not telling voters what they want to hear."
Mrs. Groark said many voters haven't made up their minds, but her low standing in early polls is damaging because her party, A Connecticut Party, barely exists as a political organization. To appeal to contributors, she must appear to be a candidate with a chance to win. And if they desert her, the polls could become self-fulfilling.
Mr. Pelto said he was surprised that Mrs. Groark hadn't made more of her largest natural constituency, women. Connecticut, he said, was the first state to elect a female Governor, Ella T. Grasso, and now it has the opportunity to elect the nation's first all-female ticket: Mrs. Groark's running mate for lieutenant governor is Audrey Rowe, Mr. Weicker's former commissioner of social services.
But Mrs. Groark said her main base of support is a coalition of women's groups. "There are a lot of women in this state who are very concerned about the promotion of women in government, who believe more women should take risks, that more women should run for office," she said.
To her, Mr. Rowland and Mr. Curry are increasingly "the guys." And guys are nothing but trouble. In a radio ad, she accuses them of "making all kinds of promises that they could never keep. But you know, the men in this race will say anything to get what they want."
With the election three weeks away, the question is whether any candidates can overcome a perception that they are out of the running. Mrs. Groark throws up her hands.
"What should I do," she said, "change the message now to say, 'Oh, I never had anything to do with Lowell Weicker and this whole thing has been a flop for four years'?"
"I am very proud of this campaign," she continued. "We have not compromised. We have told it as we believe it to be. We've not lied. And we have made no promises that we can't keep."
