HEADLINE: State Outlines a Far Different Lilco

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
Trying to sell the Cuomo administration's plan for a $9 billion government takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, state officials have been telling Long Islanders that what the state wants is not just government ownership, but an overhaul of the company.
S. David Freeman, the president of the New York Power Authority, who would manage the transformation, outlined plans yesterday for the Suffolk County Legislature: solar cells, which make electricity directly from sunlight; fuel cells, which make electricity from gas or oil without combustion; help for homeowners in making energy improvements, and thousands of trees, planted on the south sides of buildings to cut the need for air-conditioning. And there would be a new role for the power system -- fostering economic development. 
 Lilco officials and some outside experts are skeptical that any of this is economically viable. Perhaps more important, it is not clear how State Senator George E. Pataki, the Republican candidate for governor, would react if he were elected; he has said only that he would have to look at the details of a state takeover.
Mr. Freeman, whom Mr. Cuomo appointed six months ago, is leading the effort to promote the takeover. He spoke at a news conference in Mineola, L.I., on Friday and was back on Long Island yesterday, describing not only the promised 10 percent cut in electricity rates, but also his vision for an electric system with a different feeling. It would be, he said, a system with "the people being in charge of their power system, the consumers being the owners."
The idea would be to create an innovative utility oriented toward limiting demand and making electricity in environmentally benign ways.
But Mr. Freeman is fighting a difficult battle. Even David Roe, an electricity expert at the Environmental Defense Fund, a national environmental group, said that the value of conservation investments was less clear at a time when electricity is abundant.
"The big savings used to be that you don't have to build the next plant, but we're not in that era now," he said. "This is a tough one for environmentalists," he said, though conservation programs like those Mr. Freeman favors still pay in terms of reduced emissions from power plants.
Mr. Freeman, however, insists that his plans make sense, and that he accomplished the goals he has laid out for Lilco in his last job, as general manager of the Sacramento Municipal Utility District, in California.
Lilco could have been described as innovative and risk-taking in the 1960's; it ordered three nuclear reactors and invested in a uranium mine, with results that are now infamous. Even the uranium mine went sour.
The utility concentrated on conservation in the early 90's when it appeared that junking Shoreham would lead to electricity shortages, but it recently asked the Public Service Commission for permission to reduce its expenditures in that area. The commission replied that if the company could achieve the same power reductions with less expenditure, it was welcome to do so.
In his talk to the Suffolk Legislature yesterday, Mr. Freeman said he would take a far more aggressive approach to conservation than Lilco has in the past.
In Sacramento, he paid bounties for old refrigerators to encourage customers to retire inefficient models and replace them with new ones. He also installed photovoltaic cells, which make power directly from sunlight, on the grounds of the company's defunct nuclear reactor, and had utility crews plant millions of trees on the south sides of houses, to put them in shade during the summer.
On Long Island, Mr. Freeman said, he would like to install fuel cells, which combine oxygen from air with hydrogen from oil or natural gas, to make water and electricity, as well as photovoltaic cells.
Lilco has taken a different approach.
"Our view is that conservation should be pursued insofar as it makes economic sense and helps us avoid building new power plants," said Suzanne Halpin, a spokeswoman. The company has spent more than $110 million on conservation since the late 1980's, she said. But she argued that too much conservation now, when energy demand is down and the region is coming out of a recession, could lead to a decline in revenue and force Lilco to seek higher rates.
"Mr. Freeman has a different view," Ms. Halpin said, "that energy conservation is good in and of itself."
Others, too, doubt that efficiency investments by the utilities really work.
People who accept subsidies to buy better light bulbs, refrigerators, windows or other energy-saving devices "are basically in it for the free lunch," said John P. Hughes, the technical director of the Electricity Consumers Resource Council, a Washington-based group that represents big industrial users of power. Since the cost of the subsidies flows into everyone's electric bills, those users pay the cost of raising the efficiency of others.
"People will take the rebate on the light bulb or whatever, and then they'll buy a new appliance," Mr. Hughes said. "You're stimulating an acquisition mentality of the upper income class. Where real conservation comes from is poor people's response to higher electric bills."
Lilco is an unusual candidate for conversion to public ownership. For one thing, the average public power system in this country has fewer than 2,000 customers; Lilco has about a million. For another, the era of conversion to public power ended about 50 years ago.
But Mr. Freeman has said repeatedly that there is no point in public ownership unless the public sector is going to perform differently than private companies.
In his view, Lilco would be a national model for clean energy sources. He would also like to turn the electric system into a force for economic development on the Island -- offering incentive rates to new industries -- rather than a drag, as it has been for years because of rates that are the highest of any major company in the nation.

HEADLINE: Logging Thrives on Economic Scare Tactics

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Oregon, Foiling Forecasters, Thrives as It Protects Owls" (front page, Oct. 11) shows that timber industry warnings that protecting the spotted owl would lead to economic collapse of timber communities were false. Oregon timber communities have experienced a boom, yet timber officials are still claiming that economic chaos will come. They'll be proved wrong again. 
 Timber companies rely on scare tactics and intimidation to obtain their goals. In the future we can expect them to use the same scare tactics when the destructive practice of clear-cutting is taken to task.
Clear-cutting, the common practice of removing all trees from a plot of land, followed by replanting of a single species, destroys true forests, turning them into raw lumber factories. The removal of all trees speeds erosion, leading to massive sedimentation of the rivers, which is part of the reason that salmon and other native fish are nearing extinction in the Pacific Northwest.
Clear-cutting causes rapid runoff, leading to flooding, like the massive floods that devastated the Puget Sound region near Seattle in November and December 1990. It destroys the interaction of the complex forest ecosystem, both underground and above the ground. And clear-cutting even destroys timber jobs, because a young logger working on a plot of land will never return to that land in his productive lifetime. A clear-cut plot of land requires about 50 years before it can be cut again.
On the other hand, selective cutting of trees, followed by planting (or even natural seeding) of a variety of trees, reduces erosion to minimum, preventing sedimentation of rivers. This would help save native fish and prevent massive episodes of flooding. The variation of tree species and variation in their ages is a boon to wildlife as well.
Selective cutting can retain the basic intricacy of the ecosystem if done properly. A selectively cut forest is surely far more pleasing to the eye than a clear-cut plot area of bare earth littered with nothing but stumps, broken limbs and piles of unwanted wood debris.
And selective cutting allows loggers to work on the same plot of land repeatedly during their productive years. But the timber companies will fight selective cutting with even greater vehemence than they fought spotted owl protection.
They will thereby prove that their only interest is the immediate bottom line, not the long-term benefits for the forest or the total environment, not the benefits to their own workers and certainly not their own long-term bottom line.
Good forestry practices can be achieved, but they will have to be achieved over the objections of the timber industry itself, which will do everything possible to create panic among its own workers about changes to make logging better for everybody.
 
BRUCE BARNBAUM
Granite Falls, Wash., Oct. 12, 1994

HEADLINE: Logging Thrives on Economic Scare Tactics;
Mining's False Prophets

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Further on your Oct. 11 front-page article on "timber-dependent" Oregon: Western Montana, despite mill closings and projections of the loss of tens of thousands of jobs, is also in the midst of an economic boom, with unemployment rates at 25-year lows. 
 In Oregon, the threat of massive job losses was used to force public natural resource managers to allow the lumber companies to clear-cut the last of this country's ancient forests. It is important to reflect on this phony economic blackmail.
In the early 1970's, when reclamation laws were proposed for Federal strippable coal, the mining industry predicted those laws would mean economic catastrophe for the coal mining industry. Hysterical claims and a Presidential veto preceded passage of the 1977 Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act.
As has been true in the Pacific Northwest with timber, the economic threats used to block strip mine reclamation proved false. Not only did surface mining of coal not halt because of environmental regulations, but it even continued to expand, and coal companies continued to make handsome profits.
Consider the current debate over the 1872 Mining Law. The mining industry claims that any significant change in how the public allows access to publicly owned mineral deposits will lead to the collapse of metal mining in the United States, the loss of 50,000 jobs and the "shaking of the very foundation of America's industrial base."
As research by the Congressional Budget Office and "Not All That Glitters," my 1994 study for the Mineral Policy Center, have pointed out, these are absurd claims, which have the same reliability as those made about timber harvests in Oregon and stripmining of coal.
Only 4 out of every 10,000 jobs in the United States are found in metal mining (0.04 percent), and only a small fraction of those are associated with mineral deposits on Federal lands. All of the jobs that might be lost as a result of ending the unbusinesslike Federal mineral giveaways can be expected to be made up by a single day of normal job growth in the Western states.
More important, since the economic revival of the West is driven by the pursuit of high-quality living environments, protecting the West's landscape from some of the ravages of chemical strip mining improves its economic base, rather than harming it. It is time for our politicians to stop submitting to the outrageous economic blackmail of the extractive industries.
 
THOMAS M. POWER
Prof. of Economics, U. of Montana
Missoula, Mont., Oct. 12, 1994

SECTION: Section C; Page 15; Column 1; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 1273 words

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Sellars's Merchant Of Venice Beach

BYLINE: By DAVID RICHARDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 14

 BODY:
At 37, Peter Sellars, the enfant terrible of the American theater, is no longer an enfant, but terrible is still an operative adjective.
If you exclude Robert Wilson, no American director so polarizes spectators, rankling some and enthralling others. With his staging of "The Merchant of Venice" for the Goodman Theater here, Mr. Sellars is running true to form. 
 Delivered at a glacial pace, with only tables and chairs for a set, the production lasts four daunting hours. At one recent performance, two-thirds of the audience bolted at intermission and those who held out to the end had the glazed look of hit-and-run victims. At the curtain call, there were bravos nonetheless.
Even as I count myself among the dazed, I can't entirely dismiss the production's unconventional fascinations. This cool, splintered view of "The Merchant of Venice" may have no more to do with traditional Shakespeare than a hand-lettered scroll has to do with E-mail, but it does say something disturbing about American malaise in the 1990's.
Mr. Sellars's Venice is the raffish Southern California beach town -- meeting ground, if not melting pot, for blacks, whites, Hispanic- and Asian-Americans. Racial divisions are deep, and the Rodney King riots lurk in the back of everyone's consciousness. By the end of the play, when Shakespeare's characters are usually celebrating blissful unions, the director has them stumbling through the viscous darkness before dawn.
Although the words remain Shakespeare's, Mr. Sellars puts such an idiosyncratic spin on scenes that he might as well be rewriting the script. Shylock, the Jewish moneylender, is portrayed by Paul Butler, a black actor. Portia (Elaine Tse) and her entourage are Asian-Americans. From the Spanish-speaking sector come Antonio (Geno Silva), the titular merchant, and Bassanio, who were lovers once, apparently, even if Bassanio (John Ortiz) is now intent on winning Portia's hand.
Portia, arguably one of Shakespeare's smartest and liveliest heroines, has become in Mr. Sellars's interpretation of things a perpetually distraught woman of abiding neuroses. As for the clowns, Old Gobbo and his son, Launcelot, they are white. Launcelot (Philip Seymour Hoffman), what's more, is all shouted rancor and not funny in the least, while Old Gobbo wears a sandwich board covered with biblical graffiti.
Mr. Sellars argues in a director's note that such innovations extend "the metaphor and the reality of anti-Semitism" to include "parallel struggles and their related issues." Does the approach make sense? No, not always. But then, the director -- who once plopped King Lear down in a Lincoln Continental, made room in Chekhov's "Seagull" for a laser show and is forever standing Mozart's operas on their heads -- has never been one for literalism. He is purposefully breaking up accepted notions of "The Merchant of Venice," dismantling characters' psyches and spreading out all the pieces for us to examine.
Much of the production is relayed over nine television monitors, positioned onstage and in the auditorium. Just as Shylock prepares to deliver his celebrated speech "Hath not a Jew eyes?" he deliberately turns his back on the audience. Only because a supernumerary is focusing a hand-held video camera on the actor's face, do we see it -- larger than life, but also stripped of any visceral immediacy -- on the monitors. Similarly, rather than address each other, the characters often talk into the microphones that stand at either side of the stage and sit on the various tables.
What Mr. Sellars sees happening to society at large -- a pulling apart of the races and a general breakdown of humanity -- happens to his performers as well, who become less than the sum of their parts. Frequently, a conscious effort is required to match voice and body, face and feeling. You get the impression, after a while -- as actors hunch over microphones and their profiles are splashed across the monitors -- that you're watching a Congressional investigation into "The Merchant of Venice."
It's a daring approach, but one that carries severe consequences. Emotions, thus fragmented, lose their power to move us. The great Shakespearean lines register as objective evidence, not as the spontaneous expression of wounded hearts and angry minds. Mr. Sellars may possess a quick and restless intellect, but passion, direct and undiluted, makes him uneasy. Invariably, he finds ways to hold it at a distance.
The stage is largely bare. The only sense of place is conveyed by video clips -- waves washing up on a beach, a luxuriant Bel Air flower garden and, of course, blurred shots of riot-torn Los Angeles -- and by sound effects that range from the distant roar of the freeway to the chirping of birds. James F. Ingalls, aiming shafts of light at the upstage wall, turns actors into stalking shadows, while Dunya Ramicova's costumes recognize that Southern California has always been something of a sartorial grab bag. In its abstract way, the oddly beautiful design captures much of the lemony-yellow ambiance of Los Angeles, as well as its sulfurous and dangerous depths.
The performers are another matter. Subservient to Mr. Sellars's overarching vision, they have little life and psychology of their own. Mr. Butler's Shylock is clearly and resonantly spoken, but the only truly moving aspect of the performance is his sad, stern face with its enormous folds of flesh, blown up large for the television screens. Ms. Tse, a svelte and alert Portia, dissolves into a mass of nerve endings and nearly comes unhinged during the trial scene. A rare note of playfulness is provided by Lori Tan Chinn, as Nerissa. But since Mr. Sellars categorically refuses to acknowledge the romantic aspects of the play, she and such actors as Mr. Ortiz, Rene Rivera (Lorenzo), Portia Johnson (Jessica) and Carlos Sanz (Gratiano) often seem stranded in limbo.
Love is, in fact, suspect from the start. "In a country in which economic well being is the only consideration," Mr. Sellars says, "there can be no well being." Accordingly, his "Merchant of Venice" is meant to be a chronicle of dislocation and psychosis, played against a backdrop of racial unrest. That may be just the ticket for the Europeans who will get to see the production after the Chicago run ends on Nov. 5. (It is scheduled to play engagements in London, Hamburg and Paris.)
Americans may be somewhat less convinced. Provocative as the director's thinking is, throughout this "Merchant" one nettlesome question looms above all others: Wouldn't Mr. Sellars be a more potent force in the theater if he felt more and actually thought less?
 
THE MERCHANT OF VENICE
By William Shakespeare; directed by Peter Sellars; costumes by Dunya Ramicova; lighting by James F. Ingalls; sound by Bruce Odland; dramaturge, Richard Pettengill; production stage manager, Michele Steckler; stage managers, Elizabeth Burgess and T. Paul Lynch; producer for Mr. Sellars, Diane J. Malecki. Presented by the Goodman Theater, Robert Falls, artistic director; Roche Schulfer, executive director. In Chicago.
 
WITH: Geno Silva (Antonio), Joe Quintero (Salerio), Richard Coca (Solanio), John Ortiz (Bassanio), Rene Rivera (Lorenzo), Carlos Sanz (Gratiano), Elaine Tse (Portia), Lori Tan Chinn (Nerissa), Midori Nakamura (Balthasar), Dorcas M. Johnson (Stephano), Paul Butler (Shylock), Tyrone Beasley (Prince of Morocco and Jailer), Philip Seymour Hoffman (Launcelot Gobbo), Del Close (Old Gobbo and the Duke of Venice), David Anzuelo (Leonardo), Portia Johnson (Jessica), Anjul Nigam (Prince of Arragon) and Ernest Perry Jr. (Tubal).

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1339 words

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: MASSACHUSETTS;
An Icon of 60's Liberalism Goes on the Attack

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, revered and reviled as liberalism's lawmaker, is fighting the battle of his political life on the ground he finds comfortable, defending government as an instrument of hope even as his opponent ridicules him as a man of "another time."
Mitt Romney, the Republicans' hope for their biggest single victory of the fall, uses television to portray the 62-year-old incumbent as fat and feeble, an irrelevant symbol of the 1960's who stands in the way of welfare reform, the death penalty and a smaller government that, the challenger says, would let the economy boom. 
 This week Mr. Kennedy replied, confronting the season's anti-government mood at a rally on Sunday at historic Faneuil Hall. "I stand for the idea that public service can make a difference in the lives of people," he said. "I reject the laissez-faire notion that all government has to do is get out of the way, and kind, caring, generous, unselfish, wealthy private interests and power will see to it that prosperity trickles down to ordinary people."
In his speech, the Senator rededicated himself to the ideals of his brother President John F. Kennedy. He said that if critics of the 60's meant the era of the "longest uninterrupted period of growth in history" or "the 1960's that asked us to do our best and to give something back to our country, then I am proud to be associated with the 60's."
For now, the general impression among politicians here is that the Senator holds a very modest lead but that the race is basically a tossup.
The messages of the two candidates differ as night does from day. On Saturday, for instance, Mr. Romney walked the tidy streets of South Boston, where anger against Mr. Kennedy over school busing that began in 1974 still simmers. "The 1960's liberal agenda hasn't worked," he told people as he shook hands. "It is time to reform the reforms."
At bottom, the election is a referendum on Mr. Kennedy. Some columnists and talk-show hosts want it to turn on the night in 1991 when he took his son Patrick and his nephew William K. Smith for drinks at a bar in Palm Beach, Fla. Dr. Smith, who returned to the Kennedy home there with a woman, was later charged with raping her but was acquitted.
To those opponents, Mr. Kennedy's weight and lined face reflect years of hard living. Mr. Romney's ads, showing a grainy, overweight Senator lumbering about, reinforce the point. In one, Mr. Kennedy, who broke his back in an airplane crash in 1964 and has worn a brace ever since, is shown painfully lowering himself onto a bench while the voice-over accuses the incumbent of "stooping" to attack Mr. Romney.
The Kennedy side wants a test instead of the man whom Representative Barney Frank introduced on Monday as having "the most productive record certainly of any senator in this century, a leader for civil rights, health insurance, education, the author of laws from Meals on Wheels to family and medical leave."
At home he is, most of all, the senior Senator with clout, whose ads tell of jobs he has saved and new ones he has brought to Massachusetts. In Washington, he is known as chairman of the Labor and Human Resources Committee and the senior Democrat on the Judiciary Committee. But here he emphasizes the jobs potential of his lesser seat on the Armed Services Committee.
Pumped up after Sunday's speech, Mr. Kennedy carried its theme of the future through the state on Monday. "This election," he told students at the University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth, is about whether the voters will choose someone "able to go to the Senate of the United States and build coalitions," someone who "has the experience and the know-how to make a difference for Massachusetts."
The speech on Sunday, Mr. Kennedy said in an interview, was intended to "set out what drives the campaign" and to point it toward the next six years.
Yet Sunday's setting also offered a painful glimpse backward. The last time Mr. Kennedy made a major political speech in Faneuil Hall, with its heroic painting of Daniel Webster and its scowling statue of John Adams, he was announcing his candidacy for the 1980 Democratic Presidential nomination. That was a campaign that failed for many reasons that were out of his hands by 1979, from Mary Jo Kopechne's drowning at Chappaquiddick 10 years earlier to the underrated skill and tenacity of President Jimmy Carter. But there was also a crucial flaw that Mr. Kennedy could have prevented: he started too late.
And that is a question again in 1994. This campaign coasted through the late summer, seemingly overconfident, leaving the airwaves to Mr. Romney's attack ads. On primary night, Sept. 20, Mr. Romney gave a dazzling victory speech in which he identified himself as a "rocket" of change. Mr. Kennedy's halting reading of his own victory speech made it seem very plausible, perhaps likely, that the hopes of the millionaire businessman and political novice would be fulfilled.
Since then, Mr. Kennedy's own attack ads have dented Mr. Romney a bit, pointing out that some of the venture capitalist's companies have cut jobs instead of creating them. But questions that Mr. Kennedy and a nephew, Representative Joseph P. Kennedy Jr., raised about the challenger's longtime leadership role in the Mormon Church, which until 1978 excluded blacks from the clergy, may have backfired.
With Congress adjourned, Senator Kennedy has been in Massachusetts almost full time, finding his voice, rousing students at one stop and the elderly at another. Mr. Romney has seemed rattled by receiving, rather than just issuing, televised attacks. Longtime Kennedy hands are taking time off and turning up to help. One former administrative assistant, David Burke, an investment banker, travels with Mr. Kennedy continually; another, Ranny Cooper, seems to be in charge at headquarters.
Each side will spend millions more in the next three weeks -- mostly on television, although Mr. Kennedy will also put $1 million into a get-out-the-vote operation.
But the crucial moment may come a week from today, in another event redolent of history: the first of two televised debates between the candidates.
Mr. Kennedy's first nomination, in 1962, was sealed by a debate between himself and Edward McCormack, a State Attorney General who thought that his experience entitled him to the nomination over the President's youngest brother. Mr. Kennedy, on the other hand, wanted to portray Mr. McCormack as a symbol of that day's old politics.
In trying to show how much more he knew about government and issues, Mr. McCormack came across as overbearing. He said Mr. Kennedy was running on name and family, and closed the debate by declaring that if the young man's name were not Edward Moore Kennedy but instead "Edward Moore, your candidacy would be a joke."
This time it is Mr. Romney, not Mr. Kennedy, who argues for change and wants to start at the top. It is the 47-year-old Mr. Romney who looks youthful in a state that has never before seen a campaigning Kennedy in late middle age. And it is Mr. Kennedy, not Mr. McCormack, who travels the state saying he has the experience, the influence and the political skill to get things done in Washington.
Mr. Romney says the debates will help him because exposure on television will give "people a grounding in who I am." He professes nervousness, and is skeptical about local newspaper expectations that the Senator's sometimes fractured syntax will make him seem inarticulate.
Each side seems likely to spend about $10 million before the race is over, and Mr. Romney says he is ready to add to the $2 million of his own money that he has already put into the campaign. "That was part of the plan," he said in an interview on Saturday.
Polls show few people undecided about Mr. Kennedy. "We just need to get rid of that liberal nitwit," said Grace Chandler in South Boston. But Cliff Danue, a retired engineer in Attleboro, said: "You always remember what the Democrats did for you. I'll vote for him every time."

GRAPHIC: Photos: At the University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth, Senator Edward M. Kennedy stressed his experience. (pg. A1); Thirty-two years ago, the youthful political novice stumping for the Senate in Massachusetts was Edward M. Kennedy. This time it is his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, a 47-year-old venture capitalist, who got out to meet the voters of Boston at a campaign gathering on Saturday. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times) (pg. B8)

Senate Race
 Democrat: Edward M. Kennedy, 62
 Republican: Mitt Romney, 47
 
Analysis
 While many incumbents are trying to fashion themselves as Washington outsiders, Senator Kennedy insists that his clout there helps Massachusetts and his view of government as a powerful force helps the nation. Mr. Romney, the son of former Gov. George Romney of Michigan, ridicules him as out of date, and offers a younger image as a conservative voice for change.

HEADLINE: Puerto Ricans on Mainland Making Gains, Study Finds

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS 

 BODY:
Puerto Ricans born in the 50 states made striking economic gains in the 1980's -- so striking that, by one measure, their income now surpasses that of Hispanic residents generally and of American-born blacks, a new national study has concluded. But those who migrated to the mainland from Puerto Rico lag behind mainland-born Puerto Ricans in income, education and employment.
The study also found that Puerto Ricans had moved beyond longtime geographical enclaves. Among Puerto Ricans living in the 50 states in 1960, two in three were residents of New York City; today, fewer than one in three is. 
 The study was conducted for the National Puerto Rican Coalition, a Washington-based advocacy group, by Dr. Francisco L. Rivera-Batiz of Teachers College at Columbia University and Dr. Carlos Santiago of the State University of New York at Albany. It was partly intended to counter stereotypes of Puerto Rican underachievement and to buttress the coalition's fight against deficient housing, health care and education and other barriers to employment and economic advancement.
"There is a stereotypical view of Puerto Ricans in the minds of many," says the study, which is to be issued in Washington today. "This view is that Puerto Ricans constitute a more or less homogeneous group standing at the bottom of the socioeconomic ladder in the country. It is often perceived that, in contrast to other Hispanic groups, Puerto Ricans have failed to achieve significant economic progress in the United States. The evidence presented in this research report shatters these stereotypes."
The study, drawing on 1990 census results made available only recently, dealt with Puerto Ricans living on the American mainland. It found a substantial increase in income, although it also found that this increase masked contrasts between two Puerto Rican populations roughly equal in size: one showing significant gains, the other stagnant.
Measuring average household income per person, the study recorded a 29 percent increase for Puerto Ricans generally during the 1980's. That average household income per person increased 32 percent among those born on the mainland, to $8,379, and 24 percent among those born in Puerto Rico, to $8,360. (The 29 percent overall increase, the largest such gain by any major ethnic or racial group, partly reflected a decline in the size of an average Puerto Rican household.)
The result offered a marked contrast to 1979, when only Dominicans trailed Puerto Ricans in income among Hispanic American groups. The gains of the following decade gave Puerto Ricans in 1989 an income figure that was higher than for Hispanic Americans over all and for blacks. It remained lower than the household income for Americans of Cuban or South American descent, however, and was only about half what non-Hispanic whites earned.
The study found that the biggest gains in income, education and employment by Puerto Rican men and women alike had been registered largely by those born on the mainland. Among all people born in the 50 states, the rate of Puerto Rican men who were employed or looking for jobs -- what the study called the rate of labor participation -- was higher than for blacks and for Hispanic people over all; for Puerto Rican women, it was higher than even the national average of all women.
But among all immigrants (a category in which the study placed Puerto Ricans who had moved to the mainland), Puerto Ricans had the lowest rates of labor participation.
The study also traced a shift by Puerto Ricans out of enclaves like New York City. From 1980 to 1990, the Puerto Rican population grew at its highest rate in Florida, Massachusetts, Texas and Connecticut. Nearly half of all Puerto Ricans on the mainland still live in New York or New Jersey. But about 1 in 10 lives in Florida, and Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Illinois and California each is home to about 1 in 20.
"It is evident that the community has polarized into two groups," said Louis Nunez, president of the National Puerto Rican Coalition. "One shows significant movement into white-collar occupations, significant gains in education and movement to the Sun Belt; the other, mostly non-high school graduates, live in the decaying neighborhoods of the older cities."
Angelo Falcon, president of the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy in New York, agreed that even with the gains, "you're still talking about a community with one of the highest poverty rates in the country, and the growing middle class is growing in places like Texas and Florida."
In their discussion of the stereotyping of Puerto Ricans, the study's authors placed some blame on Linda Chavez, director of the Manhattan Institute's Center for the New American Community, who has written about disparities in the progress of Hispanic groups in the United States.
When asked about the study's criticism, Ms. Chavez said, "Sometimes people use me for a foil, only to find they agree with some of what I'm saying."
She said the study gave reason for optimism. "In education and individual earnings, Puerto Ricans are not at the bottom," she said. "The problem is you have bifurcated communities: those in the labor force who are doing quite well, and a very large underclass."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Merck and Lilly Post Strong Earnings and Sales

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Two big pharmaceutical companies, Eli Lilly and Merck, reported strong quarterly sales and earnings growth yesterday. SmithKline Beecham, also an important drug maker, reported a relatively modest 4.9 percent gain as it struggled with price-cutting for generic copies of its flagship Tagamet, a widely used anti-ulcer treatment.
Analysts said the industry would report earnings growth of 5 to 8 percent in the third quarter, reflecting reduced spending for sales and marketing and aggressive discounting to increase volume. 
 "Most drug companies did better than expected," said Barbara Ryan, an analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons.
Jack Lamberton of NatWest Securities said price "deflation" appeared to be moderating. He said health maintenance organizations and other managed-care insurers might have eased their demands for drug discounts after the collapse of proposals in Washington to regulate insurance premiums.
Eli Lilly & Company and Merck & Company were well ahead of the pack. Reporting an extraordinary sales quarter for Prozac, its billion-dollar-a-year antidepressant, Lilly said net income rose 22 percent, excluding a charge for research it acquired early last month in buying the Sphinx Pharmaceutical Corporation. With the charge, profits rose 8.3 percent.
Merck, the world's largest drug maker, said net income was up 11.4 percent from the third quarter of 1993, despite the lower profit margins of its Medco managed-care unit. With help from Medco's distribution networks, sales in Merck's traditional drug-making businesses increased 15 percent in the quarter. Overall sales, including Medco's, rose 49 percent.
Joyce Albers of First Boston Securities said the results for the Indianapolis-based Lilly were "far better than anyone would ever have imagined." The company had alerted investors last month that the news would be good. "Prozac is really coming through in spades," she said.
Prozac sales accelerated an extra $70 million as distributors filled their inventories after a 3.5 percent price increase was announced.
But Mr. Lamberton of NatWest said Lilly's profit margins were down, reflecting price-cutting. He said the company might have a down quarter in the current three-month period, as Prozac sales slacken after the inventory buildup.
Ms. Ryan said an important question was whether Lilly's agreement to buy PCS, a big managed-care and drug distribution unit of the McKesson Corporation, would go through as planned. The company said last week that it was postponing completion of the deal while it responded to concerns of the Federal Trade Commission staff, which is reportedly examining possible anti-competitive effects of the $4 billion proposal.
The commission, however, did approve similar recent purchases of managed-care units by Merck and SmithKline Beecham P.L.C.
Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., said quarterly earnings per share remained flat despite the profit growth, mainly because additional Merck shares were issued in the Medco acquisition. It said sales growth was led by newer products. SmithKline, based in London, said its earnings benefited from the amortization of good will in the purchase of Diversified Pharmaceutical Services, a managed-care drug distributor. Ms. Ryan said SmithKline's pharmaceutical sales included conflicting trends. Tagamet, which used to be a $1 billion blockbuster, was down 56 percent, to $125 million, in the quarter. But new products, including Paxil, an antidepressant; Relafen for arthritis, and Kytril, to help overcome nausea during chemotherapy for cancer, rose by 83 percent, to $341 million, in the period.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Busy 1st Day Of Trading For Indosat

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

 BODY:
Indonesia's state-owned international telecommunications company, the P. T. Indonesia Satellite Corporation, made its debut on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, with a 17 percent rise in its first day of trading.
Indonesia's role as an emerging market and past successes among telephone companies being privatized in other countries seemed to attract buyers as much as the potential of the company, which is also known as Indosat. 
 Merrill Lynch & Company, the lead underwriter, called Indosat the largest overseas stock offering ever by an Asian company. The Indonesian Government will keep 65 percent and sell 10 percent on its domestic market; the remaining 25 percent sold worldwide is expected to raise more than $1 billion.
American depository receipts for shares in Indosat were priced at $32.00, traded as high as $40, and closed at $37.50. More than 9 million A.D.R.'s changed hands, making it the exchange's most active issue. A.D.R.s are traded in lieu of shares for foreign companies listed on American markets.
The interest in Indosat, fund managers said, came in part from buyers eager for a piece of anything from Indonesia. With 180 million people, Indonesia is the fourth-most- populous country in the world; yet, it is little known in the United States.
"It's been a neglected market," said Anthony L. T. Cragg, a fund manager at Strong/Corneliuson Management Inc. in Menominee Falls, Wis. Mr. Cragg said he bought more than $3 million of the stock. "If you're going to go in there, this is a good long-term play."
Indosat is the second Indonesian company to be listed in the United States, after P. T. Tri Polytra, a petrochemical company that entered the market at $21 in July and rose sharply in the past week, as Indosat was oversubscribed. A.D.R.'s for Tri Polytra closed yesterday at $29.375, down 50 cents, in Nasdaq trading.
In contrast, two utilities from China have performed disappointingly. The Shandong Huaneng Power Company entered the market in September at $14.25, but closed yesterday at $11, a new low. And after it was listed on Oct. 6, Huaneng Power International sold virtually unchanged at $20 for a week. It closed yesterday at $18.75, up 75 cents.
Indosat, with 1,100 employees, had net income in 1993 of $116 million on revenues of $354 million.
To Mr. Cragg, Indosat's business is sure to grow as Indonesia becomes a bigger player in Asia's economy. He is also bullish on Indonesia, where he sees a smartly managed economy and political stability.
But the country's currency, the rupiah, is expected to continue its decline in value, which might concern Indosat's foreign investors.
Perhaps more important, coinciding with Indosat's privatization is a dismantling of its monopoly on international calls. A second company, whose investors include a son of President Suharto, will compete with Indosat for international telecommunications business.

HEADLINE: Baghdad's Kuwait Caper: Its Isolation Gets Deeper

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Two weeks after Iraq moved troops toward Kuwait in what some diplomats called a gamble to get the United Nations to lift crippling trade sanctions, the sanctions remain in place and Baghdad has little room for diplomatic or military maneuvering.
Baghdad's hope that Washington's swift military response could be checked by nations like France, Russia and China in the United Nations Security Council collapsed as the Council voted unanimously on Sunday to condemn Iraq's actions, as it has done repeatedly since the invasion of Kuwait in 1990. 
 The hope that a revived Russian diplomatic effort could rescue Baghdad, which had once relied on a close alliance with the Soviet Union, also collapsed. The Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, who led an effort to ease the pressure on Iraq last week, agreed on Monday with the United States Secretary of State, Warren M. Christopher, that the United States-Russian partnership in international matters was more important than Russia's concern for Iraq.
And within the Arab world, where Iraq found some support in the summer of 1990 when it annexed Kuwait, there has been, this time, only silence or condemnation.
Jordan, virtually the only link Iraq has had with the outside world, did not just distance itself from Baghdad. King Hussein warned last week that he would side against Iraq if it tried a military move against another Arab country. This week the King said he would sign a peace treaty with Israel, Iraq's archenemy.
This morning it looked indeed as though Iraq had been isolated, and it was far from clear what the Government of President Saddam Hussein could do to alter the situation.
Even recognition by Iraq of Kuwait's integrity and international borders -- a last card that Baghdad has been witholding as a bargaining chip -- no longer seems enough to get the United States and some of its allies, including Britain, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, to relent in their pressure to maintain the crippling four-year-old trade sanctions.
Iraqi officials and diplomats from European countries here are persuaded that the aim of the United States and its allies is to bring down the Government of President Hussein, not to obtain a fulfillment of United Nations resolutions.
"The thing is that every time we comply with an item of the United Nations resolution, they come up with another argument to keep the sanctions," a senior Iraqi official said in a conversation this weekend. "I am persuaded we cannot do enough to get these sanctions lifted by the Security Council because the goal of the sanctions in the mind of the United States is to starve the Iraqis into rebellion against their Government." Foreign diplomats here say this assessment is on the mark.
Asked what Iraq would do, the official seemed at a loss. After a while, he said: "America should change this vengeful attitude because it will result in a chaotic breakdown from which no one will benefit. Future generations of Iraqis will remember this."
The problem for Iraq, however, is what to do to save this generation of Iraqis from the suffering they are subjected to because of the sanctions, which prohibit all trade except for food and medicine.
Clearly, Iraqi decision-makers have yet to formulate an answer.
On Monday the Government convened its 250-member Parliament with the intent of officially recognizing Kuwait. But as the Security Council debate that followed the passing of the resolution dragged on in New York, it became clear that such a step would not be enough.
Finally the Parliament simply adopted a resolution that said it would do anything the leadership and President Hussein agreed to do.
This morning the Iraqi-controlled news organizations were busy looking for silver linings in this latest duel with the United States, with headlines announcing that the "big crossing" toward an end of the hardships had begun. Yet Government officials were conceding elsewhere what is becoming increasingly evident here: they are running out of concrete ways to cope with the situation.
Last month the meager rations guaranteed to every citizen, which barely fulfilled two-thirds of internationally recognized minimal nutrition requirements, were cut in half.
On Monday Iraq's Trade Minister, Saadi Mehdi Saleh, showed reporters the meager rations to which people are entitled now: a little rice, wheat flour, tea, sugar, cooking oil and detergents, saying "this is the quota for a people who are living on a lake of oil, one of the richest people in the world."
With its oil exports blocked by the United Nations, the Iraqi Government is simply running out of money, which means that Iraq is increasingly unable to guarantee the minimum requirements to feed its people.
Baghdad's apparent gamble that resorting to a military expedition might somehow help focus attention on its plight and result in lifting of the sanctions backfired as the United States moved thousands of troops and overwhelming air power to the region.
It is particularly galling for Iraq, which possesses the world's second largest oil reserves, after Saudi Arabia, to find its main source of revenue mothballed by the international community while the Saudis moved four years ago to take over Iraq's share of the international oil market. Four years ago that share stood at three million barrels a day.
When asked whether he can see the connection between the embargo and the behavior of the Iraqi Government, Mr. Saleh, the trade minister, vigorously responded: "We all stand behind President Saddam Hussein and are proud to follow him. We will resist."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: In Opening Its Finance, Mexico Bets Long Term

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Mexican and foreign executives alike welcomed Mexico's wide opening to foreign banks and brokerage houses today, putting aside the prospect of tougher competition to instead emphasize the shot in the arm for Mexico's flagging economy.
"This is a historic event," said Ricardo Guajardo, chairman of Grupo Financiero Bancomer, Mexico's second-largest financial organization. "These banks are definitely going to represent greater competition, but it is not going to come overnight." 
 In a long-awaited announcement on Monday night, the Finance Ministry said it was authorizing virtually all the foreign banks, brokerages and insurance companies that sought to enter the Mexican market.
All told, the Government said it will issue 52 licenses to 18 commercial banks, 16 securities firms, 12 insurance companies, 5 financial groups and a leasing company for one of the banks, Citibank.
A few applicants dropped out of the process, while a couple of others were asked by the ministry for more information. Officials said that in the coming weeks, they would act on the applications of several dozen leasing and bonding companies, mutual funds and other firms.
"There were no rejections," the deputy finance minister for banking, Guillermo Ortiz Martinez, said in an interview today.
Almost since the revolution of 1910, during or after which most foreign bankers in Mexico closed or sold their holdings, Citibank has been the country's lone foreign subsidiary, lending primarily to big corporations and other high-end clients.
Of the new banks now authorized -- which include Chemical Bank, the Bank of America and the Bank of Boston, Banco Santander of Spain and the Bank of Tokyo -- only Citibank is expected to compete with the 35 Mexican-owned commercial banks for retail customers.
Instead, most of the new entrants plan to expand business they have already begun to do with representative offices here -- areas like investment banking, corporate advisory services, trade financing and derivatives contracts.
"We have a great number of clients, not just in the United States but around the world, who see opportunity in Mexico," said Dennis Weatherstone, chairman and chief executive of J. P. Morgan, "and we will now be able to take care of them better."
Mr. Weatherstone, speaking by telephone from New York, said Morgan initially planned to bring about $100 million in capital to Mexico, eventually increasing its staff to 100 from 20 now. "We think there's enough business for us," he said.
Although officials say the licenses will bring about $1.2 billion in direct investment, the new banks' ability to lend in pesos is unlikely to mean much broad new credit beyond loans to big, blue-chip corporations and other wealthy clients, an area that is already the most competitive part of the Mexican financial market.
As a result, the prospect of foreigners' exerting downward pressure on Mexico's high interest rates -- now, for instance, 13.33 percent on a 28-day Treasury note -- is considered somewhat distant. Such rates, spilling over to business, limit the country's economic growth. Beyond that, banking-industry analysts say, the general lack of reliable credit information on smaller Mexican companies, discouraging to Mexican banks, will weigh even more heavily on foreigners' lending decisions.
"The competition will be in the corporate sector and international finance," Mr. Ortiz, the deputy finance minister, said. "But that is going to force Mexican banks to look for clients that have not traditionally interested them, like smaller and medium-sized companies. And with that, there will be a trickle-down effect."
Mexican officials also hope that the influx of foreigners will also help modernize finance, moving the country closer to the standards in international capital markets.
Foreign banks gained entry to Mexico as part of the wider opening to United States and Canadian investment under the North American Free Trade Agreement, which took effect on Jan. 1.
The accord initially limits foreign bankers to 8 percent of the total market, with the figure rising to 15 percent by 2000 and at least 25 percent by 2004, at which point the competition is opened entirely.
In practice, Mr. Ortiz said, the doubling in the capitalization of Mexican banks over the last two years and the limited ambitions of the new foreign licensees meant that the Government did not have to set limits on the capital of the new banks.

HEADLINE: Jordan's King Is Betting On a 'Peace Dividend'

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 18

 BODY:
During the Persian Gulf war three and a half years ago, Fouad al-Afghani did a brisk business selling key chains and lapel pins modeled on the 39 Iraqi Scud missiles that were fired at Israel. His jumbled store in downtown Amman still offers a T-shirt emblazoned with a Scud and the words, "Who will fire the 40th?"
These days, Mr. Afghani, 47, a Palestinian who barely knew his family's home in Jaffa before Israel became a state and he became a refugee, feels he has been left behind by the region's ever-shifting politics. 
 In many ways, the latest shift is embodied in the man who rules over him: King Hussein of Jordan.
During the gulf war, King Hussein looked east and aligned himself with Saddam Hussein, to the delight of people like Mr. Afghani who saw the Iraqi President as an Arab hero.
These days, Iraq is again challenging the United States, but this time the King is shunning Iraq and making peace with Israel, even trading admiring compliments with its Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, as Jordan and Israel initialed a draft peace treaty here on Monday.
"If you want to know the truth, this is a very bitter day," Mr. Afghani said. "If peace brings economic help, fine.
"But this peace means the end of the hope that I will ever get my home back again," he said of his family's former holdings. "The Israelis will never give you life."
Four years ago, passions like these among the Palestinians, who make up about two-thirds of Jordan's population of 4.2 million, drove the King to side with Iraq as Mr. Hussein sent troops into Kuwait and fulminated against Israel.
But today the Jordanian King is betting that the bulk of his people will embrace the views of other Palestinians like Ghassan Joumaa, 21, a vendor of perfumes and baby wear, who acknowledges that things have changed a lot since he took to the streets four years ago to rally behind Saddam Hussein.
"Today the situation is different," Mr. Joumaa said, breaking off the conversation to sell a pair of toddlers' tights. "Because of those days, we have suffered like the Iraqi people. So now it is time to make our own interests our priority, and we hope that our interests lie in peace."
"We have our hands on our hearts," he said, using an Arabic expression that means, roughly, "We're hoping for the best."
The King's 180-degree reversal since the gulf war shows how significantly the region's erstwhile cornerstone -- an implacable hostility to Israel -- has begun to buckle in the face of the deals Israel has struck with the Palestine Liberation Organization and Jordan and is now actively seeking with Syria.
In Jordan, a poor land surrounded by neighbors that are either more populous, more wealthy or more powerful -- and often all three -- it has a lot to do with money.
When Jordan and Israel signed an agreement earlier this year formally ending a 46-year state of war, the United States promised to move quickly to ease Jordan's huge debt and to increase economic aid.
With President Clinton planning to attend the final signing of the peace treaty next week at the Israeli-Jordanian border, Prime Minister Abdul-Salam al-Majali said today, "I'm sure that this moral support will be accompanied by a lot of economic support."
If there was one thought that consistently emerged in conversations with people in Jordan today, it was that peace with Israel would end the economic hard times that resulted from their support for Iraq.
As a result of that stand, the wealthy gulf countries expelled some 350,000 Palestinians, who flooded into Jordan's labor market and drove up unemployment.
Without jobs in the gulf, Jordanians could no longer send home the billion dollars in remittances that helped keep the economy afloat. Saudi Arabia completely severed financial aid, and, unlike Kuwait, has not even slightly softened its stand since then. The United States and other Western countries also cut off financial support.
With few natural resources of its own, and its water resources dwindling, Jordan was under strong pressure to wrest whatever economic gain it could get from peace negotiations.
"Jordan remains almost numb" from economic pressures ranging from water shortages to chronically high unemployment and poverty, a commentator, Rami Khouri, wrote in today's Jordan Times. He said those problems were "generating a frantic willingness to do whatever is required of it to survive."
After 42 years on the throne, King Hussein is known as a survivor. After the P.L.O. struck its own deal with Israel a year ago, Jordan began scrambling to deal itself back into regional diplomacy, even though not everyone approved.
Its neighbor Syria, increasingly isolated by the peace moves, immediately expressed opposition to the draft treaty initialed on Monday, repeating its long-held position of opposing two-way accords.
"There will be no stability in the region without achieving just and comprehensive peace, the Syrian Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, said in Damascus today. "That is why we always criticize bilateral treaties." Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad, flew to Cairo for a hastily arranged visit apparently spurred by his worries over the treaty.
The P.L.O., which has long vied with King Hussein for the right to speak for Palestinians, challenged the peace accord in one highly charged area: the stewardship of Muslim holy sites in Jerusalem.
When Jordan and Israel renounced hostilities in July, Israel formally pronounced that Jordan had a special status in administering those sites -- an important issue for King Hussein, as the ruler of the Hashemite dynasty, which claims descent from the prophet Mohammed. The draft treaty initialed on Monday reaffirmed Jordan's role as custodian, Prime Minister Majali said today.
The P.L.O. also claims stewardship over the shrines and calls East Jerusalem the capital of an eventual Palestinian state. Last weekend, both sides appointed rival muftis in Jerusalem, and today the P.L.O. called Jordan's position a "flagrant violation."

HEADLINE: Study Says Environmental and Economic Health Go Together

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 18

 BODY:
A new state-by-state study suggests that governments need not sacrifice environmental quality for economic well being.
In fact, the report, released last week by the nonprofit Institute for Southern Studies, a social policy research and advocacy group, shows that nearly all of the states that ranked among the top dozen using the study's environmental criteria also ranked highest using its economic criteria. 
 Similarly, nearly all of those judged lowest on environmental standards were also at the bottom economically. Most of those states were in the South.
"At a policy level, the choice is really not jobs versus the environment," said Bob Hall, research director of the institute, based in Durham, N.C. "The states that do the most to protect their natural resources also wind up with the strongest economies and best jobs."
While some economists applauded the study's general view that environmental and economic health could be compatible, they said that the interaction between the two was too complicated to allow for simple testing. And not all of them agreed with the economic and environmental categories used.
The study found that 9 states were among the top 12 in both environmental and economic health. They were Vermont, Hawaii, New Hampshire, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Colorado, Oregon, Massachusetts and Maryland. The 10 states at the bottom in both categories were Louisiana, West Virginia, Alabama, Mississippi, Tennessee, Texas, South Carolina, Indiana, Kentucky and Oklahoma.
The report used 20 economic indicators, including worker health and accident statistics, unemployment rates, job growth rates, income and poverty data, educational attainment and analyses of tax fairness.
The 20 environmental indicators included amounts of toxic products produced or discharged per capita, energy consumption, the ratio of pollution emissions to manufacturing jobs and the percentage of the state budget spent on the environment.
The study reflected what some states have already reported. In Oregon, for example, logging restrictions have not killed the timber industry, as was feared.
"The real choice is between policies that produce short-term gain for the few versus long-term strategies that improve the quality of life for the many," Mr. Hall said.
The report said that the South in particular had squandered natural resources in pursuit of jobs and development, only to end up with fewer high-paying jobs, higher poverty rates and, in many pockets, lowered economic prospects.
The South has long tried to attract business by offering many incentives and few restrictions. The strategy worked for a time, said Paul Templet, a political scientist at Louisiana State University and former Commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Quality.
Louisiana had initial success, he said, "but then we found that personal income dropped, poverty rose, income disparity ratio rose, all as environmental indicators declined. We thought it would bring in jobs and prosperity, but it hasn't, and we are getting more and more unattractive as a place to do business."
But William Kucharski, the current Commissioner of Environmental Quality, said the state's last-place ranking in the study was a result of taking particular facts -- a high concentration of chemical plants and oil refineries and a low population -- and adding them up to paint a false picture.
"There is no question that we have a great deal of poverty," he said, "but that's more associated with the businesses we don't have than with the businesses we do have."
Officials in Minnesota, which was near the top in both categories, said the study vindicates aggressive environmental protection.
"We learned a simple fact earlier than most states, and that is that you can't trash the natural resource forever," said Chuck Williams, the Commissioner of the state's Pollution Control Agency.
Some economists warned that the study did not prove that tight environmental regulation attracted economic development. Dirty air and fouled waterways might repel potential businesses, but the things that combine to make a vibrant economy are much more complicated than the study suggests, argued Roger Dower, an economist with the World Resources Institute, an organization concerned with environmental and economic issues.
In addition, Paul Portney, an economist with Resources for the Future, a research group based in Washington, argued that each new dollar spent on environmental regulation was now producing less environmental benefit while adding more to the cost of doing business.
Fred Krupp, executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund, said the study could reduce the polarization between conservationists and industry. He cited Federal legislation on acid rain that gave industry flexibility in reducing pollution. The legislation saved some companies from having to close plants, he said.

HEADLINE: Families Look at Failure on Health Care and Lament Politics

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: IOWA CITY, Oct. 14

 BODY:
In the ruins of President Clinton's promise of affordable cradle-to-grave health care, five families in Middle America have found their hopes for changing the health care system transformed into contempt for a Washington that they say, cares not a whit about them.
"Why can't they just put their political parties aside and do something good for all of us?" said Debra O'Connor, 31, of Lisbon, Iowa, a factory worker and single parent with three young sons. 
 Clifford McLaughlin, a 42-year-old factory worker from East Moline, Ill., was blunter, and jaded. Why did the health care legislation fail? "Big business said 'no,' " he said. And Congress? "That's big business."
The New York Times had already interviewed most of the families in more optimistic times, first in May 1993 as the health care legislation and its attendant debate took shape and again in Sept. 1993, when the President unveiled his plan to the public. Now, in the aftermath of the plan's demise, their disappointment is tinged with unease over what a bout of cancer or a heart attack could do to their financial health.
The families represent a broad spectrum. They are young and old, working and not working, healthy and chronically sick, middle class and poor, richly insured and uninsured. One interviewed earlier, an impoverished single mother who was fighting cancer, could not be reached. A year ago she said she would be marrying a soldier and expected the Army to provide her coverage. Another single mother in ill-health and equally poor, Barbara Jo Matson, was interviewed in her place.
Residents of a flourishing stretch of cornbelt and industry in eastern Iowa and western Illinois that is home to the University of Iowa, most of these people are Democrats who, like the region in general, tend toward moderation and ticket-splitting.
The families fault Mr. Clinton for pushing a plan that seemed cumbersome, confused and flawed, threatening their ties to cherished doctors, for example. But they salute him for tackling an issue no previous President would touch, and found enough in his plan to lift their hopes that at last, growing old, falling ill or being injured need not drive them into poverty.
The culprits they are quickest to blame are Congressional Republicans and in particular the critic who popped up most often on their television screens, Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican minority leader of the Senate. "Mean, sarcastic," said Elma Patten, 60, of Cedar Rapids, whose long history of illness has reduced her family's savings to $5,000. "You know he's creating this havoc."
Some of these people have concluded that it pays to stay poor. Ms. Matson, 37, of Iowa City, a mother of three children, has disease-wracked lungs. She might still qualify for some jobs, but then the Government might make her pay for health care. So she relies on welfare and Medicaid, the health care program for the poor.
The families of Ms. O'Connor, and Mr. McLaughlin are protected by comprehensive health insurance plans that their unions have worked out with their employers. But for them, too, the high cost of care is a constant worry.
Ms. O'Connor fears that a layoff looms and her coverage will stop. Mr. McLaughlin and his wife, Valerie, are thrilled with the policy his employer currently provides, since it has covered the cost of treating their 10-year-old daughter's diseased eyes. But the President's plan promised health insurance for Mrs. McLaughlin's healthy, 23-year-old daughter from a previous marriage, who having fled welfare and Medicaid, has gone to work and has no coverage.
By any measure, William Coen, 80, and his wife Gertrude, 78, are sitting pretty. As Federal retirees, they have all the low-cost protection that members of Congress receive and their benefits have even improved in the last year. But they worry about other elderly men and women who are not as lucky and wonder whether Congress will ever agree to even patchwork repairs on the current system.
As the debate in Washington evolved, Mr. Coen said, "We became disgusted, and our friends got so disgusted, if the paper said anything about health care, they didn't even read it."
 
The McLaughlins
Doctor's Caring Spurs Support
 For Clifford and Valerie McLaughlin, who are both 42, this has been a largely trouble-free year in terms of health. But it has been a worrisome year in terms of health care coverage. They prize the freedom they have had to choose their doctors. So they were wary of the President's plan, which they thought would force them to use designated doctors.
Now that his plan has failed, they fear that their choices may be curbed by other means: that the continuing rise in health care costs will persuade Deere and Company, for whom Mr. McLaughlin works as a $45,000-a-year press operator, to restrict the roster of doctors covered by the health plan it negotiates with the union.
The McLaughlins believe their ability to shop around for the most appropriate medical care saved the eyesight of their 10-year-old daughter, Amber. After misdiagnoses, delayed treatment and one doctor's telling them to simply accept his prognosis that Amber would soon be blind, Mrs. McLaughlin found Imir Arbisser, an opthamologist. She and her husband say that he found the root of Amber's disease -- juvenile arthritis -- then removed a cataract and enlisted specialists to treat what he could not.
Dr. Arbisser also won their hearts. After an operation at the University of Iowa four years ago, Amber received a large bouquet in her room. "It had a teddy bear with it," Mrs. McLaughlin said. "It was from Dr. Arbisser."
Mr. McLaughlin added, "He's proved to me that his patients mean more to him than money."
Amber's eyesight is now stable, but her continuing care is costly. The Deere plan paid the $18,626.19 in bills for her six months of treatment, and the McLaughlins wonder how much longer Deere will foot such bills when most employers do not.
One family member is in such a bind. Mrs. McLaughlin's daughter by a previous marriage, Kristy, 23, is the single mother of a 4-year-old boy. She had been getting by on welfare, food stamps and Medicaid.
Then she went to school to become a practical nurse and took a job in a pediatrician's office. All her aid promptly stopped, and she receives no benefits.
"She feels like, 'I should have stayed the way I was,' " Mrs. McLaughlin said. "I'm not real happy Clinton hasn't helped these people who want to help themselves. But I don't know if it's his fault. Congress -- to me it's more their fault than Clinton's."
But she thinks that Washington might still come around. "I'm optimistic,' she said. "I think that at least they're going to make employers pay for at least part of it. That's what I'm hoping for."
 
The Matsons
Poverty Offers Health Coverage
 Barbara Jo Matson, 37, and the mother of children ages 17, 14 and 10, is an example of the same disjointedness in the nation's health services that leaves a Kristy McLaughlin uninsured: The poor and unemployed can obtain more and cheaper health care than the working poor.
Ms. Matson, a client of the Iowa City Free Medical Clinic, is certifiably poor. The stub of one of her welfare checks lists her resources as "$ 0000." A disabled and unemployed mother of young children, Ms. Matson receives housing, food and disability and family aid totaling $1,354 a month. Medicaid pays for the family's health care.
With the support of scholarships, child-care and other assistance, she graduated from the University of Iowa three years ago. She has worked in the past -- waiting on tables, playing a dulcimer in the streets for change, collecting cans for a nickel each after university football games. But she cannot hold a full-time job.
After a bad bout of pneumonia when she was 15, Ms. Matson was left with permanently damaged and deteriorating lungs. "I have about 60 percent scar tissue in my lungs and a condition similar to what people with cystic fibrosis live with," she said. "It can only get worse." She also has epilepsy.
On the kitchen table, she lays out a breathing machine that she uses four times a day and a dozen bottles of inhalers and pills -- antibiotics, a steroid, medicines to control seizures, control mucous and dilate bronchial passages, as well as pills to fight the side effects of the other pills. Medicaid pays for it all.
Her companion, Gary Baker, 37, is not well, either. He has back and shoulder injuries from heavy-lifting jobs. He has hepatitis C, which, if he does not take care of himself, could kill him; Ms. Matson, too, because the disease is sexually transmitted. "I have to use a condom," she said.
After watching the health care debate, Ms. Matson concluded, "It is a money game completely, 100 percent. There are diehard Republicans who believe everybody should pull themselves up by their own bootstraps. Just because we're not in wheelchairs does not mean we're not handicapped."
She said she has no hope for change and expects to continue relying on the welfare system and free clinics for her and her children's health care.
 
The Pattens
Amid Troubles, Anger at Politics
 Elma Patten, 60, and Leon Patten, 63, of Cedar Rapids do not look sick. He has the tight physique of a 30-year-old. She is heftier and matronly. She uses a home computer to bang out furious letters to lawmakers in Washington whom he watched whittling away the number of people to be covered under the health care plans that members of Congress introduced after the President offered his own.
In a letter in August to Mr. Clinton, Mr. Dole and her senators and members of Congress, Mrs. Patten wrote, "I wish I could have the same health care you have at the same price you pay." She added, "I do not, at this point in time, expect to ever vote for an incumbent again, except for President Clinton."
The Pattens have been robust enough lately to take daily, three-mile treks around a Cedar Rapids mall. But Mr. Patten cannot negotiate the mild slope of the street in front of their home. Smoking, which he stopped 19 years ago, and the foul air of the factories in which he worked as a machinist, gave him emphysema and put him out of work eight years ago with the use of 40 percent of his lungs.
Over the years, Mrs. Patten, a diabetic, has had a mastectomy, a hysterectomy, double-bypass surgery and wrist operations for work-related injuries. She had to stop working as a retail store clerk three years ago. In June, she checked into to the hospital with pneumonia.
Not until September, however, did she start losing her stride. Doctors found that her heart was stopping periodically for five-second stretches. That resulted in another trip to the hospital, this time for the installation of a pacemaker.
The Pattens feel that they have done most things right with their lives: saving, holding steady jobs, rearing four daughters. But neither worked for companies that provided pensions or retirement health plans.
Together, they receive $1,265 a month in Social Security disability aid. Mr. Patten also receives $580 a month through a previous employer's disability insurance plan, which will stop when he turns 65. The couple has $5,000 in savings.
Both Mr. and Mrs. Patten qualified for Medicare earlier than most people because they have been disabled for more than two years. But their pre-existing conditions and high insurance company premiums preclude access to policies that would cover any treatment that Medicare does not. They pay for their medicines, which currently cost about $2,000 a year. They paid $700 of the cost of her pneumonia treatment; they have not yet received bills for the pacemaker.
While they are angriest with Mr. Dole and the Republicans for the demise of health legislation, they fault the President, too.
"I think he's naive," Mrs. Patten said. "He came in saying he could do all these things and didn't need help."
As for Hillary Rodham Clinton, she "didn't put it together for people," Mrs. Patten said. "It was too complicated."
Mr. Patten added: "They tried to run the Government like Arkansas. It wasn't a good plan."
Still, like the McLaughlins, the Pattens say they have hope. "Something's got to happen," Mrs. Patten said. "I just think people in Washington have to get away from that petty stuff. That's not what our Government's supposed to be doing."
 
The Coens
Already Covered And Still Gaining
 William Coen, 80, Iowa City's retired postmaster, and his wife, Gertrude, 78, are very well off in terms of their health care, and this year the Government relieved them of their biggest lingering burden.
Under a change in the Federal Employees Health Benefit Programs, they no longer pay anything for prescription medicine -- a saving so far this year of $2,734. "All we have to do," Mr. Coen said, "is go to the pharmacy and pick up our prescription. It's all paid for."
Like 99 percent of the population age 65 and older, the Coens have Medicare. To cover the gap between Medicare's reimbursements to doctors and hospitals and the actual charges, they pay $101 a month for insurance. On an income of around $40,000, they get along fine in Iowa City.
Every year, they say, something seems to go awry with their health. Mrs. Coen is legally blind in her right eye. The vision in her left had so deteriorated by last spring, she said, "I couldn't read fine print without bifocals and a magnifying glass."
In June she had a cataract removed. The cataract grew back, so in September she returned to the hospital. The two procedures cost $3,850, all covered by insurance.
What the Coens worry about is the help they might eventually need. Mr. Coen's mother died indigent at the age of 93 after contracting Alzheimer's disease and losing her assets to the high cost of a nursing home. Some of their friends have also been stricken.
So they were unimpressed by President Clinton's proposal to phase in long-term health coverage well into the next century. "And I was wondering about the administration of it," Mr. Coen said, "whether it would be unwieldy."
But it was a worthy beginning, they agreed. They would have been happy to pay higher taxes or insurance premiums to help less fortunate friends at the local senior center, where Mr. Coen helps serve free meals. "It got too involved politically," he said.
Referring to President Clinton, Mrs. Coen said, "I don't think he could have done more than he did. Dole. I think he went in there, come hell or high water, he was going to kill that plan."
 
The O'Connors
Wholly Satisfied But Still Worried
 Debra O'Connor, 31, a single mother living in Lisbon, Iowa, quit a job managing a pizza parlor three years ago to take a lower paid job assembling communications gear at a factory of Rockwell International, a defense contractor. She lives in her parent's old brick farmhouse because she cannot find a place of her own on wages of $8.60 an hour.
But she took the job because it has relieved her of one enormous cost. Rockwell provides inexpensive health benefits that cover her and her three boys, ages 6, 8 and 10. The plan, which is subject to change when management and Ms. O'Connor's union, the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, negotiate a new contract next year, is an unqualified blessing.
Her cost is $7 a month that is taken out of her wages. She also pays $10 to visit any of the doctors on a long list of local doctors who have agreed to participate in Rockwell's coverage. She pays a maximum of $100 for a hospital stay, $25 for a visit to the emergency room, $3 for a generic drug prescription and $10 if the prescription specifies a brand name.
In June her 10-year-old son, Adam, broke his ankle sliding into first. "I was at the game," Ms. O'Connor said. "I took him to the emergency room at Mercy Hospital in Iowa City. They X-rayed it, examined it and wrapped it. The next day I took him to the orthopedic surgeon. They looked at the X-rays and put him in a cast. The total bill was $739.42, and I had the expense of $51.12."
But she said that business has slowed at the Rockwell plant, the result of cuts in military spending, and rumors of layoffs are rife. Lose the job and she loses her coverage, something the Clinton plan would have prevented.
"At least Clinton tried," Ms. O'Connor said. "These Congressmen and Senators don't have to worry about their health care. But I do."
