HEADLINE: U.S. to Aid Big 3 in Cleaner-Car Research

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
A year-old Government partnership with the Big Three auto makers has developed "a road map" for building a car that would go 80 miles on a gallon of gasoline with no loss in performance, safety or carrying capacity, Vice President Al Gore said today.
But smaller competitors in the race for high-technology clean cars are complaining that the three giants could squeeze them out of the effort. That is because the plan calls for the Government to coordinate its research and development spending by seven Federal agencies with the efforts of Ford, Chrysler and General Motors. Much of the research involves using electricity to power cars, a technology that the Big Three have opposed, at least for now. 
 Sheila Lynch, the director of the Northeast Alternative Vehicle Consortium, a Boston-based agency that makes research grants to producers of vehicles that pollute less than gasoline-powered cars, said it was "as if the Federal Government decided in the early 70's to develop personal computers and to give all the money to I.B.M., and I.B.M. said, we're not interested in PC's."
The Government spends about $300 million a year on research and development in the field, an amount roughly matched by the private sector. The effort, called the Clean Car Initiative when it was announced a year ago and recently renamed the Partnership for a New Generation of Vehicles, is to develop a hybrid vehicle, probably with electrically driven wheels, but the details of the rest of the system are not clear.
At a White House ceremony this morning, auto company executives laid out a list of possibilities, including fuel cells, flywheels, capacitors and other energy-storage devices to be used in a vehicle constructed with super-strength lightweight structural materials. They also described a schedule for winnowing the possibilities and building a prototype.
Some of the money goes directly to the Big Three auto makers; for example, each now has a program to develop a fuel cell, a device that makes electricity directly from petroleum or natural gas without combustion. Other grants have gone to auto industry suppliers, and some money is paid so that the Energy Department's national laboratories will carry out research of interest to the industry.
President Clinton, who attended the ceremony with Vice President Gore, said the super-car project was as important to the environment and American economic competitiveness "as anything else we could be working on." Top officials of Ford, Chrysler, G.M. and the United Auto Workers also spoke glowingly of the effort.
But the three auto makers, acting as the American Automobile Manufacturers Association, have filed suit in New York, Massachusetts and Maine to block those states from requiring electric cars. They argue that they do not know how to build a car that the public would want to buy. They are also trying to prevent the Federal Government from imposing California's strict emission standards on those states and nine others in the Northeast.
Ms. Lynch, who attended the ceremony, said the Government was mistaken in going to the Big Three for the effort, because they had demonstrated hostility to requirements for cleaner vehicles, and a strong interest in staying with current technology.
"Why are the three companies that are suing getting control of all the Federal funds?" Ms. Lynch said. "There are companies out there without this dual agenda."
Bill Van Amburg, a spokesman for Calstart, a private nonprofit group that is trying to develop an electric- vehicle industry in California, was also critical of the program. "All this money is tied up in one pot with the veto power of the Big Three," he said. "How do you get innovation that way?"
Some military contractors and other big companies that are not automobile manufacturers but would like to enter the auto business have complained to him, Mr. Van Amburg said, "that they can't seem to participate in this supposedly participatory Partnership for a New Generation of Vehicles."
Auto industry executives defended the participation of the Big Three. William E. Hoglund, executive vice president of General Motors, said that cooperative work with the Government and other auto companies was "far more rational than legislating technology; legislating technology is very expensive."
And Dr. Jack Gibbons, the Presidential science adviser, said that efforts would be made to reach out to start-up companies with good ideas. "We're trying to keep the net cast widely," he said.
But the two sides are separated by a philosophical difference: though the larger companies say they are open to all sorts of ideas, they are looking for advanced technology for the long term; some smaller companies hope to refine existing technologies and put them on the road quickly.
Many of the start-up companies with vehicles now on the road are looking toward the 1996 model year. By then, New York, Massachusetts and California will require that 2 percent of the cars offered for sale within their borders be electrically powered.
"There is always going to be a scramble between the near- vs. the far-term investments," Dr. Gibbons said.
At the ceremony, Ford, G.M. and Chrysler each showed off a "concept vehicle," futuristic designs of various types. But an invitation to an electric pickup truck converted by a small Massachusetts manufacturer, Solectria, and equipped with a flywheel from United Technologies, of East Hartford, Conn., was withdrawn late the previous night. The pickup sat on a flatbed truck in Arlington, Va.
Anita Rajan, president of Solectria, said in a telephone interview that she feared companies like hers would be squeezed out.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE GOVERNOR
The Perks and Pains of Incumbency;
For Cuomo, Is the Office an Albatross or an Advantage?

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Incumbency for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, particularly the kind of mega-incumbency that afflicts a politician after 12 years in office, is clearly the political albatross that Mr. Cuomo says it is. Just look at the polls.
But in a multitude of smaller ways, ranging from Mr. Cuomo's ability to cut ribbons to the mechanics of how he travels, incumbency has also provided significant benefits for the Cuomo campaign, his opponents charge. 
 Republican leaders, including Mr. Cuomo's opponent, State Senator George E. Pataki, contend that the Governor has taken improper advantage of those benefits. The New York Republican State Committee filed a lawsuit in state Supreme Court last Friday charging that Mr. Cuomo and members of his administration have violated the state Constitution by using government resources for campaign purposes.
Top aides to the Governor maintain that they are scrupulous about separating campaign work from the business of running the state. Anne W. Crowley, the Governor's press secretary, pointed out that administration officials use personal or campaign credit cards to charge telephone calls made from the Capitol to the Cuomo campaign headquarters in New York.
Challengers have often accused incumbents of misusing the advantage of their office during election years, and the law on the subject is vague. The Constitution prohibits the expenditure of state funds for any "private undertaking." But as the state's Commission on Government Integrity pointed out in 1989, "no New York law expressly regulates the use of public funds for campaign purposes."
That leaves the courts to decide a question that is inherently gray in this and any number of previous campaigns: at what point does the use of state resources become egregiously political when state government is, by nature, a political business?
"In the absence of a law that lays this out, it's going to be tough for a court to decide what's kosher and what isn't," said Gene Russianoff, a lawyer with the New York Public Interest Research Group. "In the end, a lot of this is going to be for the voters to decide."
That, of course, is what the Republicans had in mind when they filed their lawsuit. The court papers question Mr. Cuomo's use of state aircraft to travel to fund raisers and other political events, his use of the state budget division to analyze Mr. Pataki's plan, his decision to take 11 governmental aides to a campaign-season interview at The New York Times, and Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine's use of state letterhead to promote his speeches attacking Mr. Pataki's tax plan. It also objects to a June memorandum from the state Labor Commissioner, John F. Hudacs, asking subordinates to compile lists of the department's accomplishments.
Mr. Cuomo and his aides argue that each of the cases cited in the lawsuit involve state governance. "We're living up to the letter of the law, I'm sure," Mr. Cuomo said today.
A number of Cuomo administration officials have taken leaves of absence or vacation time to work for the campaign, and many do political work in their off hours. Some acknowledged that they make or take campaign-related phone calls during working hours but feel there is no conflict as long as they meet the requirement that state employees work 37.5 hours a week.
For instance, Andrew J. Zambelli, the Governor's chief of staff, also devises and analyzes the campaign's polls. He said he does so on his own time.
But other uses of state resources are, by their nature, difficult to characterize as purely governmental or purely political.
Is it political, for instance, when Mr. Cuomo uses state funds to send a letter on Sept. 15 to "business leaders" saying that he had signed legislation enacting new wage tax credits? Was it proper to use two state employees to ghost-write "The New York Idea," a book on Mr. Cuomo's philosophy and accomplishments that was published this year? Should state workers, rather than campaign officials, have compiled the reports on technology, crime, economic development and children's issues that have formed the basis of Mr. Cuomo's campaign platform?
Then there is the issue of Mr. Cuomo's campaign travels. Under his administration's guidelines, the Cuomo campaign is supposed to share in the cost of any election-year trip that includes a political event. But political events tend to be defined narrowly as rallies, fund-raisers and endorsement meetings, not trips to disburse grants (Mr. Cuomo's press office issued seven news releases on Monday, most of them announcing economic development grants and loans).
Mr. Zambelli said the definition of a political event would not include Mr. Cuomo's speech last week at the groundbreaking for a new minor league baseball stadium in Syracuse, when the Governor segued quickly from a paean to baseball to an attack on Mr. Pataki's tax cut proposal.
"In case you're tempted to believe people when they tell you they can do a $7 billion tax cut, because the revenues are going to be so rich that they'll throw off 7 billion bucks, then you have to not only re-elect me, you have to enthrone me, because it means I created an economy so powerful it's throwing off $7 billion extra," Mr. Cuomo said. "If that's true, why would you want to get rid of me? Anyway, no politics. Let's go back to baseball."
Mr. Zambelli said Mr. Cuomo's digression did not make the event a political one, at least for the purposes of reimbursement.
"The purpose of the trip was governmental," he said. "The fact that the Governor happens to say something about Pataki in the course of the trip doesn't change the basic function of the trip."
Mr. Zambelli added: "One can obviously call everything political in a political season. The reality is that these things happen in a non-political season as well. The reality is that it's intertwined. And it's often in the eye of the beholder."

HEADLINE: Safety Bubble Bursts for U.S. Students in Russia

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 18

 BODY:
It was not the sort of start to his new life as a college student in Russia that Charles Maymes had envisioned. But to the organizers of his student-exchange program, the American Embassy's recent briefing on rape, battery, assault, break-ins and confidence games was a fitting welcome -- and warning -- to Moscow 1994.
Whereas the oppressive oversight of the K.G.B. once insured the safety of foreign students here, Mr. Maymes and his 45 fellow American students are now like average Russians in their vulnerability to the criminality unleashed by the collapse of the Soviet Union. 
 In an episode that underscored the potential for violence, a 21-year-old American exchange student, Anthony Riccio, was found dead last month outside his dormitory at the Russian State Humanities University. The police found part of a rope around his neck, and the Moscow prosecutor announced that his death was being investigated as a murder, although the possibility of suicide was left open.
But even if Mr. Riccio was murdered, American students here were far from panicked. His death was, they said, a random tragedy in a place known these days for its unpredictability.
"I was surprised, maybe even shocked," said Jonathan McPhee, a student working in an independent-study program sponsored by California State University at Sacramento. But "murders happen all the time in every city in the world," he added. "I personally didn't feel like this was going to spread to me."
Time was when American students in what was then the Soviet Union could get by just fine with a few tips from a cold war catechism of do's and don'ts: do follow your Intourist guide, do not sell jeans on the black market. Today, however, the ubiquitous tail could be a thug; the children playing outside could have something sinister in mind.
"Be alert for groups of young street children, who may quickly approach and assault you," the American Embassy warned in a press release on crimes reported against Americans from May to August 1994.
Mark Teeter, resident director for the American Collegiate Consortium, an exchange program that placed Mr. Riccio and 84 other Americans in 30 universities around Russia, put the situation this way:
"In some respects, what we are seeing today is almost the exact opposite of the situation in the mid- or late 80's. Back then, foreigners tended to enjoy a different sort of status. They walked around inside a bubble, because they knew the consequences for a Soviet if something happened to a foreigner."
Today that bubble has burst, exposing people like Jan Stinchcomb, 27, a resident adviser of the University of Texas's exchange program, to the underside of Russian life. Ms. Stinchcomb is now carrying a chemical spray and considering classes in self-defense.
Still, American students here say they are hard-pressed to equate the sensationalized Moscow of gangs and thugs with the city in which they live. At the Linguistics University dormitory, with 24-hour guards at the door and a reputation for security, students said the expression of fears for their safety were exaggerated.
"Things were nowhere near as bad as I've heard," said Logan Sanders, 21, a member of the Texas program. "If you're from New Orleans or Atlanta or D.C., every night you hear about multiple deaths and murders."
Mr. Sanders's roommate, Paul Wintle, sitting opposite him under a makeshift clothesline in their room, nodded in agreement. "Just because I'm a student and I'm an American doesn't mean I'm going to walk around in fear," he said. "Of course, people are concerned about crime here, and we all talk about it, but nobody is packing their bags."
In fact, some, like Mr. Maymes, had never dwelled on the issue at all. He is among the majority of American students here who live with Russian families in a year-old program begun by the American Council of Teachers of Russian.
For students like Mr. Maymes, with the close support of a Russian family, crime may be less a reason for fear than it is for students in dormitories. Until he attended the embassy briefing, Mr. Maymes said, "It seemed to me crime was sort of invisible here.
"But I sort of left this embassy thing thinking maybe I should be more careful."
In fact, official statistics point to little evidence of physical danger for the American students. Crimes against all foreigners in the first seven months of 1994 were a tiny fraction of those reported by Moscow's 10 million residents, and only 46 of the 956 crimes against foreigners involved Americans, almost all petty thefts, said Vladimir Zubkov, a spokesman for the Moscow police.
But statistics notwithstanding, most exchange programs have revamped their pre-departure orientation for students, with a heavy emphasis on safety. The Russian teachers' group, which this year placed 73 undergraduates at two institutes in Moscow and one in St. Petersburg, devotes up to half its orientation to safety, said Susan Slivkin, a program manager. Once in Russia, an adviser in the dormitory keeps track of the students.
By contrast, the American Collegiate Consortium, which sponsored Mr. Riccio's exchange and has been dispatching students to Russia since 1987, tries to avoid overprotecting students or restricting their exposure to the local culture.
"Ours is an immersion program," said Mr. Teeter, the resident director. "What we want to happen is for our students to have the same Russian or Kazakh experience as the Russians or Kazakhs. We could chaperone our student's social lives, institute rules against drinking."
In lieu of such controls, the consortium requires students to undergo several briefings before departure and then in Russia by advisers assigned to them, and finally, at the embassy.
For the families of some students, too, crime is low on the list of concerns. "My mother said not to breathe the air here," Mr. Wintle said. "She was much more concerned about the air pollution."

HEADLINE: Connecticut G.O.P. Nominee Defends His New Positions

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 18

 BODY:
At the start of his campaign for governor in January, John G. Rowland sounded almost benign about the state's new income tax.
"I'm not running on a statute or position of repealing the income tax," Mr. Rowland, a Republican, said on WFSB-TV in Hartford, stressing that he planned only to reduce it. 
 When asked about phasing it out over five years, he responded: "That's too far off right now. Right now, the focus is not the income tax."
Nine months later, with another candidate pledging to eliminate the tax, Mr. Rowland's focus has changed. Now, Mr. Rowland is crisscrossing the state promising to rid Connecticut of the income tax, which accounts for one-third of all state revenues.
"We are committed to repealing the income tax after five years," he said last month. "The main focus has got to be the income tax."
Mr. Rowland, who was nearly elected governor four years ago and is the front-runner in this race, calls the shift insignificant, saying he has refined his positions with time.
But his three opponents say it is one of several examples of how he is ruled by political expediency, noting his transformation to a pro-abortion-rights position just before the 1990 race and his switch this year from tough talk about laying off unionized state workers to saying he opposes such layoffs.
Whether Mr. Rowland can hold onto his lead in the polls, which has been shrinking in recent weeks, will depend a good deal on his ability to convince the electorate that such switches are his effort, as he says, to look for fresh ways to fight for the middle class. This and other shifts are minor, the Rowland people say, in the context of his strong positions on crime and limiting welfare and his longtime commitment to cutting taxes.
Until his 1990 loss, John Grosvenor Rowland enjoyed a rapid and uninterrupted rise in state politics. Born in Waterbury on May 24, 1957, into a well-known Republican family, his father and grandfather both served as that city's comptroller. Young John was captain of his high school wrestling team, president of his senior class and president of his college fraternity at Villanova University. In 1980, at age 23, he was elected to the state legislature. Four years later, he defeated a three-term incumbent to become the youngest member in Congress.
In three elections to Congress, he won by ever larger margins, running as a staunch conservative opposed to abortion, and in favor of tax cuts and a strong military. He became Connecticut's first member of the House Armed Services Committee in nearly 20 years years and was influential in protecting Connecticut contracts, like the Trident submarine.
Colleagues on both sides of the aisle liked him, appreciating his quick wit, and he broke ranks on occasion. He joined with one of the more liberal members of the House at the time, Claude Pepper, Democrat of Florida, to push for raising Medicare taxes to pay for long-term care for the elderly and the disabled.
It was not until 1990 that Mr. Rowland suffered a setback, when he left the House to run for governor.
With the state in the midst of a fiscal crisis, the time appeared to be ripe for the first Republican to be elected governor in Connecticut in 20 years. Instead, the moment was seized by Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a former Republican Senator who ran as an independent, garnering 41 percent of the vote to Mr. Rowland's 39 percent.
Now, Mr. Rowland is in a four-way race. It includes State Comptroller William E. Curry Jr., the Democrat; Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark, who is running as Mr. Weicker's successor, and Tom Scott, a leader of the anti-income tax movement and a Republican who has formed a conservative Independence Party.
Polls show Mr. Rowland ahead, with about 34 to 37 percent of the vote, the traditional Republican base. But over the last month, Mr. Curry has narrowed the gap to 6 percentage points in one poll and now has 28 percent, and it remains to be seen whether Mr. Rowland can expand his support beyond his 1990 level.
While Mr. Rowland has a $1.2 million fund-raising lead over Mr. Curry, opponents believe that he is vulnerable on certain character issues.
The state's Freedom of Information Commission is considering whether the Middlebury Police Department should be ordered to release documents detailing an argument between Mr. Rowland and his former wife, Deborah, to which police were called last April. The police last week provided a brief summary of a "verbal between husband and wife," with officers responding to a call from Mrs. Rowland.
But the police and the Rowlands have maintained that privacy rights prohibit the release of any additional documents.
"I don't think my private life, or my divorce, or my circumstances with my ex-wife are an issue in the campaign," Mr. Rowland said in an interview. The two were divorced this year.
There are also questions about financial matters.
Opponents have criticized him for 108 overdrafts from the House Bank, and in the last four years, Mr. Rowland was sued three times, accused of failing to pay personal debts. In one case, the Wirthlin Group, a political consulting company, filed a suit in December 1992 in New Britain Superior Court against Mr. Rowland and his 1990 campaign treasurer. According to court papers, the company was not paid for $23,760 of polling work conducted in 1990.
And while that case, as well as two others, was eventually settled with Mr. Rowland paying, Irving Shurberg, the lawyer for the Wirthlin Group and a Republican who supported Mr. Rowland in 1990, said: "This candidate's integrity is in question because of his lack of honesty in addressing these debts. I will not vote for him in this election."
Mr. Rowland says in response that he had numerous campaign debts, that it took time to raise money to pay them off and that ultimately the disputes were resolved.
On the campaign trail, Mr. Rowland appears more relaxed than in 1990.
"This time around I'm more confident, and frankly, the issues are more interesting to me," he said.
His speeches are peppered with tough talk about cracking down on "Club Med" prisons, passing a "two strikes, you're out" sentencing policy that would put two-time violent offenders away for life, and expanding the use of the death penalty.
At the same time, Mr. Rowland said he is working to appease people who found him to be too hard-edged in 1990. In the last election, he said, commercials promoting his intention to crack down on state employees left the impression that "I was a pretty mean guy."
Mr. Rowland had threatened to lay off state workers unless they agreed to pay cuts. In response, unions made an all-out effort to defeat him.
At a recent convention of the Connecticut State Employees Union Independent, Mr. Rowland said that in 1990 strategists had told him the way to be elected was by attacking state workers, and added, "I feel badly that I joined in that routine of being an employee basher."
While saying that he would bargain hard with them if elected, he promised that layoffs were not being considered. He said that over the last few years, he had learned that the true problem was excessive middle and top management.
But on this day, it was plain from the audience reaction that many did not trust him.
"This guy will say anything to get himself elected," said Dwight Johnson, a mechanic with the State Transportation Department.
Others accuse Mr. Rowland of political opportunism on the abortion issue. After opposing abortion throughout his career, Mr. Rowland publicly reversed himself five days before announcing his gubernatorial run in 1989 by voting for Federal financing for abortions for poor women who are victims of rape or incest, a measure he had opposed a year earlier.
Last week, Mr. Rowland said that the switch was "ancient history" and needed to be understood in the broader context of changes in the Republican Party.
He complained that the Democratic candidate, Mr. Curry, was not challenged by the press for changing from an opponent to a supporter of the death penalty. "The old story is if a Republican broadens his position, it's a flip-flop," he said. "When a liberal or a Democrat does it, it's growth."
He bristled at the suggestion that his current position, to repeal the income tax, differs substantially from his statements last January.
"At that time, that was my position," he said. "But what have I been doing since then, I've gotten the best economists I could find in the country. I've spent hundreds, no, thousands of hours on this."
Under Mr. Rowland's program, the tax would be gradually eliminated without increasing any other taxes. He said that the lost $2.6 billion in revenue would be made up "50-50" through spending cuts and increased revenues from other taxes because of the economic boom he expects to follow his first round of reductions.
His proposal details about $400 million in savings, but does not specify how he would cut the additional $900 million.
"What I did in a very conscious way was examine what we could do over a period of time," he said, "because everybody asked for it."

HEADLINE: P. J. McCarthy, 76, Cornell Statistician

 BODY:
Philip J. McCarthy, an expert in economic and social statistics who helped develop the more sophisticated polling and sampling techniques that came into use after World War II, died on Oct. 10 at Tompkins Community Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y., where he lived. He was 76 and also lived on Cushing's Island, Me.
The cause was pneumonia, a family member said. 
 A former chairman of the Statistics Department of the New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations at Cornell University, he was among statisticians who de-emphasized the use of government reports of compiled data in favor of obtaining more representative information through polling and other methods.
He was one of the experts who revised the consumer price index in the 1950's and acted as consultants on refining data at such organizations as the National Center for Health Statistics, the Department of Justice and the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Dr. McCarthy joined Cornell in 1948. He continued his research and writing as professor emeritus after his retirement in 1988.
He received an undergraduate degree from Cornell in 1939 and a doctorate in mathematics from Princeton University in 1947.
His first wife, the former Mary Ann Aselin, died in 1967.
Among survivors are his wife, Jane A. L. McCarthy; a son, Michael, of Baltimore; three daughters, Nancy Valk of Baltimore, Rita Graves of Ithaca and Kathryn, of Boston; a stepson, Stephen Lisberger of San Francisco; three stepdaughters, Lin Lisberger of Gordon, Me., Jody Lisberger of Boston and Emily Vitale of Manhattan, and 12 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Drop, Quieting a 3-Day Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities declined yesterday, indicating to some traders and investors that the recent three-day bond market rally had run out of steam.
Higher oil prices and speculation about the intentions of the Federal Reserve weighed down Treasury securities yesterday. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 17/32 , to 9524/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.87 percent, from 7.82 percent, its highest level since last Wednesday, when it was 7.89 percent. The rates of bills with shorter maturities were slightly higher, with three-month bills at 4.90 percent and six-month bills at 5.69 percent.
Crude oil prices rose yesterday on speculation that demand is rising. Rising oil prices are often considered a harbinger of inflation pressures. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for November delivery rose as much as 30 cents a barrel before closing up 16 cents, at $17.22 a barrel.
Adding to the market uncertainty caused by the jump in oil prices were comments made yesterday by Susan M. Phillips, a Federal Reserve governor, about the strong domestic economy. Her comments, which pushed Treasury prices lower early in the session, raised concerns that a rate increase by the Fed could come before November.
Ms. Phillips, addressing a bankers conference in Orlando, Fla., said the economy was growing at a surprisingly brisk pace, which some analysts interpreted as a stronger outlook than she usually gives publicly.
Many traders and dealers, however, still expect the Fed to raise short-term interest rates by 50 basis points after the Fed's policy-making committee meets on Nov. 15. And most agree that the market has already priced in such a rate increase. A basis point is one hundredth of a percentage point.
On a day with little economic news scheduled, the market's rumor mill was working overtime. It was rumored that the Fed's vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder, had said that Fed policy was on hold, with different versions of the rumor maintaining that it was put on hold anywhere from December to indefinitely. But a Fed spokeswoman later denied that Mr. Blinder had made such a comment.
Amid speculation caused by the Blinder rumors, bond prices rose as much as 10/32 , pushing yields as low as 7.80 percent.
Late in the afternoon, additional price pressures hit the market when the Treasury unexpectedly increased the size of its regular weekly bill auction by $1.2 billion, to a total of $27.2 billion. The larger supply of bills could cause rates to rise to make them more attractive to investors, according to some market participants. Some participants even speculated that the Treasury was trying to avoid any large issues of cash management bills coinciding with next month's large quarterly refunding.
David Ader, a market strategist at Technical Data in Boston, a unit of Thomson Financial Services, concluded that over all, the market did nothing yesterday. "If you go back to last Thursday the market has not gone anywhere, price-wise," he said. "The market has been building volume at a higher price level since the friendly inflation numbers last week and is presently trying to confirm those levels, shrugging off potentially bad news."
In the municipal market, where prices remained stable amid demand for new issues, the largest deal yesterday was a $178 million financing by the San Francisco Airports Commission that was priced by Lehman Brothers in competitive bidding.
Yields ranged from 4.6 percent for a bond due in 1996 to 6.65 percent for a bond due in 2024. Because the bonds are insured by the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, they are rated triple-A. According to Bloomberg Fair Value, the bonds appear to be priced at levels equal to other similarly rated bonds.

HEADLINE: Stocks Off Ahead of Data on Trade Deficit

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stock traders, pausing before the release of today's trade deficit figures, bid down the prices of stocks slightly yesterday, as measured by most leading indexes.
Blue-chip stocks, which rose on Monday, joined the overall market decline. On the New York Stock Exchange, 13 stocks fell for every 9 that rose. 
 Today's Government figures are expected to show a narrowing of the United States's trade gap with most other countries but a continuation of the huge trade deficit with Japan. The deficit has been an important factor in the dollar's slide on world currency markets; a falling dollar hurts stocks.
In a survey of economists by Bloomberg Business News, the consensus estimate was that the August trade deficit narrowed by 11 percent, to $9.8 billion. When the July deficit, reported last month, widened by 22 percent, to $11 billion, the dollar plunged, dragging the Dow Jones industrial average down by about 68 points.
Yesterday, the Dow fell 6.39 points, to 3,917.54, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index declined 1.30 points, to 467.66. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 0.97 point, to 764.81.
The volume on the New York Stock Exchange was below normal, with 259.7 million shares changing hands, about 10 percent lower than this year's average of 287 million shares.
Among the notable stocks yesterday was the State Street Boston Corporation, which fell 39/16 , to 3211/16 , after reporting quarterly earnings that were in line with analysts' expectations.
By contrast, Apple Computer rose 1 1/2, to 41 1/4, after the company released higher fourth-quarter earnings on Monday. And Sun Microsystems rose 1 7/8, to 32 1/4, after its announcement on Monday of a doubling of first-quarter earnings.
But the dollar is significant because its value on currency markets will influence whether foreign investors will want to buy assets valued in dollars, like stocks and bonds. A weak dollar means a gain in a United States asset might be wiped out when converted into Japanese yen or German marks.
The Dow has risen 4.35 percent so far this year, for example, but fallen 8.81 percent in terms of yen and 9.81 percent in terms of German marks.
The crucial factors behind the weakness in the dollar are the United States-Japan trade deficit, which in July totaled $5.7 billion, and to a lesser extent, the deficit with Germany, which in July totaled $1.3 billion.
The demand by American consumers for Japanese goods has led to a strong demand for yen and a glut of unwanted dollars.
Since mid-1985, the dollar has lost about 60 percent of its value against the yen and about 50 percent of its value against the mark.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.71 point, to 257.25 yesterday, with advancing stocks lagging declining stocks by 891 to 1,291. The American Stock Exchange market-value index fell 2.04 points, to 456.72.
Of the Dow industrial average's 30 component stocks, 18 fell, led by Boeing, which lost3/4, to 43 3/8. Of the 500 stocks in the S.& P. 500, 275 fell, led by General Electric, which was down 1/2, to 49 7/8.
The most active stock, with 10 million shares traded, was Intel, which rose 1/16 , to 58 1/4, after its management told analysts that the decline in the company's profit margins would moderate.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Aqueduct Opens, but Is It for Last Mile?

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO 

 BODY:
Aqueduct Race Track opened its autumn season yesterday in bright sunshine but with dark memories of last year's ferocious weather and with gloomy questions about the future of winter racing in New York.
Is this the last mile for racing at Aqueduct? 
 Nobody knows, especially since the answer may depend on the outcome of next month's election for Governor. But a few things are clear: the costs of racing are higher, the political storms fiercer and the number of horses going to the races fewer and fewer.
The situation has been dramatized by the feud between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and executives of the New York Racing Association, which runs racing at Aqueduct in the fall and winter, at Belmont in the spring and summer and at Saratoga for one stylish five-week summertime festival. And the future is as bleak as the arctic weather that hammered Aqueduct last winter, canceling 15 racing days and raising new clamor for an end to deep-winter racing in New York and possibly even an end to Aqueduct as a race track.
Ten years ago, the 60-day fall season at Aqueduct drew 745,600 people who bet $164 million. Two years ago, the 60-day fall season drew 480,116 people who bet $129 million. Last fall, the 61-day season drew 459,265 people who bet $119 million. On opening day yesterday: 6,695.
Perhaps the most visible sign of the times is the shorter racing fields as the foal crop in the United States has plunged from a peak of 47,346 in 1986 to a low of 33,500 last year. And while the numbers for this year suggest that the plunge has leveled off, they also suggest that there will be 22 percent fewer 3-year-olds racing in 1997 than there were last year.
The national average for the number of horses in a race is close to nine. At Gulfstream Park in Florida last winter, they averaged 9.4 horses a race in rainy weather; this winter, they expect to average 10.
But in New York, my kingdom for a horse. At Aqueduct, the average race draws seven horses. Even at Saratoga last summer, rainier than usual, they averaged seven. On the day of the Breeders' Cup preview at Belmont Park two weeks ago, the most glamorous day of racing in New York this fall, the Beldame Stakes drew only four fillies and was staged as an exhibition with no betting.
"We have a guy," said Bruce Lombardi, the racing secretary for New York's tracks, "and he's in Canada right now hustling -- trying to hustle stables into spending the winter in New York. We're doing the same at the Meadowlands. At the end of this month, Terry Meyocks and I are going to Kentucky to hustle owners and trainers. A couple of years ago, we didn't have to do it.
"New York was once the winter haven for small stables and cheap horses. But the Federal tax act of 1986 changed everything. It took away the tax incentives for breeding and raising horses. The cost of living in New York keeps small owners away, too. Now, they keep a horse in New Jersey or Pennsylvania and ship him in for one race. And, of course, the severe weather last winter was the crusher."
Across the Hudson River in New Jersey, the weather was just as frosty, but the results were much more cheering. The Meadowlands track, extending its aggressive importing of simulcast races for the second year, raised its handle by 25 percent. And, on the night of the $500,000 Meadowlands Cup last Friday, it broke the track record by taking in more than $5 million in combined bets from all sources.
But in New York, confusion and snowstorms last winter ruined the simulcasting experiment that imported five races a day from Gulfstream Park and mixed them in with seven live races from Aqueduct. Fifteen racing programs were canceled and most others failed to generate the interest or revenue that had been expected. Some sort of simulcasting is likely in January, but the races from Florida will not be interspersed with those at Aqueduct.
Some racing people believe there is another reason for New York's decline in racing: a lack of business and political sense at the race tracks and a shortage of cordial treatment for visiting horsemen.
One breeder and horseman in Lexington in the heart of the Kentucky bluegrass, who did not wish to be named, said with some heat:
"I'm amazed at the direction they're taking in New York. It was once prominent and elegant in racing, but now it isn't. When people here in Kentucky had good horses, they'd keep half here and ship half to New York. They don't do that anymore except for big races.
"It's not the purses; it's the attitude. They don't have the horses or the horsemen in mind."
Douglas Donn, president of Gulfstream Park, said there was one main factor in attracting horses, and it wasn't attitude.
"Horses go where the money is," he said. "There are cases where people leave a track for personal reasons, but money will dictate. It will drive the top-tier horses.
"Most tracks are struggling. You're limited to a few places where you can run well with good conditions and high purses: Del Mar in California, Saratoga, Churchill and Gulfstream. Our handle has shot up the last two years by 12 percent on the track and 59 percent in combined betting, with simulcasts. Our total handle is over half a billion dollars. And our purses have gone up 25 percent, from $234,000 a day on the average to $292,000."
At the high end of the scale, Gulfstream and Churchill Downs in Kentucky have countered the decline in racing by aggressively pursuing the new economics of racing. Gulfstream races in sunshine in the winter, draws star horses from all over and exports their performances by television for simulcast betting. At Churchill Downs, where combined handle soared from $3 million a day to $4 million this year, one official said bluntly: "Rarely do you see a six-horse field at Churchill."
But at the sinking end of the scale, New York faces another winter with no clue to the future format. Aqueduct could be sold, Belmont could be winterized, racing could be reduced.
"It's all possible," said Lombardi. "Right now, I'm more concerned with filling our fields at Aqueduct this winter."

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Ah, Chicago: Build New Landmarks, Bash Old Ones

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 15

 BODY:
It has long been a given that the nation's first city of architecture cares about its past. With an array of buildings by Louis Sullivan, Frank Lloyd Wright, Daniel Burnham and Mies van der Rohe unmatched by any city in the world, how could it not?
But the reality of historic preservation in Chicago is more complicated. For all the pride the city takes in its great buildings, when push comes to shove it has often done less to protect them than cities with less great architecture to flaunt. From 1929, when Frank Lloyd Wright's Midway Gardens was torn down after only 15 years, to 1972, when Mayor Richard Daley allowed Sullivan's Stock Exchange to be replaced by a banal office tower, Chicago hasn't hesitated to let its Midwestern pragmatism get the better of its artistic heritage. 
 Two events this month underscore Chicago's ambivalent attitude toward its architectural history. The first is the threatened demolition of yet another Chicago landmark, the Chicago Arts Club, the only surviving interior space designed by Mies van der Rohe, one of the 20th century's greatest architects and a man profoundly identified with postwar Chicago. It may be only an interior, but it is a remarkable interior, a suite of rooms that embodies Mies's concepts of flowing space with unusual elegance and panache. And it is the first important piece of postwar architecture in Chicago to be endangered.
The other event is the publication of the book "They All Fall Down," by Richard Cahan (Preservation Press), the story of Richard Nickel, a gifted architectural photographer with a passion for the work of Louis Sullivan. Nickel was killed in 1972 while photographing Sullivan's Stock Exchange during its demolition; he was buried in collapsing rubble. Nickel is a legendary figure in Chicago, but little known elsewhere. He was in every way a martyr to this city's architecture: he raised the consciousness of Chicagoans about it, he led campaigns to preserve it, he rescued pieces of its ornament when the causes were lost and then, in the end, he gave his life to it.
It's an eerie coincidence, the appearance of this book at the very moment that a battle to save another important piece of Chicago architecture is reaching a fever pitch. The Chicago Arts Club, finished in 1951, is a remnant of a magical moment in Chicago's history, when the city's cultural establishment, by turning to Mies to design the club's new quarters, announced its willingness to embrace the glass-and-steel modernism of the International Style. Chicago would become as well known for the architecture of Mies and his followers in the postwar years as it had been for the work of Wright and Sullivan in an earlier time. If the Arts Club was not literally the beginning of all this, it stands as an endearing symbol of Mies's movement into the status of Chicago icon.
Endearing, but perhaps not enduring. The arts club is situated in space it rents, not owns, on the second floor of an undistinguished eight-story building on a block a Chicago developer has assembled for a complex of stores and movie theaters. It's an odd location in which to find a tiny masterwork, but that's precisely what the arts club is, with its travertine foyer, elegant steel staircase and exceptionally striking mix of the minimalist Miesian esthetic and the traditional furniture the club had brought from its former home.
The building in which the club leases space is nothing as a work of architecture, but then again, neither is the garish structure proposed to take its place, a glitzy suburban mall dropped into the middle of Chicago. More to the point, the developer has been quoted in the Chicago papers as saying he doesn't plan to keep this new building for more than 20 years, since by then the economy should be strong enough so he can tear it down and put up a skyscraper.
The arts club to be lost for a building that is only supposed to be around for 20 years? That's a great testament to the notion of architecture as a force for continuity, as a defining presence in a city, as a resource protecting us from the relentless rush of time. To see some understanding of that, we have to turn back again to Richard Nickel and his remarkable and sad story.
The most important thing one learns from "They All Fall Down" is that Nickel was not a crazed zealot but simply an earnest man whose life took on greater meaning after he discovered the architecture of Louis Sullivan. Nickel saw in Sullivan's buildings -- his proud, solid structures, magnificently ornamented but always with a potent and blunt clarity to them -- the promise of a civilized world.
Then Nickel's idealism hit the stone wall called Chicago. It is an essential paradox of this city that for three-quarters of a century it could foster more architectural creativity than any other city in the United States, but that it did so by focusing so much on the new that it has never had a sense that the old could be sacred. Old things were for the walls of the Art Institute. The streets in Chicago have always belonged to the new.
That began to turn around in the 1960's, and one of the main reasons for that was Richard Nickel. He began his career as a photographer in the 1950's, when there was little understanding of what preserving great works of architecture could mean, in Chicago or any American city. Nickel became more and more excited about the works of Sullivan, and as he moved around the country to document them, he discovered how many were neglected or had even disappeared. (It's a sign of how little information was in the air about historic buildings in those days that Nickel once went all the way to New Orleans to see a Sullivan-designed train station, unaware that it had been demolished.)
His plan to photograph all of Sullivan's works became, all too often, a matter of photographing them under demolition. Like a political activist, he was gradually radicalized, and began to turn into a kind of architectural guerrilla, sneaking into buildings both to document them for posterity and to rescue pieces of the magnificent ornament for which Sullivan was best known. Preservation extremist though he was, he nonetheless goaded Chicago toward its architectural maturity, leading the campaign in 1961 to save Sullivan's Garrick Theater, the most strenuously fought landmarks battle in Chicago until Sullivan's Stock Exchange a decade later. When it was lost, Nickel received permission to dismantle much of its ornament.
Richard Cahan compares Nickel, not unreasonably, to Atget and to Lewis Hine, the celebrated photographer of the Empire State Building under construction. "Where Atget sensed the dying spirit of Parisian culture, Nickel perceived a dying idea," he writes. "Hine's cranes have been replaced by Nickel's bulldozers. Hine saw the Empire State as a reflection of those who were building it. Nickel saw the Garrick as a reflection of those who were destroying it."
Chicago's landmarks commission will hold a hearing on the possible designation of the Chicago Arts Club on Wednesday, and again the lines of battle are drawn in this city. There is talk of designating the entire block on which the arts club sits, which, paradoxically, includes a couple of buildings that are better pieces of architecture than the arts club building. Some sensible proposals have been floated to tear down the upper floors of the building and let the arts club remain, integrated into a redesigned version of the mall and theater complex, but no one seems inclined to take them seriously until it is clear which way the landmarks commission decides to vote.
It's hard to know what Nickel would have made of all this. It would never have occurred to him, surely, that Mies van der Rohe's architecture could be threatened so soon after the wars over Louis Sullivan's. Nickel despaired constantly, which is one of the reasons he comes off as so sympathetic a character in Mr. Cahan's book, but he did not want to be a martyr. He felt continually frustrated by the failure of his preservation campaigns, and was saddened by Chicago's inability to love the great art on its streets as much as he did. A man for whom loving architecture was part of loving life, he was empowered, in the end, by his own innocence.
Could any other American city have inspired a Richard Nickel? More to the point, would any other American city have needed one?

GRAPHIC: Photos: Richard Nickel, a preservationist, in 1960 atop the Republic Building, later demolished. (Courtesy of the Richard Nickel Committee) At right, Chicago Arts Club interior, designed by Mies van der Rohe. It, too, may be demolished. (Paul L. Meredith for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Plight of Dutch Tomatoes and Cheese

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: AMSTERDAM, Oct. 18

 BODY:
The Dutch tomato is having a rotten time. For years, German consumers have been throwing Dutch export varieties back over the border, saying their flavor has the chemical tang of industrial farming.
Now, the squashed image of one of Holland's prime farm exports is at the center of a national debate. 
 Newspapers have devoted editorial columns to the problem of persuading increasingly choosy European consumers to pick Dutch rather than Mediterranean tomatoes, Dutch bacon over Danish and Dutch cheese instead of French.
"We used to set the norm in Europe as far as quality was concerned," said Steven Hartman, a researcher with the management consultants A. T. Kearney. "Today we have maintained the quality, but the norms have risen."
Mr. Hartman headed a Government-commissioned survey concluding that many Dutch farm products could face declining sales in Europe unless the farming industry adapts more quickly to changing tastes.
The tomato is financially important to the Netherlands and dear to its pride as a farming nation. Holland ranks second only to the United States in agricultural exports, with 8 percent of world trade.
"About 10 years ago, European consumers were all expected to converge in the criteria for their choices," Mr. Hartman said. "The opposite has happened."
Regional differences have widened. Consumers want more choice. Cheap air travel has introduced people to new flavors, so a Briton who has tasted a sun-ripened tomato may wince at the northern greenhouse type. Dutch products were getting a reputation as cheap and mid-ranking with little variety, the survey said.
The report drew criticism from the Dutch group of market gardeners, CBT, responsible for fruit and vegetable development and export. "It is a bad report," said Ine Kleemans, a CBT spokeswoman. "They talk about 'one Dutch tomato.' We have developed a whole range."
More than one job in 10 is in the agricultural sector, which generates about a tenth of the gross national product and accounts for nearly a third of all Dutch exports. Dutch products still dominate many European agricultural trade flows, having built up strength in the largest and most sophisticated greenhouse production system in the world.
But Dutch farm exports to Europe lagged behind overall European export growth between 1987 and 1992. Slower demand was a factor. An end to protectionism hit some segments, but over all the survey found that the Dutch are changing too slowly.
The tomato is part of the picture. Cucumbers have competition from Greece. The cabbage lettuce has been quashed by iceberg lettuces from Spain and France. Dutch cheese is "strongly focused on Gouda and Edam and scarcely represented in the growth segments," the consultants said. Rivals in Denmark and France developed soft cheeses. Dutch pork has a bad reputation, they said, partly because of diseases and scandals that raised concerns about how the animals are treated.
Mr. Hartman said that much of the problem may be in perceptions and that essentially it is a battle between industry and tradition.

HEADLINE: Peace Across the Jordan

 BODY:
This week's draft peace treaty between Israel and Jordan is much more than just another incremental advance on the Jewish state's least dangerous frontier. It may lack the drama of Anwar el-Sadat's path-breaking 1977 initiative, or last year's embrace by Israel of its former archenemy, Yasir Arafat, or the hoped-for breakthrough with Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad. But Israel's new peace with King Hussein is enormously significant.
Most of the credit belongs to Israel's Nobel laureate duo of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres, along with Jordan's agile and experienced King. Still, the Clinton Administration played a supportive role, encouraging both countries and now standing behind their achievements. The invitation to President Clinton to take part in next week's formal signing ceremony in the Mideast is warranted. 
 Substantively, peace with Jordan promises to be warm and broad, unlike the many years of "cold peace" with Egypt, or the so far chilly bargaining with Syria. Israeli and Jordanian leaders actually appear to enjoy each other's company and seem likely to meet regularly in Amman and Jerusalem. Israel's agreement to divert substantial amounts of water and help build new dams will deliver a quick peace dividend to Jordanian civilians. Potentially sensitive questions of borders, sovereignty and land use were resolved by compromise, a lesson that could some day be applied to the Golan Heights. Politically, the agreement marks a new multifaceted phase of peace diplomacy. An outbreak of Hamas terrorism or a lack of progress with Syria can now be countered by an advance with Jordan. This helps Prime Minister Rabin maintain an overall momentum, and an Israeli consensus, for peace.
The various negotiating fronts are now both competitive and complementary. Peace with Jordan puts new pressure on Syria. Yet Jordan's cautious King would not have dared to move this far without some signal from Damascus that it, too, is ready for peace. King Hussein is also freer to act now that he has fully overcome his diplomatic blunder of opposing the U.S.-led military coalition against Iraq three years ago. The King underscored this point by condemning Baghdad's moves in the latest Kuwait crisis.
Symbolically, peace with Jordan means that Israel, once isolated, now has achieved security along most of its borders. At the same time, the economic isolation imposed by the Arab boycott is also beginning to break down. Only Syria and its Lebanese client still remain outside the formal peace framework, and even they may not remain outside very much longer.
The most encouraging development is that peace agreements that recently would have seemed extraordinary now seem almost routine.

HEADLINE: In America;
Promises and Deficits

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
With tax revenues off, New York City now faces an estimated $1.4 billion budget deficit. That figure, from Comptroller Alan Hevesi, is $400 million more than had been expected, and comes in the wake of $1 billion in spending cuts already made by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani.
The Mayor seems perpetually to be cutting the budget, like a harried woodsman slashing his way through an endless forest. 
 "If we solve this $1.4 billion problem, next year we start off with a $2.3 billion deficit," said Mr. Hevesi, "and $3 billion the year after that."
Into this atmosphere comes State Senator George Pataki, a candidate for governor and protege of fiscal wizard Alfonse D'Amato, with an ominous proposal to cut state income taxes by $5.6 billion over four years. People who care about New York City are aghast at the thought.
Felix Rohatyn, former chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, believes that Mayor Giuliani has done "extremely well dealing with the city's budget problems." But city and state officials have been trying to work out a long-term solution, a way of correcting the structural problems that result in huge municipal deficits year after year.
"This kind of effort is very difficult to conceive and structure and negotiate," said Mr. Rohatyn. "It is likely to be made quite impossible if we have a proposal to cut the state income tax by a dramatic amount."
Mr. Rohatyn said a tax cut of the magnitude proposed by Mr. Pataki inevitably would result in significant reductions in state aid to the city. He said it would "doom" the effort to solve the structural problems in the city's budget and would "create some type of budgetary crisis."
It would also be bad for the state. Mr. Rohatyn said: "I remember when the city ran out of credit in the summer of '75. Even though by the winter of '75 we had at least patched up a three-year plan that involved some Federal assistance, in the spring of '76 the state was almost incapable of doing its spring borrowing because people were so concerned about the potential impact of a city bankruptcy on the credit of the state. Now we're not talking bankruptcy here, but we're talking serious problems."
Mr. Hevesi said that based on recent economic growth rates he would expect Mr. Pataki's tax cut to add $4.4 billion to the city's total deficit over the next four years. He said, "That would mean, for example, that we would lose $1.2 billion in school aid if the formula remained the same."
The state, said Mr. Hevesi, could be expected to take a hit of $12.9 billion over four years if Mr. Pataki's tax cuts were enacted.
"Those are big numbers," said Mr. Hevesi. "Really huge."
City Council Speaker Peter Vallone insisted that the complaints from New York City officials were not simply the anguished cries of Democrats fearful of losing the Governor's seat to a Republican. "This is the survival of the city we're talking about," he said. "If you're going to cut the personal income tax, you're going to have to make it up with real estate taxes and sales tax increases. Those are the only other broad-based taxes."
Mr. Pataki's candidacy has thus far been greeted by a devastating silence from the office of the city's Republican Mayor. Giuliani administration officials are concerned not only by the proposed tax cut, but also by Mr. Pataki's apparent reluctance to lift the burden of Medicaid from the city's shoulders, by his refusal to acknowledge that the city does not get its fair share of state school aid and by other Pataki positions that have been perceived as less than friendly toward the city.
In addition, Mayor Giuliani has a very good relationship with Ralph Marino, leader of the Republican majority in the State Senate. But Mr. D'Amato (whose relationship to Mr. Pataki is that of Geppetto to Pinocchio) has been feuding with Mr. Marino and has suggested that his days as majority leader are numbered. Mr. D'Amato has derided Mr. Marino as a "pompous majority leader who can't get out of his own way."
Mr. Pataki is hungry for Mayor Giuliani's endorsement. The Mayor has said he will make his choice based on what is best for the city. As Mr. Giuliani is not a man who is easily bullied, Mr. Pataki and his boorish mentor can only wait and hope.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Attacking the Republican 'Contract With America'

 BODY:
CANDIDATE -- Representative Jolene Unsoeld, in a tough re-election race in Washington State, is one of many Democrats around the country broadcasting advertisements that attack the Republican "contract with America."
 
PRODUCER -- Fenn King Murphy Communications
 

ON THE SCREEN -- In slow-motion, the Republican challenger, State Senator Linda Smith, walks up to a table to sign the contract. She is highlighted, but in the background are clearly visible row after row of Republicans in suits -- a seeming tableau of the Washington establishment. The ad then shows headlines about the dangers of the Reagan Administration's economic policies superimposed over still pictures of women, children, elderly people and workers. Among the headlines: "Reagan's Ax to Cut Social Security."
 
SCRIPT -- "You're looking at Congressional candidate Linda Smith, taking the lead, signing a contract with the national Republican leadership. What's the deal she's agreeing to? More tax breaks for the wealthy, paid for by devastating cuts in Medicare. Or, increasing the deficit again. It's a contract to revive the failed 1980's.
"You remember -- trickle down economics, exploding deficits, slashing Social Security. That's what Linda Smith just signed us up for again. But why would we ever want to go back?
 
ACCURACY -- Democrats assert that the "contract with America," which promises a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget, an array of tax cuts and an increase in military spending, will inevitably mean cuts in entitlement programs like Medicare, which make up more than half of the Federal budget. Republicans reject that charge, and Ms. Smith's campaign chairman, Bill Kinkade, says the candidate "has pledged never to cut Social Security or Medicare."
But many budget experts have long argued that achieving substantial, long-term deficit reduction is impossible without some pain. Warren Rudman, the former Republican Senator from New Hampshire and a founder of the Concord Coalition, the bipartisan group devoted to reducing the deficit, said, "You cannot get deficit reduction of any substantial nature without a huge tax increase, or significant means testing of all entitlement programs, including Medicare."
 
SCORECARD -- This commercial presents a non-incumbent, non-Washington politician as a tool of Washington elites. It also tries to galvanize voters who historically have voted Democratic; the fear of cuts in Social Security and Medicare is one of the most potent fears in American politics. The risk in such ads, some analysts suggest, is they may not reach beyond the Democratic core voter.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 20, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A picture yesterday with a summary of a campaign advertisement for Representative Jolene Unsoeld of Washington State was published in error. It showed an advertisement for Representative George Hockbrueckner of New York, one of many Democratic campaigns around the country that attack the Republican "Contract With America."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE INCUMBENT;
Clinton Aids Cuomo in New York As Whitman Visits to Help Pataki

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

 BODY:
President Clinton and a sprinkling of senior aides swept into New York City yesterday to join Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in a fight for their mutual political futures, helping to raise $2.5 million to keep the Governor's job -- and the state's electoral votes -- in Democratic hands for 1996.
It was Mr. Clinton's fourth political appearance of the year with Mr. Cuomo, the third at a fund-raiser, and he has now helped the Governor raise nearly $4 million for his re-election, a total rivaled only by his help for Kathleen Brown, the Democratic gubernatorial nominee in the biggest state, California. 
 In an afternoon conference on the state's future and at a glittering evening gala adorned with celebrities from Madonna to Norman Mailer, Mr. Clinton praised the old political adversary who nominated him for the Presidency two years ago, reminding the dinner guests of the Supreme Court nomination Mr. Cuomo had forsaken to try for a fourth term in Albany.
"He is a national treasure, but he really is New York's treasure," Mr. Clinton told a packed ballroom at the Sheraton New York. "I kind of promised myself I wasn't going to mention this, but I'm going to. Every one of you know that he could have had another job, with longer tenure. Every one of you know that he stayed here because he loves you, he loves that neighborhood he grew up in in Queens.
"He cannot imagine walking away from this fight until we have had a chance to do every last thing we can to give every kid in this state a chance at a better future," the President added. "You take care of it and make sure he's re-elected."
But even as Mr. Clinton and the President were entertained by the likes of Rita Moreno and Marvin Hamlisch, just down 53d Street, at the New York Hilton, Mr. Cuomo's Republican opponent, State Senator George E. Pataki, held his own fund-raiser with New Jersey's new Republican Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, as if to suggest Mr. Pataki represented the future. [Page B10].
For his part, Mr. Cuomo recalled his impoverished roots in South Jamaica, Queens, then said young people there now do not have the chances or support he did, and worried that "we have to do a little bit more."
"We haven't begun to fight," he vowed.
In fact, the day was one long, sometimes poignant reminder of how the worm has turned for Mr. Cuomo -- whose approval ratings now lag Mr. Clinton's in the state by 10 percentage points, 45 to 55 -- and of how thoroughly the two men's old roles have been reversed.
In a new campaign memoir with Mary Matalin, Mr. Clinton's political strategist, James Carville, recalls how completely Mr. Cuomo's potential Presidential plans consumed the Clinton staff in the fall of 1991. Mr. Carville likens the endless speculations to those that once dominated Carville family discussions of a nephew named Jo Jo, who had cancer but recovered.
"Mario Cuomo was the Jo Jo factor," Mr. Carville writes. "For a while there, each decision depended on what New York's Governor Cuomo was going to do He was just kind of looming."
In a different way, Mr. Cuomo still is.
"Clearly, re-electing Mario Cuomo is a top priority for the party," one Democratic party official in Washington said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "He is at the top of our list. No matter how you do the numbers, Democrats don't win the White House without New York in the 'w' column, so there are big implications for '96, as well as '94."
Two years ago, Mr. Cuomo found much to criticize in Mr. Clinton's style, saxophone, sunglasses and tactics, before eventually nominating him, but yesterday he said: "Today, we march behind President Bill Clinton as he steers this nation away from its worst instincts and toward its strongest and best instincts."
That Mr. Clinton himself needs Mr. Cuomo to keep a Democratic beachhead in New York is also a twist on old acrimonies. After all, it was Mr. Clinton who had to apologize to Mr. Cuomo in 1992 after a tape of a conversation with Gennifer Flowers surfaced in which Mr. Clinton appeared to reflect on Mr. Cuomo's ancestry to say he was mean, and seconded Ms. Flowers's assertion that Mr. Cuomo might have Mafia connections by answering, "Well, he acts like one."
Yesterday, both men were all smiles, and Mr. Clinton doled out a bit of good news for the Governor, announcing a waiver from Federal welfare rules that will let New York proceed with experiments intended to provide new incentives for work and job training.
The two men also joked about their mutual admiration for the Governor's eldest son, Andrew, who is now an Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and so for the first time is not playing a day-to-day role in a Cuomo campaign. Gubernatorial aides said he had played a major role, however, in organizing yesterday's event, the Governor's Leadership Conference on Building the Future, which was planned and financed at state expense and included panel discussions -- listed as "concurrent interactive sessions" -- on topics from crime to welfare. It featured various Cabinet and sub-Cabinet officers, including Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and Robert E. Rubin, the head of the President's National Economic Council.
As Mr. Rubin started the conference yesterday morning, he mistakenly addressed Mr. Cuomo as "Mr. President," before catching himself to peals of laughter.
"Mr. Governor, I'm used to speaking to the President," he said. "I think this President's great, but I think the Governor wouldn't have been a bad one, either. But that's a different issue."
Mr. Rubin also quickly showed how what was billed as a conference on government affairs had inescapable political overtones as he made a not-so-veiled reference to Mr. Pataki's proposed tax cuts.
"If a candidate proposed a major tax cut, for example," without explaining in concrete detail how it would be financed, he said, "that is not an honest and responsible discussion of a major fiscal initiative."
Mr. Cuomo acknowledged that the conference would be scoured for its political overtones, "and there's no point in being cute about that, we might just as well address it." Then he went on to sound a scrappy, if somewhat elegaic, note about what his legacy as public official and politician might be.
"Maybe someone will notice that one time, in an important race in a great state, they said, 'Let's take time out to be serious and substantive,' " Mr. Cuomo said. "Not a whole lot. Because you don't want to consume all the time that's normally devoted to silliness. But a little bit."
In another move to tweak the Governor, the Republican State Committee filed suit yesterday to block efforts by the Democratic National Committee to transfer $669,000 to the state Democratic Party. The suit continues a court battle begun in August, in which the Republicans won an initial round in court, only to have the Democrats contend that the transfer violated technical rules and could quickly be corrected, and the money accepted.
But the Republicans contend that a new committee formed by the Democrats to take the money still violates the state's arcane election laws, and a hearing is scheduled for Tuesday.

 GOV. MARIO M. CUOMO

 Upon being introduced, the President gently tweaked the Governor.

I said, j'Clinton's Eighth Law: Blood is thicker than water but the paycheck is thicker than blood.' "

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 18.50 on Strong Earnings News

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Gaining a little after prices flattened in recent sessions, the stock market closed broadly higher yesterday in heavy trading after strong earnings reports continued to surprise Wall Street.
Stock prices received a lift after the Government reported that the United States trade deficit narrowed in August. But the report also showed a widening gap with Japan, and the dollar, already weak, slid further. The bond market also fell slightly. The weakness in the dollar and bonds limited the gains for stocks. Only 11 issues rose for every 10 that declined. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 18.50 points, to 3,936.04, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 2.62 points, to 470.28. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 5.81 points, to 770.62.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal, with 319.3 million shares changing hands, about 11 percent above this year's average of 287 million shares.
Quarterly earnings reports, which are being released throughout the month, are important because of what they say about a company's outlook. As much as half of the value of a typical stock, economists calculate, reflects the earnings and dividends to be paid over the next five years.
Among the notable stocks yesterday was the AMR Corporation, the holding company for American Airlines, whose stock rose 1 3/4, to 53 3/4, after it reported that its third-quarter profit rose more than 70 percent, beating Wall Street estimates.
Motorola Inc., which reported strong earnings last week, closed at 56 1/8, up 1 5/8, or close to its 52-week high on Aug. 26 of 56 1/4. Johnson & Johnson did establish a 52-week high when it reached 54 7/8 in intraday trading before closing at 54 1/2, up 1 3/8. The company reported a 16 percent rise in quarterly net profit.
Gensia Inc., on the other hand, fell sharply for a third consecutive day, losing 11/16 , to 45/16 . The stock traded on Friday at 10 3/8, but on Monday the company disclosed that its most promising drug, Protara, a heart-attack treatment, had failed to pass clinical trials and was found to be no more effective than a placebo.
The Government trade figures released yesterday showed a narrowing of the nation's trade gap with other countries, the difference between what the United States imports and what it exports. The deficit with Japan, however, widened. The overall trade deficit narrowed 12.9 percent in August, to $9.74 billion.
The outlook on inflation, interest rates and the level of corporate earnings are three factors that move markets. Inflation has been moderate all year, and earnings reports continue to be strong, despite higher borrowing costs brought about by Federal Reserve moves to raise short-term interest rates.
Only the Fed's interest-rate policy remains open to question, as recent economic data remain as ambivalent as ever -- and thus an uncertain indicator of the central bank's intentions.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.07 points, to 258.32, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining issues by 1,137 to 1,033. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.54 point to 458.26.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 17 rose, led by Aluminum Company of America, up 1 7/8 to 88 3/8. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 284 rose, led by Johnson & Johnson, Motorola, and General Electric, which gained 1/2 to 50 1/4.
