HEADLINE: Flooded Texas Area Gets Some Relief After 4 Days

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HUMBLE, Tex., Oct. 19

 BODY:
The sun came out over southeastern Texas for a time today, bringing a measure of relief from the four days of miserable rain and flooding that killed at least nine people and drove thousands of people from their homes. But many rivers, bayous and creeks remained at record levels, and the authorities warned that even a small amount of rain could cause new devastation. 
 "The threat of more rain is still in the area," said Gene Hafele, a meteorologist with the Houston area office of the National Weather Service. "We are not expecting torrential downpours, but any rain can cause some more hardship."
Late this afternoon, gray skies had returned and there were sprinkles of rain in some areas.
Houston, virtually paralyzed on Tuesday with some neighborhoods under eight feet of water or more, returned to some semblance of normal today as much floodwater receded, though public schools and some businesses remained closed.
Here in Humble, about 30 miles northeast of Houston, many of the 165 families at an emergency Red Cross Shelter at the local high school had to evacuate their homes because of considerable flooding from the overflow of a Houston reservoir. Today they were trying to assess the damage, but they could not get to their homes.
"Everyone is amazed at that thing they see up in the sky," said Royaletha Carter, disaster specialist for the Red Cross at the shelter, referring to the sun. "A lot of them thought they'd never see it again."
But even as many people in the region were making plans for rebuilding and discussing relief with Federal disaster officials, some experts suggested today that yet again, the wreckage from flooding had pointed up the folly of letting people build in areas where houses are subject to regular flooding.
Robert W. Gilmer, an economist with the Houston branch of the Federal Reserve Bank in Dallas, said much of the recovery effort will actually subsidize hazardous situations that will bring on future problems. "They're going to get Government assistance and Government loans to live in places that are dangerous," he said. "We have subsidized flood insurance to live down by the river bank. While they are very pretty places, you wonder why the Government subsidizes this."
In fairness, the rainfall and subsequent flooding was a record-shattering event in many places, and considered unlikely to be repeated for decades or more. And many people whose homes were destroyed suggested today that there was nothing foolish about choosing to rebuild in the same spot.
"We've lived there for 21 years with no problems," said Tannie Shannon of nearby Conroe, whose picture appeared in newspapers around the nation today, showing him and his wife in chest-deep floodwater as they carried their 11-month-old granddaughter and family dog to safety. "We've raised a family there. It's a nice place to live. This is an unusual situation."
Or, as Toni Beasley of Atascocita, a partly flooded section of Humble, put it: "If it's once every hundred years, you can cope with something like that."
But in other inhabited parts of southeast Texas, flooding is virtually routine. In Liberty County, the Trinity River has unleashed major flood damage on riverfront homes five times in the last four years. And Judge Dempsie Henley, the county's chief executive, said there was no question in his mind that people should not be living in many low-lying areas.
But he said his repeated attempts in recent years to negotiate a Federal or state buyout of existing homes along the riverfront had been rebuffed. His proposal is to turn the area into a wilderness park. "It might flood but there would be no human suffering," he said.
"People thought they would be cheated, they wouldn't get enough, it would be a big government deal," Mr. Henley said. "I was pushing for it but not everybody wanted to sell out. There was a lot of misunderstanding about it. Since I'm not running for re-election, I can push it."
The official flood-related death toll in Texas stood at nine today, with at least six other people missing and presumed drowned. Bob Mann, a spokesman for the Texas Emergency Management Division, said there would be no official damage estimates for at least another 24 hours.
At least 11,000 people were forced from their homes and the Red Cross set up 53 evacuation centers.
Other people insisted on staying in their homes even as the water rose to several feet or more.
Jennilee Brewer, a 22-year-old donut bakery worker who celebrated her third anniversary with her husband, Greg, in the shelter here in Humble, said her grandmother had remained in her home in hard-hit New Caney, north of here, even though the water had risen into the second floor of the house.
"She wants to stay with her land," said Mrs. Brewer, whose own one-story home, next door, was submerged. "A lot of people out there are like that. They want to go down with their land and their homes."
Flooding danger was reported north, east and west of Houston, on the Brazos, Colorado, Guadalupe and Lavaca Rivers. Many ranchers were urged to move their cattle to higher ground. "If you've ever tried to move cattle by boat, it's not the easiest thing to do," said Judge Henley.
With Election Day less than three weeks away, politicians have been out in force, surveying the damage and, not coincidentally, appearing on television news reports. "If you're going to have a flood, I'm sure the month before an election is an ideal time to have it," said Mr. Gilmer at the Federal Reserve.
Gov. Ann W. Richards toured flooded areas in an Army helicopter on Tuesday and then held a news conference at the Houston airport.
Her opponent, George W. Bush, toured a flooded Houston subdivision in a boat piloted by a Republican County Commissioner, Steve Radack, and helped evacuate a teen-ager from her home.
Both candidates said they wanted to show compassion for victims of the flood and, in Ms. Richards case, to shower all available state aid on the area. But the Governor suggested that Mr. Bush was trying to transform the floods into a political event and professed shock when reporters asked her about his appearance in the area.
"He's in a boat," she said in an awestruck tone. "Are you serious?"

HEADLINE: U.S. and Balkans: Shifting Stance

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Maneuvering again to use Serbia as the unlikely instrument of its Balkan diplomacy, the Clinton Administration is now pressing the Serbian President to grant diplomatic recognition to Bosnia and Herzegovina and to Croatia.
In exchange for such recognition, intended to further isolate Bosnian and Croatian Serbs long armed and supported by Serbia and its President, Slobodan Milosevic, the United States would be prepared to accept a further easing of trade sanctions against Serbia, Western officials said today. 
 "The highest thing on our agenda now is securing Serbian recognition of Bosnia and Croatia," one official said. "It looked like a nonstarter a couple of weeks ago, but it may in fact be possible, because Mr. Milosevic's blockade of the Bosnian Serbs already amounts to de facto recognition of the Bosnian border."
After financing their campaign of aggression for more than two years, Mr. Milosevic officially cut off all political and economic links to the Bosnian Serbs in August. His main hope was to win relief from international sanctions imposed against Serbia in retaliation for its war role.
Nonetheless, recognition of Bosnia and Croatia within their current international borders would amount to an enormous step -- one some officials close to Mr. Milosevic believe is impossible even now.
Angered by the way the breakup of Yugoslavia marooned ethnic Serbs in countries they did not wish to join, Mr. Milosevic has long dismissed the current Croatian and Bosnian borders as mere administrative lines drawn by Tito, the former Yugoslav ruler, and unjustly recognized by the United Nations. Many have seen his long support for the Bosnian and Croatian Serbs as a drive to create a "Greater Serbia."
On the other hand, Mr. Milosevic's decision to cut off the Bosnian Serbs suggests that he is a man capable of violent policy swerves in pursuit of his own hold on power.
"Mr. Milosevic now represents our best chance, short of fighting this war either directly or by proxy," the Western official said. "Recognition is a step he can take unilaterally to bring the next stage of easing of sanctions. It would open the door for greater relief."
In meetings in the United States last month, the Bosnian Prime Minister, Haris Silajdzic, said he pressed President Clinton to secure Serbian recognition of Bosnia before any further easing of sanctions on Serbia was considered. Apparently, the message had considerable effect.
The need to find some new political momentum in the quest for peace has become pressing over the past three months as an American-backed peace plan to end the 30-month war has sat on the table, rejected by the Bosnian Serbs and unlikely ever to be accepted.
For the United States, the Milosevic card looks like the only viable option. The problem is that European Governments would now like to adjust the peace proposal to make it more attractive to the Serbs.
To the Clinton Administration, such a step would amount to rewarding the Bosnian Serbs' stubbornness. American officials are insisting that this was a take-it-or-leave-it plan, offering 51 percent of Bosnia to the Muslim-led Government and 49 percent to the Serbs.
The extent of the trans-Atlantic differences emerged this week in an unusually blunt article in Le Figaro by the French Foreign Minister, Alain Juppe. Noting that the Muslim-Croat federation in Bosnia has the right to form a confederation with Croatia, Mr. Juppe said the Bosnian Serbs should now be explicitly granted the right to form a confederation with Serbia.
A United States official close to the Bosnian negotiations said the Clinton Administration considered the French ideas to be premature.
The problem for the Clinton Administration is twofold. The first is that the Bosnian Government has made it clear that any adjustment of the peace proposal -- like adding the constitutional right of the Serbs to enter a confederation -- would lead to a withdrawal of its acceptance.
The second is one of image: A Serbian confederation that includes almost 50 percent of Bosnia would come very close to the formation of a "Greater Serbia" and leave Bosnia and Herzegovina as little more than a fig leaf masking the dismemberment of the country.
That outcome may be inevitable, but it is still not attractive to a President who declared as a Democratic candidate that Serbian aggression could not be tolerated.
But in the absence of any real military pressure on the Serbs, or any likelihood of such pressure emerging, there seems to be limited usefulness in leaving the peace plan as it is. Moreover, Britain, Russia and, to a lesser extent, Germany, all see some value in Mr. Juppe's ideas.
Thus tensions exist within the "contact group" that drafted the peace proposal, made up of the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Russia.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
 
The United States' trade deficit with Japan swelled 2.4 percent in August. The report sent the dollar falling to near a record low against the yen. But the trade deficit with the rest of the world narrowed sharply on a surge in exports. [Page D1.]
 
The former chief executive of B.C.C.I. was imprisoned for more than eight years. Bank creditors agreed to accept $1.8 billion in compensation from Abu Dhabi, the bank's largest owner. [D2.]
 
Companies
 
A meeting between executives of MCA and its parent, Matsushita, left open whether Matsushita might sell MCA to end its deteriorating relationship with the American unit's management. [D1.] 

Barney is on the downturn in the roller coaster world of children's merchandising. Barney merchandise sales have tumbled, and the plush purple-and-green dinosaur may be overexposed. [D1.]
 
A U.S. trustee recommended that Weil, Gotshal & Manges be removed from the Leslie Fay bankruptcy case. [D1.]
 
First Financial will reduce its bid for Western Union's money-transfer business by $300 million and assume full responsibility for Western Union's pension obligations. [D4.]
 
Borden agreed to sell two salty snack foods businesses. [D4.]
 
U.S. Robotics, a leading maker of computer modems, will acquire Megahertz Holding, a smaller rival, in a $213 million deal. [D4.]
 
Digital Equipment showed signs of improvement, despite reporting another big quarterly loss. [D5.]
 
Compaq Computer said quarterly profit rose 88 percent. [D5.]
 
Telephone companies reported mixed earnings results. [D5.]
 
McDonnell Douglas, Northrop Grumman, and General Dynamics posted higher earnings for the third quarter. [D5.]
 
The New York Times Company said earnings surged in the third quarter, reversing a loss in the quarter a year earlier. [D21.]
 
NBC assailed a revised application filed by SF Broadcasting, a partner of Fox, to purchase a Wisconsin television station, [D21.]
 
Farrar, Straus & Giroux will soon be sold. [D21.]
 
The Economy
 
A new report by Rep. John D. Dingell describes inadequacies of state insurance regulation and criticizes regulators for failing to prevent illegal actions by insurance companies. [D2.]
 
Bank recovery spells trouble for savings and loans, which will continue to pay higher charges to rebuild their depleted insurance fund while bank premiums to the F.D.I.C. will drop. [D6.]
 
Markets
 
Stocks advanced broadly, lifted by a number of strong earnings reports. The Dow industrials gained 18.50 points. [D8.]
 
The dollar tumbled against the yen and the British pound. [D18.]
 
Copper prices rose sharply. Coffee prices also climbed. [D18.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities fell after the trade deficit report raised new concerns about an accelerating economy. [D19.]
 
Today's Columns
 
Dealers who make Nasdaq markets are being investigated by the Justice Department. The investigation appears to be focusing on suspicion of price-fixing in what investors are charged when they buy and sell stocks. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
 
Washington seems to have passed the buck on reducing air pollution, so some want the Government to dump the responsibility on auto makers while giving them flexibility to meet tougher emission standards. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
 
Affiliation helped a Hispanic-owned agency remain independent. The sharing of clients, but not agency ownership, put Ornelas & Associates of Dallas on its feet. Advertising. [D22.]

HEADLINE: Haiti and U.S. Sign Pact to Stabilize Price of Gas

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 19

 BODY:
With gasoline prices shifting nervously from a street price of about $37.50 a gallon on Tuesday to one-fifth that sum today, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide signed a $15 million agreement with the United States Agency for International Development this morning that is intended to bring gas back to the pumps, stability to the market and a river of revenue to the state as it struggles to pay for everything from back salaries to light bulbs.
But on the fourth day after the international trade embargo on Haiti was lifted, many people here were still paying black-market prices for low-grade gasoline filtered through handkerchiefs, women's blouses and smudgy rags while they talked with resignation about last-minute gouging and the slow pace at which life is stumbling back to normal. 
 A tanker delivering a long-awaited supply of fuel finally arrived this evening, hauling 150,000 barrels of gasoline, kerosene and diesel fuel, enough to supply the city for three weeks and ending a wild final ride of price hikes and dips that ended up angering buyers and sellers alike.
President Aristide took some of the shine off the tanker's welcome, however, by signaling some uneasiness with the new Government-fixed gas price, $3 a gallon, announced by the Department of Commerce last week. The President indicated that it might be too costly for most Haitians to bear in the long term.
His comments, made at a news conference here this morning, lifted the curtain to a complicated drama that has been unfolding here for the last several weeks. Negotiators for the Aristide Government and the American aid agency have struggled to come up with a formula that will not only relieve the immediate crisis but set reasonable standards for the country's longterm growth.
By nearly doubling the price of fuel from the subsidized costs before the embargo, it is believed that the Government can bring Haiti into line with other Caribbean nations and generate a reliable tax base for years to come. And it could do so at a time when high Government prices would actually seem like a relief after years of superinflated prices on the black market.
But the increase in gas prices is a risky political maneuver even for a popular President. And though the new price marks a dramatic drop from black market costs, Haitians have been quick to register shock at the official rate.
Mark L. Schneider, the assistant administrator for the American aid agency's Latin America and Caribbean bureau, dismissed those concerns today, saying the price was both necessary and economically sound. "It will restart the economy and it will restart the Government," he said. "It was the most efficient answer we could find."
Today, several vendors said they did not much mind losing their one source of income. Since the gasoline market was so volatile over the weekend, dropping to $7.50 a gallon last Friday but then soaring to a high of nearly $37.50 late on Tuesday before tumbling again today, some vendors said they ended up selling their gas at a loss.
In a place called Kuwait City, which is actually a series of gasoline drums attended by poor vendors wielding plastic jugs and tin funnels, Jean Getton, a 52-year-old mother of six, sold off the last of her supplies at prices about half of what she paid for them the day before. Somewhere, she said, she knew someone had made an extravagant profit from the wild shifts in the market. But then she shrugged: "It was not me."

HEADLINE: Clinton Ups Atom Stakes

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
In its rush to strike a nuclear agreement with North Korea, President Clinton is gambling that the promise of $4 billion in energy aid can turn what he has labeled "a rogue state" into a responsible member of the global community.
The agreement, announced by President Clinton on Tuesday, reflects the Administration's conviction that offering the Communist Government in Pyongyang a way out of its economic difficulties will induce it to give up its nuclear ambitions and stop threatening neighboring South Korea with its million-member army. 
 The complicated accord also means that, for the moment at least, those Administration officials who prefer to engage enemies have won out over those who want to isolate them. But the strategy represents a major leap of faith.
For more than a year, Washington's policy was based on the assumption that the leaders in Pyongyang were Stalinist totalitarians so untrustworthy and unpredictable that their behavior had to be punished, not rewarded.
When North Korea violated its international commitments by refusing to allow inspections of all its nuclear plants, the United States said it would seek new international sanctions against Pyongyang.
That put Washington in a diplomatic cul-de-sac. Faced with a threat by China to veto any Security Council sanctions, and a warning by North Korea that it would regard such a move as an act of war, the Clinton Administration decided to negotiate.
In doing so, officials were counting on Kim Jong Il, North Korea's new leader, to open the country to foreign trade and to follow a less isolationist foreign policy than his father, Kim Il Sung.
No matter that the younger Mr. Kim has been described by some Administration officials as a a terrorist who masterminded bombings in 1983 and 1987; for the moment, the view of Mr. Kim as a leader capable of becoming a statesman has prevailed.
Beneath the celebration of this week's victory, however, there is widespread apprehension both inside and outside the Administration.
Although he ultimately endorsed Mr. Clinton's decision, Deputy Secretary of Defense John M. Deutch objected to what he regarded as inadequate controls over North Korea's access to spent fuel rods from the new light-water reactors it would receive. He further complained that North Korea would be able to keep its spent nuclear fuel rods for too long.
In praising the accord on Tuesday, even Robert L. Gallucci, the chief American negotiator, suggested that the younger Mr. Kim was a man who could not yet be trusted. "Maybe it will produce trust, but it's not based on trust," Mr. Gallucci said of the agreement.
But many foreign policy experts feel that the Administration has embarked on a high-risk course that has often failed in the past. These experts feel the Administration has made concessions that would allow North Korea to resume weapons production quickly and set a dangerous precedent for other countries intent on making nuclear weapons.
The accord with North Korea was immediately attacked by Republicans who described it as a capitulation to dictators.
"It is always possible to get an agreement when you give enough away," the Senate Republican Leader, Bob Dole, said in a statement.
Even those who praise the agreement do not believe that North Korea is poised to change the nature of its Government or abandon its hostile intentions.
"The agreement cuts the heart out of their ability to produce nuclear weapons and that is the most serious and the most immediate problem," said Leslie Gelb, president of the Council on Foreign Relations. "But it doesn't mean it will stop them or that they all of a sudden become good guys."
The agreement also creates a major contradiction in the Administration's approach to curbing the spread of nuclear technology.
The Administration has pressured both Moscow and Beijing not to sell light-water nuclear reactors for energy-producing purposes to Iran, arguing that the Government in Teheran should not be given access to any nuclear technology.
But how can Administration officials now look their Russian and Chinese counterparts in the eye and argue that Iran should not be allowed to buy what North Korea is being given without cost? And how can Iran be expected to continue to adhere to the rules of the nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty when North Korea, which has violated those rules and will be allowed to do so for years, is being rewarded?
As one Pentagon official put it, "Life isn't fair."

HEADLINE: Transit Workers File Suit

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Six workers who said they were laid off after asking for lighter duty because of pregnancies sued the New York City Transit Authority yesterday. They were joined in the lawsuit by two pregnant women who said they fear losing their jobs. All are train operators or conductors.
The suit alleges that the women who were laid off were unable to collect unemployment insurance because the transit agency told the State Unemployment Division that they had gone on voluntary maternity leaves. 
 A transit spokesman, Bob Slovak, said no employee is allowed to remain on light duty for longer than 14 days, whether pregnant or disabled by any other condition.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE WELFARE SYSTEM;
Way Out Front on a Hot-Button Issue

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 12

 BODY:
Gov. Tommy G. Thompson strode into the dining room of the Governor's Mansion and plunged, with equal zeal, into his breakfast ham and the welfare record that has made the two-term Republican the envy of many politicians.
He called his eight-year attack on the welfare system "gutsy." He said his reducing benefits had made liberals feel as if "their hearts had been cut out." He even called the blizzard of anti-welfare campaign advertising now blanketing the country a tribute to his own bellwether instincts. 
 "All of the Republican candidates, and a good portion of the Democratic candidates, are copying Tommy Thompson," he said.
If the assessment was immodest, it was not altogether errant. In this election season, virtually every candidate -- from the liberal standard-bearer, Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, to a conservative scion, George W. Bush of Texas -- is claiming to be a stern-minded welfare reformer.
The tough talk on welfare comes from millionaire Republicans seeking Senate seats, including Michael Huffington in California, Mitt Romney in Massachusetts and Bill Frist in Tennessee. But it also comes from middle-class Democrats, both white (like Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma, running for the Senate) and black (like Representative Alan Wheat of Missouri, another Senate candidate).
"It's this kind of mantra that everyone repeats," said Ben Sheffner, an analyst for the Cook Political Report, a nonpartisan newsletter. "You say, 'We've got to crack down on welfare and make people go to work.' "
Perhaps no other politician has embraced the issue so effectively as Mr. Thompson, who has backed his tough talk with a significant reduction in Wisconsin's welfare rolls. Last year he went even further, signing legislation to abolish the current welfare system altogether by 1999 and replace it with a new, although as yet unspecified, program.
In a season of rage against incumbents, Mr. Thompson seems virtually assured of becoming Wisconsin's first three-term Governor, and he says his welfare record is a major reason. "It's a fantastic campaign issue," he said.
The 1994 campaigns are increasing the pressure on Congress to overhaul the system next year.
President Clinton has proposed a measure that would place recipients in a work program after they have received aid for two years. That proposal is far stricter than anything advanced by Mr. Clinton's Republican predecessors, but most Republicans are now calling it tepid. Some want to abolish assistance to young mothers altogether, whether they work or not. Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House minority whip, included such a provision in his "Contract With America," a policy pledge signed by more than 300 Republican Congressional candidates.
After deferring action on welfare to debate health care in the waning days of this year's session, Congress will be under particular pressure to act. "Those who opposed us on welfare reform are now coming around to it, as a need to further their re-election," said Mr. McCurdy, the leader of a center-right coalition of House Democrats that had urged the party's leadership to pass a welfare bill this year. "We'll be in a better position to move on it next year."
A television advertisement for Mr. McCurdy's Senate campaign gives a feel for the season's tenor, more Merle Haggard than the Kennedy School of Government. Standing before an oil refinery in a hardscrabble Oklahoma town, Mr. McCurdy recalls that his parents taught him "to stand my ground and fight," which is "why I'm fighting to change welfare."
The screen then flashes a welfare check that repeatedly crumbles as a deep-voiced announcer booms "no check" for those who refuse jobs or training, "no check" for having more children, "no check" to those who lack United States citizenship.
Most other candidates are making vague appeals to values. An advertisement for Representative Bob Carr, a Michigan Democrat running for the Senate, cites the state of the welfare system, along with lying and cheating, as evidence that "the moral fabric of our society is coming apart." Mr. Carr's televised solution is little more than an aphorism: "Give people a helping hand, but not a handout."
Although Mr. Thompson has clearly profited politically from denouncing welfare in Wisconsin, the lessons of his leadership remain unclear.
He ran in 1986 on a pledge to cut benefits and followed through with an immediate 6 percent statewide reduction. After years of freezes, the reduction is now about 30 percent in inflation-adjusted terms, the largest decline in the nation.
Mr. Thompson has also repeatedly won Federal approval for experimental programs like Learnfare, which reduces benefits to families whose children fail to attend school. Another experimental program reduces benefits to some newcomers to the state.
Mr. Thompson says the numbers vindicate his programs. Wisconsin caseloads have dropped 23 percent since he took office, a period in which the national figure has risen 30 percent, and they have declined in each of the state's 72 counties.
But his critics have derided him as Tinkering Tommy, a genius at garnering big headlines for minor changes in the system. They say the welfare rolls have declined in part because the benefit reductions have left fewer people eligible and in part because the state's prospering economy has made jobs available to the poor. Those were also the conclusions reached last year in a study by researchers at the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee.
"The welfare rolls' going down has had absolutely nothing to do with his experiments," said Mr. Thompson's Democratic opponent, State Senator Charles J. Chvala, who calls the Governor's approach "mean-spirited." He notes, for instance, that while caseloads have declined, child poverty in the state has risen.
Mr. Chvala acknowledges, however, that the Governor's lead of about 40 points in the polls is due in part to the welfare issue. "It's something that's a political advantage for him, no doubt about it," the challenger said.
If, as Mr. Thompson insists, Wisconsin holds the clue to the future, the welfare debate may increasingly resemble a game of chicken. In part as a dare, Democrats in the Legislature, angered by his claims of boldness, last year pushed through the bill that would abolish the system by 1999.
Speaking confidentially, some say they expected Mr. Thompson to opt for an embarrassing veto rather than face the burden of designing an altogether new system. But the Governor signed the measure into law, and has been crowing about it ever since.
"It was like serving me up a filet mignon," he said, "when I was supposed to only get a cheese sandwich."

HEADLINE: Removal of Weil, Gotshal Sought in Leslie Fay Case

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
In a stinging rebuke of one of the country's richest and most prestigious law firms, a Federal official recommended yesterday that Weil, Gotshal & Manges be removed from the Leslie Fay bankruptcy case and be forced to forfeit part of the $5.3 million in fees it has billed to date.
In a motion filed in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan yesterday, Arthur J. Gonzalez, the United States Trustee responsible for supervising the bankruptcy of the Leslie Fay Companies, said Weil, Gotshal's relationship to members of the Leslie Fay board constituted an "actual conflict of interest." In addition, Mr. Gonzalez said, the firm had failed to disclose those relationships to the court. 
 Both are grounds for disqualification under current bankruptcy law, the motion said, adding that "the court should impose an economic sanction that will preserve the integrity of -- and the public's confidence in -- the bankruptcy system."
Mr. Gonzalez did not specify the amount of the penalty but he recommended that it represent both the fees charged by Weil, Gotshal for representing an audit committee at Leslie Fay and the costs of a report on the firm's behavior prepared by an independent examiner last year. A lawyer familiar with the case estimated that the combined amount was about $2 million.
The motion was submitted just prior to a deadline set by Bankruptcy Judge Tina L. Brozman, who is presiding over the Leslie Fay case. Weil, Gotshal must respond by Nov. 4. The judge will then likely rule on the motion at a hearing scheduled for Nov. 28.
The recommendation adds weight to the report by Charles A. Stillman, the court-appointed examiner. That report, completed earlier this year, found fault with the firm's conduct in the Leslie Fay case, recommending that it remain on the job but forfeit a part of its future fees as punishment.
Judge Brozman may accept the trustee's recommendation, reject it or choose an alternative. "It's very unusual to have a law firm disqualified in a case, but it's not unheard of," said Elizabeth Warren, a professor of bankruptcy law at the University of Pennsylvania Law School.
Regardless of how the judge rules, the recommendation is an acute embarrassment for Weil, Gotshal. The firm was the fourth-richest law firm in the country last year with gross revenue of $318 million and profits per partner of $745,000, according to The American Lawyer magazine. The firm dominates the bankruptcy bar and has made its reputation handling celebrated bankruptcy cases, including those of R. H. Macy & Company, Drexel Burnham Lambert, and Eastern Airlines. In recent years, the firm has been criticized by other bankruptcy lawyers for supposedly skirting the blurry edge of bankruptcy-court ethics.
The firm released a statement late yesterday saying that it would contest the motion, which it called "totally without merit." The firm "is committed above all to pursuing the interests of its clients while adhering to the highest standards of ethical conduct," the statement said.
Prof. Warren said that while a settlement might yet be negotiated between the law firm and the United States Trustee concerning the amount of fees Weil, Gotshal could be forced to forfeit, the question of disqualification could not really be compromised.
"In disqualification, it's either all or nothing," she said. "The trustee is now taking a position. He's going to have a hard time backing off that."
Indeed, in his motion, Mr. Gonzalez went far beyond the recommendations of Mr. Stillman, whose report came after some Leslie Fay creditors raised the issue of conflicts.
Mr. Gonzalez argued that Weil, Gotshal's representation of the board's audit committee that was investigating charges of fraud at Leslie Fay had resulted in an "actual harm" to the company because committee members were also senior executives at Odyssey Partners and Bear, Stearns & Company, two major Weil, Gotshal clients. That theoretically gave Weil, Gotshal an incentive to act contrary to the interests of Leslie Fay.
Since the issue of conflicts was raised about Weil, Gotshal, many original creditors have sold their interests in Leslie Fay to so-called vulture investors. The new group of creditors have shown little interest in pursuing sanctions against the firm, which is active in other cases involving the same new investors and their lawyers. Thus, the United States Trustee, a division of the Department of Justice charged with overseeing Federal bankruptcy courts, can probably count on little support from the creditors.
Prof. Warren argued that that should make no difference. "The United State Trustee has an independent obligation to make his or her own judgment," she said. "That's the job."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
U.S. Investigating Nasdaq's Pricing Practices

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The Justice Department said yesterday that it was investigating the dealers who make Nasdaq markets, an inquiry that intensifies the pressures on Nasdaq to change in ways that could fundamentally alter the nature of the market. At a minimum, the pressures seem likely to cut profit margins for the dealers at the center of the market.
The Federal inquiry appears to be focusing on suspicion of price-fixing in what investors are charged when they buy and sell stocks on Nasdaq, the network of securities dealers linked by computer and phone. 
 The department declined to give details of the inquiry by its antitrust division, which was first reported in The Los Angeles Times, but it appears to stem from civil suits that were filed after an academic study raised the possibility of collusion among market makers.
The Justice Department's inquiry comes as the Securities and Exchange Commission is pushing to change rules in ways that will allow investors to trade at better prices more often than they have in the past. That initiative has led market makers to voice fears that their profits will be slashed, perhaps forcing independent market makers out of business.
Richard G. Ketchum, the chief operating officer of Nasdaq, said he was confident that the Justice Department would conclude "that the Nasdaq market is incredibly competitive" and that there was no reason for antitrust charges to be brought.
A study by two professors, William G. Christie of the Owen Graduate School of Management at Vanderbilt University and Paul Schultz of Ohio State University, showed that not only were spreads of 25 cents common on Nasdaq, as had been well known in the past, but also that quotes at odd-eighths were rare.
In other words, when a stock is quoted with a bid price (the price at which a market maker will buy the stock) of $50 and an asked price (the price at which the market maker is willing to sell the stock) of $50.25, it is unlikely to move by only 12.5 cents, to a spread of, say, $50.125-$50.375. Bids tend to rise or fall by 25 cents, they concluded, and to stay at even quarters of a dollar. In the above example, when the price rises, it would likely be to $50.50 from $50.25.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Christie said he had looked in vain for an economic rationale for the lack of odd-eighth quotes, and could find none. "That led us to believe there was an implicit agreement among the market makers not to use those quotes," he said. The study, released in May, prompted a wave of class action lawsuits against the main market makers; those suits seem to have persuaded the Justice Department to have a look.
Mr. Ketchum called the study "extremely flawed" because it ignored the fact that trades occurred within the spread all day long. In recent years rules have been tightened to force that, and the S.E.C. is now pushing for rules to make it happen more often.
Mr. Christie added that after the study was publicized, many market makers began to post odd-eighth quotes. Still, shortly after noon yesterday, two of the largest and most liquid Nasdaq stocks, Intel and Microsoft, had spreads of 25 cents and were quoted at even quarter dollars, with Intel at $59.75 bid and $60 asked, and Microsoft at $57.25-$57.50.
By contrast, Compaq Computer, traded on the New York Stock Exchange, showed a bid-asked spread of 12.5 cents, or $36.375-$36.50. And there were narrow spreads in some Nasdaq stocks, with Apple Computer quoted at $41.75-$41.875.
One reason for the wider Nasdaq spreads is that competition in that market has often focused on areas other than the spread. When a customer places an order for a Nasdaq stock, the broker can either execute that order from its own inventory or send it to another market maker.
Brokers sending orders outside often send most or all of their orders to a specified market maker, frequently in return for payments of a penny or two a share. That market maker will get the order, even if its posted spreads are not the best, as long as it agrees to match the best spread.
In practice, that has meant that if a market maker posts a more aggressive spread, it will narrow the profits available to all but may not bring in a lot more orders to the broker initiating the price cut.
Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the S.E.C., has identified changing Nasdaq rules as a focus of protecting investors. Under pressure from Mr. Levitt, Nasdaq proposed a rule to let many small buy orders be executed at the lower bid price rather than the higher asked price, if customers put in what is called a limit order. The S.E.C. has indicated that it wants to expand that rule to cover more orders, but Mr. Ketchum called that proposal "questionable," citing "a risk of harming the marketplace."
To many Nasdaq market makers, even the Nasdaq proposal does that, threatening to drive many firms out of business and concentrate business at larger integrated firms. They also contend that it would reduce the liquidity available in the Nasdaq market.
Mr. Levitt was at a conference in Tokyo yesterday and not available for comment.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Ready to Ask U.N. to End Bosnia Arms Ban

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration said today that it would introduce a Security Council resolution next week calling for the automatic lifting of the arms embargo against Bosnia's Muslim-led Government in six months.
The move is an opening maneuver in what are likely to be delicate negotiations with Russia, Britain, France and Germany, who have been working with the United States in a so-called "contact group" on Bosnian peace. 
 The countries have been trying to win Serbian acceptance of a peace settlement partitioning Bosnia among warring factions and reducing the area under Serbian control from 70 percent to 49 percent. The Serbs have firmly rejected the proposal, while the Bosnian Government has accepted it.
Action to lift the embargo against the Bosnian Government has been demanded by Congress and promised by President Clinton. But the Administration must find a way to avoid a Russian veto of its resolution or a split with European allies, who oppose exempting the Bosnian Muslims from a weapons ban covering all the combatants. The United States will need cooperation from its partners in coming months on other issues like easing economic sanctions against Iraq.
Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, and Richard Holbrooke, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, told delegates from the "contact group" countries today of the Administration's plan to introduce the resolution, a United States official said.
The Europeans and Russians have been opposed to what they call "automaticity" in a resolution -- setting a firm future date -- and it is likely that at minimum there will be demands for a weakening of that language, allowing for a renewed look at the issue next spring before action is taken. A French or British veto cannot be ruled out.
For the Clinton Administration, there is little public room for maneuvering at this point. Congress has mandated that American forces can no longer be used to enforce the embargo after Nov. 15 if there is no resolution on lifting the ban or if the resolution is vetoed. Senators and representatives have also vowed to reintroduce legislation requiring the United States to unilaterally lift the embargo when a new Congress assembles after this year's elections. Americans could then sell arms to the Bosnians.
After demanding an end to the ban for more than two years, Bosnia's Government recently agreed to a six-month delay, but it wants a firm deadline fixed now. Britain, France and Russia want the embargo to stay in place indefinitely.
After American lawmakers voted by significant margins in both houses to immediately lift the embargo against the Muslim-led Government, President Clinton promised in August that if the Bosnian Serbs did not accept a peace plan by Oct. 15, he would ask for a Security Council resolution to exempt the Bosnian Muslims.
Britain and France have said that if the embargo is lifted, they will withdraw their peacekeeping troops from Bosnia and Herzegovina, effectively ending the United Nations operation there. The likelihood that this action would free the Serbs to resume direct attacks on Muslim-held towns and cities, including Sarajevo, led the Bosnian President, Alija Izetbegovic, to suggest a six-month delay in lifting the ban when he spoke in the General Assembly on Sept. 27.
As talks were beginning in New York today, the White House tried to bolster the impression of American resolve by saying that if the Security Council did not act, the Administration would go it alone and let the Bosnian Muslims acquire arms.
Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, said that if the United Nations failed to act on the American resolution by Nov. 15, "then we would look at ways to perhaps lift the embargo unilaterally."
Russia, which has been supportive of the Serbs and hopeful of brokering an agreement with them, is most vigorously opposed to allowing the Bosnian Muslims to rearm themselves.
In a recent interview with the paper Moscow News, Russia's Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, said that if the arms embargo were lifted it would signal "that the world community washes its hands of the affair."
"The lifting of the embargo means a war according to another scenario," he said. "The peacekeepers would have to be withdrawn from the conflict zone immediately, while diplomacy would have to abandon the last hope for a peaceful resolution of the crisis.
"Such a step would in fact mean saying: Fight to the last Serb, fight to the last Bosnian," he said.
In a letter on Aug. 10 to Senator Sam Nunn, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, President Clinton laid out the problems he would have with Russia and some European nations if the United States acted on its own.
"I believe lifting the embargo unilaterally would have serious implications going well beyond the conflict in Bosnia itself," he wrote.
"It could end the current negotiating process, which is bringing new pressure to bear on the Bosnian Serbs. Our relations with our Western European allies would be seriously strained and the cohesiveness of NATO threatened. Our efforts to build a mature and cooperative realtionship with Russia would be damaged."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bosnian Muslim women watched a british armored vehicle pass by on Tuesday near Zenica in central Bosnia. Britain has said it would remove its troops from the United Nations force if the arms embargo is lifted. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Trade Gap With Japan Widens

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The United States' trade deficit with Japan jumped 2.4 percent in August, sending the dollar down briefly today near its lowest level since the end of World War II.
By the end of the day, the dollar had recovered slightly, to 97.35 yen to the dollar, but it was clear that the revival of the American currency's strength that surrounded a new trade agreement with Japan late last month was a flicker, not a recovery. 
 The Clinton Administration took some solace in the fact that the monthly trade deficit with the rest of the world improved drastically, shrinking 12.9 percent, to $9.74 billion, on the strength of a surge in exports.
But just weeks before President Clinton travels to Indonesia for a meeting with Asian leaders, the figures clearly showed that the United States' trade problems were concentrated in two countries: Japan, whose surplus seems resistant to all cures, and China, which during the last year has begun to prove that multibillion-dollar surpluses are not bred only in Tokyo.
The trade figures announced today seemed likely to put new pressure on the Administration to deal with a deficit with Japan that has already exceeded $41 billion this year and -- if current trends continue -- could soar higher than $60 billion to a new record. For the month of August, the deficit with Japan was $5.8 billion, not a drastic increase but a striking enough headline on traders' computer terminals to send the dollar spinning.
The reaction in the unforgiving foreign exchange markets to the worsening deficit with Japan showed how short-lived are victories like the one the Administration claimed last month -- a long-sought agreement to open the Japanese insurance, medical and telecommunications equipment markets.
Late last month, as the agreement seemed likely, the dollar began to strengthen considerably, rising to about 99 yen to the dollar. After the agreement was announced, it crept up a bit more, hovering at slightly more than 100 yen. At the time, many traders said they were betting against movement either way, saying the agreement would stabilize the dollar.
But it soon became clear that the new agreement was likely to only make a dent of roughly $2 billion in the trade gap when it was fully implemented. That represents less than 4 percent of the total deficit -- a politically insignificant change. Now, the trade agreement is no longer being used to explain the dollar's movements.
"The foreign exchange markets will not push the dollar up until the deficit begins to narrow," said Ed Yardeni, chief economist of C. J. Lawrence/Deutsche Bank Securities in New York. "And the fact is that there is little you can do about Japan's surplus, at a time that the U.S. economy is booming and Japan is still in recession."
The economic expansion in the United States increases the purchase of Japanese autos, machine tools and components, while Japan's continuing slump depresses consumer demand there. Though there are more American goods on display in Japanese stores these days, often at particularly attractive prices because of the yen's appreciation, the gains for American products have been modest.
Much of the continuing deficit with Japan is in automobiles, a subject that the Administration and the Japanese Government put to one side to strike their deal last month.
In private, some officials in the Administration who deal regularly with Japan acknowledge that they are out of fresh ideas about the way to approach trade issues. They have simply tried to keep them on the back burner, while Washington tries to win Japanese cooperation on a range of other issues.
That includes this week's effort to persuade the Japanese to make a multibillion-dollar contribution to the building of nuclear reactors in North Korea. Japanese participation in the project is a key element of the agreement that President Clinton agreed to Tuesday in an effort to stop the North's nuclear weapons program.
"I think there is a sense that we can use the trade surplus to win some Japanese help on other issues these days," one State Department official said this week. "We might as well get some indirect benefits from the deficit."
But China poses a more complicated question. In August the trade deficit with Beijing reached $3.24 billion, up $570 million from the previous month. So far, the year-to-date deficit with China is up 23.7 percent from the comparable period last year. Some economists predict that during the next few months, as the effects of the high yen set in, the trade deficit with Japan should ease a bit. But any shrinking gap will be filled by the growing deficit with China.
According to some theories, the Japanese and Chinese deficits are all of a piece. As the yen climbs, Japanese firms have been transferring more of their manufacturing capacity to China and elsewhere in Southeast Asia. That essentially moves the products from Japan's books to those of other nations.
But sorting out the Japanese content in such products is nearly impossible. And the figures also reflect goods made for American companies that are also expanding in China.

HEADLINE: South Korea Says It Will Soon Allow Business Travel to North

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 19

 BODY:
South Korea is expected to relax restrictions soon on travel by South Korean businessmen to North Korea and on investments in the Communist nation, South Korean officials say.
The expected moves were in keeping with South Korea's praise of the agreement reached with the United States earlier this week intended to halt North Korea's suspected nuclear weapons development. 
 After the accord, South Korean officials have been meeting to discuss various measures to buttress it, including possibly reopening discussions with Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, on denuclearization and economic cooperation.
In past weeks, South Korea has been wary of the American negotiating approach with North Korea, warning that Washington might be on the verge of making too many concessions. But since the accord, South Korea has praised the agreement and begun preparations for resuming political discussions and business relationships in the North.
"A turning point has been reached for South and North Korea to seek reconciliation and cooperation," the South Korean President, Kim Young Sam, said Tuesday in a speech read to the National Assembly in Seoul by Prime Minister Lee Yung Duk.
Officials and press reports in Seoul said the Government was expected to relax restrictions soon on travel by South Korean businessmen to North Korea and on investments in the Communist nation.
A few years ago, relations between South and North Korea began to thaw and the two enemies arrived at some basic agreements. South Korea's huge conglomerates began the process of setting up factories and resorts in the North, both to tap into the low-cost labor supply and to help the Communist nation's economy, which is crumbling from fuel shortages and inefficiency.
But all that activity ground to a halt in March 1993 when Pyongyang threatened to pull out of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, setting off the crisis that now, after 18 months, seems on the verge of being at least temporarily resolved.
"With the realization of the agreement, the nuclear issue will cease to be a major roadblock and we can expect more exchanges and more dialogue in due course," Han Sung Joo, the South Korean Foreign Minister, said at a news conference Tuesday evening in Seoul. He said talks could resume before the end of this year.
Although South Korean officials say they are ready to talk to the North, it is not clear if the feeling is mutual. North Korea clearly is more interested in economic and political ties with Washington while cutting Seoul, which it brands an American puppet, out of the picture.
"North Korea's basic strategy is they don't want to talk with South Korea," said Cha Young Koo, senior research fellow at the Korea Institute for Defense Analysis in Seoul. "They need an enemy, still, for the stability of their regime."
Despite these uncertainties, and the perennial suspicion in South Korea that North Korea will not keep its promises, the overall assessment of the agreement, which was reached in Geneva, was favorable. Analysts said it might indicate that the Kim Jong Il, who is believed to have taken over as North Korea's leader after the death in July of his father, Kim Il Sung, is open to negotiations.
"The mere fact that an agreement was possible between North Korea and the United States has significance in itself," said Ra Jong Yil, a professor at Kyunghee University in Seoul. "Many people felt North Koreans were people you could not reach agreement with."

HEADLINE: Less Money and Time for Charity, Study Says

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
With little time and even less money to spare, Americans are declining to give to charity.
A study made public on Tuesday by Independent Sector, an organization that does research on volunteerism, said that 3.4 percent fewer Americans volunteered in 1993 than in 1991, and that Americans are giving about $19 less per household to charitable causes than in previous years. 
 In 1993, American donated $880 per household, down from $899 in 1991, according to the study, which was based on responses from a representative sampling of 1,509 adults.
Virginia A. Hodgkinson, who helped compile the report and is vice president of Independent Sector, said people who belong to charitable organizations tended to donate more money than people who do not. In addition, she said, people who donated time to charities when they were young were more likely to support charities as adults.
Respondents who said they volunteered time to a charity donated almost three times as much money as those who did not volunteer time, the study said.
And nearly three-fourths of those who volunteered time as children continued to donate their time as adults, the study showed. On average, the volunteers donated 4.2 hours a week.
Sarah Melendez, president of Independent Sector, said Americans were giving less to charities even though the nation's economy was improving.
"Americans seem to be more insecure about their financial well being," Dr. Melendez said at a news conference on Tuesday when the results of the study were announced. "This seems to have had a negative effect on charitable contributions over the last few years."
Despite the nation's relatively sound economic condition, 73 percent of those surveyed said they worried about having enough money. In 1992, 67 percent expressed that concern.
Dr. Melendez also said that the income tax law, which does not permit taxpayers to deduct charitable contributions if they do not itemize their deductions, might be partly responsible for the drop in donations. "Nonitemizers have no tax incentive to give," she said, "and that makes an enormous difference in the amount they contribute to charity."
The report also surveyed respondents' confidence in charitable organizations. Those that instilled the highest confidence, and received the largest amount of donations, were religious organizations and educational institutions.
Those earning the least confidence, and less money, were charities for the arts and humanities, and international or foreign charities.
The East Coast was the least magnanimous region in the country, with those surveyed saying they gave an average of 1.5 percent of their income each year. Midwesterners were the most generous, donating on average 2.2 percent. Nationally, households gave an average 2.1 percent of their income to charities in 1993.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Ebb On More Inflation Talk

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for the second day after the latest trade report raised investor concern that the Fed's rate increases had not sufficiently slowed the economy to keep inflation in check.
Among other factors weighing on the market were commodity prices, which were up sharply from the start of trading. Meat components led the Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodity futures, which was up 1.45 points to 231.17. Industrial commodities including energy, copper and lumber are also posting solid gains, with precious metals chipping in modestly. 
 The rise in commodity prices added to the market's inflation anxiety. And the dollar was down against most currencies, making dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities less attractive to foreign buyers.
In trading, the 30-year bond slipped 6/32 to 9518/32 for a yield of 7.89 percent, up from 7.87 percent on Tuesday. Shorter-maturity bills were mixed.
The Treasury announced yesterday that it planned to sell $28.25 billion of new two- and five-year notes next week. In when-issued trading ahead of the sale, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.71 percent and the five-year at a price to yield 7.36 percent.
The October home builders' survey showed improvement in the six-month sales outlook, although current sales were flat. Twenty-nine percent of those responding saw good sales so far in October versus 30 percent last month, but 31 percent expected good sales over the next six months compared with 25 percent in September. Analysts said that the housing market was leveling off at a respectable pace.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, saw the trade figures as an indication that manufacturing was continuing to show strength, as was consumer spending. She also said that despite an overall contraction in the trade deficit, the surge in exports and the increase in imports were to be regarded negatively.
Exports rose by 9.3 percent while imports increased by 3.7 percent. Since the exports represent greater demand from abroad, Ms. Schaja said, "these numbers by themselves will not push the Fed" to raise interest rates. But "in conjunction with others, they show the economy is growing above potential," she said, adding, "That is why there will be more tightening in the future."
The deficit for goods and services narrowed in August to $9.7 billion from a revised $11.2 billion in July, up from the original $11 billion.
Elsewhere in fixed-income markets, the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, announced yesterday that it had set up a $20 billion global line of credit to sell debt securities in various currencies, with 10 worldwide dealers involved in marketing and distribution.
Thomas O. Marder, a spokesman for the agency, said it would provide access to clearing systems that allowed investors to trade and settle securities in their own time zones and in the contexts of their own markets. Fannie Mae, a federally chartered corporation, did not detail the amounts, currencies or maturities of the debt it planned to issue.
In corporate debt trading yesterday, the Society Bank of Cleveland priced $1 billion of short-term bank notes in a three-part sale through CS First Boston. The notes, which are not callable, are rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's.
The first part includes $200 million of 6.70 percent notes due April 15, 1996, that are priced at par to yield about 30 basis points more than Treasury securities with a comparable maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The second part includes $600 million of 6 7/8 percent notes due Oct. 15, 1996 priced at 99.86 to yield 6.95 percent, or roughly 32 basis points more than a comparable Treasury note. And in the third, $200 million of 7 1/8 percent notes due April 15, 1997, were priced at 99.918 to yield 7.16 percent, or 35 basis points more than a comparable Treasury note.
According to MCM CorporateWatch, it has been nearly eight months since the last big bank note deal. On March 1 the Republic National Bank of New York sold $1 billion of one-year bank notes.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Airline Stocks Jump as AMR's Net Surges

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
With little to cheer about in recent years, investors in airline stocks celebrated surprisingly strong third-quarter earnings by the parent of American Airlines yesterday by bidding up shares of most major carriers.
The AMR Corporation said yesterday that its net income rose 74 percent, to $205 million, or $2.47 a share, on revenues of $4.23 billion. The earnings were 23 percent better than the average of Wall Street analysts' estimates and were AMR's biggest quarterly profit ever. 
 AMR's stock closed at $53.875, up $1.875, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
AMR typically reports earnings before other airlines, and the Fort Worth-based company is viewed by many investors as a bellwether for other airline stocks. On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, rose $3.25 to $90.125 and Delta Air Lines closed at $47.125 a share, up $1.50.
The airline industry has lost $12.8 billion over the last four years, and despite yesterday's rare good news, AMR officials played down the results for reasons that had as much to do with changes in the industry as with internal negotiations with leaders of its unions.
For all the renewed optimism in the industry, carriers are still expected to earn about $1 billion this year, but because of high costs, their profit margin is expected to be only 1.1 percent.
American, like other established carriers, is also facing increased competition from low-cost airlines that offer cheap fares and few frills to travelers. Carriers like Southwest Airlines have grown rapidly and now compete with American on about 40 percent of its route network. That competition was reflected in a drop in American's yield, or the revenue that each passenger pays to fly one mile, of 3.6 percent, to 12.95 cents in the third quarter.
American is also trying to convince leaders of its unions that the airline needs significant concessions to help permanently lower its costs and improve productivity. Union representatives have not agreed to American's requests for $750 million in concessions.
"In light of our earnings, some may ask if the company still needs to change," said Robert L. Crandall, chairman of AMR. "The answer is that it clearly does."
"Our objective," he added, "must be to report satisfactory financial results, not just in a single quarter, but on a regular basis."
AMR attributed the 74 percent jump in net earnings in part to improving global economies. The airline's load factor, or percentage of seats filled, rose to 68 percent from 64 percent a year ago, more than offsetting the drop in yields.
In addition, the airline noted that its efforts to reduce costs by cutting jobs and dropping service on unprofitable routes led to a 2.2 percent drop in AMR's operating expenses.
Industry analysts said airline stocks jumped yesterday in part because AMR officials had hinted in recent weeks that yields were under more pressure than were reflected in yesterday's results. They added, however, that third-quarter AMR earnings do not signal that there has been any fundamental change in the various pressures on established carriers.
"By no means is the structural problem of the full-service majors solved," said Ray Neidl, an airline analyst at Furman Selz.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against the Yen After Trade Deficit Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell near a post-World War II low against the Japanese yen yesterday after the United States Government reported an unexpected widening of America's trade deficit with Japan in August.
The British pound also rose sharply against the dollar, advancing for a seventh consecutive session. 
 After falling in Asian trading, the dollar slid further against the yen on European and United States markets after the Commerce Department said the trade deficit with Japan had risen to $5.8 billion in August. The market had expected a narrowing of the gap. The news refocused attention on Japan's persistent surplus, which preserves a glut of dollars held by Japanese exporters that must be sold for yen.
"The trade number didn't provide any reasons to buy the dollar," said Michael Faust, foreign exchange strategist at Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser, a money management firm in San Mateo, Calif. "Bears were confirmed in their positions and bulls didn't have anything to help their case."
Some market participants noted that the dollar had gained some support from unconfirmed reports of dollar buying by the Bank of Japan and other central banks as the currency veered toward its postwar low of 96.60 yen, a level hit in intraday trading on July 12.
In New York trading yesterday, the dollar settled at 97.35 yen, down from 97.74 yen, its lowest New York close since it fell to 97.25 yen on July 12.
The dollar also slipped against the German mark. It was quoted at 1.5015 marks, down from 1.5027 on Tuesday.
The pound rose to $1.6232, up from $1.6133, in New York trading. The pound has risen about 2.5 percent against the dollar this month and is up more than 9 percent from early this year.
Analysts pointed to a number of factors in explaining the British currency's strength, including a strong economy and the effects of an interest rate increase by the Bank of England in September.
"The Bank of England has raised rates in a manner that was seen more pre-emptive than what you saw in the United States," said Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst with Smith Barney Inc. "The economy is moving ahead. If that can happen without fears of inflation, the pound will look increasingly appealing."

HEADLINE: S.& L.'s See New Threat, This Time From Banks

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 19

 BODY:
Just as the $200 billion bailout of the savings and loan industry nears its end, Federal regulators are voicing fears about a new threat to the industry.
The problem is this: Although savings and loan companies are mending, commercial banks are recovering from their recession-related troubles even faster. And that means that the premiums commercial banks pay to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation are likely to be cut drastically next spring, while the savings and loan industry will continue to pay higher charges for the next seven years to rebuild its own depleted fund. 
 At the savings and loan industry's annual convention here, Andrew C. Hove Jr., the F.D.I.C.'s vice chairman, warned today against giving commercial banks a competitive advantage through lower insurance rates. "A premium differential could place thrifts at a competitive disadvantage," he said.
Jonathan Fiechter, the Clinton Administration's top savings and loan regulator, also expressed similar concerns here on Tuesday.
Mr. Hove and Mr. Fiechter laid out three options, but they refused to choose among them. One option is to merge the bank and savings funds. Another possibility is for Congress to shore up the savings industry fund, using as much as $10 billion left unspent in the savings and loan industry rescue.
A third alternative would be to require the bank fund to share the savings industry fund's burden of making annual interest payments of $793 million through the year 2019 on Federal Government bonds issued in the late 1980's to reimburse depositors at some failed savings institutions.
Not surprisingly, banking industry officials bitterly oppose any plan that puts an additional burden on them. They contend that savings and loan industry officials and some Federal regulators -- including Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve -- are exaggerating the dangers facing savings institutions. "Why on earth should commercial banks and their depositors pay a fee to support the stock prices of savings and loans?" said Edward Yingling, the chief lobbyist for the Washington-based American Bankers Association.
A merger would mean $10 billion in extra costs for banks over the coming years, he added, mostly as contributions to the annual $793 million in payments.
The alternatives are no better. Using taxpayers' money to bail out the savings industry again would be unpopular in Congress. "I think there is going to be tremendous reluctance by Democrats and Republicans," said Howard Menell, the Republican staff director of the Senate Banking Committee.
The squabble over deposit insurance has cast a shadow over the planned end of the industry's bailout by the Federal Government. The Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency that disposes of insolvent savings institutions, is scheduled to sell the last two such institutions by the end of November.
By law, the agency will shut down next year and transfer its staff and any unsold assets to the F.D.I.C. Because the savings and loan industry has fared better this year than anybody expected, the Resolution Trust now appears likely to shut down without spending $8 billion to $10 billion that Congress had authorized the Treasury Department to raise through bond sales, Mr. Katsanos said.
Some savings and loan executives play down the dangers.
"My best guess is that they will not deliberately pass it back to their consumers," said Rudy E. Schupp, the chairman, chief executive and president of the Republic Security Bank, a savings and loan institution based in West Palm Beach, Fla.
But other executives here do not share Mr. Schupp's calm. Mixing metaphors, James F. Montgomery, the chairman and chief executive of a large savings institution, the Great Western Bank, said: "For me to try to compete with Wells Fargo and Bank of America in California with a hand tied behind my back is a pretty big hill to climb,"
Savings and loans differ from banks in that they traditionally specialized in home mortgages and construction loans. They still are required to put slightly more of their assets into housing loans than banks do. Many savings and loans now call themselves banks to avoid the stigma of the industry's bailout.
The insurance premiums assessed on a savings institution's deposits may seem small: about a quarter of 1 percent for the typical bank or savings institution. But the premiums are substantial in light of the thin profit margins in the banking industry.
This year, for instance, savings and loans are prospering, yet profits equal just eight-tenths of 1 percent of total assets.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Broad Gains Lift Copper; Coffee, Oil and Cattle Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Copper prices posted their steepest one-day gain in more than four months yesterday, spurred on by rekindled dealer demand and talk of an Australian smelter strike.
Copper's surge led a broad advance in commodity prices. Coffee, crude oil and livestock were among the gainers that lifted the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities 1.45 points, to 231.17. 
 On the Commodity Exchange in New York, copper for December delivery rose 4 cents, to $1.186 a pound, the highest in three and a half weeks. It was copper's strongest rise since June 7.
Spot copper prices peaked at a four-year high of $1.285 on Sept. 23 as recovering economies in Europe and the United States increased demand for the metal, which is used in making electrical wire, tubing and other basic products. But the market then retreated, prompting commodity investment funds to sell large holdings in copper futures they acquired during the summer, when prices were rising rapidly.
As the fund selling subsided earlier this week, others rushed in to buy, said Richard Hirsch, vice president of Sharps Pixley, a brokerage subsidiary of the Deutsche Bank in New York. "Copper's been going down," he said. "It had a lot of catching up to do."
James Steel, an analyst with Refco Inc., said the rally began overnight on the London Metal Exchange, partly in response to hazy reports of a strike at an Australian copper smelter. Australia produces about 4 percent of the world's copper.
Coffee prices rose in thin, nervous trading on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, erasing most of Tuesday's losses, on renewed worries about drought damage to the Brazilian coffee crop. Coffee for December delivery rose 6.7 cents, to $2.016 a pound.
November crude oil rose 20 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange to $17.42 a barrel after an industry group reported lower United States stocks of gasoline than traders had expected.
Cattle led livestock futures sharply higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on expectation that this week's heavy sales of cattle to meatpackers should clear up a backlog of market-ready animals. December live cattle rose 0.90 cent, to 69.30 cents a pound.
