HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Big government and the Big 3 pass the air pollution buck.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
FOUR years ago Congress got a big round of applause for requiring the states to reduce ozone air pollution to levels that don't send asthmatics to early graves. But it left the details to the states. And -- no surprise -- regulators in the heavily polluted Northeast, who must answer to diverse interest groups, are at a loss on how to get from here to there.
Worse, perhaps, the only Federal agency with the power to drive the bargaining to a conclusion that serves the public is hoping, hoping, hoping someone else will take the political heat. "The Environmental Protection Agency has abdicated its leadership role," argues Dan Dudek, an economist with the New York-based Environmental Defense Fund. 
 Mr. Dudek wants Washington to seize the opportunity to dump the primary cleanup responsibility on auto makers (as state regulators prefer), but give Detroit maximum flexibility in meeting super-tough pollution standards.
Many urban areas do not come close to meeting the national ozone standard. And in recognition of the fact that the pollutants reacting with sunlight to create ozone can travel hundreds of miles on prevailing winds, the 12 states of the Northeast are trying to set policy collectively.
Solutions that ask direct sacrifice from voters are -- you guessed it -- very unpopular. Indeed, what many regulators agreed was an obvious first step -- increased inspection and maintenance of autos already on the road -- has proved a political flop in Maine and Massachusetts. So, in their desperation to meet the Federal standard before Washington is obliged to impose punishing restrictions on local economic development, the Northeast looked to auto makers as the interest with the least capacity to resist.
New York and Massachusetts have already passed laws requiring new cars to meet the exceptionally stringent pollution limits imposed by California -- a mandate that includes the gradual introduction of electric cars into private use. And last year the Northeast states petitioned the E.P.A. to require all 12 in their group to match the overall California emissions requirement.
Auto makers, who worry that the super-clean cars demanded by California will cost a fortune to make and worry even more that the auto market will become Balkanized into a dozen or more environmental enclaves, made a counter-proposal. The Big Three offered to set a low emission standard for every car sold outside California if the Northeast would ease up sufficiently to allow them to avoid the use of exotic technologies.
The offer pleased the E.P.A., which is eager to extricate the Clinton Administration from that space between the rock and the hard place. The White House, after all, has made much of its commitment to nonconfrontational solutions to environmental problems. And it would be delighted to take credit for reductions in emission in states that have not even asked for them.
But the auto makers' proposal angered state regulators and tradition-minded environmental lobbies because it would not force technological change. And it frustrates environmental economists, who sympathize with the auto industry's desire for regulatory certainty, but also get the point that no one is representing consumers in this negotiation. "Setting the same tailpipe standard for Manhattan and Montana makes no sense whatever," argues Robert Hahn of the American Enterprise Institute.
The Environmental Defense Fund, a group that often tries to bridge the gap between environmentalists and economists, thinks there is still a way for the Clinton Administration to do well by doing good. They want the E.P.A. to accept Big Auto's 49-state offer, but beef it up with a requirement that Detroit remove as much tonnage of pollutants from the Northeast as they would by meeting California emissions standards.
And how would auto makers manage that without electric vehicles or other experimental technologies? Any way they choose, Mr. Dudek says. They might, for example, pay the owners of old cars to junk their vehicles, or subsidize the conversion of coal- and oil-fired power plants to natural gas.
Traditional environmentalists ought to be satisfied, Mr. Dudek says, because such market-based flexibility would encourage innovation where it really would be cost effective. The manufacturer of the first affordable electric car that drivers really wanted, for example, would be able to exchange the extra pollution credits for cash.
But market-based fixes are a hard sell. Most environmentalists and state regulators crave the visibility that comes with flashy technological mandates. And while auto makers certainly want the Government to forgo technology-forcing regulation, they still prefer the devil they know (explicit requirements to install antipollution hardware) to the devil they don't. More subtly, they fear emissions trading because its success would tempt regulators to ratchet down the quantity of pollutants that could be emitted.
What seems clear is that no one represents the public, which must pay for regulation whether or not it is efficient. "This is what happens," laments Joseph Goffman, a senior attorney with the Environmental Defense Fund, "when big government meets big business."

HEADLINE: Disregards to Broadway: Neil Simon's Next Play Will Be in 'Off' Category

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

 BODY:
Firing a shot across the bow of Broadway's unions and theater owners, Neil Simon has announced that his newest play will open Off Broadway when it comes to New York.
Mr. Simon is the country's best-known living playwright, and has opened 23 plays on Broadway since "Come Blow Your Horn" in 1961. 
 "It's just not economically viable for us to go to Broadway anymore," Mr. Simon said yesterday from Seattle, where his play "London Suite" has opened to favorable reviews. "It's not even an attempt to make money anymore: the big prize is just to get your money back for the investors."
Emanuel Azenberg, Mr. Simon's longtime producer said: "It's an economic judgment based on an insanity. It costs a minimum of $1.5 million to bring a straight play to Broadway versus $500,000 or $600,000 to do the same play Off Broadway. We're just not getting our money's worth. We keep saying that, and yet we keep doing it, like lemmings. Well, this time the lemming is stopping, and saying 'No.' "
"You want Broadway back?" he asked rhetorically. "Then it's got to change."
By taking this stand, Mr. Azenberg said, he and Mr. Simon are declaring war on Broadway's power structure. "I'm at war with Gerry Schoenfeld," he said, referring to the head of the Shubert theater chain. "I'm not a theater-owner lover."
After being told of Mr. Azenberg's comments, Mr. Schoenfeld said: "He's a belatedly converted lemming. If he's at war with me, then he's at war with a lot of producers who think it makes sense to bring straight plays to Broadway. Look at 'An Inspector Calls.' And 'Les Parents Terribles,' which is coming in the spring. Or 'Greater Tuna.' Or Lincoln Center doing 'Arcadia.' Or Bill Kenwright doing 'The Ideal Husband.' They're all coming."
"He's entitled to his opinion," Mr. Schoenfeld continued, "but we have a lot of plays coming in; it's a late starting season."
Other theater owners were less eager to take up the glove Mr. Azenberg and Mr. Simon threw down. Rocco Landesman, the head of the Jujamcyn theater chain, called Mr. Simon's decision "very alarming."
"It's a message we had better listen to," he said. "If we price ourselves out of the market, we're going to be out of business. Already, you have major playwrights like Pete Gurney who could have filled Broadway houses a few years ago who work entirely Off Broadway. Now Neil Simon -- wow."
Nick Scandalios, a spokesman for the Nederlander theater chain, said the Nederlanders had been prepared to bring "London Suite," a comedy similar to Mr. Simon's "Plaza Suite," to Broadway. "We were holding the Neil Simon Theater for him, and we would have put up money," he said. "We would of course prefer that he do it on Broadway. We've been his happy partner on his last three projects. But whatever Neil and Manny feel is the best thing for the play, we'll stand by them."
Mr. Simon's last Broadway play, "Laughter on the 23d Floor," received mixed reviews and closed without paying back its investors. His last musical, "The Goodbye Girl," was a critical and box-office failure.
"The economics are out of control," Mr. Scandalios admitted. "What does it say about the state of American theater when you've got almost no plays on Broadway and Edward Albee and Neil Simon Off Broadway?"
Mr. Albee's Pulitzer Prize-winning play "Three Tall Women" is enjoying a comfortable run at the Promenade Theater on the Upper West Side. And that brings up a dilemma Mr. Simon is facing. There are not many Off Broadway houses big enough to hold the audiences that would demand to see anything Mr. Simon has written.
"We want a 500-seat house," Mr. Azenberg said. "We'll settle for 450."
There are only a handful of theaters that size: the Promenade; the "Variety Arts," which has a bill of short plays opening in January; the Union Square, which has "Vita and Virginia," with Vanessa Redgrave, opening Nov. 21, and the Minetta Lane, which is to open "Das Barbecu," a satire on the Wagner "Ring" cycle, on Nov. 10.
If they can't get such a house this season, they will "postpone until the right one becomes available," Mr. Simon said.
There was little reaction yesterday -- and no evident outrage -- from the most-affected unions.
"I have no argument with the guy," said Alan Myers, a business agent for the stagehands' union. "We still have plays. We have Circle in the Square and the Roundabout and the Booth Theater. If he wants to lead a movement, as we say in Yiddish, "Zei gezundt -- go in good health."

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
Up, Up and Away: Muted Carlesimo Starts Over

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 19

 BODY:
So P. J. Carlesimo, the new coach in town, by reputation yells too much. So, what's wrong with that? The guy he replaced supposedly whined too much, and that nobody-respects-me refrain grew old and tired, along with the legs of some of his stars.
The friendly folks here will tell you that Rick Adelman grew, like weeds, on the so-called City of Roses, whose mandate is to take deep, sustaining inhalations of professional basketball, the only major league game it has. 
 Despite reaching the National Basketball Association finals twice in five and a half seasons, despite a winning percentage of 65 percent, it was time for Adelman to take his dour personage elsewhere. It was time, the multibillionaire owner of the Portland Trail Blazers determined, to bring in a high-energy, raspy voiced power boy, and how about that noisy fellow with the Smith Brothers cough drop look? How about the red-bearded charmer from back East, from the Big East, from the field of big reputations, mouths and dreams?
How about a guy who could make one of the smallest and most provincial markets in North America, coupled with one of the N.B.A.'s more phlegmatic rosters, instantly sound like the 1980's Magic Johnson Lakers relocated to heaven?
"Our goal is to win the championship," the new coach said, with the verve of Rick Pitino, with the sentiment of Larry Brown, and with more than $7 million of the computer giant Paul Allen's money guaranteed over the next five years.
Of the Trail Blazers, Carlesimo said: "There aren't too many jobs as good as this one."
This is the job that finally drew Carlesimo away from his self-described utopia known as South Orange, N.J., and his ongoing five-year rollover contract with Seton Hall because there came from within him a voice that said, simply, "Yes."
Other schools had tried to pry him away from Seton Hall, where Carlesimo coached 12 years and came within seconds and one of the most generous bump foul calls in history of winning the national championship in 1989. Other N.B.A. teams had informally inquired. It was not until last spring, when the caller was Brad Greenberg of the Blazers' front office, when the question was whether he might be interested in flying out, that Carlesimo realized he'd bit at the first sign of bait.
"Usually I would say, 'No thanks,' and then two or three days later I'd say to myself, 'Maybe I should have listened,' " Carlesimo said. "But when I heard Brad on the phone, when I thought, 'Portland,' all of a sudden it felt right."
All of a sudden, Carlesimo was at his parents' home on a tree-lined street in Upper Montclair, N.J., the family called into conference to talk Carlesimo out of leaving or help him tie the loose ribbons around his decision to go west. His father, 79-year-old Pete, presided at the head of the table, as usual. His mother, Lucy, kept the soup and pasta coming, as usual. His nine brothers and sisters, among them two lawyers, a film director, a voice-over specialist and a cosmetics executive, volleyed their famous brother's options, as usual.
"No one thought I shouldn't take it," said the 45-year-old bachelor.
The notion of this drizzly outpost on Oregon's northern border had a certain appeal, an air of comfort, of familiarity. This was where he'd sent two of his best Seton Hall big men, Mark Bryant and Ramon Ramos, where he'd come to keep a bedside vigil for Ramos when a car crash nearly killed the player in 1989. This was where his appetite for the pro game was whetted, as an assistant Dream Team coach during the pre-Olympic Tournament of the Americas in the early summer of 1992.
This was where another of those state-of-the-art, N.B.A sky box palaces was rising next door to the outdated Memorial Coliseum: the 20,300-seat Rose Garden arena doesn't open until next season but is already sold out. And this was where the owner, said to be the richest in American team sports, has stated that he wants a championship, costs be damned.
"Portland's a pretty unique situation, and it had to be to get me to leave Seton Hall," Carlesimo said.
What Allen and Portland offered Carlesimo is truly unique in this sports management era of ideological combat for economic control of big-time sports leagues. It offered small-market life style and big-market checkbook.
Small market notwithstanding, there were grand expectations in Portland, long before Allen. The Blazers won the N.B.A. championship in 1977, with Bill Walton as their star, with Dr. Jack Ramsay as their coach, with smart, fluid teamwork as their m.o. For as long as there is a franchise here, that team will set the standard for excellence, much like Red Holzman's 1970 champion Knicks in New York.
The Blazer critics are quite different from the rest of the league. The news media reacts to Blazer doings like those of the fire department and the police. The fans cheer enthusiastically when things go well. They sit in stony silence, like disapproving parents, when things go bad.
Last season, despite 47 victories and a one-round playoff incursion, things were considered bad.
"We've had a good run the last few years, but we didn't win the whole thing and so in a lot of people's minds here it wasn't good enough," said Clyde Drexler. "There's a feeling we were moving backward. P. J. helps change that feeling. He's enthusiastic. He's got a lot of energy. He's got a lot of people in Portland thinking the team is going to move forward again."
It is, until proven otherwise, wishful thinking. Drexler, the Blazers' popular star, is 32, with rebellious legs. Buck Williams, their enforcer, is 34. Last season's leading scorer, Clifford Robinson, barely saluted the incoming coach as he walked out of camp, demanding that his $2.5 million contract be redone, beyond the $4 million-a-year lines of center Chris Dudley, a shot blocker with no offense who missed almost all of last season with a broken ankle.
Into this urban anomaly and twisted set of expectations steps Carlesimo, a natural-born salesman and program builder at tiny Wagner College in Staten Island in the 1970's and then, in the early 1980's, at sputtering Seton Hall. Back then, Carlesimo was bound to be heard, which guaranteed he'd be seen. From his customary late-night Italian restaurant haunts, he lobbied cooks to keep their kitchens open, entertained students, officials, reporters, fans. He made friends. He sold tickets.
The difference here, as Carlesimo said, is "we don't have to sell tickets." There hasn't been an empty seat in years. Mostly, Carlesimo has to sell himself, as pro material, to a veteran team, jaded by disappointment, as well as by the inevitability of decline.
His reputation for high volume, for berating his players, preceded him, if only because Bryant, one of Carlesimo's first major recruits at Seton Hall, preceded him by six years.
"From what I can see, he's already toned it down," said Bryant.
Sure enough, Carlesimo was a picture of solemnity pacing the sidelines during the Blazers' preseason victory Tuesday night.
It's a question and subject he doesn't want to dwell on, but he does, anyway. He knows people wonder.
"Look, I'm coaching men now," he said. "There should be less pushing, less prodding, because these are pros who know their jobs."
To demonstrate that he is much more than voice and beard, that his Seton Hall teams won because they were always positioned right in opponents' faces, Carlesimo lifted the defensive guru Dick Harter from Pat Riley's Knicks staff. Harter is 63, respected leaguewide, and realistic enough to know whatever evolution the Blazers experience won't happen overnight.
"We don't have Patrick and we don't have Oak," he said, referring to Patrick Ewing and Charles Oakley.
Of Carlesimo's adjustment, Harter said the real challenge will be nuts and bolts, the rules, the pace of game and season. He needs time to learn, like any rookie. But, Harter said, he is too smart, too hard a worker, not to.
"The players will respond because they'll see P. J. is sincere," Harter said. "Just like in college, personality can carry the day in this league, too."
Drexler, for one, recalls Carlesimo as the assistant who would prep the Dream Team on its opponents. "He'd get up in the locker room in front of the best players in basketball, and it was like he'd been in the league 15 years," Drexler said. "You could tell he had that. . . ."
Drexler paused, groping for the right word.
"Chutzpah," he said, finally, capturing the essence of what grows now in the City of Roses.

HEADLINE: The Governor's Plan for Lilco

 BODY:
Gov. Mario Cuomo's proposed takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company is clearly an election-year ploy. Three weeks before elections, he says the takeover would yield a 10 percent cut in electricity bills for Long Island voters. But whatever the Governor's motive, his proposal warrants serious attention. Indeed, with additional safeguards the plan could yield sizable benefits to Lilco shareholders and customers.
At the core of the plan is a tax dodge. If the state were to buy Lilco from its shareholders, the utility would no longer owe Federal taxes and could borrow at tax-free -- therefore low -- interest rates. Lilco could use the low-cost loans to buy back shares, thereby eliminating dividends, and to replace existing high-cost loans. The potential saving is huge because Lilco is buried in debt, in part because it built a $5.5 billion nuclear plant, Shoreham, which it never opened in the face of ferocious opposition from nearby residents and, well, Governor Cuomo. 
 A state takeover would, then, transfer perhaps $300 million in Federal tax savings each year to Lilco. According to Mr. Cuomo's plan, Lilco would then rebate about $200 million to customers through rate cuts. The company could plow the $100 million balance into economic development and energy conservation projects.
Critics complain that the plan would put Lilco in the hands of public managers. They fear that the $300 million windfall would be swallowed up over time by managerial inefficiency. They also worry about turning over a $100 million slush fund to a publicly owned monopolist. Yet studies of private versus public utilities around the country do not show that private managers systematically do a better job controlling energy costs.
Based on experience in other states, the key to protecting Long Island customers is not whether Lilco is run by private or public managers. The key is subjecting Lilco to competition. S. David Freeman, the energy official who would manage the takeover, accepts that vision and plans to sell Lilco's generating facilities. He would then open up the company's transmission lines to companies that want to sell electricity to Lilco's customers. The idea is to drive electricity prices down by forcing companies to bid against each other for business.
But critics worry that Lilco might renege on this promise. State regulators are preparing rules that would subject utility companies to more competitive pressure. But the state regulatory authority would exert no control over Lilco once it is publicly owned. Mr. Cuomo needs to amend his proposal so that Lilco, as a condition of public ownership, would be required to adopt whatever pro-competition rules state authorities impose on private utility companies.
Competition can keep Lilco in line, guaranteeing that Long Island residents reap the benefit of a tax dodge without suffering from laggard management of its utility. That way, a clever campaign promise can become smart energy policy.

HEADLINE: Germany Discriminates Against Scientology

 BODY:
To the Editor:
For me, as a German, now living in this country, "Officials in Germany Denounce Sect as a Menace to Democracy" (news article, Oct. 13) lays out exactly the warped mind-set of the German Government when dealing with religious minorities it does not understand, even when those minorities have been recognized as religions by the highest courts of Germany. 
 From 1982 to 1992 I built up an image and fashion consulting business to more than 650 franchises across Germany. I trained each franchise holder.
In 1992 I was accused of using my business as a front for the Church of Scientology because I myself am a member of that church. The news raged in the media, and although I have always considered my religion a private affair, within two years the majority of my franchise holders had canceled their contracts because they were accused of collaborating with Scientology.
Religious discrimination to me meant watching my business disintegrate before my eyes; it meant my children were no longer admitted to kindergarten; it meant dismissal of my husband from the district board of directors of Rotary despite his outstanding service.
The sad truth is that I am not alone. Thousands of Scientologists in Germany suffer the same plight.
In 1933 Nazi soldiers paraded with boards exhorting "Germans! Defend Yourselves! Don't Buy From Jews!" And signs that proclaimed "Jews Are Unwelcome Here!" were erected at village entrances. I understand the anger and frustration that the Jews must have felt when suddenly hit with economic and social restrictions by Hitler's Nazis. I am ashamed of today's German Government.
 
JOHANNA ERDTMANN
Clearwater, Fla., Oct. 16, 1994

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: PENNSYLVANIA SENATOR
Struggle for the Senate;
In Pennsylvania, Round 2 on Healt

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Just months ago, most analysts, and many people in his own Republican Party, had dismissed Representative Rick Santorum, who is challenging Senator Harris Wofford, as too far to the right to suit the political tastes of most Pennsylvanians.
The state, after all, has a history of sending moderate Republicans to Washington -- lawmakers like Arlen Specter, John Heinz 3d, Hugh Scott and Richard S. Schweiker. Confronted with a newly conservative Dick Thornburgh in 1991, voters instead chose Mr. Wofford, their first Democratic Senator in 30 years. 
But today, the 36-year-old Mr. Santorum, who fiercely opposes gun control, abortion, family leave and extending unemployment insurance, has pulled even in the polls with Mr. Wofford, whose election three years ago helped push the issue of health care to the top of the national agenda. Indeed, Mr. Wofford paved the way for Bill Clinton's own emphasis on the issue.
For Mr. Santorum, that has provided ideal ammunition. He describes President Clinton's health proposal as "socialized medicine" that the country repudiated, and Congress's failure to adopt the Clinton plan only reminds voters that Mr. Wofford did not deliver on his central issue.
There are several other reasons Mr. Santorum, a little-known two-term Congressman from Pittsburgh, has a chance of becoming the state's first conservative in recent times to break through to the Senate. Chief among them is voters' deep dissatisfaction with Mr. Clinton. Just as Pennsylvanians used Mr. Wofford to send a message to President George Bush three years ago in a special election to fill a vacant Senate seat, they could well use him again to send a message to President Clinton.
"Bill Clinton is as enormously unpopular in Pennsylvania as he is everywhere else," said Neil Oxman, a Democratic consultant here. "If Clinton's numbers were reasonable, this wouldn't be a race."
Moreover, the striking contrasts between Mr. Santorum and the 68-year-old Mr. Wofford, ideological and otherwise, infuse every aspect of this increasingly vituperative race.
To Mr. Santorum, Mr. Wofford is obsolete, an intellectual idealist who has done little for Pennsylvania, is ineffectual in Washington and is stuck in the "unworkable" 1960's notion that big government can solve every problem.
To Mr. Wofford, Mr. Santorum is a "right-wing radical" who distorts the truth, whose mean-spiritedness appeals to the worst in people and whose election would embolden the already obstructionist Republicans in Congress.
The candidates' differences were crisply caught during a recent radio debate in Pittsburgh. Mr. Wofford was reflecting on the national service law he helped enact and how it would help students pay for college, much like the G.I. Bill, when Mr. Santorum erupted: "Somebody is going to do one year of community service picking up trash in a park and singing 'Kumbaya' around a campfire, and you're going to give them the equivalent of a G.I. Bill!"
Given Mr. Santorum's firebrand nature and commitment to the cause, Republicans in Washington foresee a high-profile future for him if he is elected on Nov. 8 and the Republicans regain control of the Senate. Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, is already praising him as a future majority leader. And Mr. Santorum makes no secret of his desire to play on the national stage.
"I'm not afraid to stand up and tell people what the vision is for this country and articulate it in terms of individual freedoms and liberties as opposed to government control," he said in an interview. "Most candidates in Pennsylvania talk about locks and dams, things that are non-ideological, and as a result, we've not had a whole bunch of impact on the national scene."
Beyond that, Mr. Santorum has benefited from Mr. Wofford's campaign, a somewhat unfocused effort, marked chiefly by the Senator's compulsion to dwell on health care. While that reminds voters that Mr. Wofford did not deliver on his central issue, he said in Pottsville, "If I'm re-elected, it will be a signal to go back to the drawing board."
Taking a cue from national Democrats, Mr. Wofford criticizes the trickle-down economic policy of the Reagan Administration, which he says left Pennsylvania "on its back."
But Mr. Santorum has an easy retort for that, noting that he was not even in Congress when Ronald Reagan was President.
G. Terry Madonna, a political analyst at Millersville University, said: "Wofford hasn't given voters a reason to vote for him. He hasn't made a connection."
Mr. Wofford has also failed to make Mr. Santorum out to be a "right-wing crazy," Mr. Madonna said, an obvious tack that many analysts are surprised he has not taken.
The Senator spent more than $1 million on television advertisements, but used them to badger Mr. Santorum on minor issues like his attendance record, which did nothing to improve Mr. Wofford's standing in the polls. Mr. Wofford said in an interview that this would soon change and that despite his reputation as too courtly to go for the jugular, he was prepared to do just that.
Still, his overarching message is that he stands for the common good and wants to bring people together.
Wofford backers suggest that Mr. Santorum is the stealth candidate of the Christian Coalition. Mr. Santorum, whose campaign has bought the mailing list of the 50,000-member Pennsylvania Christian Coalition, said the group was but one of several, including the National Rifle Association and the Pro-Life Federation, whose members are combing the state for him.
Nonetheless, the Santorum campaign seems a textbook example of what Ralph Reed Jr., executive director of the Christian Coalition, described in an essay last year. Mr. Reed said the "pro-family movement" could win elections by not harping on social issues and speaking instead "to the concerns of average voters in the areas of taxes, crime, government waste, health care and financial security."
At the same time, Mr. Santorum has received the support of the state's leading moderate Republican, Senator Specter, who openly -- but futilely -- tried to recruit a female Republican candidate who favored abortion rights to oppose Mr. Santorum in the primary.
But Mr. Specter has now lent Mr. Santorum three top aides and said, "He's had the support of my entire operation."
Granting that Mr. Santorum's votes in Congress have differed from his, Mr. Specter said, "I'm not looking for someone who agrees with me on all the issues."
Indeed, with his climb in the polls and a new-found confidence, Mr. Santorum now describes Mr. Specter as the one "out of the mainstream."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A sharing of clients, but not ownership, quickens the growth of a Hispanic-owned agency in Dallas.

BYLINE: By Kathryn Jones 

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
HISPANIC-OWNED advertising agencies often face a common quandary: how do they get the power and the clients they need to grow, yet remain independent?
Victor F. Ornelas struggled with that question six years ago when he started his own agency on his dining room table here. He decided that he did not want to be swallowed up as a Hispanic division of a general market agency, as was the trend. Instead, he built his agency by forming an alliance with Tracy-Locke Inc., now part of DDB Needham Dallas Group. 
 The affiliation, which involves the sharing of clients but not agency ownership, put Ornelas & Associates on its feet, and now it is running so hard that it is one of the fastest-growing Hispanic advertising agencies in the country. Last month, Hispanic Business magazine named Mr. Ornelas its national entrepreneur of the year, based on the agency's growth record.
Billings, which were $150,000 the first year, are expected to reach $25 million this year and $50 million in the next three years. Ornelas & Associates has won many large advertising accounts on its own, including Hispanic marketing campaigns for the Anheuser-Busch Companies, the Banc One Corporation, Borden Inc., the Southland Corporation and Wrangler Jeans.
The idea behind the affiliation with DDB Needham was to share the general market agency's clients that wanted to reach the Hispanic market -- companies like the Pepsi-Cola Company, a division of Pepsico Inc.; the McIlhenny Company, maker of Tabasco brand hot sauce, and the GTE Corporation. Mr. Ornelas has added several key Hispanic employees from DDB Needham, including his agency's account service director and creative director. His agencynow has 35 employees, most of them Hispanic.
"We knew that once we formed a strategic alliance, it could really accelerate our growth," Mr. Ornelas, who is 46, said from his office filled with brightly colored Mexican art and pre-Columbian artifacts.
Marketing to Hispanic consumers goes beyond merely translating an ad into Spanish, Mr. Ornelas said. It means developing a separate strategy for the Hispanic community, with consumers from many different countries bound by a common language.
"If you're marketing soft drinks, for example, how much do they consume, where, when and what?" Mr. Ornelas said. "First and foremost you have to understand what is relevant to the Hispanic community. We recommend a lot of primary research, such as focus groups and quantitative surveys. Once you have that foundation, you can test the market strategy and position and see if it's relevant and works."
Tracy-Locke was handling Pepsi's national promotions and field advertising and marketing -- including major Hispanic markets in Southern California and Texas -- when it decided on the affiliation with Mr. Ornelas in 1989.
"It was the right move at the right time," said Mike Rawlings, president of DDB Needham Dallas Group. "We got a great resource and can act as one agency on a GTE or a Pepsi account. We have close financial ties, but it's his company."
The "Pepsi Man" campaign, introduced in June 1993, established Ornelas & Associates as an agency to watch. Styled as a caped crusader to do battle with rival Coca-Cola, Pepsi Man, played by the comedian Paul Rodriguez, took the Pepsi Challenge taste test to the Hispanic market. It was, indeed, a challenge because many Hispanic consumers had grown up drinking Coca-Cola.
"Coke does have an advantage in the Hispanic market because historically they have had a stronger Latin American business than we have had," said William C. Cobb, Pepsi-Cola's vice president of marketing for colas.
While Pepsi-Cola declined to release any specific sales figures or market data, Mr. Cobb said the "Pepsi Man" campaign had increased brand awareness of Pepsi in key Hispanic markets.
"In San Antonio, for example, business is absolutely booming," Mr. Cobb said. "We're very pleased with our sales results in intensely targeted markets."
The campaign is still running and is one of the largest advertising campaigns ever aimed at a Hispanic audience -- how large, neither Pepsi nor Mr. Ornelas would say, except that it was in the millions of dollars. Pepsi-Cola is the largest client of Ornelas & Associates.
The agency also created Wrangler's "Viva la Tradicion" campaign, which featured a Mexican vaquero, or cowboy, and developed a campaign for Budweiser that doubled the beer's share of the Hispanic market in Texas.
But the market is a moving target, Mr. Ornelas said. That might pose challenges for advertisers in the future, but it also could give Hispanic agencies more opportunities to grow, he said.
"The whole market has become a paella," Mr. Ornelas said, referring to the traditional Spanish dish with saffron rice as its base and an assortment of vegetables, seafood and meat tossed in. "Every element is unique and distinct. General market agencies have not become that diverse. They can't walk the bicultural line."

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Build Laser to Create Nuclear Fusion

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
In the first major step toward the restructuring of the nation's nuclear weapons complex for the post-cold-war era, the Energy Department has approved a proposal to build a giant $1.8 billion laser machine at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California. The announcement, to be made by Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary, is planned for today.
The device is to generate miniature blasts of thermonuclear fusion energy for studying how the stars shine, how such nuclear fire may be harnessed on earth to generate electrical power and how the reliability of hydrogen bombs can be maintained without full-scale, explosive tests underground. 
 Housed in a building the size of two football fields, the project would easily be the world's largest and most powerful assemblage of lasers.
The decision to build the machine marks a turning point for Livermore, a cold-war bastion set adrift with the demise of its old job of designing nuclear warheads. The project has also sparked vigorous debate within Government and scientific circles over whether it will help or hinder the spread of nuclear weapons.
If the plan is approved by Congress, which seems likely, the giant laser will give the sprawling, 8,500-person laboratory a new lease on life. The laboratory has lost 1,500 jobs in the last few years, and an injection of money would check the downturn with new recruits, especially young physicists.
"This is a big step not just for the complex but for the nation," Secretary O'Leary said in a telephone interview from California, where she had traveled to make the announcement at Livermore.
The Secretary said that both President Clinton and Congress had asked the department for a means of insuring the integrity of the nation's nuclear arsenal without having to resort to explosive testing. "This answers the question of maintaining our core competence," she said.
Dr. Henry W. Kendall, a nobel laureate in physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who advises the Energy Department, hailed the decision as key to keeping Livermore alive scientifically and ready to battle with a growing number of "global environmental and resource problems that are beginning to stun us."
On a local level, the machine, known as the National Ignition Facility, or N.I.F., should also help boost the battered Northern California economy, which will get lots of the 1,500 new jobs the project is expected to generate in construction, manufacturing and operations.
News of the machine's approval also stands to aid California Democrats now engaged in do-or-die re-election campaigns. Senator Dianne Feinstein and other members of the California delegation, have been invited to the announcement today at Livermore, which is in a dry valley about 40 miles east of San Francisco.
Congress is increasingly worried about the stewardship of the nation's nuclear stockpile after the cold war and is seen as likely to approve the costly effort, which is backed by the Armed Services Committees in the House and the Senate.
Some experts worried about the spread of nuclear weapons argue that the laser machine makes the United States look hypocritical as it urges other nations to forgo the weapons testing while perfecting a new device to do so in miniature.
But other experts say the project is a necessary evil that allows the United States to spearhead the drive for a global ban on nuclear testing, which is a major goal of the Clinton Administration and is the subject of negotiations in Geneva. The United States is maintaining a self-imposed ban on testing.
The machine would help scientists push back the frontiers of nuclear physics and astrophysics while learning scientific subtleties that might be applied to nuclear weaponry, and would create a cadre of experts that, in theory, could design new bombs if needed.
No nuclear weapons could be designed with N.I.F., Government officials and private experts say. Its relationship is more indirect, in that certain weapon-physics problems could be studied experimentally.
Secretary O'Leary, as part of the approval process, has asked for a detailed follow-up study that would resolve the question of whether the giant laser would aid or hinder the nation's efforts to curb the spread of nuclear weapons. The study is to be ready sometime next year.
"Frankly, I do not believe this is a threat to nonproliferation," she said. "But having heard those concerns raised with great vigor by people I respect, we're going to examine that question more thoroughly."
The cost, goals and proposed site of the project at Livermore have made it a political hot potato.
The Energy Department was to have decided in May whether to include a request for the construction of the project in the Federal budget for the 1996 fiscal year, which begins on Oct. 1, 1995 and is now being prepared by Federal agencies for the Clinton Administration. By all accounts, its approval was assured.
But at the last minute, the decision was put off till now, apparently because of a debate over whether the project might inadvertently foster the spread of nuclear weapons.
Today's announcement will be the first of many expected in the next few years as the Government seeks to recast the role of its national complex of laboratories and nuclear-production plants, which was born half a century ago at the dawn of the nuclear age and now employs more than 100,000 people in 15 states.
The Energy Department safeguards the nation's nuclear arsenal, dismantles warheads, conducts scientific research and is spending a growing amount of its $18 billion budget on a cleanup meant to ameliorate some of the most deadly environmental legacies of the cold war.
If successful, the N.I.F. would be the world's first device to control thermonuclear ignition, in which hydrogen or isotopes of hydrogen are fused together to form helium, releasing a burst of energy, a process better known for lighting stars and powering hydrogen bombs.
The machine would work by firing the dazzling light from 192 lasers down a labyrinth of mirrors, focusing a titanic bolt of energy -- a thousand times the output of all the power stations in the United States -- onto a single tiny pellet of super-cold hydrogen fuel and creating a miniature thermonuclear blast.
No lights in the United States would dim when it was fired. Energy for the machine's discharge would be slowly stored up and then released in a fiery discharge lasting one-billionth of a second or so, its shortness giving it incredible strength.
In theory, the machine would be strong enough to go beyond the break-even point in the quest for controlled nuclear fusion, where the energy consumed in the effort equals the energy released. Instead, it would go into the realm of "ignition," where sufficient heat is generated to make fusion reactions self-sustaining.
The National Ignition Facility is envisioned as a national resource, to be run jointly with the nation's other two nuclear-weapons labs -- Los Alamos and Sandia, both in New Mexico -- and the University of Rochester, a pioneer in laser fusion.
The project's $1.8 billion price tag includes operating costs over the laser's projected lifetime of 15 years.
In the Government's current current fiscal year, studies related to the project are getting about $8 million, Energy officials say. With the approval, the budget for the next fiscal year will swell to between $50 million and $60 million, and be much bigger in later years as construction gets under way.
Dr. Thomas B. Cochran, a senior scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council in Washington, has studied the laser project proposal and found it wanting. "They desperately need to address the nonproliferation issue," he said. "They need to address whether N.I.F. is really the right strategy."
Dr. Cochran acknowledged that the proposal was likely to sail through Congress next term, but that it might face trouble later on. "In effect," he said, "this kicks the hard decision off another year or so, until you have to spend serious money for construction."
Herbert F. York, Livermore's first director and a consultant to the Government on the restructuring of the nation's atomic complex, applauded Secretary O'Leary's decision, saying that fears about it aiding the spread of nuclear weapons were not unfounded but had to be weighed against the greater good.
"This science-based stockpile stewardship is part of the bargain that makes it possible to have a comprehensive test ban," he said. "And that itself is a powerful tool for the promotion nonproliferation. So in the net, I think going ahead with N.I.F. is a good way to support further moves in the direction of arms control and disarmament."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE APPEAL;
Pataki Courts Black Voters As Jackson Backs Cuomo

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:
On a campaign day that highlighted the importance of black voters, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo won a rousing endorsement from the Rev. Jesse Jackson while his opponent, George E. Pataki, traveled to southeast Queens and Harlem to argue that black New Yorkers should vote Republican because they are so often the victims of violent crime.
Polls suggest that black voters will side overwhelmingly with Mr. Cuomo on Nov. 8, as they have in his three previous elections. But both campaigns also understand that a Cuomo victory may depend on a huge turnout by black voters, perhaps as large as the 50 percent turnout for David N. Dinkins, New York City's first black mayor, in last year's municipal elections. 
 To inspire a large turnout, Mr. Cuomo and his surrogates are depicting Mr. Pataki, in the language of one Cuomo brochure, as "too frightening for us to let him win."
Mr. Jackson advanced that theme yesterday afternoon at a rowdy rally at the Manhattan headquarters of Local 1199 of the hospital workers union as he endorsed Mr. Cuomo. "If you vote Republican, or don't vote at all, you aid the bird in the bush and the phantom," he said.
The Pataki campaign is responding to such attacks by placing the candidate in black neighborhoods and the pulpits of black churches in a calculated effort to demonstrate that he is not the demon the Democrats have made him out to be.
"We've seen the Cuomo campaign repeatedly sling mud and paint George as a member of the radical right, and anyone who knows George Pataki knows that's not true," said a top Pataki campaign official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. In addition, the official said, the Pataki campaign is not entirely ceding the black vote to Mr. Cuomo. "They, like other New Yorkers, want streets that are safe from crime," the official said.
Mr. Pataki has saved his hardest pummeling on the crime issue for the closing weeks of the gubernatorial campaign. He began broadcasting a television ad this week in which a mother from Red Hook, N.Y., blames Mr. Cuomo directly for her son's murder this year because the assailant had been paroled from a state prison.
Mr. Cuomo said yesterday that the ad "sounds ugly and it sounds as though they're desperate." He also said the ad was not factually correct because the killer would have served out his full sentence by the time the attack occurred, even if he had not been paroled.
"I think it's a lie actually," he told reporters. "The question of taste I'll leave to the people who see it."
But Mr. Pataki adopted some of the ad's emotion-packed language in his remarks in Queens yesterday, saying the state needs to remove "those predators" from the streets.
To deliver that message, Mr. Pataki chose the setting of Carmichael's Diner, which is owned by King Carmichael, a prominent black businessman who was shot nine times during a robbery outside his restaurant last week.
The event had been planned before Mr. Carmichael's shooting as a discussion on economic development between Mr. Pataki and local business owners. But Mr. Pataki used it instead to make the case that black New Yorkers are disproportionately affected by crime, and should therefore support his candidacy because of his proposals to eliminate parole and impose longer, determinate sentences for violent felons.
"It is particularly the African-American community that is most vulnerable to the crime and the rampant lawlessness that we see far too often on the streets," he said.
Mr. Pataki also appealed to black voters by saying the Republicans had been guilty of ignoring them over the years.
"It wasn't the fault of the African-American community," Mr. Pataki said. "It was the fault of the Republican Party that didn't reach out, that didn't express our understanding that we're in this together." He added: "This is a new era. This is a new party. We are reaching out."
And yet, even some of Mr. Pataki's black supporters acknowledged that low turnout in the black community on Nov. 8 would probably help him. "There's no doubt about it," said Morris R. Lee, a black Republican district leader from southeast Queens, who said many people may stay home or skip voting for Governor, "which will put our man in office."
Mr. Jackson endorsed Mr. Cuomo yesterday afternoon at a rowdy rally at the Manhattan headquarters of Local 1199 of the hospital workers union. After attesting to Mr. Cuomo's support for the poor and itemizing votes by Mr. Pataki that he said had hurt "people of color, poor people, and workers," Mr. Jackson suggested a new slogan for the Cuomo campaign. "Pataki," he said, virtually spitting out the name. "Just plain tacky."
He added: "If you vote Republican, or don't vote at all, you aid the bird in the bush and the phantom."
Mr. Cuomo said he was grateful for the support, and pledged to fight for funding for health, education and social services programs for disadvantaged youth. "Don't talk to me about, 'We're spending too much money trying to save our children. Let's abandon them,' " he said. "That's a different view. It's a shrunken view. It's a desiccated view."
Mr. Jackson won 37 percent of the vote in the 1988 Presidential primary in New York, finishing second to Michael S. Dukakis. More than 90 percent of the black voters supported him, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls.
But since the day in 1984 when Mr. Jackson was quoted as calling New York City "Hymietown," the civil rights leader's endorsement has been a mixed blessing in the state, capable of both inspiring black voters and alienating Jews.
Several prominent Jewish Democrats said yesterday, however, that they did not believe Mr. Jackson's backing would steer Jewish voters away from Mr. Cuomo this year, and that those who might be influenced probably would vote against the Governor anyway.
"My guess would be that his ability to pull out the incremental African-American voter far exceeds the extent to which he may remind a Jewish voter that he once was indiscreet privately," said Mark Green, the New York City Public Advocate.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Skid On Fears Of Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Fears of future inflation, heightened by two new Government reports showing that the economy continues to move ahead briskly, today sent bond prices lower and long-term interest rates up to the brink of 8 percent.
The fall in the bond market pushed the stock market lower, with the Dow dropping 24.89 points to 3,911.15. Traders in both markets were also worried that the dollar fell to a post-World War II closing low against the Japanese yen and a two-year low against the German mark in New York. [Pages D6 and D15]. 
 The declines in the bond and stock markets began this morning when the Commerce Department reported that the nation's home builders broke ground on new homes at the fastest pace of the year in September, and construction in the two preceding months was stronger than initially estimated.
"We're back to the highs of earlier this year," said David Lereah, chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Assocition, assessing the unexpectedly vigorous activity in September, when the annual pace for new homes was 1,525,000, a 4.4 percent monthly rise. "There must be a lot of raised eyebrows at the Federal Reserve."
Adding to the worries in the credit market was a report by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, which showed manufacturing activity accelerating in the region and the prices of raw materials and finished goods surging to a five-year high. Another factor that sent bond prices lower was a sharp rise in commodity prices, which pushed the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodity futures up nearly 2.75 points to 233.89. The high for the year is 239.72.
The 30-year bond fell 15/32 to 9413/32 , pushing the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, to 7.99 percent, up from 7.89 percent on Wednesday. That was the highest since May 5, 1992, when it was also 7.99 percent. The yield briefly touched 7.997 percent, which rounds off to 8 percent.
Shorter-maturity bill rates were up an average of 9 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Analysts said that the string of economic data this week pointed to unexpectedly robust growth. "I've raised my estimate for third-quarter gross domestic product to 3 percent, from the 2.5 to 3 percent range," said Donald Fine, the chief market strategist at Chase Securities.
The Federal Reserve is likely to raise short-term interest rates not only by its Nov. 15 policy meeting, analysts said, but could also follow such a move with another rate increase at its December session.
"Now if this type of economic strength continues, we may have another move at the F.O.M.C. meeting on Dec. 20 as well," Mr. Fine said. "It certainly does not appear to be the Fed's last tightenting move."
What most surprised the markets was that rising interest rates seem to have had remarkably little damaging effect so far on the industry that is typically the first casualty: housing.
"This should lead people to revise their thinking about how fast the economy's slowing down," said Robert R. Davis, chief economist for the Savings and Community Bankers of America, referring to the strength in housing.
Permits for future construction, a harbinger of activity in coming months, also jumped. They rose 6.5 percent to a pace that, like starts, was the highest since December.
"Underlying strength in the economy is keeping consumer confidence at a relatively high level," said David W. Berson, top economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, "and this is to a large extent offsetting the rise in mortgage rates."
In a separate tally, the Labor Department reported today that first-time claims for unemployment insurance eased 3,000 last week, to 326,000, and that the four-week average now stands at 321,000. Analysts tended to dimiss this reading, however, because of a big upward revision for the Oct. 8 week, which was the first week of a new quarter when it is more advantageous for some people to file, and because of the Columbus Day holiday.
Analysts said the housing market was buoyed by new enthusiasm for adjustable-rate mortgages, which are now used by more than 40 percent of buyers, or twice the share that prevailed last autumn when long-term interest rates began to climb.
Adjustable-rate mortgages are still available for 6 percent or less, at least for an initial period, and consumers seem confident enough about jobs and incomes to risk the eventual upward adjustment. By contrast, conventional 30-year mortgages averaged 8.68 percent in September, and 8.93 percent last week, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
This compares with a 25-year low of 6.74 percent in October 1993.
Although the September strength was far from uniform -- the West was strongest in starts and permits and the Northeast was weakest -- analysts said they were highly impressed. Of particular note was a jump in permits for apartment construction, a sector that has rebounded smartly after restoration of a tax credit for building units for the poor.
Single-family homes accounted for all of the September gain, however, with groundbreaking in the West running at an annual rate of 386,000, up 21.4 percent from the 318,000 August pace. The Midwest posted a 6 percent gain, to 337,000 from 318,000.
The Northeast's decline was 4.5 percent, to 133,000, while the South, far busier than the other regions, edged down 1.5 percent, to 669,000.
Without seasonal adjustment, builders started 131,600 homes last month, 5.5 percent below the August level, the report also showed.
All but 9,000 of the 88,000 total rise in permits, to a 1,442,000 annual rate, was for buildings with two or more units.
For the first nine months of 1994, starts ran at 15.8 percent of the 1993 pace, while permits were 17.7 percent ahead.
Shipments of mobile homes, today's report also showed, rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 288,000 in August, virtually unchanged from July's 286,000 rate.

HEADLINE: Stocks Are Off Sharply As Interest Rates Rise

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market, rising for much of the month because of a steady string of higher earnings reports, plunged yesterday in heavy trading.
Stocks fell as yields came tormentingly close to 8 percent on long bonds, the highest level of corporate borrowing costs in nearly two and a half years. The 30-year Treasury bond closed at 7.99 percent. 
 Evidence of a strong economy -- from a Philadelphia Federal Reserve survey, a report on higher housing starts and increasing commodity prices -- again stampeded traders into bidding bond yields higher.
Good earnings reports from companies like I.B.M. were not enough to offset the surprising decline in North American operations at General Motors, despite the company's overall profitability. The G.M. stock plunge accounted for more than 10 points in the Dow Jones industrial average's drop of nearly 25 points.
The dollar, already weak, fell further when Lloyd Bentsen, Secretary of the Treasury, said the Government had no plans to intervene to support the dollar.
"It was a culmination of events," said Kathleen Camilli, chief economist for Maria Fiorini Ramirez Inc. "The Philly Fed, housing and commodities prices all contributed. Plus, it's hard for foreigners to buy our bonds when the Treasury Secretary is talking the dollar down."
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 24.89 points, to 3,911.15, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 dropped 3.43 points to 466.85. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 2.38 points to 768.24.
Despite the declines, Todd Clark, senior director of equity trading for Mabon Securities, said he was somewhat encouraged by the relatively mild drop in most indexes, especially the Nasdaq. "It held together pretty well, what with the bonds tickling 8 percent," he said.
The drop in stocks came despite strong earnings at I.B.M., which eased 3/8, to 75, at AT&T, which gained 3/8, to 54 1/4, and at Microsoft, up 2, to 59 5/8. On the New York Stock Exchange, two stocks declined for every one that rose, with 702 advancing stocks and 1,523 declining stocks.
The most striking fall of the day was General Motors, which dropped as much as 4 3/8, or nearly 10 percent, in unusually heavy trading. It closed the day at 43 1/8, down 3 3/4, and set a 52-week low. G.M. executives acknowledged that cost-cutting and productivity in North America had been disappointing.
G.M. was also the most active stock, on a volume of more than 16.9 million shares. That was twice the volume of the next most-active stock, Microsoft. Almost a quarter of the daily volume in G.M. came from a single huge trade of more than 4.1 million shares at 43 shortly before 2 P.M. The identity of the seller was not immediately known.
Other big decliners included Sundstrand, an aerospace and electronics company, which fell 5 7/8, to 45 3/4, after it predicted that 1995 earnings would disappoint analysts. Kimberly-Clark fell 5, to 52 3/4, after reporting disappointing quarterly profits.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal with more than 331.4 million shares changing hands, about 15 percent more than this year's average of 288 million shares.
Stock traders are caught between a rock and a hard place. They want to see higher earnings so stock prices will rise. Yet a strong economy scares bond traders, who believe robust economic growth leads to higher inflation.
Yesterday, stock and bond traders were surprised by a sharp jump in the October price indexes of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve survey of businesses, a quick snapshot of business conditions.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.78 point to 256.54 and the American Stock Exchange market value index fell 0.5 point to 457.76.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 18 fell, led by G.M. and Procter & Gamble, which fell 1 7/8 to 62 5/8. Of the 500 stocks in the S.&P. 500, 337 fell, led by G.M. and General Electric, which dropped 1 1/4, to 49.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE PRESIDENT;
Clinton Finds Stride in Massachusetts

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Oct. 20

 BODY:
By the standards of an ordinary political autumn, it would not have been an unusual sight. But in an angry election season when Bill Clinton has served more as punching bag than as President, his performance at a town hall rally in New England today, and the acclaim he found there, offered a hint that he had begun to discover his true campaign voice.
The rally, bursting with Democratic fervor, was something of a coming out for Mr. Clinton, who has devoted most of his political energy this fall to raising money at events in hotel ballrooms, largely because so many Democratic candidates would rather not be seen with him in public. 
 Today Mr. Clinton raised not a dime, but he found many admirers.
There on the stage with him were Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the five-term Massachusetts Democrat whose troubled re-election bid was the main reason for the Presidential pilgrimage here; Representative Edward J. Markey, the Democrat who represents this liberal stronghold 20 miles west of Boston, and other Democratic candidates for every office from governor to state representative.
And packed into the hall before them, beneath an American flag the width of the stage, were hundreds of supporters who waved blue Kennedy signs and stamped their feet to the beat of a high school band that spilled out of the building and onto a Main Street crowded with even more well-wishers.
"The fog is beginning to clear," Mr. Clinton declared in a full-throated address, contending that wary voters were starting to recognize just how much Democrats had achieved since he took office. "We've still got a long way to go," he said, "but America's in better shape now than it was 21 months ago."
Since taking to the road on Wednesday, Mr. Clinton has seemed emboldened in part by foreign policy successes that, for now, have eased major worries from North Korea to Iraq. In New York on Wednesday afternoon, with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo at his side, he ticked off those successes as evidence of progress made by his Administration across a broad front. Today, from the town hall steps here, he said American soldiers who helped restore President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to power in Haiti had displayed "the best of this country."
But his appearances on the two stops, his most prominent of the campaign season so far, were most of all celebrations of common cause that have become rare among Democratic candidates, who in many parts of the country have chosen to go it alone.
Before today's raucous crowd, Senator Kennedy, who was first elected to his seat in 1962, even put forward a vision that few other Democrats have dared describe. "As soon as we re-elect old Kennedy to the United States Senate," he declared, "we're going to start on the 1996 campaign."
Mr. Clinton is perhaps more popular in Massachusetts than anywhere else in the country. A poll by The Boston Globe last month found his approval rating in the state to be at 60 percent, nearly 20 points above what was then the national figure. That warmth has been largely generated by an exceptionally sharp decline -- to 5.2 percent from 7.9 percent -- in the state's unemployment rate since he took office.
Even so, today's midday rally was open only to ticket-holders, many of whom carried signs and wore buttons that identified them as Democratic faithful. And while the stage was crowded with more Democratic candidates than had been willing to share a platform with Mr. Clinton on any other occasion this fall, White House officials acknowledged that the back-to-back show of public zeal by Governor Cuomo and Senator Kennedy was likely to prove an exception.
Other Democratic senators struggling in their re-election bids this fall, including Jim Sasser of Tennessee and Harris Wofford of Pennsylvania, have demonstrated no interest in inviting Mr. Clinton to campaign for them, apparently out of concern that his lack of popularity will rub off. Others, including Charles S. Robb of Virginia and Dianne Feinstein of California, have proved willing to appear with him only at fund-raising events that are open only to generous donors and limited press coverage.
And although Mr. Clinton will end a weekend campaign trip in Ohio on Monday, his aides have said he will be appearing there only for two Democratic candidates for the House. Joel Hyatt, the Democratic lawyer who is trying to succeed his father-in-law, Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, has apparently signaled that he has no interest in Presidential appearances on his behalf.

HEADLINE: A New Quality in Brazil's Exports

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GUARULHOS, Brazil, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Under the 10-acre roof of the Ford Motor Company's car-radio factory here, the modern face of Brazil's newly efficient export industries becomes as apparent as the plant's new Japanese robot, triple-checking electronic circuit boards with a laser's exacting eye.
"Under our quality-control program, we are cutting defects in half every two years," said Luis Carlos A. Oliveira, the quality and productivity manager for the Ford electronics plant in this industrial suburb north of Sao Paulo. The factory, which employs 4,000 workers here in the Sao Paulo industrial belt, ranks among the world's largest manufacturers of car radios and automotive electronics. 
 Four years after Brazil began opening its long-protected industries to international competition, Brazilian companies contrary to some expectations, have not tumbled like dominoes. Instead, they have invested heavily in ratcheting up their productivity to world standards. As a result, the Sao Paulo industrial center, the biggest in Latin America, is emerging as a tough and efficient challenger in world markets.
"Brazil will offer the U.S. a mixed picture in the future," said Jeffrey E. Garten, the United States under secretary of commerce for international trade, after visiting Sao Paulo. "We will have bigger markets, but we will also face more competition."
A yardstick of Brazil's rising industrial efficiency is the jump in the number of companies awarded certificates of quality from the Geneva-based International Organization of Standardization. The organization, known in manufacturing circles by its original initials ISO, has set quality standards for 107 nations since 1947.
Today, 410 Brazilian companies are ISO-certified, compared with just 18 three years ago. Government officials project that 5,500 Brazilian companies will be approved by the end of 1997.
The certificates, first issued in 1987, provide assurance of a company's ability to deliver a product or service that consistently satisfies customer requirements. Sometimes referred to as international visas for quality, the certificates create confidence among business partners, often eliminating the need for long and costly inspections of products received from suppliers.
"It is not an obligation for doing business in Europe, but it is increasingly becoming a market requirement because customers ask for it," said Roger Frost, a spokesman for the standards organization in a telephone interview from Geneva. "Brazil is one of the fastest-growing countries in the world for the number of companies certified."
Elsewhere in Latin America, Mexico has 133 companies certified, Colombia has 25, Venezuela 22, Argentina 17, and Chile 5.
The ratings are important for Brazil because about a quarter of its exports go to countries in the European Union, which adhere to the Geneva organization's criteria, and a further 21 percent to the United States, which demands similar quality.
While some American business executives still cherish hazy notions of Brazil as a coffee-bean exporter, the reality is that coffee now ranks seventh among Brazil's $5.7 billion worth of exports to the United States so far this year -- after shoes, piston engines, telecommunications equipment, refined gasoline, auto parts, and pumps and compressors.
"One of the major barriers to Brazilian exports is quality so companies need an internationally recognized diploma," said Luiz Carlos M. Brandao, who checks ISO standards in Brazil for the American Bureau of Shipping Quality Evaluations, a Houston-based auditor. He said the number of Brazilian companies asking to be monitored have risen to 210 from 3 in 1992.
The competition for quality has become so fierce that "the best business in Brazil is to become an industrial quality consultant," said Ailton Barcelos Fernandes, executive secretary of Brazil's Ministry of Industry, Trade and Tourism, who reported that the country's industrial productivity jumped 18 percent last year over that of 1992.
Interest in modernizing business practices has become so widespread that Brazilian bookstores last year sold 1.5 million Portuguese-language copies of 300 business-administration manuals. Only 10 titles were available two decades ago.
"Brazilian industry has made a productivity leap of 30 percent since 1990," said Hermann J. Wever, president of Grupo Siemens, the Brazilian subsidiary of the German multinational. In the last four years, the Siemens subsidiary, all nine of whose Brazilian factories are certified by the Geneva standards organization, quadrupled its exports, to $80 million.
In July, the McKinsey Global Institute released a study of productivity in steel, banking, telecommunications and processed food in Latin America's five largest economic powers -- Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Mexico and Venezuela. Productivity levels averaged slightly less than half of United States levels, but Brazil came out on top, with productivity averaging 26 percent higher than that of Mexico, the region's next largest economy.
Brazil's steel industry, the biggest in Latin America, has doubled its productivity since 1990, attaining annual production of 315 tons a worker, which is close to Japanese levels.
At Caterpillar's Brazilian subsidiary, a six-year, $300 million investment has cut the average assembly time for a tractor to three days from five.
At Marcopolo, the world's third-largest bus manufacturer, productivity tripled since 1987 at its plant in southern Brazil.
"People have stopped holding their noses at Brazilian products," said Luis Jimenez Roman, industrial manager of the Brazilian subsidiary of the American company Stanley Tools, another certificate holder.
"When we started exporting five years ago, at least half of our products had to go out without the label 'Made in Brazil,' Mr. Roman said, because customers did not want the origin identified. Now, he said, only one Chilean client wanted the label left off.
The cumulative effect of this industrial efficiency drive has shown up in Brazil's trade surplus, which is the world's third largest after those of Japan and Germany. Brazil is expected to register a $13 billion surplus on a record $43 billion in exports this year, despite an overvalued currency and imports surging 17 percent.
By contrast, Latin America as a whole is recording its third consecutive trade deficit, jumping this year to $21 billion. Of Latin American non-oil exporters, only Brazil and Chile will show trade surpluses this year.
Looking to the future, economists predict that Brazil will become an increasingly muscular player in the international trading arena.
Anticipating continued strong domestic sales as well as exports, Brazil's auto makers plan to increase car production to 3 million in 1996 from 1.4 million last year.
Brazilian companies also find themselves in a better position to invest for overseas competition because their debt loads average one-third of those carried by their United States and Japanese competitors.
As a result, manufacturers are looking beyond their traditional markets. "We are now well situated in Europe and the United States, and are moving into South Korea," said Luiz Fernando Antonio, international operations director for the Ford plant, which now ships 40,000 electronic units a day. "The ISO has been a key to open new doors."

The certificates give assurance that a company's products meet internationally recognized standards for consistent quality. HEADLINE: Officials Give Up Opposition To Company to Run Schools

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

 BODY:
Hartford city officials agreed this week to drop their opposition to hiring a private company to manage the city's public schools, even as test scores released by Baltimore officials raised questions about the company's performance in schools it manages there.
The Hartford Board of Education voted on Oct. 3 to hire the company, Education Alternatives Inc. of Minneapolis, even though the city's Corporation Counsel refused to sign the contract, saying it gave the company too much control over the city's budget. 
 But on Wednesday, a legal challenge to the contract was averted when City Council members and city lawyers and finance officials reached agreement with the school board on revisions.
The revisions strengthen oversight of the company's spending of the city's $171 million education budget, plus $29 million in grants, and eliminate a provision calling on the city to increase the budget each year by an amount at least equal to inflation.
One goal of Hartford in hiring Education Alternatives is to improve the performance of students on Connecticut's standardized tests, which rank the city's school system last in the state.
But board members said they were not concerned by the release of test scores in Baltimore that show overall averages on math and reading tests declining in the nine schools managed by the company there, while the overall averages for other schools rose.
"Hartford is not Baltimore," said Kathy Evans, who led the school board's negotiations with the company. "Education Alternatives has a different role in Hartford. We have our own strategic plan that it will implement."
In June, Baltimore officials released 1993 test results for the company's schools showing improvement. But this week, in releasing results for the entire school system, they said the earlier figures were wrong.
Philip E. Geiger, divisional president of Education Alternatives, said the company was investigating the discrepancy. "We have initiated a complete review of those test scores -- student by student -- and the summary of this review will be fully disclosed as soon as possible," he said.
Education Alternatives has been working in the Baltimore schools since 1992. Reports of the decline in test scores drove down the company's stock more than $2 a share, 10 percent of its value, on Tuesday. The stock closed yesterday at $20 a share, up $1.375, in Nasdaq trading.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Railroad stocks, it seems, are no longer run-of-the-mill.

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
THESE are heady times for mergers and acquisitions specialists with clients in the railroad industry. The Union Pacific Corporation is trying to elbow in on Burlington Northern Inc.'s plans to merge with the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation; the Illinois Central Corporation is proposing to acquire the Kansas City Southern Railway, and a steady stream of smaller consolidations is in the works.
In most other industries, the high level of merger activity would have arbitragers and others who love to play the takeover scene salivating. But railroad marriages often take years to win regulatory approval. The Burlington Northern and Santa Fe, for example, expect clearance to merge in the spring of 1996, if everything goes smoothly. 
 Not surprisingly, speculators who like quick returns generally stay away from the sector, and the merger activity has done little to lift railroad stocks. Indeed, so far this year the group is down 12.5 percent, apparently because of fears that rising interest rates portend an economic slowdown that will depress earnings.
The Wall Street consensus, though, is that investors are too bearish. Not only are there many buy recommendations now on the Street, but also not a single sell-side analyst following the industry is recommending that any of the companies be sold, according to Zacks Investment Research Inc., a Chicago-based firm that tracks Wall Street's views of different stocks.
Thomas Galvin, who follows the industry for C. J. Lawrence Deutsche Bank Securities, expects most railroad stocks to rise 20 to 25 percent over the next year to 18 months as investors start to recognize the basic improvement in the industry's competitive position. The stocks have been shortsightedly lumped with the other cyclical groups that are vulnerable to fears that an economic recovery is nearing its peak, Mr. Galvin said.
"The whole group is undervalued," agreed Anthony Hatch, who follows railroads for Paine Webber. "The industry is in a truly rare situation where its biggest problems are all related to growth in volume."
Long-term contracts with key shippers and competition from other forms of transportation make it hard for railroads to raise prices. Since deregulation in the early 1980's, the key to raising profits has been to cut costs and smoothly move as much traffic as possible. When demand climbs too quickly, though, delays mount. That limits the total volume getting through the system and piles on expenses for overtime.
As a prime example, Mr. Hatch cited Conrail Inc., the dominant carrier in the Northeast. He estimated that capacity problems were shaving at least a percentage point off its operating margins this year. That translates to a loss of $20 million in net income, or between 22 cents and 25 cents a share. Mr. Hatch expects earnings during the fourth quarter and next year to demonstrate that Conrail has sorted out many of the problems.
Other railroads with capacity problems are the Chicago & North Western, which has more coal traffic out of the Powder River Basin in Wyoming than it can handle, and the Union Pacific, which wants to acquire Santa Fe to help overcome bottlenecks on its transcontinental route through Nebraska to California and the Northwest.
One positive result of the strong demand on key routes and growth in intermodal traffic -- in which truckloads are carried long distances on trains -- is that railroads are beginning to get actual price increases for some services, albeit still below the rate of inflation. "We are seeing the first broad-based test of whether rates can actually rise after deregulation," Mr. Hatch said.
