HEADLINE: How Rich We Are! And Yet How Poor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Oh, how rich we Americans have become!
Our private net worth after discounting for inflation has increased over the last 50 years by fivefold. On a per capita basis and in real (inflation-corrected) terms, Americans are three times richer than we were 50 years ago. 
 We are properly concerned about our $4.5 trillion national debt, but our private net worth -- after deducting private debt -- exceeds $23 trillion. This means 260 million Americans today possess an arithmetic average wealth after subtracting debt of nearly $90,000 each, or more than $350,000 for every family of four.
The 1994 Statistical Abstract of the United States shows that in 1992 those living in poverty included 24.5 million whites, or 11.6 percent of the white population; 10.6 million blacks, or 33.3 percent of the black population, and 6.7 million Hispanics, or 29.3 percent of the Hispanic population.
Despite the country's wealth, the plight of the needy appears to have deteriorated since 1970. The Statistical Abstract discloses that while average private wealth was enormously increasing, the percentage of Americans living below the poverty line appears to have risen. In 1969, 12.1 percent of Americans lived in poverty; by 1992, in this far richer country, the figure had risen to 14.5 percent.
How can this be? Our Federal Government has spent far more billions than ever on housing for the poor, food stamps for the needy and health care through Medicaid for the impoverished. But our health is an international disgrace. We suffer the shortest life expectancy of any developed, industrial nation. We lead the developed world in the incidence of heart disease and cancer. We have become the fattest people who ever dwelt on this earth.
This sorry record has little to do with health care. The answer is that we eat far more and exercise far less than any other nationality.
It is not just our Government that is failing. It is the individual American!
 
WILLIAM PROXMIRE
Washington, Oct. 20, 1994
 
The writer is the former United States Senator from Wisconsin.

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
THE BELL CURVE: Intelligence and Class Structure in American Life, by Richard J. Herrnstein and Charles Murray. (Free Press, $30.) The evidence the authors see indicates to them that society is layered in rough accordance with I.Q. and that I.Q. is largely heritable, findings they believe society needs to take note of.
 
THE FOLLOWING STORY, by Cees Nooteboom. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace, $14.95.) An insignificant man who has experienced transformation by imagination awaits his turn at death in this "Eurofable" by a Dutch novelist.
 
IN THE LAKE OF THE WOODS, by Tim O'Brien. (Seymour Lawrence/Houghton Mifflin, $21.95.) This grim, telling novel deals with the incapacity to register reality of a politician whose disappearance from the record of the My Lai massacre precedes his vanishing from the earth.
 
NATURALIST, by Edward O. Wilson. (Shearwater/Island Press, $24.95.) A memoir by a distinguished biologist who has never lost his boyhood enchantment with nature, though he has suffered abuse for his sociobiological synthesis.
 
THE PHYSICS OF IMMORTALITY: Modern Cosmology, God and the Resurrection of the Dead, by Frank J. Tipler. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Life is eternal, says a mathematical physicist, given the nature of this universe; a 123-page mathematical appendix is offered for skeptics.
 
THE SCIENCE OF DESIRE: The Search for the Gay Gene and the Biology of Behavior, by Dean Hamer and Peter Copeland. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) A readable, cautious account, by a scientist and a journalist, of an investigation into whether homosexuality is genetically determined.
 
SNOW FALLING ON CEDARS, by David Guterson. (Harcourt Brace, $21.95.) A handsomely constructed, densely packed first novel whose characters are those who suffered and those who profited from the internment of Japanese-Americans in World War II, called upon by a criminal trial to act decently later on.
 
STALIN AND THE BOMB: The Soviet Union and Atomic Energy, 1939-1956, by David Holloway. (Yale University, $30.) A superb history, showing how Stalin both helped and hindered his nuclear scientists, and telling more about the Soviet H-bomb project than is known about our own.
 
TAFT, by Ann Patchett. (Richard Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $21.95.) This generous novel concerns abandonment, dislocation and the recovery of community in a Memphis bar whose owner is a surrogate parent to two displaced teen-agers.
 
WHAT I LIVED FOR, by Joyce Carol Oates. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $23.95.) Ms. Oates shrewdly dissects the national myths of manhood and success in a novel whose easily confused hero understands less than the reader does of what passes through his own mind.
 
WHO WILL RUN THE FROG HOSPITAL? by Lorrie Moore. (Knopf, $20.) A sad, witty, disillusioned fairy tale whose heroine, approaching 40, recalls the illusion of limitless possibility she used to feel.

LENGTH: 422 words

HEADLINE: No More Whining

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Concerning Robert Pinsky's essay "A Man Goes Into a Bar, See, and Recites: 'The Quality of Mercy Is Not Strained' " (Sept. 25), which perceptively discusses the committing to memory of poems: 
 It has seemed to me for a long time that the entire apparatus of poetry workshops, writing schools, etc., would be better off totally dismantled, and replaced with what Robert Graves assures us was the ancient Welsh method of training poets: by having would-be poets memorize thousands of lines of poems, and composing their own work (after this rigorous apprenticeship) strictly on classical models. In doing so, we would lose, perhaps, the much-vaunted "individual voice" that such workshops are said to nurture (along with most of Generation X), but we would also be spared the mediocre collegiate whinings of endless introspection: whinings perhaps unique, but only in the way that the yelps of seal pups are unique to their anxious mothers.
It takes no real budgeting of time to do this, either. Simply photocopy a good text, snip it into logical segments, tape these to index cards (making sure to number each card sequentially) and carry them whenever the vagaries of life are likely to put you at the tail of a slow-moving line. I've memorized long poems like Yeats's "Easter 1916" (which Mr. Pinsky mentions), Browning's "Childe Roland," Donne's "Extasy" and the entirety of Spenser's "Epithalamion," as well as countless shorter verses by Shakespeare, Keats, Roethke, Housman, while waiting to make a deposit at the bank, or for a load of skivvies to dry. More impressive, students of mine, many of them from virtually illiterate backgrounds, have in this manner memorized poems equally long or difficult.
There are many reasons for engaging in this apparently fruitless activity. (It's a hit at parties, and great for defusing tense urban confrontations.) Mr. Pinsky outlines some of the deeper ones in referring to the roots of memory and language. But one of the more telling reasons may be formed, I think, by a projected future image: yourself on your back, perhaps blind, unable to move, with nothing whatsoever to fall back on but what you've assimilated in a lifetime. How nice -- or, at any rate, how reassuring -- to be able to whisper, with Emily Dickinson, "Superiority to Fate / Is difficult to gain / 'Tis not conferred of Any / But possible to earn / A pittance at a time / Until to Her surprise / The Soul with strict economy / Subsist till Paradise."
 
JOHN MELLA
Wilmette, Ill.

HEADLINE: The Stultification of Washington

BYLINE: By Adam Clymer; Adam Clymer, the chief Congressional correspondent for The New York Times, is writing a political biography of Edward M. Kennedy.

 BODY:

ARROGANT CAPITAL
Washington, Wall Street, and the Frustration
of American Politics.
By Kevin Phillips.
231 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $22.95. 
 AMERICANS believe special interests run Washington. Many think that even members of Congress whose work they approve of should not be re-elected, but somehow they get re-elected anyway. The parties work best together when they are doing something for themselves like voting their own pay raise or when carrying forward programs validated by experts that ordinary citizens dislike, like a tax increase or a free trade agreement that might cost American jobs.
Kevin Phillips, a thoughtfully prescient student of election trends since "The Emerging Republican Majority" was published in 1969, argues that the problem with Washington is that elections don't change things the way they used to, when an election like the one in 1828 that put Andrew Jackson in the White House, or the one in 1932 that gave Franklin Roosevelt his first term, changed Congress and especially the executive branch down to their roots.
"Since the 1960's," Mr. Phillips writes, "revolutionary elections have been stymied by the interlock between interest-group power and the political system. Presidents can only govern by accepting, placating and bargaining with the interest-group structure."
With a comparable disdain for the markets and financial institutions generally, which he argues produce little except "derivative instruments able to speculate on everything short of war with Mars," Mr. Phillips's briskly written manifesto sees two major economic consequences tied in with the stultification of Washington. One is that the effective interest groups protect stockholders, not workers, and that speculative finance is the most favored economic enterprise of all -- because of the way the financial sector can steer campaign contributions to needy politicians.
The second and more lasting problem is that just as electoral revolutions have been extinguished, so have the cycles of "self-correcting capitalism." Instead of bankruptcy and tough regulation following the collapse of speculative bubbles, the interests that run Washington now provide cushioned bailouts.
But this sort of argument goes down uneasily. One is left discomforted, concerned that the consequences -- here the blow to the economy of huge financial bankruptcies -- have not been thoughtfully considered and found to be overstated, or worth the risk, but have merely been brushed off. Similarly, it's one thing to say the parties are both out of touch but quite another to say partisanship is muted. What about health care?
Yet Mr. Phillips's occasional rhetorical overkill is not a major weakness, though it may be put to ill use in one cause of Washington's failure that he overlooks, the mindless cheapening of public debate.
That omission creates an important gap. The ineffectiveness of Washington is not entirely its own doing. The American people, not exactly the politically involved outraged yeoman farmers of the Jackson era, demand the political free lunch, the promise that the Government can do more for them without raising taxes or that military muscle can be flexed without risk of a soldier being shot. Special interests "like giant mushrooms in a tropical rain forest" are a menace, but are they really a worse menace than the 30-second spot that helps imprint political simple-mindedness? Mr. Phillips will doubtless be quoted approvingly by Rush Limbaugh and the lesser yammerers of the radio right, but no one is seriously proposing term limits for those poisoners of political discourse.
The blind spot shows when another polluter of the public dialogue, Newt Gingrich, comes in for an approving mention in this book. The member of the Republican leadership from Georgia hardly contributes to thoughtful debate when he asserts, as he did on the ABC news program "This Week," that a "police state" is the only way to assure universal health insurance.
Mr. Phillips's solutions to what ails the system are an eclectic and interesting collection designed to stir the Washington pot. They range from Congressional term limits to moving Congress out of Washington for a couple of months each year and exiling some departments like Interior to distant cities.
His weapons against what he calls the financialization of the economy are "a Federal tax on financial transactions that would simultaneously reduce the profitability and volume of speculative trading," and a taxing device to make "individual and corporate investments overseas less rewarding than domestic ones."
Some of these proposals seem more provocative than carefully weighed. Term limits are highly popular, but Mr. Phillips hardly considers whether shuffling lawmakers while leaving the bureaucracies of Congress and the executive branch in place would give the people more of a voice.
For every old hack committee chairman like a Charlie Rose (who runs the House Administration Committee, puts North Carolina wine on the restaurant menu and complains when leaders ask for tough votes) there is an old battler like a David Obey (chairman of the Appropriations Committee, liberal and a curmudgeonly reformer). There is little in the vast but generally petty freshman class elected to the House in 1992 that suggests that turnover for its own sake makes the Congress better.
But the last thing to do is kiss off this book the way House Speaker Tom Foley kisses off criticism of Congress as just an American tradition. As Mr. Phillips argues, the old criticism was often stimulated by the interests that were controlling the Government at the time when Washington was "little more than a parade ground for power rooted elsewhere."
Now Washington is the enemy itself, and "Arrogant Capital" makes a convincing and connected case for why the issue is more than gridlock, or more than political action committees or any one element of what has become "an interest-group fortress, essentially unconquered by the public since the walls and turrets began rising after World War II."

HEADLINE: Whither the Universe? Sideways!

BYLINE: By Dennis Overbye; Dennis Overbye, the author of "Lonely Hearts of the Cosmos," is working on a book about Albert Einstein.

 BODY:

VOYAGE TO THE GREAT ATTRACTOR
Exploring Intergalactic Space.
By Alan Dressler.
Illustrated. 355 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $25. 
IN 1980 seven astronomers -- Sandy, Alan, Dave, Roger, Roberto, Donald and Gary -- set out like characters in some cosmic road movie on an expedition through the universe. Armed with giant telescopes, computers and a list of 500 galaxies, they hoped to gain an important insight about the origin and evolution of those starry conglomerations -- the galaxies of the expanding universe. What they found after six years of hard work was more dramatic, even ominous.
At a small meeting of cosmological experts on the Kona coast on the island of Hawaii in January 1986, they announced, in contradiction of the most fashionable and carefully nurtured cosmological theories of the time, that the universe was expanding lopsidedly. They reported that a vast region of space 500 million light-years in diameter, containing hundreds of thousands of galaxies, was being drawn sideways, as it were, through expanding space, like a raft being pulled downstream at two million miles per hour toward some cosmic Niagara, a putative colossal concentration of mass later dubbed the Great Attractor. In 20 years of science reporting I have never seen such pandemonium at a scientific meeting. "What are we to do," one exasperated theorist was later to declaim, only half jokingly, "with these seven, these, these . . . these seven samurai?"
Alan Dressler has now written an insider's account of the events that led up to this discovery and its subsequent impact on the science and lives of those so-called samurai (the name stuck). His book, "Voyage to the Great Attractor," is a small classic. Writing with spare eloquence and rare candor about himself, his colleagues and the frontiers of a complicated science, Mr. Dressler has managed to produce a book that reads like a novel, with strong characters, conflict and suspense, as well as the inevitable deep thoughts.
Deftly cutting from scenes of a long night at the telescope to a leisurely history of cosmology to the story of the Great Attractor itself, Mr. Dressler introduces his colleagues one by one as they are recruited into the project. They are a casting director's dream roster. The leader of the group is a woman, Sandy Faber, who channeled the resentment she felt at not being able to play Little League baseball into becoming one of the outstanding scientists of her generation. Roberto Terlevich is a self-imposed political exile from Argentina. Donald Lynden-Bell, the group's lone theorist, is a prudish Anglican; Roger Davies is a steelworker's son from the industrial north of England, and Gary Wegner, the last to join the team, is a quiet but opinionated family man from the Northwest.
Mr. Dressler, a former student of Ms. Faber's at the University of California, Santa Cruz, a self-described loner who seems to have almost glided to a position of prominence as a young astronomer, is reluctantly dragooned into the collaboration by Dave Burstein, a fellow student of Ms. Faber's, with whom he has a long history of personality clashes. Mr. Burstein, overcompensating for a disastrous incident during graduate school that set back and nearly derailed his career (his mind was affected by the high doses of Valium prescribed for a back injury), strikes Mr. Dressler as pushy and presumptuous. In turn, Mr. Burstein finds Mr. Dressler smug and overrated.
Nature, of course, in the form of those majestic galaxies, is the main character in this narrative, and it throws this unwieldy team of scientists one curveball after another. At their first meeting to discuss their results, in Cambridge, England, they discover, among a slew of other problems, that a large chunk of data hasn't even been analyzed. Donald is furious; Sandy, suffering excruciating back pain, is confined to a cot, and the author finds the food and other amenities wanting. Forced into the role of workhorse, the overburdened and underappreciated Dave finally explodes. Not until many such stressful meetings have passed do the astronomers slowly and reluctantly realize that their data are hopelessly tangled because they have misjudged the motions of the galaxies. In addition to being carried outward by the general expansion of space, the entire sky they have measured is adrift, in the gravitational grip of the Great Attractor.
Fittingly, it is the beleaguered Mr. Burstein who gets to report the news of the Great Attractor to the cosmologists in Hawaii, and they know immediately what it portends. It means they don't know what the universe is made of. The possibility that whole galaxies are being pulled toward a colossal mass would imply that the universe is far lumpier than would be permitted by the reigning theory based on something known, for technical reasons I won't explain here, as cold dark matter. The presence of the Great Attractor was about as welcome to this community of cosmologists as a wrecking ball. The samurai have since broken up, but the confusion they wrought continues to this day.
THROUGHOUT this tale of snarled data and snarling astronomers, Mr. Dressler manages to keep us involved even when the technical details threaten to go over our heads; he explains the science with the same restrained polish that probably drove Mr. Burstein crazy. Too much of this can sound glib, but the author has a soothing knack for mixing in the personal when you least expect it. His explication of the mysteries of the inflationary theory of the universe, introduced by an anecdote about his uncle, is as clean and unhyperbolic as any I have read.
With characteristic boldness Mr. Dressler has added a thoughtful concluding essay that is alone worth the price of the book. In it he argues that within a few hundred years science is likely to reach its limits as far as fundamental laws are concerned, that some questions, such as what happened "before" the big bang, will be left forever beyond the pale, and that we will, nonetheless, have acquired enough knowledge to engage in the kind of genetic and biomechanical tinkering that will splinter the human species forever. "It is my conclusion, therefore," Mr. Dressler writes grimly, "that we are most likely near the end of what we have known as humanity. Nature's gifts to us have led to the secret keys of evolution, and we are not likely, I think, to long refrain from unlocking this box of treasures and troubles."
Whether the Great Attractor winds up as a cosmological landmark or a footnote, whether science reaches some ultimate limit or not, "Voyage to the Great Attractor" will remain as a valuable account of how astronomy and cosmology were really done in the late 20th century.
 
 
 
HE CALLED IT THE GREAT ATTRACTOR
 "People feel a sort of familiarity with the sky and astronomy," says Alan Dressler, the author of "Voyage to the Great Attractor," an account of a pathbreaking study he undertook with six colleagues to explore the spread of galaxies through the universe. "Usually you get a very positive response when you tell people you're an astronomer. They say 'That's neat. I was interested when I was a kid.' "
Mr. Dressler, who is 46, single and a first-time author, said in a telephone interview that he was determined to write "without pulling any punches." "I wanted to break this idea that science isn't a human thing, that it's somehow infallible or unemotional," he said.
So he concentrated on the daily routines of the scientists with whom he worked, revealing, for instance, how they spend only "a few dozen nights a year" observing the stars. Mr. Dressler, who lives in Altadena, Calif., where he is an astronomer at the observatories of the Carnegie Institution, said people think astronomers spend their time "peering night after night into a telescope."
"When we teach science we rarely teach how it's done," he said. "People have this idea of white lab coats and test tubes."
The culmination of his group's work was the detection of an enormous unseen mass, which he called the Great Attractor, exerting a gravitational pull on the Milky Way and its neighboring galaxies. That finding shook traditional cosmology to its core. "I didn't know whether this result was going to endure," he said. "There was no question, though, that it changed people's thinking. That is far more important to me. That's the most you can really hope for in science." SCOTT VEALE

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 23, 1994

SECTION: Section 6; Page 38; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3108 words

HEADLINE: CREATOR OF A PARADISE LOST;
Eduardo Machado

BYLINE: By Ben Brantley; Ben Brantley is a theater critic for The New York Times.

 BODY:
IT WAS 9:30 A.M. ON AN AMTRAK TRAIN BOUND from New York City to Providence, and the playwright Eduardo Machado, who had gone to bed only three hours earlier, was a very pale shade of green. He had a lot to worry about: he had abruptly left his apartment of five years and moved to a provisional sublet on the Lower East Side; a whopping back-taxes payment had wiped out all his savings, and the evening before, his first "endless night" in over a year, had concluded in a rancorous, Champagne-fueled argument with a friend in a Hell's Kitchen transvestite bar.
Dwarfing all of these concerns was that in four days he would be leaving for Los Angeles, for rehearsals of "Floating Islands," a series of plays Machado has been writing over the past 14 years. It was looking as if the two-part, six-hour production, which opens today, would be the most expensive ever mounted at the Mark Taper Forum, the cradle of such comparably scaled projects as "The Kentucky Cycle" and "Angels in America." And it would be sure to guarantee the kind of mainstream theatrical recognition, and scrutiny, that has thus far eluded the 41-year-old playwright. 
 Yet as the train made its lurching, hangover-stirring way northward, only one thing seemed to truly concern Machado. It wasn't that he had only half the rewrites requested by his director, Oskar Eustis, whom he would be meeting in Providence. It was getting on the plane to Los Angeles on Saturday; it seemed ominous that he couldn't find his ticket.
"I'm a person who can get anxious crossing the street," he said. "Once I get to a place, I'm fine. But that moment of leaving is very hard for me. It always has been."
Leaving, in its most dramatic sense, is something Eduardo Machado knows intimately. It is also what "Floating Islands" is all about. The four-play cycle, which was published in an early version by the Theater Communications Group in 1991, follows four generations of a Cuban family, from the days of Gerardo Machado y Morales (no relation), the "butcher dictator," in the late 1920's, to the era of Fidel Castro; from insular affluence in a suburb of Havana to vulnerable exile in California.
Drawn directly from the family history of the playwright, who came to America from Cuba as a child in 1961, the plays are steeped in both sober economic and political detail and shadowy mysticism, in expansive comedy and unabashed melodrama. On one level, with their portrayal of domestic power struggles as a mirror for a society in flux, they suggest a Hispanic version of Lillian Hellman's "Little Foxes." But earlier productions have also evoked comparisons to such disparate precedents as Garcia Lorca, Chekhov and "I Love Lucy."
The recent exodus of thousands of Cuban refugees has brought an inescapable topicality to "Floating Islands" that Taper executives are well aware of. Moreover, the plays are the first of their scale and visibility to address the experience of the Hispanic immigrant, which, unlike the experiences of the Eastern European Jew and the Asian, has been scantly represented in American drama.
Eustis, who directed "Angels in America" at the Taper and was recently named artistic director of the Trinity Repertory Company in Providence, acknowledged the importance of stressing the epic qualities of the work.
"The task of this thing," Eustis said, "has been to draw out the big themes enough so that people will know why they're watching six hours of it."
Certainly, big themes now swarm through "Floating Islands," from the corruption that came with the rise of capitalism in Cuba to the role of women and homosexuals in a classically macho society. But there is another story connected with "Floating Islands" as multilayered as the plays themselves. It's about the relationship between art and memory, the complicated reshaping of real lives into literature, the sexual and ethnic stereotypes faced by a gay Cuban-American in theater and what it takes, both economically and psychologically, to survive as a playwright today. Indeed, in many ways, Eduardo Machado is a rich study in at least two of the traits James Joyce identified as essential to an artist's identity: exile and cunning. Silence is another matter.
MACHADO IS A PLUMP MAN with dark, glittering eyes, an unlikely cross between Peter Lorre and a silent-movie Latin lover. He has a slow, rolling gait and a brisk, unswervingly assured manner of speech. He thrives on drama, he says, both on stage and off, yet he describes deeply emotional events with a bemused, singsong lilt that suggests a hard-won sense of distance.
"Eduardo is very cynical and very sentimental," says his friend John Finch, an actor. "I also have to say that there are many, many things that have happened to Eduardo personally that I would not have believed unless I had known for sure that they happened."
One humid afternoon last summer, Machado talked about his family in the comfortable but sparsely furnished sublet he had recently moved to. The only possessions he had brought with him were his clothes, his word processor and his photographs, mostly of his family in Cuba.
The pictures evoke a Proustian sense of vanished luxury and formality: there are men in white linen suits, women with gloves and parasols and children in creaseless sailor outfits. One photograph shows Machado's mother, at 17, on her wedding day. She's seated before a curved, glass-topped vanity table in an elaborate bridal dress with a skirt that seems to go on forever. Her expression before the mirror -- her gaze suspiciously to one side, her lips tensed questioningly -- is not that of a happy bride. "That's where the plays come from, this picture," said Machado. "I always write with it around."
Machado's parents, Hilda and Othon, were 19 and 20 when Eduardo, the first of their five children, was born. His father was studying accounting, and Eduardo spent his first eight years in his paternal grandparents' mansion near Havana, in which several aunts and uncles also lived with their families. His mother's parents lived across the street.
"My father's mother and father didn't have a happy marriage at all," he said. "My grandfather was a very flamboyant man, who caused a lot of people a lot of pain. I think a lot of them drank a lot. So it was a very dramatic life. And there was a revolution going on."
He was particularly close to his maternal grandfather, Oscar Hernandez, the basis for the character in "Floating Islands" named, with singular directness, Oscar Hernandez. Hernandez was an orphan who rose to affluence through a bus company he started with capital invested by his wife's father, a butcher. Hernandez's story is closely paralleled in "The Modern Ladies of Guanabacoa," the first play of the tetralogy, which also draws upon the unsolved murder of Hernandez's father-in-law. And the climactic scene in "In the Eye of the Hurricane," comes from Machado's own memory of Hernandez's buses being driven away by milicianos working for Castro.
Allegiances shifted in Machado's family from support of the strongman Fulgencio Batista, to Castro and back again. Revolution and counterrevolution became the stuff of domestic life, and Machado remembers finding machine guns that his grandfather had stowed in his toy closet, and helping family members bury money.
"I started having these hallucinations," he said, "where vampires and men with canes were coming to get me, and then I would pass out." At 5, he went to his first psychiatrist.
In 1961, on the day before Halloween, Hilda and Othon, taking advantage of a permissive emigration law, put the 8-year-old Eduardo and his younger brother, Jesus, on a plane to Florida. The boys were kept in detention for 12 hours in Havana. In Miami, "they sat us in a little room to make sure we weren't Communists, and gave us shots. I was so terrified, I was numb. I think I remember everything so clearly because I was outside of it all."
The boys lived in Hialeah, Fla., for six months with an aunt and uncle before their parents joined them. Shortly after, the family moved to Canoga Park, Calif. Othon entered an accounting firm, where he rose quickly, and the family moved to a succession of increasingly affluent neighborhoods in the San Fernando Valley. "My father has an obsession with new houses," said Machado. "They get newer and newer, and they seem more and more unreal."
Throughout his childhood, his family kept before him the vision of Cuba as a lost Eden. "If you were, say, having a steak, somebody would eventually say, 'It doesn't taste as good.' Or if you were at the beach at Malibu, my dad would say, 'How can we get into the water when it's so cold?' In Miami, the water was too hot. If you were doing well, and you bought a six-bedroom house, it wasn't as good as the mansion.
"And so you grew up thinking that you weren't really living in the place that you were living in. To this day, it's one of my problems, that I always think I'm not living anywhere."
His only real home is the theater, he said, and he identified his attraction to it early on. By 17, he had become a professional actor and also, with considerable ambivalence, a professional Latino. "When I was growing up, I just always thought we were strange," said Machado, who began attending California public schools before he was fluent in English. "Because my parents were so volatile, I felt I couldn't bring anybody home. But I didn't think I was a minority. I thought we were in exile, which is different.
"When I got an agent, I was shocked. I was told to get a mustache and a tan and call myself Ed Machado." He appeared in many small parts in sitcoms, usually as a waiter with a thick accent.
At home, Machado fought often and bitterly with his father (mostly about "show business and homosexuality," he said). At 18, he left his parent's house to marry Harriett Bradlin, whom he had met in Reichean therapy.
In some ways, his wife's background paralleled his own. She was the child of a Russian Jewish immigrant who had started a lucrative chain of clothing stores. She was also a Marxist, more than 20 years Machado's senior and the mother of eight daughters.
"She was a wild, very attractive woman," said Machado, who today is openly gay. "I think everybody in L.A. thought of themselves as bisexual then, so that's how I thought of myself." The marriage lasted more than a decade, and the couple still keep in touch.
In the late 1970's, Machado began acting in the summer playwrights' festival in Padua Hills, near Los Angeles, where the teachers included Sam Shepard. "The whole experience made me realize it was O.K. to want art," he said. He was also deeply impressed at that time by "the luridness" of the films of the German director Rainer Fassbinder, and he began attending writing workshops conducted by Maria Irene Fornes, the experimental Cuban-American dramatist.
Fornes remembers seeing an early draft of Machado's first play, a one-act about a wealthy Cuban family in the early days of Castro. Permeated with a Gothic sense of the supernatural and built around an incestuous relationship between two brothers, the play's Cuba bore little resemblance to the Cuba she had known. But she was struck, she said, by the work's "boldness and mystery. The characters were not classical types; they were specifically human, complex and interesting."
The title of the play was "Fabiola," which was also the name of one of Machado's aunts, who had died in childbirth a month before he was born and whose possessions remained in the house. When her body was exhumed for reburial, in accordance with Cuban custom, two years after her death, it hadn't decomposed, and Machado said the family believed they saw her ghost in the house. "It haunted me for the longest time," he said. "I still find it a very emotionally packed play to work on." It is now, in an almost completely rewritten version, the third play in the "Floating Islands" cycle.
By the early 1980's, Machado had moved to New York and become a full-time playwright. He hasn't stopped writing plays since, nor lobbying for means of getting them produced. His works -- whose subjects range from a Latin American political prisoner (played by Machado, in the nude) to the crossed-dressed jazz trumpeter Billy Tipton -- have been presented at the Ensemble Studio Theater in New York, the Los Angeles Theater Center and the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. The reviews have been, in fairly equal parts, encouraging and devastating.
"Some things that were said about him as a writer would take other people years to recover from," said John Finch. "But it was like he had one bad afternoon and moved on."
He was also extremely adept at convincing people to finance his work. "He knows how things work," said Morgan Jenness, director of play development for the New York Shakespeare Festival, which recently commissioned Machado to write a play about the Cuban embargo. Indeed. He has received numerous foundation and government grants (the Pew Charitable Trusts is underwriting $100,000 of this production of "Floating Islands"), has done uncredited rewrites on movie scripts and has taught classes in playwrighting. He has also had patrons, including James Hammerstein, who directed the first production of "Modern Ladies" in 1983 and subsidized Machado for a year's work on the cycle.
"I think what Eduardo did nat urally was write plays with a lot of characters," said Hammerstein, "which is something we allow Chekhov, but almost no one else, to do. He didn't have that hero/antihero thing we're so acquainted with. I had no desire to teach him differently."
By 1991, all of the plays that would become "Floating Islands" had been produced in some form or another. Machado and Eustis wouldn't come upon the idea of doing them as a tetralogy until a year later. The pair had met in 1990 on a theater panel for the National Endowment for the Arts, shortly after the public uproar over the revocation of grants to four performance artists whose material was perceived as obscene.
When John E. Frohnmayer, then the N.E.A. chairman, asked the panel members to introduce themselves and say where they were from, Machado began by announcing, "My name is Eduardo Machado, and I write homoerotic plays."
"But where are you from?" asked Frohnmayer.
"That's where I'm from," answered Machado. After that, all of the panel members identified themselves as producers, directors or writers of "homoerotic plays," whether they were or not.
"That absolutely blew my mind," said Eustis, who in 1991 was asked to oversee a reading at the Taper of "In the Eye of the Hurricane." Eustis, who already knew the play, noticed that it took on a startling psychological intricacy when it was read aloud. The problem was convincing Gordon Davidson, the Taper's artistic director, to do it. "The Taper doesn't do plays," said Eustis. "The Taper does events."
It was Machado who suggested trying a reading of all four plays, which was done at the Taper in April 1992. "By the end, simultaneously, everybody said we should do it," said Eustis. "We knew, of course, there would have to be a ton of rewriting."
And so there has been. One day in Providence in mid-August, the director still seemed to feel the plays needed further condensation and clarification. Part of a discussion of the ending of "Hurricane" went something like this:
Machado: "I see. I have to totally destroy Oscar. I have to destroy him and Manuela and leave them both destroyed and then destroy Mario."
Eustis: "It needs personal consequences."
Machado: "You mean I have to be depressed so I can write it? Thanks. . . . It isn't anything I've ever written. [pause] Okay, I'll do it tomorrow."
Eustis: [pressing Machado's right toe reassuringly] "If you really do finish that relationship, it'll be the first time I feel we're not missing a chapter."
The actual production of the plays has brought its own host of problems. There have been lengthy debates over how many real buses can be on stage, as well as over the inclusion of a simulated rainfall and, for "Fabiola," a supernatural fire. "The rain is in; the fire is out," Gordon Davidson said, although Machado swore, "There's no way there's not going to be flames coming out of a piano."
The debate over whether or not to have an all-Latino cast was more violent, and familiar. Machado and Eustis said the roles should go to those who were best in them, and Machado was accused by "a white person at the Taper in a very high-powered job" of being "ashamed of being Latino." The play now has an all-Latino cast. The actors are, said Eustis, the best who auditioned.
No one is predicting how the Latino audience in Los Angeles will react to "Floating Islands." There is also, of course, a much smaller segment of the audience to consider: Machado's family. His father, the inspiration for the morally adaptable Oswaldo in two of the plays, still hasn't seen or read any of them. ("We don't speak," said Machado.) Hilda Machado, however, knows all of them.
Divorced from Othon for more than 20 years, she still speaks little English. In a phone conversation translated by her daughter Michelle, she admitted she had little difficulty identifying the models for the play's characters, including herself. "I'm a little nervous," she said, of the Taper production. "But it's a play. It may be based on certain things, but part of it is made up. If people think everything's exactly like us, then they don't know us very well."
Machado has been known to leave rehearsals of "Floating Islands" muttering, "I can't spend any more time with my family." But he also feels there's a new distance between the characters and their prototypes.
His feelings about Cuba have changed, too. For years, he said, "I saw it as something that had made me neurotic, that had cheated me out of my life. When I was growing up, at first I blamed Fidel; then, when I was 19 or 20, I blamed my parents for being right-wing bourgeois pigs. Then you reach a point where you say, 'This is not simple; it's this very complicated mess.' "
In early August, before the recent exodus put a new strain on Cuban-American relations, Machado considered returning to his homeland for the first time to do research for the plays. "I'm supposed to go back this weekend, and I'm not going to do it," he said, and, for once, his voice sounded weary. "I couldn't go now. It's just one thing too many."
Anyway, he says, "I think, except for the plays, I've forgotten Cuba. I think I'm so American now. But then I can always go back to 'Floating Islands' and be Cuban for a couple of hours."

PUB-DATE: October 23, 1994

SECTION: Section 2; Page 5; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1947 words

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
A Good, Sharp 'Paddywack'

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby 

 BODY:
DANIEL MAGEE'S "PADDYWACK," WHICH is opening the new season at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, is an angry play, and so entertaining that not until the final scene do you get the full measure of the intensity of the playwright's feelings. Though set in London and free of poeticizing, "Paddywack" is as Irish as anything by Brian Friel. The scale of the play is small, but it's also as politically committed as Sean O'Casey's early work. By saying that, I don't mean to place Mr. Magee, who comes from the Roman Catholic working class in Belfast, in a league with either Mr. Friel or O'Casey. It's only to emphasize that on the basis of this one play, he seems to be a refreshingly aggressive new Irish voice. No sad songs for him. He speaks tough, efficient prose.
"Paddywack" is initially about bigotry, but it's also about politics. At the play's center is Damien, a young Belfast construction worker who says he has come to London looking for work. He's polite and wellspoken, but he's also terribly sure of himself. For a member of the working class, he has a surprisingly large vocabulary, as well as the kind of ferocious wit that withers the opposition in any argument. 
 It's no wonder that he's a figure of some mystery and then of suspicion in the seedy digs he shares with three other men: Brian, a Cockney who blames the Irish (Paddys), black and Pakistani immigrants for all of England's (and his) problems; Michael, an older Irishman who, to survive as a laborer in London, has become almost as bigoted and right wing as Brian, and Colin, a piously left-wing, upper-middle-class fellow, a product of the London School of Economics, who is living in digs as part of his field study of the underclass.
Brian's suggestion that Damien may be an active member of the Irish Republican Army isn't at first taken seriously by their other two mates. Little by little, though, Damien appears to incriminate himself. He stays apart from the others, coming and going at all hours. There is a kind of righteousness about him that antagonizes both Brian and Michael. The possibility of I.R.A. connections dazzles the impressionable Colin and, more importantly, Colin's upper-class friend, Annette, whose political activism is limited to marches and bicycle rides on behalf of good causes.
Damien plays it cool, denying nothing and refusing to condemn the I.R.A., which is what a serious terrorist might be expected to do. Is Damien or isn't he? He doesn't help himself by suggesting that Brian, and all of the other Brians in England, might more profitably question the impulse behind the I.R.A.'s terrorist activities. A play that begins as a comedy of mismatched personalities and unequal minds, condemned to share impossibly close living quarters, escalates into the primal struggle that is the play's harrowing climax.
The Long Wharf production, directed by John Tillinger, has the benefit of two excellent actors from the London cast of "Paddywack," which was staged at the Off West End Cockpit Theater last March. They are James Nesbitt (Damien), who has the implacable presence of someone who may possibly be a saint, and Michael O'Hagan, whose Michael has lost both home and backbone after 10 years in England. The American actors are equally persuasive in equally rich roles: Alessandro Nivola (Colin), Sarah Long (Annette), Patricia Kilgarriff (the landlady) and Denis O'Hare, who's wickedly funny and vicious as Brian, sharing the play's most riveting moments with Damien.
In some ways, "Paddywack" is an unfashionably well-made play, meaning that after the first scene, there is never any doubt about the points Mr. Magee wants to make, but it is so well written that those points still surprise and shock. Mr. Magee's dialogue can be both raucously funny and cruel: "I don't hate Pakis or Paddys," says Brian early on. "I just don't see the need for 'em . . . not nowadays, what with robots and the like."
For all of its craft, "Paddywack" is not slick. Within Damien there is an ambiguous heart. Though Brian is a commonplace bigot with fascist leanings, Damien flaunts his principles with an arrogance that eventually invites disaster. He's a victim, but he's also a perpetrator.
"Paddywack," a good play, will be running at the Long Wharf through next Sunday.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
'Unexpected Tenderness'
 Near the beginning of Israel Horovitz's "Unexpected Tenderness," young Roddy Stern (Jonathan Marc Sherman) says in an aside to the audience, "I know what you're thinking: a nice little ethnic comedy." The boy is right. The makings for a nice little ethnic comedy are all there on the stage at the WPA Theater. The audience is introduced to a closely knit, Jewish working-class family composed of a loving mother and father, a sensitive boy in his early teens, his slightly older sister and their ancient, exhausted paternal grandparents. "Unexpected Tenderness" first brings Neil Simon to mind. Then we seem to be in the territory explored by Herb Gardner in "Conversations With My Father," but there's a major difference.
The father in the Gardner play is a paragon of easily expressed love, compassion and understanding compared with Archie Stern (Steve Ryan). Archie adores his wife, Molly (Caitlin Clarke), to the point of obsessive jealousy. He says he's leaving for work, then stands outside and peers through the kitchen window as if expecting to catch Molly in the arms of her lover, even before the kids have left for school. It's a family joke but, as the performance proceeds, the joke grows increasingly dim until it disappears altogether. "Unexpected Tenderness" turns into a nice little ethnic drama about serious assault and battery.
It's also a difficult play to assess since the comic moments, having the elements of shtick, don't have the weight of the dramatically brutal marital confrontations. Archie is in desperate need of medical help. To enjoy this play fully, you need to be in the same state of denial that poor Molly has been in throughout her marriage.
The subsidiary material in "Unexpected Tenderness" is ethnic-funny, and sometimes ethnic-funny with a sharper than usual edge. It comes as no surprise that young Roddy learns from all of the mayhem he witnesses at home. Yet never has a play's happy ending seemed quite so bleak.
The performances, under the direction of Steve Zuckerman, are all that he and Mr. Horovitz could ask for; New York seems to have an infinite supply of good actors. The production continues at the WPA Theater through Nov. 6.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
'Killer Joe'
 "Killer Joe," now being given a physically modest but intelligent production by the 29th Street Repertory Theater and Darren Lee Cole, is a first play by Tracy Letts, and what a play it is: an often funny, heedlessly offensive comedy about greed, matricide, dope dealing and the (in this case) hopeless all-American dream of bettering oneself. Mr. Letts is a Chicago-based actor most recently in the Steppenwolf Theater's production of Steve Martin's "Picasso at the Lapin Agile." It just may be that he also knows how to write.
The setting is your basic, worn-out living-dining-kitchen area of a trailer home parked somewhere outside Dallas. Sharing this space are Chris Smith (Thomas Wehrle), whose jittery mannerisms may come from drugs or from seeing too many Emilio Estevez movies; his layabout dad, Ansel (Leo Farley); his stepmother, Sharla (Linda June Larson), who walks around wearing curlers in her hair, a T-shirt and nothing else, and his pretty, quiet sister, Dottie (Danna Lyons), who has preserved her virginity into her 20's.
The situation is this: Chris, in need of money fast, persuades the family to hire someone to murder his mother (Ansel's first wife) for her $50,000 insurance policy, of which Dottie is the beneficiary. The hit man turns out to be a moonlighting Dallas police detective named Joe (David Mogentale). When the family can't whomp up Joe's $25,000 fee, he accepts the use of the waiflike Dottie as his retainer.
"Killer Joe" is constructed of comic and sometimes terrifying reversals: Joe treats Dottie with reverence one minute and the next minute is humiliating Sharla, forcing her to simulate fellatio with him in front of the family. Before he has finished with the Smith family, everyone except Dottie has double-crossed someone else. Joe is an avenging angel.
As played by Mr. Mogentale, Joe has the presence of Gary Sinise in Sam Shepard's "True West." For all his nice manners and genteel vocabulary (he compliments Dottie for fixing "a lovely dinner"), Joe is a steely and ruthless character, the only fixed point in a chaotic universe. Mr. Mogentale is very good, as are all the members of the cast. Wilson Milam, who has worked as an assistant director at Steppenwolf, has directed "Killer Joe" with authority and invention. He possesses an unusual ability: he goes too far without actually going over the top. "Killer Joe" isn't camp. Though it's not always easy to watch, it's shock theater of consistent style. It runs through Nov. 30.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
'Blaming Mom'
 David Edelstein is a former colleague who was the film critic for The New York Post and, before that, a critic for The Village Voice. Now he's on his way to becoming a playwright. He's the author of "Blaming Mom," a longish one-act comedy about urban relationships, and a curtain-raiser, "Soupy and Adena," playing at the Ohio Theater on Wooster Street through next Sunday. Mr. Edelstein writes funny lines, which are about evenly distributed between the two pieces presented by the Watermark Theater. Since "Blaming Mom" is so much longer than the curtain-raiser, "Soupy" inevitably seems the more successful.
It's a breezy, live-action cartoon about the problems of Superguy (Jordan Lage), called Soupy, when he saves a pretty, cigarette-smoking young woman, Adena (Kristen Lee Kelly), from the inferno caused by a live butt tossed into a wastebasket. Adena may be in the air, but she's not yet swept off her feet. Soupy is not the fastest mind in the sky. "Would you like me if I couldn't fly?" he asks with jocklike confidence, jumping light-years ahead of Adena, who hasn't yet expressed any preference at all.
Adena is a hard-sell. Unlike Lois Lane, she's not impressed by flying over Manhattan in the middle of the night, especially in the arms of a guy who doesn't always look where he's swooping. The piece is cleverly staged by Nela Wagman, the director of the double bill, and played with delight by the two-member cast.
"Blaming Mom" is about Willie (Sean Runnette) and his unhappy relations with women, all of which can be traced back to his terrible Jewish mother. She insisted that he get a hair transplant in his teens because she was too young to have a bald son. Now in the full flower of his yuppiedom, Willie believes that a person needs a mom to define himself against.
This is not material of the first freshness, but in Lucy, one of Willie's girlfriends, Mr. Edelstein has written a marvelously vivid character. A woman who treats her lovers as if they were puppies in need of obedience training, she's played with priceless lack of tact by Patricia Scanlon. The rest of the piece is both shapeless and very familiar.
Onward.
 
PADDYWACK Daniel Magee's play is small in scale and big in political commitment.

KILLER JOE A comedy about matricide goes too far without going over the top.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
What It Costs To Phone Home

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
A TRACTOR-TRAILER driver outside a diner in upstate New York was observed by Martin R. Schemer of New York shouting into a pay phone that if the operator did not connect him to his regular long-distance company, a repair crew would have to be sent out. Clearly rebuffed, he backed over the booth, crushing it.
Few phone-users are equipped to do this, but many wish they could. The angriest are people who cannot get through to their long-distance company, and end up being billed by a company they do not know at rates they consider outlandish. 
 A friend called New York from the Cape Cod National Seashore in August, charging the call to a credit card, and was billed $8.48 for two daytime minutes; a relative called Massachusetts from rural Maine, also on a credit card, and paid $13.74 for an evening call of six minutes. As it happens, both were served by a company called Oncor Communications, an "alternate operator service." The per-minute cost of the two calls averaged $2.77. This is pretty steep; for comparison, the same credit-card calls placed through the A.T.&T. system would have cost $1.36 and $1.76 in all.
Trying to call home, or anyplace, continues to be one of the difficult aspects of travel, and complaints to this department as well as the Federal Communications Commission demonstrate that price is the top source of distress.
Gordon C. Kimble, a spokesman for Oncor, based in Bethesda, Md., said that the cost of calls was affected by the higher commissions his company paid to the owners of the phones. "We go to many rural areas and urban centers where our competitors don't because of the low rate of return," he said. The company now provides service from 150,000 pay phones and 600,000 hotel rooms nationally, mostly hotels with fewer than 100 rooms, he said.
As to how Oncor got to be the provider at Nauset Light Beach, Andy Ringgold, the site manager, is baffled. He said the National Seashore signed a new contract last January for local service to be provided by Nynex for five years, with A.T.&T. specified as the long-distance carrier. He said his contact at the local phone company had not called back to explain.
In contrast, in the Rocky Mountain region of the National Park Service, according to Jeff Craig, in the concessions department in Denver, supervisors were advised not to allow "alternate operator services" to hold long-distance contracts. There is no systemwide policy in the Park Service, said James A. Owen, also in the concessions division.
 
Requiring an Alternative
 In March 1993, an important rule under the Federal Telephone Operator Services Act came into force. This required hotels to fix room phones so that guests could dial the long-distance service they wanted; after the breakup of A.T.&T., electronic blocks often forced guests to use the service the hotel chose. The only exemption left, according to Kurt Schroeder of the F.C.C., applies to hotel phones where removing the blockage would cost $15 or more. These must be adapted by 1997.
However, the major long-distance operators say customers are still complaining that they are blocked from using a five-digit access code known as 10-XXX to get to their service. In response, Sprint, A.T.&T. and M.C.I. emphasize the 800-number access. (These numbers are given in the adjoining box.) It is a pain in the neck: Customers must dial 11 digits for access, 11 digits for the number they are calling and 14 digits for the credit-card number.
I have met pay phones that block these calls, too, going dead after 800 is dialed. This is against the law and should be reported to the state utilities commission on an in-state call and to the F.C.C. otherwise. The Enforcement Division of the Common Carrier Bureau, F.C.C., is at 2025 M Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20554. Complaints should be in writing.
Hotels do not usually block 800 numbers, although they may surcharge these calls. They are permitted to add a surcharge for reaching a long-distance company, if it is equal for all companies. And they're allowed to add a surcharge for other 800-number calls (they must provide cards specifying surcharges).
 
What the Hotels Charge
 The trend is away from surcharges. Marc Pujalet, Westin's senior vice president for marketing, said that phone charges ranked No. 1 in surveys of guest complaints. Other chains gave similar reports. Westin hotels charge 50 cents to $1 for access to long-distance companies and nothing for calls to 800 numbers. Mr. Pujalet said Westin was doing research to find a way to lower this complaint level. One problem, he said, is that for five years or so individual hotels have been making a profit from phone service.
Here are policies of other hotel chains on surcharges to reach long-distance services; these data do not cover calls charged to the room.
Over the summer, Marriott hotels changed its policy, eliminating a 75-cent charge for reaching a long-distance company. So far, 170 of the company's 202 domestic hotels have made this change, according to Gordon D. Lambourne, a spokesman.
The motels in the Hospitality Franchise Systems, Days Inn, Howard Johnson, Ramada, Super 8 and Park Inns, set their own policies, according to Lisa Garb, a spokeswoman. She says the management believes few charge for access to long-distance companies.
The Choice group is "pushing" its Quality, Comfort, Clarion, Sleep, Rodeway, Econo Lodge and Friendship motels to provide free access, according to Betsy Bromberg O'Rourke, a spokeswoman. She said 85 percent of the Sleep Inns provided free access, and 50 percent of the motels in the other chains.
At Sheraton, according to Lisa Dickason, a no-charge policy is being phased in. The premium-rate Club Level eliminated the access charge in April. On Sept. 1, the 63 North American hotels owned, leased or managed by Sheraton itself eliminated the charge. On Jan. 1, all 207 franchise properties will follow. Any fee must be below $1, she said.
At the Radisson hotels, the new premium-rate Business Class rooms levy no charge. In regular rooms, the hotel is urged to make no charge but there is no top limit, said Thomas J. Polski, a spokesman. He said 50 or 75 cents was the usual charge.
At Hyatt hotels also, the premium-cost Business Plan rooms make no charge. Otherwise, the hotel may charge up to 75 cents for access to a long-distance carrier.
Hilton hotels set a policy of no surcharges for access in June 1993, and by this month, according to Kendra Walker, 154 of 240 hotels had this policy in effect.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2650 words

HEADLINE: Finding a Temporary Place to Call Home

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
IT can be a nightmare. In early summer, Dr. Arthur I. Pober, just named head of the video-game industry's ratings council, quickly had to find a temporary place to stay. The lease on his old apartment had expired and the co-op he had recently bought and was renovating was not yet fit for human habitation. So he took a room at a nearby hotel, not far from his office.
"I knew I was in trouble the moment I got in the elevator," Dr. Pober said. "The bellman looked at me and said: 'Why are you staying here? I wouldn't stay here.' " 
 His room, he said, "was like something out of 'Midnight Cowboy.' " One evening he came back to find it had been given to someone else.
"They said they thought I had checked out," he said. "I told them I hadn't and asked why, if I had left, my clothes would still be in the room?" His television had no buttons in it -- he had to put a pencil in the hole to turn the set on.
After four days, he said, he left, stayed with friends for a while and wound up "sleeping on rubble in my apartment as it was being constructed."
It doesn't have to be that way. People seeking short-term stays in Manhattan these days have more and more choices.
They may, like Dr. Pober, be having their new apartment renovated. Or they may be having their current home repaired. They may be moving to New York and looking for a permanent apartment, or be here for a few months on business, or for medical treatment.
But whatever the reason, there are an increasing number of options for people seeking temporary quarters. Two top-of-the-line residence hotels have opened recently, catering largely to a deep-pocketed corporate trade. Middle-level residential hotels have studios that start at $3,200 a month. Short-term leases can be had in condominiums and town houses. Special arrangements can be negotiated at regular hotels. And at least one new building, the Mondrian on East 54th Street, has set aside two floors for short-term residents.
There are, real-estate brokers say, two prime reasons behind the increase: The real-estate recession of the early 1990's created a need to fill suddenly empty hotel rooms and apartments, and entrepreneurs have increasingly recognized what had been a somewhat neglected niche in the marketplace.
Two luxury buildings established specifically for this market on the east side of Manhattan are the Sutton Hotel and the Bristol Plaza.
The Sutton, on East 56th Street just west of First Avenue, opened in 1992 after more than 10 years in mothballs and a $17 million, 18-month renovation to turn it into a residence hotel intended for stays of a month or more. The owner, Hongkong and Shanghai Hotels Ltd. and its hotel unit, the Peninsula Group, created in old-world style 85 studio, one- and two-bedroom apartments ranging from 400 to 1,500 square feet.
The units have full dining areas and kitchens with all utensils, refrigerators with ice makers, stoves and microwave ovens, built-in coffee makers, color cable televisions and VCR's. The hotel has a health club with a 55-foot-long lap pool. Apartments on the upper floors have terraces, balconies or solariums. And there is full maid service. The minimum stay is 30 days.
David and Rosemarie Robinson came to New York at the end of the summer with their three sons, 2 to 16 years old, because they decided they wanted the eldest, Max, to experience an American education.
They had lived mainly in London and Ireland in recent years and Max had gone to boarding schools there. (Mr. Robinson is an executive with a Los Angeles-based recording company, American Recordings, but spends much of his time traveling around Europe.) They enrolled Max in the Loyola School on the East Side, where he's a junior, and booked rooms at a hotel while they looked for an apartment. But finding an apartment for five for the next two years has proved more difficult than they thought -- "three children is quite a lot of children for Manhattan," Mrs. Robinson said -- and the hotel was just too public and impersonal for them. So they went to the Sutton. And they are happy.
"This is heaven," Mrs. Robinson said in her two-bedroom suite. "We have the privacy of home with all the comforts of a hotel, all the care of a hotel. Someone is washing your towels. We can cook meals in the kitchen so we don't have to eat out all the time. There's a washer-dryer in the health club. And the kids' room has desks so they can do their homework."
There are limits, of course; two bedrooms and three children can get a bit crowded. The youngest son sleeps on a cot in his parents' room. "I was the one who wished for him, so I get to keep him," Mrs. Robinson says with a laugh.
CLAES Y. LOVEN, the Sutton's general manager, said he encountered a fair number of out-of-towners and foreigners looking for more permanent quarters. Mr. Loven said his clientele also included diplomats coming to New York for the United Nations General Assembly sessions; Wall Street corporations -- among them Morgan Stanley, J. P. Morgan & Company and Bankers Trust -- seeking housing for trainees and out-of-town employees; people coming to town for medical treatment at nearby hospitals; residents of Sutton Place and other nearby areas who are renovating their apartments or cleaning up asbestos problems, and the spouse in a pending divorce who does not get to keep the marriage home.
Film-production companies also use the Sutton to put up cast and crew while they're in town filming on location.
The films the Sutton has been home to include "Carlito's Way," "It Could Happen to You" and "Die Hard New York."
"One reason they stay here and not at a regular hotel is that we provide complete privacy," Mr. Loven said. "This is not a place people come and sit outside waiting for a star to show up."
Like many things in Manhattan, life at the Sutton does not come cheap. Studios go for from $3,900 to $4,700 a month, one-bedrooms from $4,500 to $8,000, two-bedrooms from $7,500 to $9,500 and tower and penthouse suites from $7,500 to $12,500.
(Rates at all the hotels are subject to hotel taxes of 14 1/4 percent plus an occupancy tax of $2 a night; after 90 days of a stay, the rate drops to 10 percent plus the $2 a night, and after 180 days, there is no tax, and the previous tax payments, except for the $2 a night, are reimbursed.)
The coffee served in the lobby each morning, though, is free.
But also like many things in Manhattan, there are enough people with enough money to take advantage of what the Sutton offers. Mr. Loven said that business was good, with occupancy averaging more than 90 percent.
Business is also good at the Bristol Plaza, at 210 East 65th Street, near Third Avenue.
The Bristol opened in 1988, in tandem with a higher-rise condominium next door, and as an apartment-hotel it caters to essentially the same clientele as the Sutton, providing luxury to guests with a minimum 30-day stay.
In its 167 studio, one- and two-bedroom units, the Bristol also provides full kitchens with microwaves, refrigerators, ice-makers and coffee makers, full maid service, color cable televisions and VCR's. It also has on-premises garage and valet parking, laundry rooms on each floor and a health club with a 50-foot pool, a retractable dome roof and an open sun deck.
Rates start at $4,200 a month for a studio. One-bedrooms, with wraparound bay windows, go for up to $6,000.
Paul Beckwith, a refugee of nine years in Los Angeles, arrived at the Bristol Plaza on Sept. 1 at 2:30 in the afternoon. He had decided "after being shaken within an inch of my life" in the Los Angeles earthquake that he needed to focus more of his business time on the East Coast.
"It had been concentrated west of the Mississippi," he said.
So he bought a studio for his business on East 73d Street, then bought an apartment in the building next door and brought his computers and his personal effects east to expand his work as a publisher of information directories.
His publications include the International Star Car Directory, which provides lists of vintage automobiles, boats, trucks and planes to creators of films, advertisements and television shows who might need them. He knew that his new office and home would not be ready until Nov. 1, but he needed to begin work in the East at the end of the summer.
"I didn't want to have to live in dust," he said, so he decided to stay at the Bristol Plaza.
"When I arrived I wanted coffee, and they had coffee ready and waiting for me," Mr. Beckwith said, adding that what he appreciates most about the Bristol Plaza over a standard hotel is the personalized service and the sense of security.
"I HAVE the same maid five days a week," he said. "She knows me and knows what I like. And as far as security is concerned, this place is like Fort Knox. A regular hotel is a public building. The traffic is limited here. And the people know you. It's nice to come home after a day when things haven't worked out and have the person at the desk say, 'Mr. Beckwith, how are you?' "
There are many other alternatives to the Sutton and the Bristol. Manhattan East Suite Hotels has about 1,900 studio, one- and two-bedroom suites in its nine hotels, eight of which are on the East Side. All have fully equipped kitchens and offer full hotel services.
Brooke D. Barrett, the partner in charge of sales, said that the hotels offered daily as well as monthly rates, with about 25 to 30 percent of its business coming from stays of a month or longer.
"We get a lot of corporate business from Wall Street," Ms. Barrett said, "from training programs or from people who come here for six months to work on special projects."
The hotels include the Surrey at 76th Street and Madison Avenue, Lyden Gardens at 215 East 64th Street, the Dumont Plaza on 34th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues, and the Southgate Tower at Seventh Avenue and 31st Street.
Rates vary: A studio suite at the Southgate starts at $3,200, while one at the Surrey, with its more prestigious location, begins at $5,200. A two-bedroom suite is $6,600 and up at the Southgate, $7,500 and up at the Dumont and $9,800 and up at the Surrey.
ON the Upper West Side, one possible choice is the Olcott Hotel, at 27 West 72d Street. The Olcott, longtime home of the actor Martin Balsam and the Oscar he won for "A Thousand Clowns," and one-time residence of Tiny Tim (he of Johnny Carson fame), offers about 40 percent of its 200 rooms and suites to temporary guests. Most of them, said Lee Rosen, the general manager, stay for one to two weeks.
The Olcott has a long tradition of providing temporary homes for performers at Lincoln Center and the Metropolitan Opera, as well as those in Broadway and Off Broadway plays who are looking for a place to stay for the short or long run.
"We have performers from 'Les Miserables,' 'The Phantom of the Opera' and 'Miss Saigon,' " Mr. Rosen said, "those who are appearing in the Broadway shows as well as those who are preparing to go into the road companies."
"It's homey," Mr. Rosen said. "One of the things people find most attractive here is that the staff knows everybody. We have very little turnover. It's like a home away from home. That's what sets us apart. We get a lot of people who can afford to stay in other places but choose us because they know us."
Weekly rates, not including tax, are $500 for a studio and $680 for a one-bedroom suite; there are a few two-bedrooms for $975. Maid service is included. The suites have cable television and cooking pantries that include refrigerators, pots, pans and sinks. There are no stoves; instead there is what is essentially a two-burner hot plate.
"You can get up and make your own coffee every day," Mr. Rosen said. "And on the West Side, everybody delivers."
Battery Park City, with its proximity to Wall Street, provides several buildings that cater to the temporary crowd. Liberty View, at 99 Battery Place, has 120 units rented primarily to the corporate market. Other Battery Park City buildings offering short-term rentals include 200, 3 and 380 Rector Place.
Some companies choose to buy or rent their own apartments throughout Manhattan to put up trainees and out-of-town visitors. J. P. Morgan & Company, for instance, has taken units at Lincoln Square, the Millennium Partners high-rise on Broadway and 68th Street, to house employees participating in training programs.
And some individuals choose to find an apartment to rent for a short term. One way to do so is to consult the listings of a rental agency.
"There are a whole spectrum of what we call professional listers," said Nancy Packes, head of Feathered Nest, one of the major rental agencies. "There are individuals who own two or more properties that they lease on an interim basis, who make furnished condominiums and town houses available for short-term rental."
The problem, Ms. Packes said, is that there are only a small number available these days. "This is the tightest market I have seen in 15 years," she said. "The picture at this moment is extremely limited. I would say there are maybe 100 such apartments available in Manhattan right now."
RENTS vary, she said, but all are at a premium over unfurnished rentals of a year or more, and the shorter the term of a lease the higher the premium. A one-bedroom apartment that might go for $2,000 a month in a lease of a year or more, she said, would cost about $2,500 a month for a six-month lease and about $2,800 a month for three months.
"And in this marketplace, the commission is almost always paid by the tenant," she said.
The commission for a lease of one or two months is a half-month's rent, she said; for three to six months, it's a month's rent, and for six months to a year it's 15 percent of the total rent.
"But the bottom line is that a furnished apartment rental is invariably cheaper than even the most reasonable apartment hotel," she said. The rental, though, does not include the hotel services.
For those who do not wish either an apartment rental or an apartment hotel, another alternative is a standard hotel. Regular hotels have always had longer-term guests, but Ms. Packes said that in recent years the number of rooms set aside for such tenants had increased.
"Every major hotel has some kind of program to promote longer-term rentals, primarily to corporate tenants," she said. "The programs kicked in when occupancy went down as a result of the recession, and the hotels have cultivated them."
Some condominiums are also cultivating short-term leases. The owners of the 179-unit Mondrian, which opened last November at 250 East 54th Street, at Second Avenue, have set aside two floors with 12 furnished units specifically for leases of three months or more.
Will Zeckendorf, the rental and sales agent for the building, said that a furnished studio rented for about $2,600 a month, a one-bedroom for about $4,000 and a two-bedroom for about $6,000. The apartments, of course, come with no hotel or maid services.
"We're spending the first year figuring out whether to expand the program," Mr. Zeckendorf said. "The issue of turnover is a problem. People don't renew at these rates. We rent the apartments as quickly as we can but it takes time to turn them over and the vacancy rate goes up. With an unfurnished unit and a one- or two-year lease, there is very little down time."
A few blocks away, back at the Sutton, Mrs. Robinson hopes that, as much as she likes the Sutton, she will not have to renew. She has booked for only a month but knows she may have to stay longer.
"It depends on how difficult it is to find a place in Manhattan," she said.
And she knows that if she is still there when her youngest son turns 3, the Sutton will be in for a severe challenge.
"It will be a real test of the hotel," she said, "to see if it can survive a birthday party for 3-year-olds."
