SECTION: Section 9; Page 5; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1135 words

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Trouble On the Terrace

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS 

 BODY:
A TERRACE or a balcony in a New York City co-op provides a personal oasis in a concrete desert. But they can prove troublesome.
One problem is that owners' proprietary feelings about these treasured spaces are increasingly running afoul of co-op corporations' needs to make sure that the entire structure, of which a terrace or balcony is an integral part, remains safe and habitable. 
 This, lawyers say, is leading to a growing number of disputes as buildings get older and incidents of water leaks -- the most common problem associated with terraces and balconies -- increase.
Arguments tend to erupt about who must foot the bill -- the shareholder with the personal outdoor space or the corporation as a whole. Technically, the answer is that virtually all such areas are the responsibility of the co-op, noted Richard Siegler, a partner with Strook & Strook & Lavan, a New York law firm that handles many co-ops. But quarrels immediately arise for two reasons.
First, the co-op may insist the damage is a result of misuse by the shareholder. For example, heavy or leaking potted plants may have wrecked the underlying surface long before its time. And if the co-op is under pressure to trim costs, Mr. Siegler said, it is loath to spend thousands of dollars that might legitimately be picked up by someone else.
Second, even if the responsibility is not in dispute, the shareholder may panic at the thought of the upheaval and security risk associated with opening the doors to a repair crew. In those instances access becomes the core of the controversy.
"They resent the intrusion," said Aaron Shmulewitz, a partner with Parker Duryee Rosoff & Haft, a New York law firm with 130 co-op clients.
Terrace and balcony cases can drag on interminably because they often involveshareholders with deep pockets and the strong resolve.
It's been nearly two years, for example, since the 278-unit co-op at 200 East 27th Street began trying to gain access to a terrace belonging to Douglas Colbert, one of its shareholders, to make repairs. Although the board won an injunction permitting access in October 1993, claiming the health and safety of other residents was being adversely affected, Mr. Colbert won a stay, contending that his objections had never been brought before the judge.
"Mr. Colbert had done custom work on the terrace," explained Paul Loomie, his lawyer. "He was worried. He was not even convinced the work was necessary."
Moreover, Mr. Loomie said, his client still has claims outstanding for damages from past terrace work that the co-op refuses to acknowledge.
And so the job remains undone.
Clearly, new ways may have be found to keep both sides from continually taking expensive and time-consuming pot shots at each other.
Mr. Siegler favors rewriting the house rules associated with terraces and balconies to further minimize wear and tear and more clearly define rights and responsibilities. The rules need to be far more specific, he said, and include suggestions as well as prohibitions.
For example, a restriction against excessive weight might also include a suggestion to use railroad ties (also known as dunnage beams) to create a raised platform under planters. A platform allows drainage and avoids the possibility that roots could seep through the base undetected. It also spreads the weight more evenly. Automatic sprinkling systems need to be abolished, Mr. Siegler said, because so many have proven unreliable. And there must be requirements concerning clear drains.
"When people go away for a long period of time the leaves pile up and clog the drains," he said. This, he has found, causes a backup of water that seeps into walls. Thus, he said, shareholders should also be required to notify building staff to clear those drains whenever the owner is away.
Mr. Siegler's comprehensive four-page list of restrictions, compiled over two years, is so detailed it is almost impossible to misconstrue what is acceptable (very little, in fact). Small wonder, therefore, that so far it has been adopted by only one co-op. A half dozen more have adopted slightly less onerous rules adapted from the original.
More acceptable, however, is Mr. Siegler's companion idea of requiring anyone taking a terrace unit to acknowledge his or her awareness of the rules by signing a copy before even setting foot in the unit.
"This way," said Mr. Siegler, "they're more likely to abide by them."
Bruce A. Cholst, an associate with Rosen & Livingston, another Manhattan law firm specializing in co-ops, also believes in taking a more pre-emptive stance to keep litigation at bay. He favors regular and mandatory inspections of personal outdoor spaces to help lessen the damage that can fester undetected for years.
The right of entry, he points out, is already in the proprietary lease. Although he admits the idea won't be popular, it could become more acceptable, he maintained, once the economic benefits were more widely recognized by all.
Mr. Shmulewitz believes there are nevertheless times when compromise makes for better neighbors. Recently, for example, he handled a case involving a shareholder with a terrace at the 88-unit co-op at 225 East 73d Street. Workmen needed to get in to replace its parapet walls and tile floor. The shareholder, Delilah Henry, had been denying access because she worked out of her apartment and feared the dirt, commotion and noxious fumes, said her lawyer, Richard Blatt of Lebensfeld & Associates in Manhattan.
Further, she was not convinced that an adequate job would be done, and the work was scheduled for the only season when she could use the terrace. She also wanted the co-op to move her planters but it refused, saying she might later insist the moving had killed her plants.
The co-op threatened court action to gain access, but a compromise was reached: The co-op agreed to move her planters after she agreed to sign a release absolving it of any responsibility for plant damage. The work started in September.
Another sign of the future, said Mr. Shmulewitz, was the recent agreement worked out by a client co-op on East 52d Street.
An upper-floor resident had requested private rights to space outside his unit for a roof terrace. Since other shareholders would not be adversely affected, the co-op worked out a deal under which he bought the rights to a 350-square-foot area. He paid for his space by buying additional shares and will thus also pay additional monthly maintenance.
This gave the co-op a cash infusion. However, the agreement also included specific language regarding the rights and responsibilities connected with the space.
"It was an attempt to go forward in a way that should avoid the sort of contention and litigation we've seen in the past," said Mr. Shmulewitz.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Easing Corporate Relocation to Fairfield County

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
FROM January 1993 through the second quarter of this year 58 companies moved into Fairfield County from out of state, occupying 1.3 million square feet of space and bringing with them nearly 4,000 employes.
Since 1989 there have been 289 such incoming corporate moves, according to Sacia, (formerly known as the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association) based in Stamford. 
 And the parade is not over. In a special session of the General Assembly earlier this month Connecticut changed its laws to permit foreign banks to conduct trading, underwriting and other nonretail banking activities in the state. It was another step in smoothing the way for the Swiss Bank Corporation of Basel, Switzerland, to move its headquarters from Manhattan to an 11.9-acre site in downtown Stamford. Connecticut's aggressive corporate recruitment package containing $145 million worth of tax credits over 15 years was a persuasive element in Swiss Bank's decision to move.
Approval to build 1.3 million square feet of office space for an eventual 3,000 employes during a 10-year construction period is expected from the city's planning board and other agencies in the next few months.
With housing costs in the area among the highest in the nation, a question arises: Where are all these people from so many companies are going to live?
Apparently, it's no problem. Most of the relocating employees are highly paid ("The average salary of Swiss Bank people is $140,000," said Christopher Bergstrom, Stamford's Director of Economic Development.), existing housing is selling briskly and new construction is on the rise. Permit activity statewide has been increasing steadily, and August figures for Fairfield County were up by 648 housing units from the previous year, or 69.5 percent.
To further accommodate new businesses, the state has introduced a pilot program for helping employes of incoming companies to buy or rent houses and apartments at reasonable cost. However, the modest income and home-purchase price limits preclude the program's having much impact on the wealthy Gold Coast towns of southwestern Fairfield County, nor is it intended to aid the affluent.
What it may do is help entry-level and junior management transferees to buy or rent in towns north and east of lower Fairfield, unfortunately intensifying the transportation problem that began during the 80's boom. The area became so unremittingly expensive that finding a secretary, mail clerk, policeman or teacher who lived within 35 miles of his or her job was a major accomplishment. A result is still evident in severely clogged road and rail traffic.
Companies moving to areas other than Fairfield County, where housing is within the program's limits, will reap its benefits. The as yet untried Connecticut Housing Finance Authority program "will be offered to corporations coming into Connecticut through the Department of Economic Development," said Carol Montesi, spokeswoman for the Department of Housing.
It offers incoming businesses a tax credit of up to $100,000 a year out of a $1 million-a-year pool to create a housing assistance fund for its employees. Each company's plan for dispersal of the funds must be approved by the state.
THE money will be available for down payments, closing costs, points, security deposits for rentals, or whatever is needed. Fifty banks and mortgage companies that have agreed to participate in the program will offer mortgage rates of 1 to 2 percentage points below market for employees relocating to Connecticut, and qualifying home purchase price levels in the Stamford area have been raised from $179,500 to $251,862. Income limits for applicants have also been raised for a family of four, from $72,300 to $102,700. Eligibility limits vary in different parts of the state, based on Federal Housing and Urban Develpment Department guidelines.
A reserve of $5 million in mortgage money is committed for homeowners from other states who are reluctant to move to Connecticut without company or other assistance. The funds will be administered by the state's housing finance agency.
By stepping in where many corporations have backed away from the cost of moving key employees, Connecticut is creating another enticement for relocating businesses.
"Benefits offered to transferring families are not as generous as they were in the past," said Anne Moore, vice president of housing relocation for William Pitt Real Estate in Stamford. "They will move household goods, but very few will offer a buyout of the old house or help with down payments on the new one."
Among the more generous employers is WITCO, a chemical manufacturer that moved 800 jobs from several locations into a world headquarters in Greenwich last June.
"They offered everybody above a certain level a job in Connecticut," said James Little, regional manager of Weichert Relocation Management, a division of Weichert Real Estate Corporation in Morris Plains, N.J. Weichert, like Coldwell Banker, Prudential, and other national real estate firms, has spun off separate divisions whose sole function is to service relocating corporations.
"WE bought the homes of all the employees who were moving to Connecticut," said Mr. Little. WITCO paid the employe's legal fees, real estate fees, moving costs and any shortfall resulting from selling at a loss.
"It was hard to leave friends and my own public relations business in Columbus, Ohio," said Barbara Burnside, "but WITCO was very good about it."
Although it is her husband, William, who works for WITCO, the company helped her relocate her business and paid for a trip to Connecticut to search for a house with a local real estate broker. "Greenwich was not an option with the $600,000 average price of housing," Mrs. Burnside said.
"Our office sold five houses to new WITCO people," said Lonnie Shapiro, manager of William Pitt's Ridgefield branch. And, she added, in the first two weeks of this month 14 houses were sold from plans for a new subdivision of 71 lots, with prices ranging from $299,000 to $350,000 for houses of 1,900 to 2,300 square feet. "We are selling new homes at $800,000 to over $1 million as well," she said.
Stamford builders, including Avalon, Clay Fowler and Vaneck Brothers, are building, or soon will break ground for, almost 700 rental apartments and more than 100 one-family homes and the city's Urban Redevelopment Commission is planning to build more than 100 one- and two-bedroom apartments renting for less than $1,000, the current minimum for newly built, privately financed apartments in Stamford.
Robert Scinto, a Shelton developer, built 26 homes of 2,200 square feet in the Town of Fairfield, selling for $350,000. His houses in Milford are selling for around $185,000 and in Trumbull he is building town-house condominiums priced from $225,000 to $245,000.
"Connecticut has the highest per capita income in the country," said Joseph Cohen, spokesman for the state's Department of Economic Development. "If you took out Fairfield County it would be second, behind New Jersey. That's reflected in the cost of living and parallels the quality of life."

HEADLINE: 23 Vie for Assembly in 8 Races

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

 BODY:
WITH the words "lower property taxes" on nearly all their lips, 23 candidates for the State Assembly are running in eight districts in Westchester and Putnam Counties. Among the candidates are six Democratic incumbents, including four in their first terms, whose challengers are focusing on taxes and crime. In two of the districts, the incumbents are not running.
The decision of Cecile D. Singer of Yonkers, the only Republican member of the Westchester Assembly delegation, not to seek re-election in the 87th District has led to a two-way race in which no Democrat is running. 
 Michael J. Spano, a county legislator whose brother Nicholas is a State Senator and whose father, Leonard, is the County Clerk, is seeking Ms. Singer's seat on the Republican and Conservative lines. His opponent, from the Right to Life Party, is Edward M. Stanton, a retired Yonkers traffic consultant who said he has "no backers and no money" and is "campaigning on a very limited scale."
Andrew J. Spano, chairman of the County Democratic Committee and no relation to the other Spanos, said that Alexander Restaino had been a Democratic candidate in the 87th District but that the "Yonkers party was unable to get him enough signatures" to place him on the ballot. Andrew Spano said suggestions that this was a Democratic scheme to keep Republican voters at home "make me out to be a genius" but had no basis in fact. "I'm disappointed we didn't have anyone," Mr. Spano said.
Mr. Restaino, a businessman, said he had announced his candidacy early but had withdrawn -- as had many other potential candidates -- when the Yonkers City Council President, Vincenza A. Restiano, appeared ready to run. After she withdrew, he was asked to run only days before the deadline for signatures, Mr. Restaino said, and was 25 names short.
In the heavily Republican 91st District, which includes all of Putnam County and part of Dutchess County, a political heir and a neophyte are apparent the front-runners in a four-way contest for the seat vacated by Vincent L. Leibell 3d, a Republican and Conservative who is running for the State Senate. Willis H. Stephens Jr., a Republican lawyer whose father and grandfather both represented Putnam County in the Assembly, is being strongly challenged by a Democrat, Louise C. Bosogno, an award-winning television writer and first-time candidate who was the founding president of the League of Women Voters of Putnam County.
Ms. Bosogno won a large following in her successful grass-roots campaign against the construction of a sludge- and sewage-treatment plant in Putnam County and has been endorsed by the Sierra Club. Jerome Goldberg, who lost the Democratic primary to Ms. Bosogno by a slim margin, is running as an independent, while David J. Gamache, a Conservative, said less than a month before Election Day that he "hadn't set a strategy yet" for his campaign.
Andrew Spano said he expected most of the incumbents to have "absolutely no problem" winning re-election. But Naomi C. Matusow of Bedford, who represents the 89th District and has been called a "coming star in the Legislature" by Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, will have "the toughest race in the county," Mr. Spano said.
"The Republicans have targeted her," the chairman said, adding that the party was holding "a lot of fund-raisers" to help Ms. Matusow, who won narrowly two years ago. "It's a Republican district, and she's getting all the guns aimed at her."
Ms. Matusow's Republican opponent is Robert A. Spolzino, lawyer for the village of Mount Kisco, who won the nomination after Richard A. Flynn, a county legislator, withdrew from the race because of cancer. Mr. Flynn's name is still on the Conservative line, while Joseph F. Mannix, a retired businessman, is running as the Right to Life candidate.
Ms. Matusow, a Tennessee native and a lawyer, said she is emphasizing the record she established during her first term in Albany, including her sponsorship of a ban on assault weapons, which passed in the Assembly and awaits Senate action, and her role in the successful effort to eliminate the 25 cent tolls on the Saw Mill River and Hutchinson River Parkways on Oct. 31.
Mr. Spolzino, who managed Assemblyman Peter M. Sullivan's unsuccessful campaign against Ms. Matusow in 1992, said, "Our taxes are out of control, and unless we do something about that, New York will remain economically uncompetitive." He said that his experience in local government would help him in Albany, adding that the Assemblywoman had not been tough enough on crime and lowering taxes.
A supporter of the death penalty, Mr. Spolzino called for mandatory pre-trial detention for repeat violent offenders and more stringent penalties for the illegal possession of weapons.
Defending her record, Ms. Matusow, who opposes the death penalty, said she had introduced bills that would eliminate early parole for violent felons and prevent violent offenders from plea-bargaining.
She said she had actively opposed efforts by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke to raise the county sales tax and had helped her district by obtaining increases in school aid, $11 million in state transportation funds and $7 million in unrestricted local aid to help stabilize property taxes.
Mr. Silver, who last May appointed Ms. Matusow as chairwoman of the Assembly's Hudson River Task Force, said in an interview that she was "forever speaking up" about a variety of issues, particularly the importance of school aid to suburban districts.
In the 84th District, James Gary Pretlow, a Democrat from Mount Vernon is running for his second term against Eric Lustig, a systems analyst for Grey Advertising in Manhattan, who has the Republican and Conservative lines. Mr. Lustig, a two-time candidate who said he would spend "a lot less than $1,000" on his campaign, criticized the incumbent for voting against restoration of the death penalty. "I would propose to toughen the penalties for all weapons, not just assault weapons," said Mr. Lustig, a Yonkers resident.
Mr. Pretlow, the county's first black assemblyman, said he was the co-sponsor of the ban against assault weapons but would "continue to vote against the death penalty." The Assemblyman, who served eight years on the Mount Vernon City Council, said he was seen as sensitive to minority concerns. "Some people feel I can relate better to them, even if I don't represent their district," he said. Agnes L. Foulke is running on the Right to Life line.
Thomas A. Greco, a businessman from Larchmont, is challenging the five-term incumbent, Ronald C. Tocci, in the 85th District. Mr. Greco, the owner of Computer Perfect in New Rochelle, said that to save money he would "immediately phase out all money for the arts" and "privatize medical services for prison inmates."
Mr. Greco, the Republican candidate, charged that Mr. Tocci, who is running as a Democrat with Conservative endorsement, had the "highest absenteeism of any Westchester legislator." Mr. Tocci said that he had missed only "2 days in 10 years in Albany" and that he had been "excused for legislative reasons" from voting at other times.
Mr. Tocci, chairman of the Committee on Veterans Affairs, said he was working to "put in place for New York a veterans health-care corporation," would include a network of nursing homes. His other mission, he said, was to finance local schools through the state income tax rather than property taxes, which "would be more equitable."
Sheila S. Naughton is running as the Right to Life candidate as she did in 1988 and 1992.
Another longtime incumbent is Richard L. Brodsky of White Plains, who is running for his seventh term against the Republican, Gerard R. Gershonowitz, and the Right to Life candidate, Adelaide Donohue, in the 86th District. Mr. Gershonowitz, also of White Plains, said he had put his insurance business "on hiatus" in order to campaign for office.
The challenger said Mr. Brodsky had "raised taxes everywhere" and was "not being paid to be a patsy" for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. Mr. Gershonowitz said he would support a separate income tax for financial aid to schools and would "like to see state lottery money used specifically for education."
Mr. Brodsky said he has led in the fight to remove the parkway tolls -- which he said discriminated against county taxpayers -- and had achieved "measurable results" in obtaining state aid to reduce local property taxes in the form of the Consolidated Local Street and Highway Improvement Program and the Suburban Highway Improvement Plan.
Mr. Gershonowitz, a first-time candidate, said Mr. Brodsky had a "nonexistent rapport" with the Greenburgh Town Supervisor, Paul J. Feiner. Mr. Feiner, however, disagreed, saying that Mr. Brodsky had been helpful in discussing legislation to reduce the impact of state reassessment mandates in the town and in obtaining a $2.1 million grant to expand the Fairview-Greenburgh Community Center. "Personally he has never been such a big supporter of mine," Mr. Feiner said, "but that hasn't interfered with our day-to-day government dealings."
Robert J. Walsh, who has the support of the Republican, Conservative and Right to Life Parties, is challenging the Democratic incumbent, Audrey G. Hochberg in the 88th District. Mr. Walsh, a retired transportation company owner, said he supported "less government and smaller government" and would bring a "business mentality instead of a political mentality to Albany." Ms. Hochberg said she was campaigning on her "very strong and diverse record."
In the 90th District, Gary Ajello, a lawyer from Yorktown Heights, a nine-year member of the Yorktown Town Board, is a candidate on the Republican, Conservative and Right to Life lines against the Democratic incumbent, Sandra R. Galef. Mr. Ajello called himself "a very old friend of George Pataki" and said that Ms. Galef "represents everything the Democrats stand for, and I believe everything the Republican and Conservative Parties stand for."
Ms. Galef, an Ossining resident, said she was a proponent of "much more open and responsive government" and that she viewed herself as "a very independent thinker who never followed the leader." A County Legislator for 13 years, she is leading an effort for an amendment to the State Constitution that would require an on-time state budget.

HEADLINE: 'SHOW BOAT';
Producers Sing A Familiar Tune

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I read with interest the headline "The High Cost of Broadway" [Sept. 25] that accompanied a short article about ticket prices for the current revival of "Show Boat." In an article with the headline "Our Expensive Theater" that ran in The New York Times in December 1927, the month "Show Boat" had its premiere, the first sentences read: "It is not exactly stop-press news, of course, that the cost of everything has been mounting high in recent years. The theater, it need hardly be added, has been one of the affected areas -- witness the advance of the theater ticket from $2.50 to $5 and $6 and even $7." 
 The reason for the increase in ticket prices, according to Florenz Ziegfeld, then the producer of "Show Boat," was precisely what today's producer of "Show Boat" cites: Broadway economics.
Ziegfeld's share of the gross for one week of producing the show on the road in Pittsburgh was $32,359.60. His largest single expense was salaries, which came to $17,659.80 weekly. After other expenses, which included some unusually costly railroad fares, his profit on a capacity week was $1,907.46. As The Times reported at the time, "Mr. Ziegfeld will be the first to tell you that it is not by such margins that production expenses are repaid."
Plus ca change, plus la meme hefty weekly operating expenses.
 
JOHN TAURANAC
New York

HEADLINE: MORE MANHOLE COVERS

 BODY:
The Sunday feature "More Manhole Covers" (Sept. 25) brought back memories. Not only did our third-grade class at the Downtown Community School take a field trip to watch the Third Avenue el being torn down, but we diligently made rubbings of dozens of different manhole covers in the blocks around East 11th Street in Manhattan. Manhole covers taught us history, art, economics and the story of how the city grew. With our rubbings, we took possession of a piece of our urban world. 
 I have always credited manhole covers for turning me into an urban historian.
 
DEBORAH DASH MOORE
Director, The American
Culture Program
Vassar College
Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Beyond German Elections, Pessimism

BYLINE: By Nathaniel C. Nash 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
LEADING up to Germany's presidential elections last Sunday, some investors thought the time had come for the 1994 German bull market. The polls indicated that Chancellor Helmut Kohl would win an unprecedented fourth term in office, and stocks on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in anticipation of that victory were soaring.
Five trading days after Mr. Kohl's narrow election victory, however, many are wondering where all their joy has gone. On Monday, the market started heading downward, and by the end of the week, the DAX 30 stock index had lost more than 4 percent of its value, closing at 2,016.60. 
 Analysts here say that the weakness in German stocks may have little to do with the political process. Yes, there is some nervousness as to whether Mr. Kohl's conservative coalition government, and its thin 10-seat majority in Parliament, will be able to push through deep spending cuts needed to bring down Germany's ballooning budget deficit.
But most point to the performance of the dollar as the key reason for the plunge in stock prices.
"It's amazing, but the German stock market is strongly linked now to the value of the dollar," said Ralf Conen, chief equities strategist for Salomon Brothers in Frankfurt. "As long as the dollar doesn't hit bottom, I am not going to buy an export-driven stock market."
The reason is quite simple. Much of German industrial strength is based on exports -- cars, chemicals, machinery and industrial equipment. As the mark strengthens against the dollar, German exports get more expensive -- and less competitive -- abroad, so earnings go down.
And it was a week of struggle for the dollar as investors rushed to buy German marks. With Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen saying on Thursday that the United States Government would not intervene to support its already weak currency, the dollar broke an important psychological barrier of 1.50 marks, falling as low as 1.4893, before closing in New York at 1.4993 marks.
Some analysts foresee a further drop in the dollar, which would translate into deeper losses on German stocks.
"Everybody and his grandmother is talking about a 1.3850 dollar," said a currency trader with a major German bank, referring to the record low of the dollar against the mark set two years ago.
"There are no strong arguments for buying the dollar," said Richard Reid, chief economist at the Union Bank of Switzerland. "Central bankers seem to be reluctant to put any floor under the dollar."
As such, predictions on the near-term rise in German stocks are modest, especially since the market in 1993 experienced a run-up in value of almost 50 percent.
At Morgan Stanley, Alfred Mockel , chief equities strategist in Frankfurt, sees only a 5 percent to 8 percent rise in stock prices over the next 15 months.
Based on projected 1995 earnings, he says, many German stocks are overpriced compared with stocks in the United States and elsewhere. Daimler Benz shares are trading at 19.2 times projected 1995 earnings. BMW is at 12.8, and Volkswagen, 15.5.
At the same time, Volvo, the Swedish car maker, has a price earnings ratio of 4.7 percent, and the American automakers are selling at price-earnings ratios of between 5 and 9.
Despite a generalized pessimism, analysts are still saying there are some German stocks to buy.
The Union Bank of Switzerland has buy recommendations on chemical companies like BASF and Hoechst, which in the past three years have restructured themselves, laid-off employees, reduced costs and become more highly competitive.
Michael Hagmann, one analyst here, also recommends Linde, the world's largest maker of fork-lifts and the largest producer of industrial gases in Germany. The company produces gases such as oxygen, hydrogen, argon and nitrogen for industrial use in the health care, food processing, electronics, metals, and chemical industries.
"Linde is a play on the growth of East Germany and Eastern Europe," Mr. Hagmann said. "It has invested heavily there, and gases are needed for the region's industrial growth."
At Morgan, Mr. Mockel is looking at different stocks. He has a buy recommendation on Schering for two reasons. One, it is the first pharmaceutical company that has brought to market a drug that retards the advance of multiple-sclerosis. And second, Schering is the largest manufacturer of the birth control pill, which Mr. Mockel sees experiencing a sales boom in the wake of the Cairo conference on world population growth.
In the Germany banking sector, he is recommending Deutsche Bank, the country's financial giant. But he also likes the Bayerische Vereinsbank, a financial institution that has benefited from a surge in German mortgage lending and is said to have real estate holdings that alone are worth more than the value of its stock traded on the Frankfurt exchange.

HEADLINE: Business Diary: October 16-21

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
General Motors Doesn't Have the Bugs Out Quite Yet
It's said that car buyers have a lot of brand loyalty, but you can hardly say that for car investors. On Thursday, in the midst of Detroit's ongoing victory parade, General Motors took a tumble, reporting that although it made more than half a billion dollars for the quarter, it lost big money -- $328 million -- in North America. That's where productivity is supposed to be rising and costs falling. On the news, the stock plunged $3.75, and $1.875 more on Friday, to a yearly low of $41.25. Both days, volume was huge, making G.M. far and away the Big Board's most active stock. Don't look now, but shares in G.M. -- the giant of an again-mighty industry -- have been falling steadily all year. What's the problem? It isn't market share -- it inched up to 31.5 percent. The trouble is that while Chrysler, say, makes $1,000 a car, G.M. loses nearly $300. That doesn't compute. 

Are the Caviar Wars Over?
Forget Lee Iacocca. Forget Lou Gerstner. Let's talk about business clout per square foot. Which brings us, of course, to Murray Klein. This marketing genius helped turn a little store called Zabar's into a phenomenon, an institution whose fame radiates far beyond its Broadway home. Not only do two million customers a year pass through those fabled aisles -- spending $40 million in the process -- but ex-New Yorkers everywhere find themselves pining for the glories of Zabar's. It's said that nothing in New York stays the same -- but who ever thought it would come to this? Last week Mr. Klein retired after four decades of fiercely selling the cheapest caviar around.
 
I.B.M., One of the Gang Again
Ho-hum. Quarterly earnings were a surprisingly high $710 million. Cost cuts are paying off. Even mainframes are selling strongly. And the stock stubbornly drifts downward -- a fraction on Thursday, the day of the earnings report, and another fraction on Friday. It must mean that I.B.M. is back -- back, after its near-death experience, among companies that are expected to turn in such results routinely. Or maybe investors are worried that the mainframe news can't last, that cost controls have done whatever magic they can. But Louis Gerstner was quick to say that more of a recovery was needed: "We still have a lot of work to do in several areas of our business."
 
Block That Footprint!
One sure way of tracking technology's relentless tinkering with our lives is to monitor the jargon spawned by that technology. Just listen: last week an analyst (analysts surely lead the way in instant jargon) was discussing a "P.C.S.-avoidance strategy" and "how you get a big enough cellular footprint." Cellular footprint? Are we talking molecular biology? Jurassic Park II? No, it was four top cellular companies -- Bell Atlantic, Nynex, U S West and Airtouch -- teaming up to build a nationwide wireless network to take on AT&T-McCaw. And P.C.S.? Personal communications services licenses, of course. You want to avoid having to bid for those.
 
A Slap on a Very Rich Wrist
Weil, Gotshal & Manges dominates the bankruptcy game, but some say it clawed its way to that perch by being less than scrupulous in avoiding conflicts of interest. And last week the law firm got what those critics surely saw as a long-overdue slap on the wallet. Weil, Gotshal represented a board committee looking into possible fraud at Leslie Fay, but members of that committee were also top executives at big Weil, Gotshal clients. On top of that, said a Federal bankruptcy trustee, the firm failed to disclose those ties -- resulting, the trustee said, in "actual harm" to Leslie Fay. His remedy: last week he recommended to the court that Weil, Gotshal be removed from the case and forfeit part of its $5.3 million in fees. Ouch.
 
Honk If You're Sick of Barney
A year ago Barney was everywhere, pushing parents nearly to the screaming point. Well, this year, in their quiet way, they've let out that scream: they're sick of dinosaurs, and they aren't going to buy them any more. A Florida man even created an I Hate Barney Secret Society. At Hasbro, the biggest of numerous licensees, Barney revenues have plunged from more than $130 million last year to perhaps $30 million this year. How could this happen? Kids still love him, and Barney's No. 2 in children's television. But maybe it's finally happened: there might actually be so many Barneys out there that even the voraciously acquisitive preschool set doesn't have room for another creature. Marketers, jot this down: There can be too much of a good thing.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Japan: The Gap Keeps Widening
Last month, Washington made much of a supposed market-opening agreement with Japan. But that pact covered fringe items like insurance and medical equipment -- it didn't go to the core of the problem, which is cars. Last week the numbers made that starkly clear as America's trade gap with Japan widened by 2.4 percent and seemed headed for yet another record. It was small comfort to the Administration that the overall trade gap shrank significantly, because the Japanese number is the one that keeps Washington awake at night.
 
In Mexico, Invasion Is Welcome
You might think Mexicans wouldn't want all sorts of foreign banks and brokerages swarming over them, but when Mexico threw open the doors last week, a chorus of welcomes rang out. As part of Nafta, the Government granted entry to just about all the financial companies that came knocking, but Mexicans didn't seem concerned about competition -- they were more interested in the lift the new investment would give the economy. "This is a historic event," said one Mexican banker. And Mexico is protected for a while: not until 2004 can foreigners go beyond 25 percent of the market.
 
TH ECONOMY
 
Eeeeeeeeeeeeek!
Please: a moment of silence to pay homage to progress. No, make that Progress. Just look at current primitive habits: we grab some bills and coins, shuddering to think how many soiled hands they've passed through, and risk heart attack or vehicular violence or a lightning assault by walking to the store. There we exchange this germ-laden tender for the object of our consumer desire. But this nightmare's almost over: last week began trials of "E-cash": you sit, you log on, you click, you pay -- all on the "World Wide Web," which is somewhere in cyberspace. No muss, no plastic, no invasion of privacy. And cyber banks will duly record all E-transfers and E-deposits. Egad.
 
A Fortune 500 Senate Race
Politics and business are different animals. Everyone knows that. But at some dollar level, don't they converge? When Senate candidates spend vast sums to go to Washington (only to be reviled by the public once they get there), hasn't it become big business? You plow in the cash, and if all goes well the product emerges -- though it's a Senate seat, not widgets. In California, it's now reported that Michael Huffington and Dianne Feinstein spent a total of more that $27 million by Sept. 30 -- already a record for a Senate race, before any October ad blitz is tallied. This comes to $100,000 a day since Jan. 1. That's a lot of widgets.
 
Barefoot on Broadway
How do you get to Carnegie Hall? Oh, you know. And how do you get to Broadway? Bring a limo full of cash. And don't have any illusions about breaking even -- no matter how big your name. Even Neil Simon, owner of probably the biggest name around, says that with skyrocketing costs, "It's just not economically viable" to open a show on Broadway today. So last week he said he'd open his latest one Off Broadway. It seems axiomatic that playwright superstars would show their wares in the ultimate showcase; this defection suggests that something's amiss. Or as Mr. Simon's producer put it, a bit less politely, Broadway economics is "an insanity."
 
An 8th Here, an 8th There . . .
Wall Street math is simple: If brokers buy and sell at the same price, they don't make money. So stock prices have "spreads": Buying? That'll be $50. Selling? Sorry, just $49.875. On big exchanges, such eighth-point spreads are standard, and at last report, brokers could still afford loafers. But Nasdaq, it seems, is different. A recent study showed that 25-cent spreads were the norm, and that odd eighths were rare. And double the spread, of course, means double the profit. So last week the Justice Department said it was investigating Nasdaq dealers -- and the focus of the inquiry is said to be price-fixing. So now maybe you'll get those odd eighths -- all you'll have to worry about is picking the right stock.
 
The Market Is Not Happy
The stock market wants to hear that General Motors is doing fine and that there's no inflation, but it heard neither as the week ended. G.M.'s poor results combined with various inflation alerts to send 30-year Treasury yields close to 8 percent, and the Dow industrials down 45 points in two days.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
The Dollar Is Low, Despised, And a Good Buy

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
INTEREST rates are up, and the dollar is down.
That is not the way it is supposed to be, at least in terms of traditional economic analysis. Indeed, the prescribed method for defending a currency is usually to raise market interest rates in order to draw in capital from abroad.
Yet that is what happened, and the prevailing wisdom is that it will keep happening. Market sentiment is decidedly bearish on both bonds and the buck. 
 To appreciate just how painful the last year could have been for someone who bet wrong on both rates and currencies, imagine a Japanese or German investor who bought a 30-year Treasury zero-coupon bond last Oct. 15. With interest rates soaring, that investor would have lost 44 percent of his dollars since then. With the buck also down, about half of that investor's yen or marks would have vanished.
Few investors bet that badly. But a lot lost money when interest rates turned around and began rising. And those losses led to capital flight. "On a short-term basis, portfolio flows have become the most important thing in currency markets," says Chuck Clough, the chief equity strategist at Merrill Lynch. Rising rates have scared people out of American markets and thus out of dollars.
At the same time, there has been a surge of investment overseas by American companies and a rapid flow of money into foreign stock markets. In the 10 months through August, the latest figures available, mutual fund buyers poured $47 billion into funds that specialize in foreign stocks while taking $30 billion out of funds that buy Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities.
Those have not been the only reasons for the declining dollar. The American economy, growing faster than the economies of most other industrialized countries, is importing much more than it was. Exports, stimulated by the lower dollar, have also boomed, but not to the same extent, and the trade deficit is again growing, putting more pressure on the buck. That pressure may ease in coming months, however, as foreign economies strengthen.
It is the strong American economy that dominates the market news these days. Bond traders were stunned to learn that the rise in interest rates, which has caused them so much pain, seems to have barely touched the housing market, where starts continue at a very strong pace. As the bond boys jumped to sell, the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds topped 8 percent for the first time since the spring of 1992. It was at 5.78 percent when rates bottomed last October.
To encourage investors to buy dollars, it may take a combination of higher interest rates and a belief they will not rise much more -- meaning that those who buy our bonds will get good coupons without capital losses. When the Federal Reserve next tightens, the immediate question will be whether the increase is large enough to convince traders that it won't happen again.
In the more than two decades since the end of fixed exchange rates, currency markets have become famous for the way they can move to extremes of valuation. But eventually the issue of what you can buy for each currency begins to count for something. On a purchasing-power basis, the dollar is ridiculously cheap. It could get cheaper, of course. But a year hence, the chances are good that now will look like a great time to have bought bucks.

HEADLINE: Technology;
Back From the Brink, RCA Is Forging a Digital Future

BYLINE: By ROBERT E. CALEM; Robert E. Calem writes about technology from New York.

 BODY:
THE reincarnation cost almost $2 billion and took seven years, but RCA, under the wings of Thomson S.A., is once again alive and well and still living in Indiana.
In fact, the company that invented color television in 1954 has this year pioneered a digital satellite television receiver that has become one of the best-selling new consumer electronics products ever. 
 Now named Thomson Consumer Electronics Americas and including the General Electric brand name for audio, video and telecommunications products, RCA was sold by G. E. in 1987 for $800 million in cash and the medical electronics business of Thomson S.A., which at the time was valued at about $300 million. Since then, Thomson, which is owned by the French Government, has pumped about a billion dollars into the firm. As a result, Thomson Consumer Electronics ranks in the top three in market share in every consumer electronics category in which the company sells a product.
The company, which sells its products throughout North and South America and is headquartered in Indianapolis, said it will have revenues of $5 billion this year, up from $2 billion in 1987. Although the parent company does not break out profit-and-loss data for Thomson Consumer Electronics, Joseph Clayton, the executive vice president in charge of sales and marketing, claims the company will be profitable this year for the first time since 1986. Last year, the company broke even on revenues of $3.5 billion.
Some skeptics, such as James I. Magid, a consumer electronics industry analyst at Needham & Company in New York, still wonder about the extent of the company's profitability. "In real terms, profit margins on TV's and VCR's have eroded from 15 percent in 1977 to negative five in the last 10 years, and they're just getting back to zero. Productivity has been squeezed and prices have eroded," Mr. Magid noted. "So I'm not sure how profitable Thomson is today. But surviving is a great accomplishment."
But no one denies that Thomson Consumer Electronics is well positioned. "This year is a lot better than any of the last five years," Mr. Magid conceded, adding, "I think they're on an upward trajectory."
Mr. Magid predicted that Thomson's DSS digital satellite system, which allows users to receive televison channels through an 18-inch satellite dish, will sell well in rural America. He said demand for color televisions is still growing because prices, in real terms, are declining. "Barring a big recession, next year should be profitable."
Thomson's bankers are also upbeat about the recent performance of Thomson's American arm. "I recently attended a meeting of their bankers, and I'm very impressed with the quality of their management team," said Peter H. Koesler, a vice president at Citibank Global Finance in Chicago.
Before its purchase by General Electric, RCA had pulled back from the consumer electronics market after the failure of its video disk player. Under General Electric, RCA stayed profitable only by cutting costs. "We reduced headcount by 25 percent between 1986 and 1987, advertising expenditures fell to half what they had been before General Electric bought us in the fourth quarter of 1986, and we closed plants" instead of investing in new ones, Mr. Clayton recalled. "From General Electric's standpoint, they didn't pay for RCA for the consumer electronics business. They bought RCA for NBC and to get our defense electronics business."
In fact, at the time of the sale to Thomson S.A., John F. Welch, the chairman of G.E., called consumer electronics a "semi-stepchild in this company."
BY contrast, Thomson S.A. saw RCA as an entry ticket to the American consumer electronics market, where it had no presence, and a chance to compete here with Sony, Matsushita, Hitachi and North American Philips, which sells products under the Magnavox label.
Under Thomson S.A., the renaissance of Thomson Consumer Electronics began almost immediately, with an investment of $500 million to rebuild RCA's infrastructure, including a new color TV assembly plant in Juarez, Mexico. Nearly $100 million went to upgrade a new factory in Marion, Ind., for the production of regular large-screen picture tubes, and another $80 million expanded a factory in Circleville, Ohio, that makes glass for picture tubes.
About $50 million went toward significantly increasing the automation at the company's Bloomington, Ind., color television assembly plant, where RCA manufactured the world's first color television. Today, the company says the plant is the largest factory of its kind in the world, producing more than 3 million televisions a year.
In 1992 Thomson Consumer Electronics boosted its ad spending to $17.2 million, up from $13 million in 1987, and, with beefed up production capacity, increased and repositioned its television products. The company unveiled Proscan, a high-end color television that would pit RCA against Sony, Mitsubishi and JVC. The RCA brand was refocused to compete with televisions from Magnavox, Zenith, Panasonic and Toshiba, while the G.E. models would vie with lower-priced Korean and Japanese models from Goldstar, Samsung, Sanyo and Sharp.
LAST year, Thomson began "investing in growth" by boosting research and development of digital technologies, said James E. Meyer, senior vice president of product management. "Video and communications -- telephones, answering machines, camcorders, VCR's and TV's -- will all eventually go digital," he said. DSS, which cost $150 million to develop, is RCA's first entry into the digital video business. Mr. Meyer said it gives Thomson "the core digital compression technology" to develop products.
Digital compression reduces the amount of data needed to send video or audio signals from one place to another. A DSS encoder at the broadcast source compresses the video before it is sent to the viewer's home, where a TV set-top decoder decompresses the signal.
Although DSS was developed in a joint effort with GM Hughes Electronics' DirecTV unit, Thomson retained ownership of the compression and decompression technologies it uses. Any other company that markets DSS will then have to pay Thomson royalties. Sony will be the first, probably next summer. DirecTV agreed to let Thomson have exclusive rights to market DSS for 18 months or until the first million units were sold. Thomson expects to hit the million mark next year.
Last month alone, Mr. Clayton said, the company sold more than 100,000 of the new satellite systems. Over 200,000 DSS systems have been sold since its June introduction.
Eventually, Mr. Clayton said, the company will launch G.E. and Proscan versions of DSS and expand the RCA line into what is now G.E. territory: more powerful cordless phones and digital answering machines. He also plans to increase the presence of Thomson Consumer Electronics in Latin America.
Clearly, the company will face some hurdles as it grows. For example, Mr. Clayton said, "Sony moving into DSS is a double-edged sword. They can be a major threat" because of their marketing prowess. But they can also lend the product a great deal of credibility and boost everyone's sales. Moreover, he said, "I also wouldn't count cable TV out." He said that if cable operators ever unite, they could compete with DSS.
Describing RCA's long struggle back from the brink of extinction, Mr. Clayton seems glad to be able to predict any future for his company. "Without Thomson," he said, "I'm convinced our business would have died."

HEADLINE: Carnival Air: It's Not the Clown of the Skies Anymore

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.

 BODY:
AVIE COHEN, a resident of North Miami Beach who sells bakery equipment, was livid after his first two attempts to fly to New York on Carnival Air Lines.
"They had one flight a day, and both times the flight was delayed," he said, recalling the troubles Carnival had three years ago in its early days as a scheduled airline. 
 But because Carnival employees sympathized with his plaints and because the carrier offered low fares without requiring an advance purchase or Saturday stayover, he gave it one last try; now it is his airline of choice. "I've flown them maybe 40 times since then, and every flight has departed and arrived on time," Mr. Cohen said.
Though a blip in the industry -- it carried 1.2 million passengers last year, compared with Delta's 84.8 million -- Carnival is making a name for itself apart from its rich older relation, the Carnival cruise line.
Founded by Ted Arison, who started and still controls the giant cruise ship company, the airline is now mostly owned by one of his three children, Micky. But while Carnival Air began life in 1988 as a modest sideline, a one-route charter carrier, ferrying high-rollers from its base in Fort Lauderdale to Mr. Arison's Crystal Palace Resort and Casino in Nassau, the Bahamas, it is now much more than a feeder line for the father's other operations.
With 40 flights daily from Florida, New York, San Juan and Los Angeles, Carnival Air earned $4.1 million on revenues of $147 million in the fiscal year ended last June 30. One quarter of those revenues came from charter business and 5 percent came from delivering passengers to ships operated by Carnival and competitors like Royal Caribbean.
The rest of its passengers are attracted by low fares coupled with full service, a combination made possible by the kind of hustle that turned the economy-priced Carnival cruise line into the biggest company of its kind in the world and made the Arisons billionaires many times over.
In Carnival Air's case, that has meant scooping up personnel from Eastern Airlines and other moribund carriers and joining foreign airlines in ambitious route-sharing arrangements. It means operating without unions. And it also often means using secondary airports, like those in White Plains, Islip and Newburgh, N.Y.
"Our vision is not to try to compete with the major carriers," Micky Arison said in a phone interview, "but to grow conservatively by taking advantage of the Carnival name and bringing service to small markets."
There's apparently a lot more growth to come. Almost as an afterthought, Carnival earned more than a third of last year's profits hauling cargo. Next month, the carrier is set to begin daily nonstop passenger service between Fort Lauderdale and Philadelphia, West Palm Beach and Philadelphia, New York and San Juan and Fort Lauderdale and Newburgh.
There is talk of taking the airline public, as the Arisons did in 1987 with the cruise line, now called the Carnival Corporation.
"Going public has been under consideration for quite some time," said Micky Arison, who bought the airline for an undisclosed amount in 1990, when his father, an Israeli emigre, decided to move back to Israel. Reuven Wertheim, who runs the day-to-day operations of the airline as chairman, said the offering would probably occur later this year or in early 1995.
In an interview in his no-frills office here, Mr. Wertheim -- a 23-year veteran of El Al Israel Airlines who served with Ted Arison in the Israeli Army in that country's war of independence -- said the carrier "has been valued by different investment bankers at somewhere between $70 million and $80 million." But even when it goes public, he added, "I don't think the owners will relinquish control."
That was the case with the cruise line offering, which raised nearly $400 million. The Arison family still owns about 60 percent of the Carnival Corporation's publicly-traded class A stock, a stake worth $3 billion at today's prices, and all of its illiquid class B shares, conservatively worth another $1.2 billion. Both classes pay comparable dividends, but the B's have five times the voting power that the A's have, and elect nine of the company's 13 directors. The cruise company earned $318 million on operating income of $1.56 billion in the year ended last Nov. 30.
In the airline's case, a stockholder would be getting a share of a much smaller company that is one of many small, low-fare carriers that have emerged in recent years. That roster includes Kiwi, Mark Air, Tower Air, Valujet, Midway, Reno Air, American Trans Air and Morris Air (which was acquired last year by Southwest Airlines, the perennially profitable model for low-cost carriers). Costs at these carriers, which are mostly nonunion, average less than 7 cents a mile, compared with an industry average of almost 9.5 cents.
As a group, these upstarts will account for 4.4 percent of the domestic industry in 1995, according to a recent study by CS First Boston, and will generate about $1.8 billion of revenue. Carnival Air, the study estimates, will carry 2 million passengers this year, up nearly 70 percent from 1993, and almost 2.4 million in 1995.
Carnival Air owes some of its success to a coincidence. It was taking off as a scheduled carrier just as three airlines with a big presence in Florida -- Pan Am, Eastern and Braniff -- were crashing financially.
The demise of those airlines gave Carnival its opening wedge. Although its charter business to the Bahamas was profitable, it was also highly seasonal. The solution was to fly scheduled routes and keep costs down by leasing surplus planes and dipping into the big pool of former Pan Am, Eastern and Braniff employees for new hires.
While Carnival says its salaries are among the highest paid by small airlines, they are still far below those of the major carriers. And most of its fleet, which will grow to 21 planes next month with the delivery of its second and third Airbuses, is leased at favorable rates. In many cases, Carnival is charged only when the planes are in the air.
Carnival still flies between Fort Lauderdale and Nassau, although the Carnival Corporation sold the Crystal Palace two months ago to the Ruffin Hotel Group. Its routes also include six daily nonstops between Florida and New York (doubling to 12 in the winter), as well as service between Newark and San Juan and Miami and Los Angeles.
On each route, Carnival offers fares at least as low as those offered by rival carriers and sometimes lower. Its basic Fort Lauderdale-Newark fare, for example, is now $79 one way and a ticket from Miami to Los Angeles now goes for as little as $179.
And unlike Southwest, for example, Carnival is a full-service airline: it serves meals, reserves seats and transfers baggage to other airlines for connecting flights.
Carnival's deliberate approach to growth is designed to avoid the hasty expansion that proved so dangerous to other start-up airlines as well as minimize financial risk.
That is why the carrier uses many secondary airports, where departure gates are more readily available and operating costs are lower than at bigger airports. It is the only airline, for example, to fly from metropolitan New York to Ponce and Aguadilla in Puerto Rico. And it flies three daily roundtrips (five in the winter) between Fort Lauderdale and Islip, L.I.
Even Carnival's fine-tuned strategy doesn't always succeed, but the carrier has no compunction about cutting its losses.
Just two months after starting daily service in December 1992 between New York and the Dominican Republic, Carnival pulled the plug, citing a sky-high rate of no-show passengers. In May, it pulled out of Worcester, Mass., after just six months.
There have been no such problems serving the Hispanic market, which accounts for about a third of its business. There are the frequent flights between the mainland and Puerto Rico and New York and Florida. In addition, Carnival has an innovative arrangement with South America's LanChile Airline and Spain's Iberia Airlines.
The LanChile arrangement involves that carrier's daily flight from Santiago, Chile, to New York, which stops in Miami. While LanChile passengers bound for New York stay aboard the Boeing 767 and are joined by Carnival passengers, a bilingual Carnival crew takes over the flight to New York.
Because Carnival y leases the LanChile plane in Miami each morning and LanChile buys the seats it needs from Carnival for its continuing passengers, the deal gets around a rule that barsforeign airlines from boarding passengers in one United States city and transporting them to another. Carnival has a similar arrangement with Iberia. Passengers arriving in Miami from Madrid switch from an Iberia Boeing 747 to a Carnival Airbus 300 for a continuing flight to Los Angeles. Iberia buys a block of seats, and a bilingual Carnival crew wears uniforms that combine features used by both carriers.
Carnival is seeking more opportunities to share routes but not at the expense of its own plans. "We've been approached to fly to Haiti," Mr. Wertheim said, "but we have applied to fly there ourselves."
 
 
SHAREHOLDERS ARE BUMPED
 FOR all its billions, the Arison family has never minded using its clout as majority owner of the Carnival Corporation to get first-class treatment.
The giant cruise company paid $5.5 million to lease a plane from Ted Arison, the company's founder, for his own use. Another $1.3 million went to his personnel company for locating executives for Carnival. The company bought $3 million of equipment from businesses Mr. Arison controlled, and gave $528,000 to a foundation he runs. The most eye-popping outlay: $2.5 million in consulting fees paid to Mr. Arison's brother-in-law -- posthumously for the last four years.
All that could pale next to the killing the family may make if its privately-held Carnival Air Lines realizes its dreams to go public. Public shareholders of the Carnival Corporation may wonder why they missed out on a piece of the action.
It was the cruise company's passengers, after all, who rang up $68 million in bookings for the fledgling airline, nearly one out of every five dollars it has grossed since inception, and the bulk of its revenues during the crucial start-up phase.
A spokeswoman for the Carnival Corporation said Federal law prevents the cruise line, as a foreign corporation, from owning a United States airline. (The corporation is incorporated in Panama for tax reasons.)
In its proxy, the cruise company also insists that the rates charged by Carnival Air are comparable to other air fares. ALISON LEIGH COWAN

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/1995 VOLVO 960;
A Box That's Well Rounded

BYLINE: By MARSHALL SCHUON 

 BODY:
SO I get into the 960, right? It's the new Volvo, a 1995 four-door station wagon dressed in a green so dark that it looks black -- except when the sun is on it, and then there are speckles of gold in that lovely forest paint.
But I'm confused. Where are the side-impact air bags we've heard so much about? I've read that they are in the seats, and they pop out to protect the occupants if the car is T-boned. But where are they? Well hidden, is my first guess. 
 But that guess (like so many of my notions) turns out to be wrong. Further investigation shows that the bags are in the 850, which is Volvo's top-of-the-line sporty car. But they are not in this wagon, or in the 960 sedan, which are Volvo's top-of-the-line luxury cars, and they won't be in anything but the 850 until the 1996 model year.
That's a disappointment, but it just means you have to be a bit more careful of your flanks. You wouldn't want to mess up the 960's stylishly redone body in any case -- and you still get Volvo's otherwise thorough commitment to safety.

 
 For '95, that commitment includes daytime running lights in all of the Swedish company's models sold in the United States. The lights go on, albeit somewhat dimmed, when you start the engine, and the idea is that they make your presence on the road more apparent. The lights are required in Canada and in several European countries.
"We have seen in country after country that daytime running lights do help enhance visibility and contribute to safety," a company spokesman said. "We believe it's just a matter of time until all cars are equipped with them, but we wanted to be first."
The headlights have also been tweaked as part of the 960's design, and they are now as good as -- perhaps better than -- any I have seen, turning the darkest road into a well-lit path. The lights span most of the new front end, which includes a smaller chrome grille with the familiar diagonal band of trim, and lower fenders.
Bumpers are now keyed to the color of the body, and they are integrated better, although they still look like bumpers, which these days is refreshing. Door handles, body moldings and window trim have been refined, and both sedan and wagon are smoother than their predecessors.
Not that they will be mistaken for anything but Volvos, mind you. And that is all to the good. The boxy shape has always been useful for packaging passengers or parcels, and the wagon is one of the more useful luxury vehicles on the road.
The front-wheel-drive 960 also looks more expensive than it is, with a base price of $29,900 for the sedan and $31,200 for the wagon. There are only three options -- a $750 compact-disk changer, cold-weather equipment that adds $350, and a $300 roof rack -- so the base price actually means something.
Standard equipment includes a full complement of creature comforts and niceties, including individual wipers for those spectacular headlights. There is, of course, the usual array of power assistance, and there is also a standard sunroof and a three-position memory system for the driver's seat.
For '95, the interior has also been redesigned, and the dark-green wagon had tan leather on the front buckets and on the folding bench in back. A one-piece hatch opens on the rear cavern, which is fully carpeted and has a locking compartment under the cargo floor.
The seats are medium-firm but very comfortable, and the driving position is all that could be asked. Like the seats, the four-spoke wheel is wrapped in leather and its fat rim is padded but firm. The entire hub serves as a horn, and other controls have been made somewhat larger.
Burled wood trim graces the dash, the doors and the center console, which holds the shifter for the automatic, the only transmission choice available. There is a control to select one of three transmission modes -- W for winter, S for sport or E for economy -- and the button changes the shift points, depending on driving conditions.
No new Volvo would be caught without dual air bags, and the 960 manages a passenger bag that doesn't begrudge the glove box, unlike so many installations. The box is reasonably large, and it is abetted by other ample storage space throughout the car. Even the ashtray is large and easy to use.
On the down side, so to speak, the rear windows open only part way. But that is one of the few complaints in a beautifully finished, roomy and well-thought-out interior.
Under the hood, the 960 carries over the all-alloy, 2.9-liter in-line six cylinder, but the 24-valve engine has been recalibrated to provide greater torque than the 1994 model. That torque is now present at lower engine speeds, giving the car better off-the-line performance, and that is noticeable when you leave an on-ramp and merge into traffic.
No question, the car is quick -- even though the recalibration has cut the horsepower rating to 181, from 201 in the '94 model. More than being fast, though, the 960 feels completely competent. Part of that has to do with its new chassis and suspension.
At the front is the MacPherson strut system that was designed for the 850 Sportswagon. In back is a transversely mounted leaf spring made of plastic composites, similar to the one used in the Chevrolet Corvette. With the new underpinnings, the Volvo is flatter on corners; the engineers say there is 35 percent less body roll than in the past.
I believe them. This is a quiet, comfortable handler that is fully endearing. In fact, it took me almost no time to fall in love -- after I stopped looking for those side air bags.
 INSIDE TRACK: Amazingly, a slicker presentation of the basic box.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 23, 1994, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The Behind the Wheel column in Automobiles today, about the Volvo 960, describes the car's drivetrain incorrectly. As noted in an accompa nying table, it has rear-wheel drive.

HEADLINE: Lighting Up, But Only In Public

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
INSIDE the French Roast Cafe in Greenwich Village on a recent night, Dawn Randall sat blowing fat clouds of smoke. They drifted over the tables of the people squeezed all around her, some of them sipping lattes, others mowing down undersize sandwiches and one of them simply knitting.
In that self-contained world of small food, drinks without danger and a natural-fiber baby blanket in the making, Ms. Randall was doing something decidedly bad. 
 That fact seemed to please her.
"I gave up everything else," Ms. Randall, a 30-year-old makeup artist, said. "I don't drink. I don't do drugs. But I still get pleasure from smoking. I like the taste, the comfort. You eat, you smoke. You have sex, you smoke. It kind of all goes together."
While the number of heavy smokers has changed little in the last decade, and although high school students are still making their rite of passage to the school bathroom, where ritualistic puffs have been taken since the first crop of tobacco advertisements hit the airwaves, a group of people in their 20's and early 30's have begun to occupy a new category: "social smokers."
As with people who call themselves "social drinkers," these social smokers say they puff only occasionally, especially when they are with people. They say that they know smoking is unhealthy and that they feel guilt about it, but they defend it as a social pleasure.
"Two years ago, smoking among this group was looked down on," said Rex Briggs, a researcher who tracks the habits of people in their 20's for Yankelovich Partners, a market research and consulting firm in Norwalk, Conn. "But now there is this strange emergence of 'I'm going to do my own thing.' "
The evidence of a social-smoking trend is anecdotal. But in random samplings of 4,000 people nationwide, Yankelovich found that among people 16 to 29 years old, the number of those concerned about how much they were smoking rose from 21 percent in 1993 to 30 percent in 1994.
In a 1994 study of about 3,000 Americans, Yankelovich noted that 36 percent of all smokers were 25 to 34 years old, the largest percentage of any age group, up from 28 percent in 1993. Researchers at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta have also expressed concern over the increase in smoking among people in their 20's.
But despite the widely reported determination that nicotine is addictive, many in this group say they are able to restrict their smoking to nights or weekends.
With Rolling Rocks planted firmly in hand, young women in clubs drag on Marlboros, perhaps under the illusion that doing so will help them resemble Uma Thurman, but then say they will not smoke again for months. By definition, social smokers wouldn't dream of lighting up outside their office buildings at lunchtime, but they puff away with ease at happy hour.
This group does not buy, it bums.
The odd new trend, some marketing experts say, is confounding, given how educated the group should be about the dangers of smoking. But others argue that social puffing is simply an inexpensive pleasure for people who feel they are being glamorous by flirting with danger.
Perhaps five years ago the same group would have rented a limousine and zipped through Manhattan, yelling at traffic. Cheap thrills are not static -- like hemlines and restaurant trends, they change with the culture and the economy -- but they must always be bad.
"This is a group whose parents quit or never did smoke, so to do so is a mild rebellion," said Dr. Audrey Gusky, a professor of marketing at Duquesne University in Pittsburgh. "The 20-something group feels lost in the demographics. They feel like they are always left out, so this is a way to get noticed, for people to recognize them."
Mr. Briggs, the Yankelovich researcher, said the phenomenon may actually be a result of an improved economy, though this argument is usually reserved for an increase in, say, sales of washers and dryers.
"We are coming out of a gloomy state," Mr. Briggs said. "We are starting to feel optimistic. Occasional smoking is part of having fun and doing something different.
"An interest in status symbols like expensive cars and jewelry has decreased a lot in our nation. We are looking for things that are satisfying on a personal level rather than things that look good to others."
That statement about sums up how William Brangham, 25, a documentary film producer who lives in Manhattan, feels about the half-dozen cigarettes he allows himself each week.
Mr. Brangham, who has smoked casually for about nine years, said that despite the spooky poster that once hung in the teen-age section of probably every public library -- the one that depicted an old hag clouded in smoke and read, "Smoking is very glamorous" -- those few moments he puts in with tobacco in fact make him feel just that way.
"I love the way the tobacco tastes and the way the smoke feels passing through you," Mr. Brangham said.
"I like the sensation, the neatness, the sound of that crackle when you take the first puff of smoke. It's beautiful, and it's terrible, but I just don't do it enough to make it troublesome."
Many young smokers say they feel shame about their habit, and shame, like a juicy secret, is always better when shared. So for many, social smoking is a social sport.
"I only like to smoke around other smokers," said David Mowers, 29, a fund-raiser from Manhattan. "There is something really romantic about it. When you light someone else's cigarette, they touch your hand, blow out the flame, make eye contact with you and then say, 'Thank you.' I just love it."
Advertisements for cigarettes too, have played their part by depicting crowds of smokers puffing happily together. Couples who inhabit the ad world share a love of things like imported instant coffee beverages; the drinkers and smokers congregate in groups.
"Closet smokers create a sense of community when they do it together," Mr. Briggs said. "When you bum a cigarette, you can build a communal link, and every time you smoke, you reinforce that. You build a bridge between yourself and other people who only smoke occasionally."
DESPITE the tobacco industry's protestations to the contrary, all recent scientific reports on nicotine clearly state that it is addictive. But some psychologists say that the current pariah status of smokers is such that social pressure alone may keep puffing to a minimum.
"I have had a number of patients over the years who have been able to bring their smoking down to a casual level," said Dr. Barry Lubetkin, the director of the Institute for Behavior Therapy in Manhattan. "There are some people who can organize themselves, through a combination of their personality and an environment where they feel so pressured not to smoke during the week, that they simply give it up and do it only on weekends.
"Now, the ultimate study of casual smokers has not yet been done. But is casual smoking advisable for a goal? No."
But danger has to be part of the point.
As Richard Klein wrote in "Cigarettes Are Sublime" (Duke University Press, 1993), a monograph that explains the appeal of smoking, "warning smokers or neophytes of the dangers entices them more powerfully to the edge of the abyss, where, like travelers in a Swiss landscape, they can be thrilled by the subtle grandeur of the perspectives on mortality opened by the little terrors in every puff."
Or could this all simply be latent high school trauma, the sort that sent those who were cut from the volleyball team to the park behind the school to puff away angrily while denouncing society as a whole?
Philip Shane, 26, who was smoking one of his girlfriend's cigarettes the other night outside the California Pizza Oven in Greenwich Village, sees it as somewhat more simple. "I feel like I am in a movie," he said. "It just seems cool."
