HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE CABINET;
Bearing Gifts, White House Hits Hot Spots For Election

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22

 BODY:
Hazel R. O'Leary, the Energy Secretary, said on Friday that the Clinton Administration will construct the most powerful laser on the planet near San Francisco, expanding the frontiers of science, injecting a huge wad of cash into the local economy and creating a raft of jobs. Officially, this has nothing to do with the national election taking place in 17 days.
Unofficially, this is a season in which Democrats need all the billion-dollar lasers they can lay their hands on. So when Ms. O'Leary announced the project at a ceremony in Livermore, Calif., her party's candidate for the area's Republican-held House seat, a businesswoman named Ellen Schwartz, was basking in the television lights at her side. 
 Ms. O'Leary is a surrogate -- an Administration celebrity supplementing the President's political rounds -- and a lucky one, too. In an era of big deficits and small budgets, few Cabinet officers have such largesse to bestow on the good citizens of the many battleground states and Congressional districts in this year's election.
But like the Republican Cabinet officers who preceded them, they are trying very hard anyway.
As Mr. Clinton campaigns through California and Washington this weekend, he will find not only Ms. O'Leary's tracks, but the trail of Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who was in Seattle on Wednesday and San Francisco on Thursday. He could stumble across Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, who was in San Francisco on Friday and is in Palm Springs today. He could even pick up the tracks of Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, who was in Fairfield, Calif., on Friday.
And if he were to hang around an extra day, he might bump into Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena, who is dropping by Seattle on Monday to campaign for a House Democrat.
"Our job is to go wherever the hell people want to see you at the last minute," said Mr. Babbitt's spokesman, Kevin Sweeney.
For the most part, such trips have two purposes. Uppermost is to raise money for the final pre-election push. The need is especially urgent in California and Virginia, where Republican Senate candidates have shattered all spending records.
The second purpose is to rouse the party's faithful -- the so-called Democratic base -- in a year when the party's prospects seem dismal enough to spur many loyalists to stay home on Election Day. An example: the re-election hopes of Senator Charles S. Robb, the Virginia Democrat, may rest on whether Virginia's overwhelmingly Democratic black vote turns out next month. So next week, two of the Administration's top black officers, Veterans Affairs Secretary Jesse Brown and Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, will be in Virginia.
Not so long ago, Mr. Sweeney said, the Interior Department was a cornucopia of election-year dams, mineral leases, mining rights and grassland leases. But the salad days are over. "We don't have many gifts to give out," he said. "No dams. No dams."
Still, there remain a few ways that an Administration can remind voters how their tax dollars are at work and a few strategists who argue that if votes cannot be bought, they can at least be rented.
Tony Coelho, a former United States Representative and the Democratic Party's chief political adviser this fall, told reporters at a Washington breakfast last month that the re-election campaign of House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington was in trouble because Mr. Foley had not given his constituents a reminder of the benefits a speaker can confer on his district. Asked whether he was suggesting that Mr. Foley bring his voters some political pork, Mr. Coelho hoisted his bushy eyebrows and replied, "Why not?"
Indeed, on the day that Mr. Foley returned to Spokane last week to campaign in earnest, he announced that the Justice Department had set aside enough money for the city under the first phase of the new crime legislation to hire 26 police officers -- more than Seattle or San Francisco or Pittsburgh will get under the bill.
The next day, Mr. Foley said the Pentagon had decided to shift 151 trainers from other locales to Spokane's Fairchild Air Force Base.
Mr. Foley argued that the Air Force move was not pork, but part of a long-planned consolidation that he said would save the Pentagon $15 million a year. "There is no way that saving money is pork," he told The Spokane Spokesman-Review.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

INDUSTRY: SIC5145 CONFECTIONERY (60%);

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: FLORIDA;
The Political Scion vs. the Veteran Politician

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 21

 BODY:
"It's not working," Jeb Bush said one afternoon this week, as he cruised down I-75 in the motor home with the bedroom in the back and the work space in the front that he uses to tour Florida in his campaign for governor.
The "it" on Mr. Bush's mind toward the end of a campaign in which he stands an excellent chance of defeating Gov. Lawton Chiles is the state's government and society in general all wrapped into one. That is why Floridians are so unhappy, he explained. "I don't think people have sorted out why it's not working," he said, "but they know it's not working." 
 Tall and thin with an unruly black forelock, button-down collars and a wide, lopsided smile that make him unmistakably George Bush's son, Jeb Bush is preaching a hard-edged conservatism that goes far beyond what his father would have espoused even on his most fervent days.
He would require that all new state taxes, no matter how small, be approved by voter referendum.
He would force mothers and children off welfare after two years with no provision for job training or child-care beyond what is now available.
He would build space for thousands more prisoners, make sure that juveniles are punished more severely for crimes than they are now, remove from prisons some creature comforts like television sets and exercise rooms and execute more convicts who have committed serious crimes.
He would take money that now goes to public schools and give much of it to parents to help pay tuition to private schools.
This is a campaign, a platform, a style that has Governor Chiles on the ropes. Statewide public opinion polls this month have shown Mr. Bush, who has never held elective office, anywhere from 5 to 10 percentage points ahead.
It is not an insurmountable lead with almost three weeks to go before the Nov. 8 election. But it is a surprisingly solid one, given that Mr. Chiles, who is 64, has been in Florida politics for more than a generation -- 12 years in the State Legislature, 18 years in the United States Senate and now four years as Governor -- without ever losing an election.
Unusually gentle and modest as politicians go, Mr. Chiles has responded uncharacteristically to the Bush challenge. In his television advertisements and campaign speeches he has lashed out with personal attacks on his younger opponent that have often landed far off mark.
This week, for instance, Mr. Chiles accused Mr. Bush of a variety of supposedly improper tax and business deals that Mr. Bush was able to explain away easily. And the Governor said Mr. Bush had not bothered to vote in the 1992 election, an accusation Mr. Bush was able to refute by proving that he cast an absentee ballot.
In a debate at Walt Disney World on Tuesday morning and at a joint appearance in a rally at Lakeland on Wednesday night, Mr. Chiles seemed shrill and defensive, Mr. Bush calm and confident.
Over lunch at Reececliff Restaurant in Lakeland, Mr. Chiles's hometown, where he has gone for apple pie all his life, the Governor acknowledged that he was frustrated.
"I have never run against anyone in a statewide campaign who has no public record at all," he said. "He has a nice mama and a nice papa, but I don't know what he's done to be governor of Florida."
Much as his father moved from New England to Texas in 1948 to make his fortune in the oil business, so Jeb Bush moved from Texas to Miami in 1980. His in-laws lived there, he said, and it seemed like a good place to become involved in what he called entrepreneurial activities.
Within a few years, he had made millions as a real estate developer. The only public office Mr. Bush has held was Florida Secretary of Commerce, an appointed position in the Republican administration of Bob Martinez, Mr. Chiles's predecessor.
Mr. Chiles, by contrast, is a lifelong politician. The son of a railroad conductor, he was active in campus politics at the University of Florida, won a seat in the Legislature shortly after he graduated from law school and was elected to the United States Senate in 1970.
His victory in the Democratic primary that year was an astonishing upset, won after Mr. Chiles, short on cash and name recognition, campaigned by walking from one end of the state to the other. In the years that followed, countless politicians around the country tried to emulate Walkin' Lawton's technique, but few ever did it so successfully.
After 18 years in the Senate in which he rose to be chairman of the Budget Committee, Mr. Chiles decided not to run for re-election in 1988. He announced that he suffered from depression and was taking medication. But in 1990, his illness apparently under control, Mr. Chiles challenged Mr. Martinez and won the governorship handily.
In many respects, his race for governor paralleled Bill Clinton's campaign for the Presidency two years later. In the middle of a recession, Mr. Chiles called for change, for an end to politics as usual. On Election Night, he proclaimed that a new era of Camelot was upon the state.
But the Governor was damaged by some early slips, and the high expectations he brought to the office came crashing down.
He raised the salaries of top appointed officials, a move that generated so much political ire that he was forced to back down. He dismissed the able and popular Republican lottery secretary and replaced her with an inexperienced Democrat, leaving the impression with some Floridians that he was not a new kind of governor at all.
Finally, Mr. Chiles's tax reform plan, the centerpiece of his agenda and the political equivalent of President Clinton's health care proposal, was rejected by the Legislature.
Mr. Chiles is so affable, so charming face to face, that while his disapproval rating in the polls has soared above 60 percent, he remains personally popular. Because of that, Mr. Bush is careful to address him as "sir" and to avoid attacking him. "He served this state with dignity," Mr. Bush said at a rally in Gainesville this week. "His problem is that he actually believes government is the best means by which we can solve problems."
The Governor does believe that. He holds that the way to combat crime, the biggest worry expressed by Floridians, is not to build more prisons, as Mr. Bush proposes, but to see that pregnant women and infants get proper health care and that schoolchildren get better public education.
"It's not as sexy," he told the residents of a retirement home in Lakeland, "but it's a lot more efficient than prisons."
Mr. Chiles's problem is that his whole campaign is unsexy. He has no memorable slogan, no pointed message about the direction in which he would like to lead the state.
The population of Florida has doubled, to 14 million from 7 million, since he first won statewide office by walking across the state. The snowbirds who have moved here have caused Republican registration to quadruple in that time, to a point where there are almost as many Republicans as Democrats. Campaigns here have become like those in California, dominated by 30-second television advertisements.
Pressing the flesh, remembering names, exuding charm face to face, expressing country aphorisms -- Mr. Chiles's time-honored style -- may fall prey to Mr. Bush's well-financed, meticulously organized campaign and his finely honed conservative doctrine.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Jeb Bush, the Republican candidate for governor of Florida, has mounted a strong campaign by promoting a conservative agenda that is farther to the right than that of his father, the former President. The younger Mr. Bush was greeted by supporters in Lakeland last week; Gov. Lawton Chiles, a Democrat, has spent 34 of his 64 years in Florida politics without losing an election. But this campaign is in trouble, with polls showing him trailing his opponent. Mr. Chiles listened to educators and parents at Dixieland Elementary school in Lakeland last week. HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Lurking Behind All Those Masks Are Managers Waiting to Happen

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Their equipment used to be popularly known as the tools of ignorance, but catchers obviously display no ignorance in their quest to become managers. Recent developments on the managerial employment line reinforced the belief that former catchers make better managers than players who played other positions.
Of the six managers who have been hired since the season ended prematurely, four were catchers in their playing days -- Bob Boone of Kansas City, Kevin Kennedy of Boston, Johnny Oates of Texas and Bruce Bochy of San Diego. Kennedy and Oates were available because they had been fired, but they were snatched for new jobs almost before the ink on their pinks slips was dry. 
 With all of the vacancies filled, 8 of the 28 managers are former catchers. Seven managers were outfielders and nine were infielders, but given the far greater number of outfielders and infielders, the ratio of catchers in managing jobs is remarkable.
Besides Boone, Kennedy, Oates and Bochy, the roster features Jim Leyland of Pittsburgh, Gene Lamont of the Chicago White Sox, Rene Lachemann of Florida and Joe Torre of St. Louis. Walt Jocketty, the Cardinals' new general manager, hasn't disclosed his decision on Torre's status, but he is expected to keep him in the job.
"The catcher is the manager's representative on the field for the game," said Dan Duquette, the Red Sox general manager, who grabbed Kennedy six days after the Rangers dismissed him. "The catcher is involved with every pitch, every pitcher, and he's the only player on the field who has the whole field in front of him. A catcher has to work with the manager, and a good catcher also will manage the pitchers to get the most out of them.
"For those reasons, you have to develop a good understanding of the game, and you're intimately involved in the decision-making to get 27 outs for your ball club and to get the most out of your pitching staff. It's also a position of leadership if done properly. You lead the defense while you're in the field."
Doug Melvin, the new general manager in Texas, brought Oates into the Baltimore organization as a minor league manager in 1988 and last week made him Kennedy's successor as the Rangers' manager.
"They probably study the whole game," Melvin said, speaking of catchers generally. "They're involved in the advanced reports because they need to know about the pitchers and the defense. They're more studious about the game. Through their careers, maybe they sat down by the manager and followed the game a little bit.
"If you watch when they come off the field, the manager usually says something to the catcher more than other people. What was that pitch, what did he throw in that situation? The catcher also goes to the mound, brings the infielders in and says this is what we're going to do. They've been put in a position to make sure things get done."
Melvin noted that in many instances, the former catchers were backup catchers and probably spent their time in the dugout studying what managers and other players did.
Kennedy and Leyland never made it to the major leagues and weren't even everyday catchers in the minors. Lamont, who was drafted ahead of Johnny Bench in 1965, and Lachemann each spent one entire season and bits of others in the majors, though not as starters. Bochy never caught more than 55 games in any of his his nine full or partial seasons. Oates caught as many as 91 games in a major league season only once. Torre and Boone were the exceptions.
Leyland, who never played above the Class AA level of the minors, said catchers have a better feel for what goes on in games than other players.
"Their concentration level is probably a little higher," said Leyland, who is generally considered the best manager working today. "You're so much more involved. It probably gives you a better focus and perspective of the overall game."
Boone caught 2,225 more major league games than Leyland and now starts out as a rookie manager.
Speaking from catching experience, he said, "You're getting a lot of simulated managing experience while you play. You have to relate to people on your pitching staff. You have to know the most important aspect of the game, which in my opinion is to deliver the right pitch in the right spot. That's probably the most important asset you need as a manager, teaching that aspect of the game.
"As a catcher, you learn a little bit of the mechanics of pitching. You're a troubleshooter as a catcher and that's what you are as a manager. That gives you the advantage of learning while you're on the job. As a catcher, you manage the game. I managed every game I played in. I just didn't have the control."
Oates said no one should be surprised at the evolution of catchers into managers.
"Catchers, if they want to manage, should have a big leg up on everyone else," the Rangers' new manager said. "When you go to spring training and the manager starts working on fundamentals, there's not one fundamental a catcher is not involved in": pitchers' working on curveballs in the bullpen, cutoffs and relays, calling pickoff plays, rundowns, the bunt defense.
"An outfielder might be out there catching fly balls," Oates said. "But the catcher is involved. He's involved in everything that goes on in the field."
Managing, though, is not for every catcher, Boone noted. "I've known a lot of dumb catchers," he said. "Just because you're a catcher doesn't mean you're going to make a good manager."
 
Alou Wins Without Bonds
 Upon learning he won the Baseball Writers Association award as National League manager of the year, Felipe Alou of the Montreal Expos remarked, "I thought to be manager of the year, you had to manage Barry Bonds."
An astute observation, to be sure. In three of the previous four years, the N.L. manager of the year had Bonds on his team -- Jim Leyland in Pittsburgh in 1990 and '92 and Dusty Baker in San Francisco last year. Beyond that similarity, however, lay another: Bonds was the N.L. most valuable player each of those seasons.
He won't be this year, which makes it all right for Alou to be manager of the year.
 
Catchers at the Bat
 Syd Thrift, an underappreciated veteran baseball man, was talking about catchers, not as managers but as hitters. He was talking about his experiences with them in a visual training program he conducts to help players improve their concentration and their ability to pick up pitches quickly.
When they bat, Thrift said he asks catchers: "how come you don't apply the same principles and techniques you use when you pick up the ball from the pitcher's hand to be a better catcher? Even though you know what's coming, you have to be able to pick up the ball out of the pitcher's hands and track it. You have to know where a curveball is going. You have to be ready to block the ball if it's in the dirt. You can't be careless; you can't pull your head off the ball."
The fact is, Thrift said, catchers simply don't concentrate the same way when they bat. Fatigue from catching sets in, and they get careless.
Cut loose in a front-office change-over by the Chicago Cubs, where he had been assistant general manager the past three years, Thrift is available to lend his services in a variety of ways, particularly scouting, evaluating talent and conducting training programs others have never considered.
Anybody who was able to resuscitate the comatose Pirates and help save the franchise for Pittsburgh, as Thrift did in the late 80's, is too valuable to leave unemployed.
 
The New Mr. October?
 Sayeth Bud Selig, presiding over the void that has replaced World Series Week: "The long-term gain is worth the short-term pain."
The pain will persist, though, because Bill Usery Jr. doesn't figure to be able to duplicate the fall heroics of Joe Carter and Bill Mazeroski and Reggie Jackson and Carlton Fisk and Ron Swoboda and Don Larsen and Cookie Lavagetto. Even though Robert Reich, the Secretary of Labor, called him the "Mr. October of labor negotiations."
Neither side realistically expects the mediator to hit a grand slam in the last inning of the seventh game. If, on the other hand, he induces the owners to sacrifice their coveted cap to a serious effort to reach agreement with the players, he could be named the player of the month.

HEADLINE: Whining Toward the Throne

 BODY:
Britons are caught up in another fit of argument over why they should keep the monarchy. The American answer is simple. Of course, they should keep it -- for our amusement.
Listen, this is a fine show, not least from a journalistic point of view. In the United States, the pathological marriage of Prince Charles and Princess Diana is a tabloid television entertainment. In Britain, it is still largely a print story, and nothing brings out the deep-rooted obedience of establishment journalists more quickly than bad behavior toward or by the royal family. 
 The source of bad behavior toward the royals is the tabloid press whose sneaky photos and transcripts have raised the palace shades. In a cruel twist of fate, the tabloids' firebombing of the Windsors' facade of respectability has been abetted by the Sunday and daily Times of London. Monarchists believe that the papers' publisher, Rupert Murdoch, and a former Sunday Times editor, Andrew Neil, have done more damage to the crown than anyone save the children of Elizabeth II.
It was Mr. Murdoch's Sunday Times that published the Prince's caddish declaration that he never loved his wife and anyway his daddy frightened him into marrying her. Also, his mother was distant and the boys at his perfectly awful school picked on him. Today, The Sunday Times is expected to offer the Prince's authorized version of his affair with Camilla Parker Bowles.
Charles's grandiose self-pity masks his truly sad human situation. He is a reasonably intelligent, educated man captured in a not-too-bright family that has never been much for school. His profession is waiting for his mother to die.
All that, alas, is not enough to excuse the terrible hash he has made of things. In the days since his confessions, a band of God-save-the-Queen writers has been doing its best to invent arguments for preserving an institution that the tabs, the Prince and Mr. Murdoch seem bent on obliterating.
The daily Times obligingly gave William Rees-Mogg, a former Times editor and Thatcher Government censor, a platform for his salvage operation. Mr. Rees-Mogg rated all Princes of Wales on a scale of 1 to 100. Talk about grade inflation. The current Prince got a staggeringly generous seven for "personal responsibility" on the way to a total of 71. (George III got a 63 despite managing to lose the Colonies.) The Rees-Mogg verdict? Prince Charles is still fit to be king, but he really must stop bleating about his mum in public.
In the conservative Daily Telegraph, the former editor and Thatcher crony Bill Deedes had a clear solution for the "botch" Charles had made of his life. It was to wrest control of The Times from "an absentee landlord like Rupert Murdoch."
These are the yelps of old boys who prefer a dysfunctional nanny to none at all. Even The Economist, which endorsed sacking the Queen in theory, could not contemplate life without her. The royals really ought to go, The Economist concluded, but it was more important to reform other parts of the British Constitution first. Even then, "if the people wish," the monarchy could continue.
Such contortions may seem strange to a tradition-impoverished country like ours. But England did not survive the loss of empire without learning the virtue of smiling while institutions collapse. So it was left to The Independent, the newest of the quality dailies, to find the virtue in Charles's nuclear-strength whining. According to an Independent columnist, the I-never-loved-her-anyway defense showed that Charles was a modern heir who had figured out how to match Diana's public-relations wiles. By publicizing his anguish, "he has shown he can play Diana at her own game -- and win."
Yes, indeed, and with a few more such victories, Charles might slip to 70 on the Rees-Mogg scale.

HEADLINE: Journal;
The Sell Curve

 BODY:
What if you yell "Fire!" in a crowded theater when the sprinkler system is already on?
This may be the only real philosophical question raised by "The Bell Curve," the book by Charles Murray and the late Richard Herrnstein that has monopolized magazine covers and inflamed pundits for two weeks. 
 Supposedly "The Bell Curve" is controversy incarnate. By offering an alarmist interpretation of the fact that blacks as a group score 15 points lower than whites in I.Q. tests, the book's authors are, in their words, bravely tackling "a taboo issue" or, as their critics have it, recklessly fanning the flames of racial division in a nation already at the brink.
But isn't it also possible that a publisher is simply hawking a book? The incendiary "science" in "The Bell Curve" is not new; its policy prescriptions are conservative boilerplate. Had the authors compared the I.Q. scores of men and women, that might have been a cry of "Fire!" in a societal tinderbox. As "The Bell Curve" stands, however, Mr. Murray and Mr. Herrnstein might be more accurately charged with rehashing the work of others (and sometimes their own) for financial and political profit.
One of those others is William Shockley, a memorable nut who argued a quarter-century ago in favor of sterilizing those with low I.Q.'s. Shockley receives only one guarded paragraph in the 845 pages of "The Bell Curve." Yet his old pronouncements are everywhere.
Shockley attributed the lower income and higher crime rates of blacks to the same 15-point I.Q. test differential. He concluded that "a major cause of American Negroes' intellectual and social deficit is hereditary and racially genetic" and "not remediable to a major degree by practical improvement in environment." He bemoaned welfare for encouraging the procreation of the population's "least effective elements," black and white.
The more elegantly written "Bell Curve" has the same drift. Shockley bequeathed its authors their self-congratulatory tone as well: He boasted about raising "questions that are usually swept under the rug" as they do about breaking taboos. Mr. Murray and Mr. Herrnstein also emulate Shockley by asserting expertise in academic disciplines (like genetics) outside their own and by protesting too much against those who might accuse them of making a fetish of race.
Since the "Bell Curve" authors cannot add to the science and pseudo-science they selectively cull from their primary sources, they update Shockley's politics for the 1990's (affirmative action should be abolished along with welfare) and tack on apocalyptic predictions of the sort found in best sellers heralding the next economic crash. "The Bell Curve" imagines a polarized, totalitarian Futureworld where the I.Q. elite will confine the dumb poor to a high-tech "Indian reservation." And how could this be prevented? Rather than provide answers requiring original thought, the authors fade off into a nostalgic paean to old-fashioned, self-governing neighborhoods.
Anyone looking for fresh, specific ideas about overhauling welfare -- and who isn't? -- will not find them in "The Bell Curve." Instead there is padding: enough equivocating disclaimers for another "Hamlet," and a mother lode of graphs designed to lend the book an air of unimpeachable authority, much as all those radar maps impart meteorological gravity to Willard Scott.
Even the authors concede their bell curves can be ignored. Lest they lose a single low-I.Q. customer, they announce in a revealingly caste-obsessed preface that their book is "only about 30 pages long" if read "at the simplest level," since there are italicized Cliffs Notes throughout. The graph-packed main text is "accessible to anyone who enjoys reading, for example, the science section of the news magazines," but the appendices that follow are suitable for only the very smartest -- no doubt the Asians who perform highest on I.Q. tests.
Such clever merchandising may make "The Bell Curve" the best-selling unread book since the last novel by Umberto Eco. Then again, Mr. Murray and Mr. Herrnstein may have outsmarted themselves. A book that blames low I.Q.'s for what ails America may have tough sledding in a culture where even conservatives have been rushing to deify the 75 I.Q. of Forrest Gump.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: HOUSE;
For Congressional Candidates, Washington Is a Four-Letter Word

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

 BODY:
In this year of the anti-incumbent, almost any Washington connection beyond a trip with the kids to the Lincoln Memorial is being considered a potential weapon to be used against Congressional candidates.
The evidence is all around the New York region. Gary L. Ackerman of New York, after 11 years in Congress, says he isn't really an incumbent because redistricting has made him a new face for many of his constituents. A spokesman for Carolyn B. Maloney, a first-term Congresswoman from New York, defends his boss's honor by pointing out that she has been in Washington for barely 18 months. And amid charges and countercharges of experience inside the Beltway, Philip M. Schiliro, a Congressional hopeful from Long Island, is defending himself against attempts to make an issue of the fact that he recently lived in nearby Virginia. 
 With Republicans hoping for a record turnover in the House of Representatives, anti-incumbent fever has given rise to a surprising number of close races across the region. Congressional Democrats in traditionally safe seats, and even some newcomers, say they fear the taint of the "I" word.
Hamilton Fish Jr. is an adviser to a human rights group, producer of two Marcel Ophuls documentaries on the Holocaust, and former publisher of The Nation, the liberal opinion magazine. He has never held elected office. But as the son of a veteran Congressman with a different party but the same name, he wonders whether anti-incumbent sentiment will move some people to try and vote him out before he's even in.
"There's an anti-incumbent sentiment that may merge with the name-confusion factor and they may think they're voting against the incumbent if they vote against me," Mr. Fish said. He is a Democrat in a close race against Sue W. Kelly, a former hospital-patient advocate and Republican fund-raiser, for the Hudson Valley seat being vacated by his Republican father, who is retiring after 13 terms.
Mr. Fish quickly added that there are also plenty of voters who will see his family name as a powerful recommendation. Indeed, there has been a Hamilton Fish in Congress since the candidate's grandfather was elected in 1922.
But an unpopular President, a long and ultimately fruitless health care debate and a festering distrust of the political class have made experience in Washington less of an asset than ever. Even freshmen elected two years ago on a wave of discontent with politics as usual find themselves defending charges that they, too, are part of the problem in Washington.
And Marshall Miller, press secretary to Ms. Maloney, who is in a close race in the 14th District, which includes Manhattan's East Side, Astoria, Queens and Greenpoint, Brooklyn, insists that her opponent, City Councilman Charles Millard, is an incumbent, too.
"Anti-incumbency feeling is to the Congresswoman's detriment, of course," Mr. Miller said. "But he's also an incumbent of a kind."
 
New York: 4th District
In one of the stranger races in the New York area, the worst that is being murmured about Mr. Schiliro, a Democrat, is that he is "from Virginia." The Long Island native has in recent years worked in Washington for Representative Henry Waxman of California.
In this heavily Republican district, Mr. Schiliro's opponents happen to have far more serious problems to overcome. The incumbent Republican Congressman, David A. Levy, was defeated in a bitter primary rematch with former Assemblyman Daniel Frisa, who also ran on an anti-incumbent platform of discontent with high local taxes.
The only Republican incumbent in the country to lose in the first round, Mr. Levy contested the race, which he lost by just 54 votes, and is expected to draw at least 10 percent of the vote running on the Conservative line. Mr. Frisa, meanwhile, is off to what has generously been characterized as a slow start. Early last week, he could not be reached for comment because the only telephone number local Republicans had for him was answered by a malfunctioning message machine with a beep that wouldn't quit.
And in yet another creative attempt to turn anti-incumbent feeling to his advantage, Mr. Schiliro's campaign is claiming that even without Mr. Levy, the local Republicans are acting like incumbents.
"If you ask people what's wrong with Washington, they say nothing gets done because people argue and bicker too much," said Tom Lyons, Mr. Schiliro's press secretary. "The only way Republicans have distinguished themselves in this election is they can argue and bicker more than anyone else."
 
Connecticut: 2d District
Most of the anti-incumbent animus is, of course, aimed at the Democrats, who control Congress. The most intriguing Congressional race in Connecticut is a rematch of the 1992 squeaker in which the dean of the six-member delegation to Congress, Sam Gejdenson, barely held his seat against a challenge from a little-known former Republican State Senator, Edward W. Munster.
Last time out, Mr. Munster, a retired Pfizer Inc. statistician who once got a campaign worker to dress up like the television character Herman Munster to boost his name recognition, lost by only 3,875 of the 242,707 votes cast. Mr. Gejdenson, who is seeking his eighth term, seemed not to take Mr. Munster seriously then. But he is fighting back harder this time, with television commercials that portray his Washington savvy as reaping huge benefits for the district, which stretches out across the eastern portion of the state.
 
New York: 5th District
In this district, which includes slices of Queens, Nassau and Suffolk counties, Mr. Ackerman describes his Republican opponent, Grant M. Lally, a 32-year-old lawyer in his first political race, as "one of the young Republicans without any fingerprints."
"My opponent does live on Long Island," he said, "in a 14-room, seven-bath estate with his mother and father in Oyster Bay."
Mr. Lally's retort? His opponent not only has a couple of lovely homes himself, but is, yes, an incumbent. There, he said it. (He also said he lives alone. "I have my own place I rent from my folks on an adjacent property.")
The district is Democratic-leaning, but Republicans are hoping that Long Island voters will favor Mr. Lally over a six-term incumbent in a district redrawn two years ago, when Mr. Ackerman won with only 52 percent of the vote. But Mr. Ackerman, who is still likely to win over a political novice, is betting that the redistricting will actually protect him from the backlash against incumbents.
"My district is a newly created creature, so in 95 percent of it, I'm a first-term Congressman," he said. "It's not like I'm an old worn-out face."
 
New York: 26th District
Among the freshmen facing an uphill race is Representative Maurice D. Hinchey in a rematch against the Republican Bob Moppert in the 26th District, which stretches from the Catskills to Binghamton and north to Ithaca.
The lineup of national Republicans who have made campaign appearances with Mr. Moppert there includes Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the minority whip, Representative Susan Molinari of Staten Island and Representative Bill Paxon from the neighboring 27th District. Mr. Hinchey also has imported support, and has been joined on the stump by Vice President Al Gore, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development Henry Cisneros, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt and Gloria Steinem.
Mr. Hinchey says the race will be decided on the intangibles of reliability and integrity; his opponent, a Binghamton moving-company owner who came within three percentage points of Mr. Hinchey in 1992, says the defining issue of the campaign is jobs and the economy.
Though Mr. Hinchey says his opponent has been so changed by consultants sent in from Washington that "he's scripted by D.C.," Mr. Moppert seems convincingly unspoiled by his new handlers: When asked to describe himself in a few words, for example, he included the adjective 'overweight.'
And when asked about anti-incumbent feeling, he said without hesitation: "That's what I'm counting on."
 
New York: 19th District
In the open seat being vacated by Hamilton Fish, both candidates say the main issue is jobs, with major employers like I.B.M. laying off thousands of workers and General Motors scheduled to close its assembly plant in North Tarrytown in 1996.
But Mrs. Kelly has also made an issue of her ties to her opponent's father, the Congressman, calling herself "the woman he called to open his first offices in Putnam and Westchester."
Of her opponent, she says: "I've known him since he was a kid. I've always called him Hammy, but people say that sounds derogatory so I don't know what to call him."
But both the Congressman and his son took exception to Mrs. Kelly's characterization of her relationship with their family, saying she did not meet Mr. Fish until he was a grown man, when she was on his father's payroll for a total of 45 days in 1972.
Mr. Fish also criticized Mrs. Kelly for a recent trip to Washington, where she signed the "Contract with America." The pledge -- much ridiculed by Democrats -- was taken on the Capitol steps by more than 300 Republican Congressional candidates who swore their commitment to tax cuts, increased military spending and a constitutional amendment to balance the budget.
"She ran ostensibly as an anti-politician" in the Republican primary, he said. "Then the first thing she did was run down to Washington and sign on with the clubhouse down there."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 23 about anti-incumbent sentiment in Congressional races in the New York region referred incorrectly to the Congressional service of members of the Hamilton Fish family. It has not been continuous since 1922; a Hamilton Fish was elected in 1920 and represented the Hudson Valley area until 1944, and his son, Hamilton Fish Jr., held the seat from 1969 until this year.

HEADLINE: What's on Your Mind, Kid?

BYLINE: By Anthony Gottlieb; Anthony Gottlieb is on the editorial staff of The Economist. He is writing a history of Western philosophy.

 BODY:

THE PHILOSOPHY OF CHILDHOOD
By Gareth B. Matthews.
136 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Harvard University Press.
$18.95. 
 AN old Jewish joke tells of a student who boasts to his grandmother that he has become a doctor of philosophy. "A doctor? Wonderful. But what kind of a disease is philosophy?" Wittgenstein would have liked that story; he thought of philosophy as something that needs to be treated and cured. Gareth B. Matthews, a professor of philosophy at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, plainly does not share that depressed and depressing sentiment. But his work with children shows pretty conclusively what kind of a disease philosophy would be if it were a disease at all.
Adult philosophizing would be a form of arrested development. Between the ages of about 4 and 7, children commonly and naturally ask philosophical questions, Mr. Matthews writes, but it seems that "once children become well settled into school, they learn that only 'useful' questioning is expected of them. Philosophy then either goes underground, to be pursued privately, perhaps, and not shared with others, or else becomes totally dormant." In other words, grown-up philosophers are those whose curiosity has not been driven underground. So Plato was in a sense a Peter Pan.
Mr. Matthews's earlier books, "Philosophy and the Young Child" (1980) and "Dialogues With Children" (1984), recounted many charming conversations, classroom exercises and spontaneous questions from children, and so does his new one ("Mama, are we 'live' or are we on video?"). "The Philosophy of Childhood" begins with a wonderful philosophical dialogue with his daughter, then 4 years old, who was watching the de-fleaing of Fluffy, the family cat:
" 'Daddy . . . how did Fluffy get fleas?'
" 'Oh . . . she must have been playing with another cat; fleas must have jumped off the other cat onto Fluffy.' . . .
" 'How did that cat get fleas?' . . .
" 'Oh, it must have been playing with yet another cat . . . they must have jumped off that cat onto the one Fluffy later played with.' . . .
" 'But Daddy . . . it can't go on and on like that forever; the only thing that goes on and on like that forever is numbers!' "
It is, it seems, not only professors' children who talk like that if given the opportunity. And it is not merely by chance, not merely because children go through a stage of prefacing everything with "Why?" that they sometimes manage to hit philosophical bull's-eyes. Mr. Matthews's guided dialogues with children show that they consistently and happily develop philosophical trains of thought, evaluate those of others and try to think things through, often reaching solutions that are essentially the ones propounded by the big people who are lucky enough to be paid for doing it. Children are not, of course, as good at it as some grown-ups; Plato after all was not just a Peter Pan.
With careful listening and without distorting preconceptions about what children might or might not be capable of doing, Mr. Matthews has unearthed a seam of would-be wisdom. His open-minded attention to the way children's minds work has also yielded a new concept of childhood intelligence that may bear on the question of children's rights, children's art and the status of literature for children. He argues that the philosophy of childhood should be a respectable branch of philosophy, like the philosophy of science or the philosophy of law. This strikes me as too modest a goal. Mr. Matthews's incisive investigations into the relations between the world of children and the world of adults are too thought-provoking to be confined to one branch of one academic subject.
A THIRD of Mr. Matthews's book is an analysis of various theories of development. He subjects Jean Piaget's theory of cognitive development and Lawrence Kohlberg's theory of moral development to simple and searching criticisms that make his book essential reading for anybody interested in early childhood education. But his main concern is to argue against the "conventional view of childhood as a development through a sequence of roughly age-related stages that aims at maturity." Instead Mr. Matthews tends toward a theory that has fewer precise developmental hurdles marked on the calendar and that looks more for similarities than differences between adults and children.
This leads to the political question of children's rights, to the related issue of medical disclosure and to a discussion of children's literature. Sometimes Mr. Matthews goes a bit far. Though he is likely to make some people dig up a few children's books they might have missed long ago, he is less likely to persuade them that Arnold Lobel's "Frog and Toad Together" is a "philosophical classic." And though he brings new respect to children's art, I was skeptical of his suggestion that some work by young children should be in the permanent collections of major museums.
Still, most of Mr. Matthews's sweetly reasonable arguments turn out to be, like children's philosophical questions, both intriguing and unanswerable.

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 1; Column 4; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2004 words

HEADLINE: New Haven Has an Attitude, a New One

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN 

 BODY:
HELP! Bang! Bang! New Haven's Children Cry." The blast of graffiti, scrawled in brightly colored letters across the Church Street side of the former Malley's building, now boarded up, is an image hard to miss. Painted by graffiti artists in the last two years, it broadcasts the message to anyone visiting New Haven that the city is a precarious place to be.
But if anyone knows New Haven, particularly its urban neighborhoods, it is Sgt. Richard Randall who says the message conveys only part of the story. The head of a community policing substation on the corner of Edgewood and Day streets, the sergeant also patrols an area each day that includes both the wealthiest and poorest areas of the city. 
 "The fears people have about New Haven are not accurate," he said one recent afternoon while in his police car on the way to clear the front of an apartment building of loiterers. As he waved to residents along the way and pointed out the successes and disasters of city projects, Sergeant Randall talked about his hometown with grace, proclaiming its vitality, diversity and ability to contain all the contradictions of life.
He grew up in New Haven during the city's first major urban renewal program in the 1950's and 1960's. Three times his family was uprooted as entire neighborhoods were demolished under the city's slum clearance plan. But these days, he said, New Haven is in the initial stages of a renewal as much psychological as physical. "The city is always correcting itself," said Sergeant Randall, who is 42 years old. "We realize we can't live in a vacuum. We're all a part of the ecology of our community and we have to cure ourselves from within. And nowadays there's a lot of hope."
It appears that many people in New Haven share the police officer's sentiments. Apart from the most obvious signs of renewal -- like the refurbishing of a four-block area of 19th-century brick buildings in the downtown district, and the renovation of the shopping strip on Broadway -- residents and officials say that the fatalism that seemed so embedded in the city over the last few years has lifted, and a a perception is growing that the city is moving forward.
The new zeal comes after years of news reports highlighting the city's high taxes, strapped budgets, poor management and violent crime. Residents say that although severe problems remain, in recent months several developments indicate that New Haven is regaining its footing. In addition to a spate of new construction projects, residents point to the explosion of interest in the city's art and music scene and the infusion of ambitious new immigrants, which has boosted the city's cosmopolitan appeal.
Indeed, parts of New Haven appears positively vibrant with ethnic restaurants, boutiques, outdoor cafes and bookstores. On Elm Street, a few blocks from Sergeant Randall's substation, the Daily Caffe (one of several coffeehouses that have opened in the last few years) holds poetry readings and art exhibits that attract a crowd of devoted patrons, many wearing the latest in grunge, crunch or bohemian black. Amid the din of espresso machines and Pearl Jam, one of the owners, Steve Shapiro, said, "Lately, there's a sense that New Haven is starting to go in the right direction. Unlike a few years ago when all anyone did was talk about what's wrong with the place, people are now saying what's right about it."
Laura Guada Ouelette is a 29-year-old artist who frequents the Daily Caffe and recently had an exhibit there of her paintings, which she described as post-modern realism. With its cultural and career opportunities, the city remains a magnet for young people from all over the state, said Ms. Ouelette, who moved to New Haven from Berlin six years ago. "New Haven always gets a bad rap and I have to admit I was afraid to move here," she said. "But it's the best place in the state to live if you're an artist. There's a very rich intellectual life. It's a great alternative to living in New York City."
Panzie Hixson, 39 years old, works behind the cafe's coffee bar. An actress and jazz singer, she said she experienced firsthand the rise and decline of the city's art community during the 1980's when the alternative theater production company she worked in lost its financial support and had to close. "After all the money dried up, people started to panic," said Ms. Hixson, who was raised in the city. "The mood was, 'New Haven isn't a cool place to be.' "
But over the last three years, she said, that feeling has begun to change. The opening of several nightclubs that support and promote local musicians has sparked an explosion of homegrown bands.
Ms. Hixson, who sings on weekends at Cafe Nine, a new rhythm and blues club on State Street, adds that the business support is important -- but so is the new notion that to survive as an artist you have to do it on your own. "Artists have had to become more self-reliant," she said. "And the city provides an atmosphere where that's possible."
Residents said that the city's ethnic and racial diversity was also giving it new vitality by reshaping the cultural life and propelling the local economy. Romulo Torres from Quito, Ecuador, and Mizael Mendez from Escuintla, Guatemala, work as carpenters for a Puerto Rican contractor who renovates houses in low-income neighborhoods. The two men say they have never been without work since arriving in New Haven.
"In New Haven, I've met people from all over the Spanish world," said Mr. Mendez, 31 years old, who arrived in the city a year ago, "Something I could never do if I stayed in Guatemala."
The two share an apartment in Fair Haven with another Ecuadoran man and they often socialize in clubs offering Latin music. Mr. Torres, 29 years old, came to New Haven four years ago and studies English at Gateway Community College. Both men dream of returning to their native countries -- but add that the pull of New Haven is hard to resist. "Who knows?" Mr. Mendez said. "Maybe I can start my own business."
Despite the surge of optimism the city is far from a full recovery. A recent announcement by the Southern New England Telephone Company that it would close its George Street building and move its 1,135 employees to other city offices was a major blow to efforts to restore the downtown district. The move could also have a devastating impact on nearby businesses, where merchants say they rely on the employees for up to 50 percent of their sales.
The crime rate also continues to fuel the city's poor image. Earlier this summer the city was stunned after a patron at a downtown coffeehouse took out a knife and stabbed seven people. New Haven received national press attention last month after a 15-year-old girl and an 18-year-old boy were slain when a gunman fired several shots into their car on Sherman Avenue.
Last week two teenagers were shot dead in separate incidents, bringing the murder rate thus far this year to 22. A year ago at this time, the city had had 16 murders, and 1993's total came to 22. In addition, The New Haven Register recently ran a front page profile of Victoria Pastore, the 76-year-old mother of New Haven Police Chief Nicholas Pastore, who told reporters she was afraid to leave her apartment on Derby Avenue because of the amount of drug trafficking in her neighborhood.
Still, Mayor John DeStephano Jr. often talks about the resilience of the community, and how its future is critical to the economic health of the entire region. In a recent interview in his office in the newly refurbished city hall, he said he was tired of the television and radio pundits who insist that the cities are beyond saving, adding, "In a lot of ways the cities are the better part of our nature. And, like most central cities, New Haven remains the center of commerce, art and education."
He downplayed construction projects and instead emphasized efforts by the city and Yale University to help poor neighborhoods, including a project scheduled to begin next fall that would create centers offering child care, health care, adult education, employment training and recreation seven days a week. The program is being developed by Edward F. Zigler and the staff of the Yale Child Study Center and the Bush Center in Child Development and Social Policy at Yale.
The Mayor also stressed recent plans to revitalize blighted buildings and offer about a third of the 700 abandoned buildings the city owns for private ownership.
But Mr. DeStephano and other city officials said one of the most daunting tasks has been to convince nearby towns to help the city regain its health. Many business and government leaders in New Haven tout the message of David Rusk -- an urban planner and author of "Cities Without Suburbs" (Woodrow Wilson Center, 1993) -- who says that the most successful cities in the country have succeeded in large part because they help maintain a metropolitan government enabling them to share resources with suburban towns.
The more isolated the suburban towns remain from their core city, he says, the more the entire region suffers economically and socially. Mr. Rusk, a former Mayor of Albuquerque, cited New Haven, Bridgeport and Hartford as cities that have declined because they have lost the ability to expand, due in part to state laws and the indifference of neighboring towns.
The president of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce, Matthew Nemerson, said convincing suburban residents to think of the region as one big city has not been easy, but that more people are beginning to accept interdependence.
"Throughout the country the suburbs are the strongest where the inner city is the strongest," Mr. Nemerson said. "Unless the core city is strong, you cannot expect the suburbs to survive and grow."
Mr. Nemerson and other business leaders in New Haven said they would like to see New Haven and the surrounding towns begin to share some municipal services such as public works, public safety and sanitation, which would be managed by a council made up of the mayors and first selectmen of the region. Doing so, Mr. Nemerson said, would benefit everyone. "A regional plan doesn't mean New Haven is going to take over," he said. "The city holds only 23 percent of the population in the region and only a third of the job base. The suburbs are clearly the dominant culture."
Dr. Christopher Doob, an urban sociologist and professor at Southern Connecticut State University, said if the suburban towns continue to isolate New Haven, it will reinforce racial and economic segregation and force the city to rely more and more on Federal and state aid. In the long run, he added, it would inhibit the whole area from responding to economic challenges. "It's clear that cities like New Haven are at the crossroads," he said. "And the next couple of decades are critical."
Sergeant Randall said he would continue to revitalize the city from within. It's a job that requires patience and versatility. One day he might supervise neighborhood children who visit his substation to use the library there that is sponsored by St. Raphael's Hospital. On another day, he will meet with landlords anxious to clear the front of their buildings of prostitutes and drug addicts. ("If you didn't rent to them, they wouldn't be there," he tells them.)
On a recent day, he sat outside a crack house on Winthrop Avenue and watched a drug dealer who has been arrested many times. "The court system has got to change," he said. Later, he responded to complaints that a boy was shooting a BB gun from a window. He found the child and returned him to his mother. Back at the substation, he scanned a fax sent to him by a resident who wanted an abandoned car removed from his neighborhood. A few minutes later he was off again. As he drove along Day Street, he thought a moment about the graffiti on the side of the former Malley's building, then said, "The key is people pulling together. We all have to try to keep New Haven's children from crying."

HEADLINE: Job Performance Belies Disability Myths

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

DATELINE: RYE BROOK

 BODY:
DISPELLING myths is a good way to celebrate National Disability Employment Awareness Month.
At a recent breakfast reception, sponsored by Arrowwood Conference Centers, the job performance of those who received the 1994 Westchester Achievement Awards showed that given employment opportunities, people with disabilities are eager to become a valuable part of the work force. 
 As for the myths, they are barriers that interfere with giving people with disabilities a chance to work. To wit:
Myth: Employees with disabilities have a higher rate of absenteeism and tardiness than other employees.
Fact: "Not true. If anything, my employees who are 'developmentally challenged' are so glad to work that they are almost never absent. And they come in early and would stay late if we would let them." Those are the words of Jonathan White, a former engineer who started the Egg Farm Dairy in Peekskill last April. It produces high-quality butter, clabbered cream and handmade cheeses. "Our products have already won first and second prizes in the 1994 American Cheese Society competition," Mr. White said. "The methods we use are old-fashioned, they go back 100 years. Most of the handwork, molding the cheeses and filling butter molds, is monotonous and repetitious. I got in touch with a training center, and they set up interviews with people in a sheltered workshop, and we hired and trained three of them. I'd say they are better workers than anyone else. They are absolutely committed to the job and take great pride in their work."
Myth: People with disabilities are unable to become self-employed.
Fact: "Two years ago, I had a hiking accident, which left me a quadraplegic," said Serge Ciampa, who lives in Hastings-on-Hudson. "Before the accident, I had a successful business designing, manufacturing and installing refrigerator systems for private and commercial yachts. Now except for limited arm movement, I have no function below my neck. I'm in a wheelchair, and I lost the use of my hands. The thought of being self-employed and productive again seemed impossible. But then I was referred to Vesid."
Vesid, is the acronym for the New York State Vocational and Educational Services for Individuals with Disabilities, sent Mr. Ciampa to Choice Center, a training facility in New Rochelle.
"At the Choice Center I was put into a computer multimedia and desktop training program," he said. "Now I'm able to type using a splint, which is fastened to the palm of my hand. With the multimedia technology, I can use my Apple MacIntosh computer to produce text, high-quality color graphics and designs with sound tracks for reports, presentations and proposals. With it, I'm able to create simulations, prototypes and interactive animation for engineering and scientific visualization."
Mr. Ciampa is now a successful entrepreneur, running a profitable business. "Not only do I have my old customers back, but I have new ones," he said. "With my new skills, I am providing sales and technical support to boat builders, charter fleets, marinas and boat yards. I'm also able to do layout design on new equipment installations. I work with Ocean Air, a marine refrigeration and air-conditioning contractor in Mamaroneck. I receive a percentage of the total job."
Mr. Ciampa is also creating an animated instructional presentation, which incorporates technical writing, to produce how-to videos on installing electrical refrigeration and air-conditioning systems for his marine customers. "This will help me market and sell equipment directly to the consumer," he said.
Vesid serves people with a broad range of disabilities, said Gina Wander, a Vesid job-placement specialist in White Plains. "A variety of services, including vocational evaluation and counseling, are available to disabled people so they can meet the labor needs of employers," Ms. Wander said.
Brian Mazzitelli, the manager of the Lord & Taylor restaurant in Eastchester, said he employs two disabled workers. "I wish I had more of them," he said. "They are marvelous. A pleasure to work with."
Chris Stelzl, the manager of the Radio Shack store in the Cross County Shopping Center in Yonkers, agrees. "For six years we think we have been fortunate to have Arthur Steisfeld, who is in his late 40's, working for us," Mr. Stelzl said. "Not only is he an excellent employee but the amount of work he does is just amazing. He works in the stock room, helps with shipping and repairs. A few weeks ago, unfortunately, he was hit by a car and he has been laid up for a time, but the point I'm making is that we had to hire two people to replace him."
People with disabilities represent a valuable resource for meeting workplace needs, said a speaker at the breakfast, Richard Drucker of the State Office of Economic Development. "We want to see people with disabilities employed in an integrated setting," Mr. Drucker said. "This can be done by employers, and it is the right thing to do. All across the state, employers have found that disabled people have the skills and the ability to become productive and dedicated employees."
Maureen McLaughlin, training supervisor for Food Emporium, said that in her experience, "Once one of our managers in our stores is convinced to take a chance and hire either a physically or mentally handicapped individual, they quickly ask me for more disabled people to work in their store. Disabled workers have proven to be so loyal, so enthusiastic and so dedicated to their jobs that they make the manager's life easier. Especially in our industry, where people jump ship so often the turnover is very high.
"By contrast, employees with disabilities really appreciate being given a chance and are totally committed to their jobs."
Jim Morra, who was hired by Mr. White to work at the Egg Farm Dairy, has been on the job for five months. For Mr. Morra, who is 33, this is his first job outside a sheltered workshop. "I pack butter and cheese, and the job is very good," Mr. Morra said. "I like it much better than the workshop. It's a good feeling to be earning money and being independent."
Through her job as manager of development at Kraft General Foods, Elizabeth Aldworth, who is legally blind, has been able to help others who are blind. With the encouragement of Gus Garcia, a Kraft manager, Ms. Aldworth has taken on a big project. She has translated the directions for Kraft puddings and gelatin desserts into Braille.
"It was a huge job," Mr. Garcia said, "but clearly an important accomplishment."
The yearly award event in which both employers and disabled employees received awards, was sponsored by the County Office for the Disabled, the Rehabilitation Network and Vesid to recognize the accomplishments of both Westchester employers and their employees, said Richard Manley, director of the Office for the Disabled in Westchester.
"Our goal is to provide more employment opportunities for qualified people with disabilities," Mr. Manley said. "We work with many nonprofit vocational-rehabilitation organizations who train disabled individuals so they can meet the labor needs of employers. Employers who are seeking help will be helped by trained counselors who will find them the right employee and provide supportive and follow-up services. Just give us a try."
For more information on programs for the disabled call the Office for the Disabled at 285-2957 or the Vesid placement unit at 946-1313.

HEADLINE: Just 1 Fight Stands Out Among 4 State Senate Races

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

 BODY:
WHEN voters in the county head to the polls on Election Day, only about a fourth of them will have a choice between major party candidates for the State Senate. Three of four candidates -- all incumbents -- are running virtually unopposed. The only real race is in the 37th District, where the Democratic candidate, Alfred B. DelBello, is vying with the Republican nominee, Vincent L. Leibell 3d, for the seat abandoned by George E. Pataki in his pursuit of the statehouse.
The lack of choice offered the vast majority of voters this year is seen by some as a reflection of a campaign finance system that gives an overwhelming advantage to incumbent legislators and discourages challengers. Incumbents enjoy perquisites like legislative mailings, large staffs wanting to keep their jobs and statewide political committees that provide financial support. 
 "There is such a bias toward incumbents that it's hard to counteract," said Amy Paulin, president of the League of Women Voters of Westchester. "Money is the key factor. It's something that campaign-finance reform would go a long way to change, but right now it's very disappointing because without two viable candidates, people become more disenchanted, more discouraged, and they think their vote isn't worth anything."
In the 35th District, Democrats put up no one against Nicholas A. Spano, Republican of Yonkers. The Right to Life candidate is Peter J. Toner. In the 34th District, Guy J. Velella, Republican of the Bronx, chairman of the Senate Republican Campaign Committee, is running on both the Republican and Democratic lines, with Thomas Byrne running on the Right to Life line. With the exception of a Right to Life candidate, Paul McEvoy, the Democrat Suzi Oppenheimer is also running unopposed in the 36th District, which she has represented since 1984.
The race between Mr. DelBello and Mr. Leibell in the 37th District is providing a choice between two very different candidates (The Right to Life Party is running Adele M. Sarlitto). The district encompasses three counties, beginning in northern Westchester and including New Castle, Mount Kisco, Bedford, Cortlandt, Lewisboro, North Salem, Peekskill, Pound Ridge, Somers and Yorktown. It also incorporates all of Putnam County and runs up the corridor of Route 22, through Dutchess County to the Massachusetts state line.
But 60 percent of the roughly 300,000 people in the district live in Westchester, a fact Mr. DelBello is banking on. (An additional 30 percent of the voters are in Putnam; the other 10 percent in Dutchess.) Mr. DelBello's name is familiar to many Westchester residents because he served as County Executive from 1973 to 1982. His name also has statewide recognition from his stint as Lieutenant Governor.
Mr. Leibell, however, has strong ties in Putnam County, which he has represented in the State Assembly for 12 years. Voter registration figures give him a powerful edge -- there are 15,000 more Republicans than Democrats in the district.
If Mr. Leibell is elected, he will join a tightly controlled Republican majority in the Senate. Mr. DelBello said that there is only a five-vote difference between the two parties, and that if elected he could join the reform-oriented Democratic minority as a voice for change.
The two candidates see the key issues in the race differently. Mr. Leibell said the No. 1 issue concerning his constituents is crime. He said he would introduce legislation similar to "Megan's Law," a bill proposed in the New Jersey State Legislature to require notifying communities of a convicted child molester moving in. Mr. Leibell also said he believed the work-release program from prisons was a failure. He said he was concerned about domestic violence and rape.
Mr. Leibell said he viewed abortion as a decision "between a woman and her doctor" but did not support Medicaid's abortion payments because no provisions were made for tracking women to offer counseling.
"If a woman comes in and has 10 state-financed abortions, and there's no counseling out there, she's going to have all sorts of emotional problems, and I feel that's my responsibility," he said.
Mr. Leibell also voted against a state assault-weapons ban, because, he said, he believed it was a Federal issue and that the New York bill was too broad in its definition of the guns to be banned.
Mr. DelBello said several local issues are driving the race -- primarily the matter of the New York City watershed and reform of the way schools are financed. On the watershed, he said a balance is needed between the environmental community, which wants to keep the water supply pristine, and developers and chambers of commerce, which believe that complying with city regulations stifles economic growth. The controversy, Mr. DelBello said, reflects a lack of a regional plan. He said the regulations should be clarified but not softened, and should be administered locally.
On education, Mr. DelBello said the state lacked vision and has lost sight of putting a priority on academic achievement. Not only is the state education bureaucracy too large, he said, but also too involved with the management of local schools.
He proposed a two-part solution for school aid: an academic component and a component for programs mandated by the state. The state, he said, should pay 100 percent of its mandated social programs, while the academic component should be shared by local and state government. He added that school aid is currently based on a political formula, not on need.
Mr. DelBello supports Medicaid payments for abortion and favors a state ban on assault weapons.
Both candidates discussed the need to open up what has been referred to as "the secret chamber" -- clandestine budgets and closed conferences.
Mr. Leibell said he believed legislative conferences should be open to the public, acknowledging that "debate has shifted away from the floor and into conference." He added: "When you come out, there's not a lot left to see. It's unconscionable that every dollar of public money is not accounted for."
Mr. DelBello questioned Mr. Leibell's willingness to buck his own party's leadership in the Senate, a party that has been well served by the current system. He said that abuses of power and the influences of special interests have rendered the Legislature incapable of addressing New York's economic decline.
"The public has lost all confidence in the New York State Legislature, and I can't blame them," Mr. DelBello said. He proposed establishing a bipartisan commission to investigate chronic abuses and develop a code of ethics for legislators.

HEADLINE: The Los Angeles Resale Market Makes a Comeback

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
ALAN MESCON, a retired teacher in the San Fernando Valley area of this city, felt anxious last month when he considered putting his late mother's house up for sale. The market for resale houses here had been notoriously weak for nearly four years.
"I had heard all kinds of stories about the market being so terrible that it would take five or six months to sell the house," he said. 
 But his fears turned out to be misplaced. His broker showed the two-bedroom, one-bath house to other sales agents on a Friday in September. By the following Monday Mr. Mescon had received two offers, each with checks for earnest money. He agreed to sell the 1,300-square-foot house for $210,000, very close to the $214,000 asked. By Tuesday, he said, the deal was "nailed down cold."
He said he was satisfied with the price, even though some real estate people had told him he could have gotten more. "It was a fair price," he said, "not a fire sale."
Sales are rising in Los Angeles, with sellers apparently more willing to resign themselves to lower prices from those of a few years ago. The pick-up in sales along with declining prices is a familiar situation in the early stages of turnarounds.
At the end of September, sales were up 13.8 percent for the year that started Oct. 1, 1993, while the median price of an existing home fell 2.8 percent, to $175,000, said TRW Redi Property Data, a real estate research firm based in Riverside, Calif.
At the peak of the market, in the summer of 1989, the median price was $225,600. But only five years earlier the median price was $116,700.
One local residential brokerage, Prudential California Realty of Beverly Hills, says its sales have risen 30 to 40 percent above last year's levels and prices in deals they have brokered have fallen 5 to 15 percent, depending on location, according to Rick Merrill, the agency's chief operating officer.
The quantity of houses available for sale is falling sharply in almost all locations, including the high-priced oceanfront Ocean Park district of Santa Monica. "I had 17 to 20 listings last year and now I am down to 6," said Alison St. Onge, a sales associate at Fred Sands Realtors. "I have never been this low. But homes are selling, so I am not complaining."
Resale activity has picked up steam elsewhere in the country as well. In the combined area of Nassau and Suffolk Counties on Long Island and the borough of Queens in New York City, sales of existing one-family homes increased by about 20 percent from August 1993 to last August, according to the Long Island Board of Realtors. Over the same period sales were up 12 percent in Chicago and 3.3 percent in Houston.
But in Greater Los Angeles prices fell about 2.8 percent from August, 1993, to last August, whereas elsewhere resale prices are holding steady or climbing, suggesting a more advanced state of recovery. In the Nassau-Suffolk-Queens area, for example, the median resale price in August remained at $165,000, the same as a year earlier, while in Chicago the median price rose 12 percent, to $154,393. In Houston it rose 0.2 percent, to $81,000.
THE phenomenon of falling prices and rising sales largely reflects the fact that sellers who had held their houses off the market are now putting them up for sale, according to Cynthia Kroll, a regional economist for the Center for Real Estate and Urban Economics at the University of California at Berkeley. They are willing to take a more realistic view of prices, she said, and the houses are moving.
The sales market had stopped cold after its surge in the mid- to late 80's in the area. Michael Edlen, an associate broker in the Pacific Palisades office of Prudential California Realty, recalled a period when prices were rising at about 2 percent a month. By the time the market had peaked in early 1989, asking prices were out of reach of even comparatively affluent households.
"Prices were really out of whack," said Stephanie Vitacco, associate broker in the San Fernando Valley office of Fred Sands Realtors. "In 1989 a young married couple with two incomes could barely afford a condominium."
Now, she said, "the same couple can afford a single-family house."
Among the couples benefiting from the recent fall in prices are Nick and Terah Tidy, who recently bought a house that had been foreclosed by a bank in the Pacific Palisades area of Los Angeles for about $440,000. Although far above the Greater Los Angeles median price of $180,000, the price is considered entry-level for the exclusive Palisades district.
The Tidys -- he owns a graphics business -- and their 3-year-old daughter were displaced by the Jan. 17 earthquake when their house in Santa Monica was deemed uninhabitable and they lived in a hotel while looking for a new one.
"We couldn't find a house in Santa Monica, where we wanted to stay, because homes were out of our price range or they needed too much work," said Mr. Tidy. "So we looked in the Palisades, where it was very possible for us to buy, because the prices had gone down."
Sales activity is being enhanced by a Federal Housing Administration program that gives earthquake victims no-money-down home loans, according to the San Fernando Valley Association of Realtors.
The association said that sales to first-time buyers commanded 44 percent of the resale market in San Fernando Valley last August, with the busiest price category being in the $140,000-to-$160,000 range. Ms. Vitacco, the sales agent, also reported strong activity in high-end homes of $800,000 and more, although the range of $300,000 to $600,000 was less robust.
Citywide, sales seem brisk in all price categories, according to Mr. Merrill of Prudential California. "The slowest category to improve is the 'upper-upper' market of $5 million or more," he said. "Other than that, all segments of the market are vastly improved over the prior year."
Despite the activity, Mr. Merrill said he was not confident that prices would soon recover. The problem, he said, was an overabundance of bank-owned homes that are being sold at discount prices, indicating that there will be "downward pressure on prices for the time being."
One possible exception is the Santa Monica beachfront, where prices start around $400,000. Ms. St. Onge of Fred Sands Realtors believes they will soon rise in value.
"My neighborhood attracts a lot of people in the motion picture industry -- creative, talented people who are trying to find what they want and are not nearly as concerned about what it costs," she said.
Ms. Vitacco, also of Fred Sands, was ambivalent about a continued flatness in home prices. As a sales person, she has benefited from the low prices, which have brought out the buyers. "I'm selling more homes than I have ever done in my seven-year career," she said.
But as a homeowner who bought her house at top of the market in 1989, Ms. Vitacco said she would like to see her own home regain some of its lost value. "Personally, I understand the meaning of depreciation," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nick and Terah Tidy with their daughter, Scarlette, at their new house in Pacific Palisades. (Michael Tweed for The New York Times)
