HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Sao Paulo

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH HEILMAN BROOKE; ELIZABETH HEILMAN BROOKE lives in Rio de Janeiro and writes occasionally for The Times.

 BODY:
Sao Paulo, South America's most important business center and the world's third most populous city, has quietly displaced Rio de Janeiro as Brazil's main port of entry. While Rio lost its last direct flights to New York this past summer, Sao Paulo has seen its schedule of direct flights to New York expand to 23 a week. This energetic, if gray, metropolis is now the air hub for business and vacation travel throughout Brazil.
The capital of a state with an economy the size of Argentina's, Sao Paulo is home to 17 million people and headquarters for most of Brazil's banks and leading corporations. In a change from Rio, visitors to Sao Paulo typically have more cause to don a business suit than a bathing suit, but as in Rio they should be cautious when walking the streets. With Brazil's economy rapidly opening to foreign investment and trade, more and more of the visitors filling hotels here are Americans. 
 Long a magnet for immigrants from Germany, Italy, Japan, Lebanon, Portugal and Spain, Sao Paulo exhibits a surprising ethnic richness and has some of Brazil's finest restaurants. And as a center for art, music, dance and sports, the city increasingly rivals Rio, Brazil's traditional cultural capital.
Sao Paulo will get a new link with Rio next month when the refurbished luxury Silver Train begins making the overnight trip 300 miles up the coast. To be inaugurated Nov. 18, the train will offer a leisurely alternative to the Ponte Aerea, or "Air Bridge," a shuttle that connects Brazil's two largest cities. The train will depart from Estacao da Barra Funda at Rua Mario at 8:30 P.M. several days a week and arrive in Rio at 6 A.M.. Departures from Sao Paulo will be Monday, Wednesday, Friday; from Rio, Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday. The fare is yet to be determined.
 
Events
 Since 1951, Sao Paulo has been host to the Sao Paulo Bienal, which presents an opportunity to view the latest in Latin American art, as well as work by artists from all over the world. The 22d Bienal opened Oct. 12 and closes Dec. 11. Piet Mondrian, Diego Rivera, Kasimir Malevich, Robert Rauschenberg and Julian Schnabel are among the more than 200 artists from 70 countries whose works are on display in the three-mile gallery space designed by Oscar Niemeyer in Ibirapuera Park. The exhibit is open Tuesday to Friday, 2 to 9 P.M.; Saturday and Sunday, 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. Admission is $4.60, calculated at the rate of .87 reals to the dollar.
One of Brazil's most important art collections, the Sao Paulo Art Museum, 1578 Avenida Paulista, 251-5644, is within walking distance of some of the city's best hotels. Paintings by Rembrandt, Van Gogh, Picasso and Goya are among the museum's treasures, and temporary exhibits of Brazilian artists and private collections provide additional incentive to explore this homely concrete art museum. Until Dec. 18, the second-floor gallery is showing 350 works of foreign artists, including Georg Heinrich von Langsdorff, Albert Eckhout and Jean-Baptiste Debret, who painted scenes of Brazil while traveling through the country from the 1500's through the 1800's. On Sundays, an antiques fair takes place outside the museum. Open Tuesday to Friday, 1 to 5 P.M.; weekends, 2 to 6 P.M.; $2.30, except Thursday, when admission is free.
The Theater of Artistic Culture, 196 Rua Nestor Pestana, 258-3616, is a venue for musical performances. (The country code for Brazil is 55, the city code for Sao Paulo is 11.) Shows start at 9 P.M. Concerts are scheduled on Monday, Tuesday and/ or Wednesday, plays on weekends. The New World Symphony, conducted by Michael Tilson Thomas, will perform works by Beethoven, Brahms, Mozart and the Brazilian composer Heitor Villa-Lobos Nov. 13 and 14. Tickets are $46 to $115.
 
Sightseeing
 Avenida Paulista is worth a stroll. Once an elegant residential row for Brazil's most powerful industrialists and coffee barons, the 1.4-mile-long boulevard still displays architectural vestiges of its neoclassical past. While chrome and glass have generally replaced gracious columns and balustrades, a few turn-of-the-century houses have been preserved. There is even an unexpected McDonald's in a restored house at 709 Avenida Paulista. The recently restored Casa das Rosas, 37 Avenida Paulista, 251-5271, is now used as an exhibition space, with small exhibits on loan from museums and collections throughout Brazil. Tuesday to Friday, 1 to 7 P.M.; Saturday and Sunday, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.; free.
A patch of Atlantic rain forest, the Trianon Park, at 949 Rua Peixoto Gomide, is just off the avenue. Here, marmosets can be seen clinging to trees around the park. No admission.
To truly appreciate the essence, the size and the wealth of Sao Paulo, visitors can get a bird's-eye view from the Banespa building, at 24 Rua Joao Bricola, 604-1013. You must take two elevators and walk up three flights to a 36-story observation deck that on a clear day offers a 25-mile view. The Municipal Market and the Industrial Palace, built in 1924, are within sight. The deck is open weekdays, 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; free.
 
 
Where to Eat
 Reservations are usually necessary in Sao Paulo restaurants; credit cards not always accepted. A 10 percent service charge is often included in the bill.
Thanks to the city's sizable Italian population, Italian restaurants are popular as meeting places for both dining and negotiating. At Fasano, 1644 Rua Haddock Lobo, Jardins, 852-4000, bankers, politicians, artists and writers enjoy crab and endive risotto, lamb with rosemary vinegar and wild rice or ravioloni stuffed with buffalo mozzarella and topped with fresh tomato sauce. Dinner for two with wine is about $138.
Massimo, 1826 Alameda Santos, Jardins, 284-0311, whose innovative menu changes daily, is particularly crowded at lunchtime. A dinner of classic carpaccio, veal in wine sauce with polenta, tiramisu and a modest Italian wine for two is $182.
Sao Paulo's Liberdade neighborhood is home to one of the largest Japanese populations outside of Japan and serves sashimi, sushi and yakisoba at half Tokyo prices. At Sushi Yassu, 98 Rua Tomas Gonzaga, 279-6622, diners slip off their shoes and sip sake. Yakisoba (sauteed vegetables, meat or seafood with noodles) is particularly good here. A combination of sushi and sashimi and sake for two is $72.50.
For a taste more typically Brazilian, Fogo de Chao (Camp Fire), at 6824 Avenida Santo Amaro, Santo Amaro, 247-8786, is a rodizio, where waiters dressed in the cowboy attire of the pampas present diners with skewers of sizzling sausage, rump roast, chicken livers and fillet. Dinner draws a business crowd, while weekend lunch (around 2 P.M.) resounds with boisterous family reunions. Desserts include papaya and pineapple creams. The rodizio with all accompaniments, but no drinks, is $18.40 a person.
Truta Rosa, 318 Avenida Vereador Jose Diniz, Boa Vista, 247-8629, specializes in fresh and smoked rainbow trout. Diners cross a four-step bridge over an indoor brook to reach a trout bar. Smoked trout quiche, rainbow trout sashimi and a carpaccio of trout are among the appetizers. Cappeletti filled with trout, basil, tomatoes and shiitake, and trout roasted in coarse salt and bacon, are among the creative presentations. Trout for two with a local wine is $37.
For thin-crust pizza, Paulistas gather at Cristal, 551 Rua Professor Artur Ramos, 816-6227. Cristal has a number of restaurants throughout the city, but this address is the original. Two individual pizzas and draft beer are $19.30.
 
 
Where to Stay
 The Caesar Towers Higienopolis, 66 Rua Aracaju, 289-7200, fax 825-7409, is a hotel with 38 one- or two-room modern apartments in pastel colors -- all with kitchens. There is also a pool, a sauna, a Japanese restaurant and a coffee shop. Doubles are $120.
The 156-room Eldorado Higienopolis, 836 Rua Marques de Itu, 222-3422, fax 222-7194, offers elegant surroundings. Built in 1977, the hotel has a large, ornately decorated lobby with marble columns, a restaurant, a bar and a pool. Doubles, about $138.
Budget: Planalto, 117 Avenida Casper Libero, 227-7311, fax 227-7916, is in the downtown Centro neighborhood. The 272-room hotel, with mirrors and marble floors, has a restaurant and coffee shop. Double rooms are $118, plus 10 percent tax.
Luxury: L'Hotel, which opened in June less than a block from Avenida Paulista at 266 Alameda Campinas, telephone and fax 283-0500, offers a haven of understated European refinement and excellent service. Among the 84 sumptuously furnished rooms are three suites; all rooms have adapters for cellular phones, laptops and fax machines. Doubles are $390.
The Maksoud Plaza, 150 Alameda Campinas, 253-4411, fax 253-4544, also ideally situated, is considered one of the city's best business hotels, with 420 comfortably furnished rooms. There is a 24-hour executive service center with translation and secretarial services, fax, telex and copying machines, as well as six restaurants, a theater and a nightclub. Doubles are $352.
 
 
Night Life
 The weekly magazine Veja Sao Paulo and the newspapers Folha and Estado are the best places for finding out who is singing, dancing or playing on a given week. The Municipal Theater, Praca Ramos de Azevedo, Centro, 283-4012, is the traditional turn-of-the-century setting for ballet, opera and orchestra performances. Tickets from $23 to $103.50. Performances start at 8:30 or 9 P.M.
International stars such as Diana Ross usually play at the Olympia, 1517 Rua Clelia, 252-6255. Brazil's world-famous singers and songwriters, such as Gal Costa and Leila Pinheiro, can be heard at the Palace, 213 Avenida dos Jamaris, Moema, 531-4900, which can seat as many as 1,700 people. Ticket prices depend on the artist; there is no minimum drinks charge. Shows begin Thursdays at 9:30 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays at 10 P.M.; Sundays at 8 P.M.
The city's discos are particularly fashionable among local residents on weeknights. Resumo da Opera, Eldorado Shopping Center, 3970 Avenida Reboucas, 211-2411, has a twin in Rio de Janeiro; both have D.J.'s playing international pop music for a young crowd. Admission: $10.35; minimum $10.35.
Columbia, 1570 Rua Estados Unidos, Jardins, 282-8086, close to many of Sao Paulo's best restaurants and bars, is also a trendy place to dine and to dance. Admission: $11.50; minimum, $5.75; 10:30 P.M. is the time to make an appearance on the dance floor.

HEADLINE: How Veddy

BYLINE: By Hugh Brogan; Hugh Brogan is the R. A. Butler Professor of History at the University of Essex in England.

 BODY:

MRS. THATCHER'S MINISTER
The Private Diaries of Alan Clark.
By Alan Clark.
Illustrated. 421 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $30. 
 THE immortal diarists -- Samuel Pepys, say, or Harold Ickes -- are those who give their daily experience the color and drama of a strong personality. It is easy to write a dull diary about great events; the master diarists can excite us about the fate of a bird or a night in a bad hotel. Alan Clark is among the classics. He was a Conservative Member of Parliament for 18 years and a minister of the crown for eight. He is not, apparently, a nice man. Though he has some redeeming traits, the only words really suitable to describe him are unfit for a family newspaper; he himself observes in his introduction to this selection from his journal that his entries are "sometimes lacking in charity; often trivial; occasionally lewd; cloyingly sentimental, repetitious, whingeing." Never mind; they are also funny, moving, scandalously indiscreet and written with a mastery of language that compels admiration and attention. It is not in the least surprising that the diaries have been a best seller in Britain.
From the American point of view, however, "Mrs. Thatcher's Minister" has one serious drawback. The diaries are so very English. Before Mr. Clark was a politician, he was a very good military historian. As a scholar he knows what is needed to help the reader, and has taken immense trouble, putting ample notes at the foot of virtually every page. But the world he describes is so esoteric, and his language likewise, that no one who does not know England well can possibly understand everything. For instance, there are repeated references to "my boxes." British readers do not need to have this explained; all know that Government papers are circulated to ministers in red boxes, which have to be emptied before the victim can go to bed. How many American citizens know this?
On the other hand, any patient reader is likely to get the message in the end, so often are the boxes mentioned; so perhaps anyone tempted by the prospect of seeing Margaret Thatcher's Government from the inside, as recorded by an immensely intelligent writer, should simply plunge in. The human interest is intense, and as the pages turn, the slang, the nicknames, the literary, political and journalistic allusions, the bureaucratic jargon will become sufficiently comprehensible. And the patient reader will be rewarded by sharing a richly awful experience.
For Mrs. Thatcher's administration was a snake pit. Perhaps this is true of all democratic governments, but the reflection does not make the spectacle of politicians (all supposedly on the same side) plotting against one another seem less crazily fascinating. Some allowance must be made for the diarist's character. He is the son of Kenneth Clark, the famous art historian, and has inherited, along with his father's money and his castle in Kent, his father's fastidiousness. He regards most other human beings as loathed inferiors. Perhaps his colleagues were not, individually, quite so odious as he shows them; but collectively they emerge as nothing but a gang of selfish mediocrities, scurrying around, biting and snapping, as their country's power, prosperity and happiness, for which they are responsible, ebb fast away. And they were ruled by "the Lady," a woman so passionately unreasonable, and increasingly so domineering and so far removed from reality, that in the end they got rid of her, thinking (or at least saying) that she was insane. One of Mr. Clark's most brilliant passages describes a confrontation with Margaret Thatcher in which she scuppers a cherished measure for animal welfare. At such moments he plays H. R. Haldeman to her Richard Nixon.
Yet the total effect is more comic than dispiriting, because Mr. Clark sees so much and writes so well. Once, for instance, he is jolted into a moment of self-knowledge. He confronts a demonstration of unemployed workers, and "one man . . . looked dreadfully thin and ill. He had a nice brindle greyhound on a leash, but it looked miserable too. . . . Uncomfortable, I thought what Soames and I can spend between us on a single meal at Wiltons." ("Soames" is a grandson of Winston Churchill.) He records Margaret Thatcher's letting fall an aphorism worthy of Mayor Richard J. Daley: "I've learned one thing in politics. You don't take a decision until you have to." He complains that entertaining friends is too difficult: "It's so expensive, with good claret at 100 -- minimum -- per bottle." There are a hundred other such give-aways. This is an ideal bedside book, like all the great diaries.

HEADLINE: Where's the Money?

BYLINE: By Lawrence S. Ritter; Lawrence S. Ritter is the John M. Schiff Professor Emeritus of Finance at New York University. He is the author, with William L. Silber, of "Principles of Money, Banking, and Financial Markets."

 BODY:

A PIECE OF THE ACTION
How the Middle Class Joined the Money Class.
By Joseph Nocera.
464 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $25. 
 ONLY a generation ago, financial decisions required little thought. To earn interest, you took your money to a bank and opened a passbook savings account. For dividends or capital gains, you bought shares of Ma Bell or I.B.M. And to pay for everyday expenses, you either dug into your wallet or else wrote a check on your commercial bank checking account; until 1980, only commercial banks were allowed to issue checkbooks.
Now things are different. A savings account is no longer the only choice open to thrifty households -- money market deposit accounts, negotiable order-of-withdrawal accounts and money market mutual funds offer alternative opportunities. More adventurous investors no longer have to like AT&T or I.B.M. in order to make a killing; there are mutual funds tailored to suit any taste, as well as an array of index funds and stock futures and options that allow you to buy or sell groups of stocks, or even the whole stock market, all at once. And for daily expenses, we can all be as aloof as the Queen of England, who is said to carry nary a farthing in her purse. Nowadays credit cards are often more convenient than either currency or checks, and in an emergency, automatic teller machines stay open around the clock.
In "A Piece of the Action," Joseph Nocera, a financial columnist at GQ magazine, traces how we got from yesterday to today. He emphasizes the role of double-digit inflation in the 1970's in making middle-class households interest-rate conscious, the restless revolutionaries in double-breasted suits who unearthed ways to circumvent restrictive Government regulations, and the philosophy of financial deregulation that took hold in the Carter Administration and gained momentum in the Reagan years.
For example, Mr. Nocera notes that money market mutual funds might never have come into existence in the 1970's if it had not been for Government regulations that kept an unrealistic lid on the interest rates that banks were allowed to pay. Depositors became upset because Government-imposed interest-rate ceilings prevented them from getting market yields on their savings. Even banks that wanted to pay market rates in order to keep their old depositors, or attract new ones, were not allowed to do so. Bank certificates of deposit carried market interest rates only if they were in denominations of $100,000 or larger. Depositors with a few thousand dollars turned to Treasury bills to get a better yield, but the United States Treasury countered by raising minimum bill denominations from $1,000 to $10,000.
In that atmosphere of frustration, money market mutual funds were created by entrepreneurs who saw an unfilled need and figured out a way to satisfy it. They gathered together the funds of many small savers, in batches as small as $1,000, and packaged them in amounts large enough to meet the minimum denomination requirements of certificates of deposit, Treasury bills and other money market instruments. Since money market mutual funds were brand-new and politicians had not yet had a chance to shackle them, they were free to offer competitive interest rates.
Technology, the traditional stimulus to change in business and industry, is powerful in financial markets as well. Mr. Nocera shows how the computer explosion created the foundation for financial innovation. It would be impossible to have automated teller machines without computerization of the deposit and withdrawal functions. Nor could credit cards have become so ubiquitous without the instant storage, retrieval and transmission of vast amounts of information. Computers have revolutionized the speed and cost of processing data, with financial consequences that are probably still in their infancy.
MR. NOCERA is especially fascinated by the flamboyant group of talented innovators who dreamed up the concepts, tried to figure out which would work and which wouldn't, and embarked on stormy shakedown cruises of the new financial instruments. We get to know, among others, the fun-seeking Charlie Merrill, who dreamed of "bringing Wall Street to Main Street" and in 1914 founded the firm that would become Merrill Lynch; the handsome Gerry Tsai, the first celebrity mutual fund manager; the mercurial Dee Hock, who ran Bank of America's (later Visa's) credit card operations from 1970 to 1984; the quiet Ned Johnson, the head of Fidelity, who actually did bring Wall Street to Main Street; the brilliant Peter Lynch (not related to the Lynches of Merrill Lynch), the former manager of Fidelity's Magellan Fund and the most successful of all mutual fund managers, and the mathematics and computer genius Andrew Kahr, inventor of Merrill Lynch's cash management account and the Schwab One Account, who still found time to devise the ingenious concept of a "nonbank bank."
The "nonbank bank" idea had enormous ramifications. Above all, it undermined the functional separation of commercial and investment banking, a bedrock financial principle that had been sacrosanct since the enactment of the Glass-Steagall Act in 1933. Commercial banks are defined in the statutes as institutions that both accept demand deposits and make business loans. Mr. Kahr reasoned that by dropping one of these functions, usually the making of business loans, institutions could transform themselves into "nonbank banks" -- that is, they could continue to deal in checking accounts but no longer be bound by the numerous Government restrictions that had historically confined the activities of commercial banks.
Once the Federal Reserve Bank gave its reluctant approval to the "nonbank bank" concept, "the consequence," writes Mr. Nocera, "was that companies felt restrained only by the limits of their own imagination." Thus Bank of America promptly acquired Charles Schwab & Company, a discount brokerage house; Merrill Lynch, Dreyfus and Prudential-Bache bought commercial banks, and Security Pacific National Bank bought a seat on the New York Stock Exchange. With banks in the securities business and brokerage houses in the banking business, it soon became difficult to tell one kind of financial institution from another.
"A Piece of the Action" is not a complete financial history of the last quarter-century, nor does it pretend to be. International monetary problems, the savings and loan debacle, junk bonds, leveraged buyouts, insider trading and derivative financial instruments (options and futures) are hardly mentioned. Mr. Nocera sets out to demonstrate "how the middle class joined the money class" and he does just that: credit cards and mutual funds have indeed, for better or worse, transformed the spending and saving habits of millions of middle-income Americans. More than 70 million households use credit cards today. There are 4,900 mutual funds, and they hold assets of more than $2,000 billion. The assets of mutual funds exceed that of life insurance companies or savings institutions. How it all happened is a story worth telling, and Mr. Nocera narrates it admirably, with rare insight and considerable flair.

HEADLINE: The Trouble With Multiculturalism

BYLINE: By Leon Wieseltier; Leon Wieseltier is the literary editor of The New Republic.

 BODY:

DICTATORSHIP OF VIRTUE
Multiculturalism and the Battle for America's Future.
By Richard Bernstein.
367 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25. 
PLURALISM is hard, for individuals and for groups. In the United States, however, we have been so vain for so long about pluralism that we have forgotten its hardships. Pluralism, after all, is premised not only on difference, but on the proximity of difference: another way to live is never out of mind in America, because it is never out of sight. The sidewalks are crowded with incommensurabilities. You live and work and play with people for whom your view of the world is nonsense, or worse.
Exclusiveness is an illusion when experience is so porous, when everything is everywhere. There is no safety in numbers. There is safety only in sameness; and so pluralism frequently provokes noisy fits of sameness. The recent movement in culture and politics known as multiculturalism is one of those noisy fits. It will pass, but it will come again. It is a regular feature of the American situation. Multiculturalism claims to originate in a fear of homogeneity, of an erasure of the particular by the general; but in truth it reflects a fear of heterogeneity, which is a classically American fear.
It should be obvious, as an empirical matter, that American society has been, for at least a hundred years, a multicultural society. A multicultural society, however, produces multicultural individuals. And multicultural individuals, from the standpoint of the ancestral group and the inherited tradition, are lost individuals, and fallen. They join, in their persons, influences and instructions that were not supposed to be joined. The American problem for groups and traditions has been to retain the tolerance of the country and the loyalty of their sons and daughters. And so the ideal of traditionalists in the United States is a multicultural society of monocultural people, an American nation that is nothing more than a peaceful association of conformities. They believe in an impossible union of insularity and democracy. But their mixture of tolerance in the street and intolerance in the home often comes to ruin, and so they, the free and strung-out communities of America, panic. They read, and eat, and marry, inconsistently with their own.
Richard Bernstein has written a study of panic. It is itself, unfortunately, a little panicked. "Dictatorship of Virtue" is a weak and important book. Its importance is owed to its author's indefatigability. A cultural correspondent for The New York Times, Mr. Bernstein has documented in detail the extent to which the attempt to promote "diversity" has stifled diversity, and the attempt to rectify racial and sexual stereotyping has reproduced it. Mr. Bernstein roams widely across the boardrooms and the newsrooms and the classrooms of America, where he has discovered (and, in a few cases, thinks that he has discovered) the gutting of the meritocratic vision by racial and sexual preferments.
His most harrowing tales, however, come from the embattled precincts of American education. In Washington, an educational consultant complains that "many educators fail to recognize important cultural differences between Europeans or Euro-Americans and Africans or African-Americans," and proposes to turn back the hegemony with a curriculum according to which "Africans know through symbols, imagery and rhythm, while Europeans know through counting and measuring." And there is this example of politically and sexually enlightened pedagogy on the campus: "The number of seconds required to perform a six-week vacuum aspiration abortion was recorded for a sample of six such abortions," a professor of mathematics at the State University of New York tells his students. "The results were as follows: 84, 100, 80, 85 and 84. For this sample, find: (a) The mean and the median. (b) The range, the variance and the standard deviation." Never mind that the professor was so smitten with the righteousness of his six examples that he gave only five results. Mr. Bernstein misses the mistake, but he is perfectly on the mark in noting that "here is a way to impart political points of view without bothering to have to defend them or discuss them."
Mr. Bernstein has grasped also that there is something new about the contemporary panic. Multiculturalism has contributed an emphasis to the repertory of American resentments, and that is the vanity of victimhood. It is a fine thing that the oppressed (or their descendants) no longer feel shame about their predicament; but many of them have gone all the way from shame to pride. This, of course, plays right into the hands of their predicament, by promoting it into the foundation for a politics and a culture. Lachrymosity, for individuals and for communities, has became exhilarating. Scars have become signatures; and the prevailing notion of honor requires that scars not heal. Self-reliance is no longer an American characteristic, when the work of one's hands is interpreted as the successful seizure of what one is owed. For many of the angry and animated people whom Mr. Bernstein has visited, there is no advancement, there is only restitution, and the restitution for racial and sexual oppression will never be complete.
Since it is impossible for one's pain to be understood with precision by someone else, it is the better part of social wisdom to be patient with misunderstanding; or the efforts even of good people will be experienced as insults. But patience is disappearing from the United States, and our public life is becoming a brawl of insults. Of course, insulting with impunity used to be one of the distinguishing marks of a democracy; but Mr. Bernstein offers instance after instance of individuals and institutions in America who refuse to suffer what he nicely calls "the normal offenses of everyday life," who would rather tamper with the freedom of others than thicken their own skins. His accounts of sensitivity training in the workplace and on campus are especially discouraging.
The problem is that Mr. Bernstein's gift for anecdote is greater than his gift for analysis. He despises multiculturalism, but he is not exactly sure what it means. In one chapter it is the "derapage," or the skid, of liberalism, and in another chapter it is the "secret victory" of the counterculture. (For Mr. Bernstein, everything to the left of the right is pretty much the same.) He wishes to seem a reasonable man, advocating no more than "a certain common-sensical approach" and observing that multiculturalism is merely "far too much . . . made of a few useful insights"; but then he is put in mind of Robespierre, and then in mind of Mao, and then in mind of Stalin. Such analogies rattle the reader's confidence in the reporter.
Mr. Bernstein's anger at the multicultural burlesque of pluralism is, much of the time, not at all misplaced, but it also gives way before a troublesome complacence, as when he remarks about the systematic destruction of the Indian population of America that "history is often a tragic process." There is no crime that cannot be marginalized with a reference to tragedy, and it is a strange retort to those who insist upon the essential guilt of America to insist upon its essential innocence.
Mr. Bernstein handles ideas coarsely. When he turns from the work of the journalist to the work of the intellectual, he makes mistakes. "Reify" is not a "New Age academic term," as anybody who sets out to write about the contemporary convulsions in the humanities should know. Worrying about cultural relativism, Mr. Bernstein flirts with false and ugly notions about the superiority of some civilizations over others. (From the fact that all civilizations are not the same it does not follow that they are not "equal.") And he believes that multiculturalism represents a revival of what he calls, much too suavely, "that discredited 19th-century concept called Marxism." This is preposterous. Multiculturalism will make no revolutions and establish no concentration camps; and compared to the tribal mystifications of race and gender, the economic simplifications of Marx are the sterling stuff of universalism.
Many of Mr. Bernstein's stories fill one with horror. Good people have suffered, personally and professionally, at the hands of the anti-egalitarians. Still, multiculturalism in America does not amount to a "New Consciousness," or to any kind of cultural conspiracy. You would not know from Mr. Bernstein's melodramatic book that the anti-egalitarians are meeting decent and fierce resistance. Or that they are, finally, divided against themselves: nobody ever responded to the temptations of an open society by resisting them completely.
The airless, cheerless order of the diversity police will be defeated by the diversity of the land in which they have prospered. Many things are possible in America, but the singleness of identity is not one of them. This is what Mr. Bernstein's villains, and also some of his heroes, do not see. The dream of liberalism was not the multicultural society, it was the multicultural individual; and in America the dream came true.

HEADLINE: What Those Figures on New Jobs Really Mean

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Statistics Reveal Bulk of New Jobs Pay Over Average" (front page, Oct. 17) leaves a misleading impression that the economy has recently been creating large numbers of very high-paying managerial and professional jobs. 
 While it is true, as the new Bureau of Labor Statistics figures show, that a large fraction of the new jobs created in the last few years have been in those categories, you did not discuss two other important facts.
(1) Most of the new managerial jobs are in very low-paying industries (for example, lodging, retailing and fast food restaurants) with average compensation considerably below the average of all existing managerial jobs.
(2) Many of those in newly created professional jobs were victims of corporate downsizing. For lack of other opportunities, they have become self-employed consultants, in most cases earning far less than when they were employed full time.
This helps explain why the increase in average hourly pay for all workers since 1990 lags far behind the rate of increase in the 1960's and 1970's, even though the economy is now considered to be at or close to full employment. Indeed, as the graphs in your article indicate, the growth in average hourly compensation since 1990 is barely higher than during the 1980's, which was by far the worst decade for employee compensation since World War II.
The bottom line is that while living standards in the United States may be slightly better than during the 1980's, they are on average improving only marginally at best, lagging far behind the gains that were made in earlier decades. This is partly because a large fraction of the new jobs that are being created provide relatively low compensation, despite the opposite impression left by your article.
 
LAWRENCE CHIMERINE
Managing Director, Chief Economist
Economic Strategy Institute
Washington, Oct. 20, 1994

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE MAYOR;
Giuliani Takes Political Roles In Other States

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
After rarely venturing out of New York City for the first nine months of his mayoralty, Rudolph W. Giuliani stood last week in the grand white living room of a home in the Detroit suburbs flashing grin after grin as local Republicans posed for pictures beside him, Michigan's Governor and the Republican candidate for state attorney general.
Mr. Giuliani was just moving into his fund-raising pitch for the long shot in the attorney-general race, John A. Smietanka, when a man murmured a number -- the size of New York City's budget gap. "What?" Mr. Giuliani asked. "Our deficit? We're going to overcome it." He mentioned cost-cutting and privatization before turning his focus back to the out-of-town politics. 
 While New Yorkers wonder will he or won't he support the Republican contender for governor, George E. Pataki, Mr. Giuliani has stepped gingerly onto the national political trail, endorsing Republicans in his own image: those who favored the Federal crime bill, or support abortion rights, or once served, as he did, as a Federal prosecutor.
He has visited Connecticut, New Jersey and Detroit and plans to stump for candidates in Massachusetts and Rhode Island. He has used some of his appearances to spell out a vision of a more centrist Republican Party, one that will recognize that it is now electing big-city mayors and will be more responsive to urban concerns.
And two weeks ago in Atlanta, Mr. Giuliani told Republican women to fight to remove the anti-abortion plank from the national party platform in 1996 -- taking his message to the backyard of Representative Newt Gingrich, the more conservative Republican who is the House minority whip and may be the Speaker if Republicans win a majority in the House.
The travel comes at a time when Mr. Giuliani's failure to back Mr. Pataki has riled Republicans across New York State. Some see the endorsements as a way to assure his party that he is a loyalist while at the same time making ties he could need if Mr. Pataki wins and threatens to eclipse him as the up-and-coming New York Republican.
Mr. Giuliani calls the timing coincidental and says he would have supported the out-of-state candidates no matter where he stood in the New York race.
He said that several of the candidates, like Mr. Smietanka, a former Federal prosecutor, were friends from his days in the Justice Department. Over all, he said, the group was largely what he would describe as "fiscal conservatives and social moderates" who he thought would be sympathetic to the concerns of New York City.
"The more relationships that I can develop, the more people you can win over, it makes it much easier to call on the phone and explain to them the position that New York City can be in," he said in an interview. "The more of this that I can do and do strategically, the more effective I can be if fights like the crime bill come up again."
Mr. Giuliani is not the only newly elected Republican out on the campaign trail. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey had preceded him to Michigan and was the star attraction at Mr. Pataki's Manhattan fund-raiser last week. It is not lost on Republican officials that it is such early steps on the political hustings that help a future candidate build visibility and a base of support.
"You help people and you help yourself," said Chuck Yob, a Republican national committeeman from Michigan who was helping shepherd Mr. Giuliani through the Detroit suburbs last Tuesday.
Mr. Giuliani deflects questions about his ambitions. "I have a simple view about the future -- try to do your job the best you can," he said. "I don't think that in a job like mayor you spend a lot of time thinking about the future or you make a big mistake."
His aides and political advisers, however, openly speculate about a possible governor's race or Vice-Presidential bid.
But can a Republican Mayor of New York City remain mainstream enough for his own party? While Mr. Giuliani's fiscal conservatism is in line with Republican economic policies, the Mayor has increasingly struck a course that has put him at odds with other Republicans -- whether it be stumping at President Clinton's side for the Federal crime bill or flirting politically with Mario M. Cuomo, the Democratic Governor, at a time when Republicans have their best shot at the Governor's Mansion in Albany in 12 years.
And recently, as he has maintained that New York does not get its fair share of Federal aid, he has used Mr. Gingrich's Georgia as an example of a state that gets more than its share. During his first months in office, Mr. Giuliani often referred instead to President Clinton's Arkansas in such a context.
Such political independence has caused Mr. Giuliani's popularity ratings to rise in predominantly Democratic New York City. But some officials wonder whether he is hurting his ability to seek a higher office in the Republican Party, making comparisons to John V. Lindsay, the city's last Republican Mayor, who was re-elected on the Liberal Party line and later became a Democrat.
"You have to be a different kind of Republican to be elected Mayor of New York City," said Guy V. Molinari, the Republican Borough President of Staten Island, who broke with Mr. Giuliani over his support for the Federal crime bill.
"But you can't change overnight and become a Republican with a capital R and expect the party statewide and nationwide to embrace you. There are too many other Republicans out there with solid credentials who have first call."
Mr. Giuliani's description of Mr. Smietanka's credentials last week on a Detroit radio talk show provided a glimpse at how he may be trying to position himself in an era in which voters are angry at government and suspicious of politicians.
He spoke of "a time in which people want someone who can make decisions, as opposed to what I think they describe as someone with a total political background, someone who has been in politics, their whole career is politics."
With Republicans divided and expected to be in a battle to define their party's soul in 1996, Mr. Giuliani has also been calling for a centrist party that would find positions in favor of gay rights and abortion rights palatable.
At a breakfast meeting in Atlanta with Republicans who favor abortion rights, Mr. Giuliani said a political party that favored laissez-faire government in fiscal affairs should also allow people to make choices in their personal lives.
"For a party which has such a strong belief in economic choice -- which really comes out of the notion of freedom -- it would seem to me that it would be entirely consistent that that choice would also extend to the most personal and difficult decisions that people have to make," he said.
"What we have to do is get as many people back to the center of the Republican Party as possible," he said. "I believe that is a battle that will be fought out over the next two years, and frankly I think it will determine whether we win the Presidency, irrespective of the position that President Clinton is in right now. With very, very few exceptions, you can't win Presidential elections by appealing to extremes. You win Presidential elections by appealing to the broad goals of the American people."
For now, as a Republican Mayor of New York City, Mr. Giuliani is a curiosity. With Mr. Smietanka at his side, Mr. Giuliani fielded questions from Ronna Romney, a talk show host back on the airwaves after her recent narrow loss for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate from Michigan.
Mrs. Romney, a feisty conservative whom a local columnist described as having a tongue that could "strip the varnish off the living-room floor," showed none of her tough side in questioning Mr. Giuliani. She asked about his son, Andrew. Whether the Mayor goes to bed wondering if he is really up to the job. Whether it is harder to be Mayor of New York or Los Angeles.
"I think that when you won, it was really the beginning of perhaps a historical breakthrough in politics in America," Mrs. Romney said, unabashedly confessing during a break that in this particular interview she was not playing hardball.
Mr. Giuliani was able to use his air time on WJR to enunciate a Jack Kemp-style vision of home ownership for the urban poor and to say that the election of Republican mayors like himself give the party "a new opening, a new opportunity, and some of the programs of the party now have to open up to the cities, to make themselves relevant to cities."
There were a few signs that Mr. Giuliani, who may seem slightly right of center in heavily Democratic New York City, felt the balance shift on him among Republican circles in Michigan. He remained quiet when Mrs. Romney made an off-air sardonic reference to homosexuals in New York's St. Patrick's Day Parade. But when she said she would like to see prisoners packed four to a cell to make prison "a really lousy experience," he interrupted.
"Now there's another aspect of that," he said. "If you were the prison warden or the prison guard, you would have a concern that the conditions of a prison not be so lousy because a prison that goes below, let's say constitutional, standards, it's obviously a dangerous prison."
Afterward, the talk-show host said she was impressed. "If his accomplishments in New York are measurable," Mrs. Romney said, "he should be someone we should look at."

HEADLINE: Welfare Mothers Find Jobs Are Easier to Get Than Hold

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Poor women leave the welfare rolls for jobs much more often than was previously thought, but the low-paying and sometimes unattractive work rarely provides a long-term solution to dependence, according to several recent studies.
Most of the women soon quit or lose the jobs and return to the welfare rolls. The reasons for leaving work can be as varied as economic problems, like low wages or the loss of insurance, and personal difficulties, like drug abuse or fights with bosses. 
 And at an employment program here near Cabrini-Green, the vast housing project, many women cite a complication rarely noted in official debate: jealous interference or even physical assault by boyfriends who felt threatened by the prospect of their independence.
The frequent cycling on and off the rolls challenges the common perception of a welfare mother as a woman who has never worked. And it suggests that Congress faces a doubly difficult challenge as it seeks to overhaul the system -- not simply getting women into jobs, but keeping them there.
The women at Project Match, the employment program here, can recite long lists of jobs they have won and lost in between lengthy sojourns on public aid. They have bottled lotion, changed hotel beds and worked at convenience stores. They have fried hot dogs at horse tracks and cruised the aisles of catalogue warehouses on roller-skates, filling customer orders.
Most of the women complained that the low-paying jobs left them nearly as poor as they had been on welfare, and in some cases caused them to lose their children's health insurance. But many also faulted themselves, lamenting what they called their bad attitudes or insufficient drive.
The most extensive study of welfare cycling comes from LaDonna A. Pavetti, a researcher at the Urban Institute in Washington. Ms. Pavetti found that 64 percent of the women coming on the welfare rolls for the first time left within two years. But more than three-quarters of those who left welfare eventually returned, and 45 percent returned within a year.
The policy implications of Ms. Pavetti's work are up for grabs. Some people have argued that the data make the case for placing strict time limits on assistance. They say the cycling shows that jobs are available but that welfare recipients lack the perseverance to keep them.
But others cite the cycling phenomenon to criticize time limits. They say it shows that the women are already motivated to work but are thwarted by forces beyond their control. The way to bolster employment, these people say, is to offer health insurance, child care, transportation and wage subsidies, so that jobs become profitable.
Roslyn Hale, one Project Match participant, can serve as a case study of the difficulties of leaving welfare, having landed and lost a succession of jobs for reasons that alternately invite and discourage public sympathy. She worked as a hotel maid in the nearby business district for several years, she said, but lost the job after a fight in which she was accused of physically threatening her supervisor.
She then got a checkout job at a convenience store. But it required her to work the overnight shift, where drunks from a nearby bar taunted her and one threatened her at knife point. She left and found work at another convenience store, where she felt safer. But business took a downturn, and Ms. Hale was laid off. Now, at the age of 30, she is again supporting her 4-year-old son on a grant of about $270 a month, along with food stamps.
Sometimes Ms. Hale blames economics for her problems. "All the low-class jobs mostly start for you at minimum wage," she said. And sometimes she blames herself. "I have an attitude," she admitted.
But most of all, she stresses that simply landing a job is no guarantee of gaining a foothold on a middle-class life. "I have worked, gotten on aid, worked, gotten off aid," she said, describing the pattern that prevails throughout her neighborhood.
Ms. Pavetti has refined much-publicized studies done by David T. Ellwood and Mary Jo Bane, former Harvard University professors who now are Assistant Secretaries at the Department of Health and Human Services.
Mr. Ellwood and Ms. Bane found less fluctuation than did Ms. Pavetti because they used a different database, one that recorded whether a person had received aid in a given year. But Ms. Pavetti examined month-by-month records and found that women sometimes hopscotched on and off assistance several times in a year.
All three researchers studied the main Federal welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, which now supports more than 14 million people.
Ms. Pavetti's work has also unearthed new information about why women leave the rolls. The earlier studies had estimated that of those who left, only 21 percent did so because they found work, while 30 percent left because they got married.
But Ms. Pavetti's study found that work was by far the most common reason for leaving the rolls, accounting for 46 percent of all exits. And other recent studies, using different data and time periods, have come up with even higher estimates.
Scholars generally used to divide welfare recipients into two categories, long-term and short-term, but Ms. Pavetti's work has led them to discuss a large third group: cyclers.
Ms. Pavetti estimated that about 40 percent of the women who began a welfare spell went on to fit the cycler category. They collected checks for more than 24 of the next 60 months, although their use of the system was intermittent. By contrast, only 18 percent became long-term users, collecting checks continuously for the five years that Ms. Pavetti examined. And 42 percent had short stays, using the system for less than 24 of the 60 months.
Ms. Pavetti noted that while long-term users were a small percentage of any group beginning a stay on welfare, they accounted for about two-thirds of the people on the rolls at a given moment.
Still, Ms. Pavetti said, researchers have little statistical basis for judging the reasons that people lose jobs. "We're only starting to understand what causes people to move on and off," she said.
Project Match has won a national reputation for following recipients after they get jobs, on the assumption that problems will arise. "People don't keep their first job," said Toby Herr, the program's director.
When researchers from Northwestern University examined the program, they found that 46 percent of the women lost their first jobs within six months and 73 percent did so within a year. Some of the reasons the researchers noted are those commonly cited by advocates for the poor, including a lack of child care or health insurance.
But they also found that the women often lacked the social skills necessary for work. Many of the women resented the authority of supervisors, quarreled with co-workers or customers or failed to report on time. Ms. Herr adds to the long list of employment hurdles interference of resentful boyfriends, some of whom even follow the women to work and threaten them. She said an overhaul of the welfare system would not work unless it found ways to also improve the employment of men.
"It's the untold story," she said. "The men are not working, and they don't want the women feeling better. They don't want to think they're not needed anymore."
Sitting in the Project Match office, Vanessa Williams agreed with Ms. Herr's theory, explaining how she had lost a succession of jobs because of disasters with men. She quit once, she said, because the man she was living with was using her absence from the house to throw drug parties, when he was supposed to be baby-sitting. She left him, found a new boyfriend and landed a job at an automotive glass company that paid $8.50 an hour.
But she said her new boyfriend also began using drugs. When she put him out by changing the lock, he knocked down the door, then burned it and beat her so badly that "I thought I was dead." Ms. Williams, who is 34, said she quit working "because he used to come to the job and threaten me."
Often, the women who leave jobs do so because they encounter several problems at once. When Alesia Waits explained why she left her telemarketing job, for instance, she first stressed the loss of health insurance. Her daughter injured herself by dropping a radio on her toe, and Ms. Waits, 26, found herself with a $131 hospital bill. Reclaiming her insurance by returning to welfare, she said, "was a real relief."
But she also explained that she found the job dreary and the pay low, at $5.25 an hour. The men on the other end of the telephone would sometimes turn the conversation from sales to sex. She got only two bathroom breaks every five-hour shift, she said, and her supervisor kept her under close watch. "I believe she was prejudiced," she said.
After another stay on welfare, Ms. Waits is now back at work, earning $7.50 an hour at a racetrack concession stand, where she enjoys the company of her customers and the other workers. The job offers health insurance, and the government provides child care.
"You have to like where you're working at," she said. "And like the money. And have the benefits. And get a baby sitter. Then there's no reason for you to go on welfare."

HEADLINE: TRAINING OF POLICE IN HAITI HAMPERED BY PERSONNEL GAP

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT with JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's plan for maintaining order in Haiti has been thrown into jeopardy by the disappearance of most of the 7,000 Haitian soldiers and police officers who were to be candidates for a temporary force, senior American military and civilian officials say.
But with no good alternative, the United States is plunging ahead with a patchwork system in the hope of allowing American troops to hand off policing duties, which they accepted only reluctantly. 
 Justice Department experts are to begin training a new, permanent Haitian police force in January.
Administration officials consider the task of policing Haiti's streets to be the biggest headache in what they see as an otherwise remarkably smooth intervention.
They worry that their original plan -- to purge the existing security forces and quickly retrain them -- may be impractical because of the deep anger among Haitians who suffered under military rule. That anger has led many Haitian soldiers and police officers to abandon their posts rather than risk retaliation.
But in the meantime, the Administration is trying to coax back thousands of members of the security forces to serve in a temporary force. About 1,200 Haitians from refugee camps in the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, have been recruited and trained to be clerks and to direct traffic. And some of the police officers who did not flee are being sent from their home districts to cities where subprecincts have vanished.
American Army commanders two weeks ago tried to install new policemen in Cap-Haitien, the country's second-largest city. But a crowd of several hundred people hooted down the recruits when they recognized them as veterans of the repressive Haitian military who had served in the northern city.
Residents have cautiously accepted a second group of Haitian military veterans from elsewhere in the country who are supervised by police monitors from Argentina.
The problem of the army and police, actually one joint force, has consumed much of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide's first week back in office after three years in exile.
Appointment of a new commander is under consideration, along with the restructuring of the general staff. Earlier last week, a dozen colonels who had been important supporters of military rule were packed off to comfortable posts abroad as military attaches at Haitian embassies.
Diplomats from the United States Embassy in Port-au-Prince and aides to President Aristide are screening candidates for the interim force from military and police rosters. The officials are supposed to reject anyone with a history of human rights violations or with a criminal record.
"The notorious need not apply," Maj. Gen. David C. Meade of the Army, commander of the 10th Mountain Division, said in a telephone interview from Haiti.
But other senior American officers have expressed concern over the screening standards.
Gen. Wayne A. Downing, the head of the United States Special Forces Command, which has 1,100 commandos in rural towns across Haiti, told reporters last week: "How do you establish the cut line? That's a good question. How clean do their hands have to be?"
Just determining how many police officers are left is also a difficult question.
Asked how many police officers there are now, Col. Mike Sullivan, commander of the 16th Military Police Brigade, whose M.P.'s are stationed in police buildings, replied: "I've been trying to figure that out myself."
"Some days there might be 20 people show up at a station, some days there might be 50," Colonel Sullivan said. "We've been trying to find their rosters. Some are handwritten, some are typed with written additions. It's not a very well-organized force. It was organized for the top officers, but not for the men."
Raymond W. Kelly, the former New York City Police Commissioner who heads the 1,100-member monitoring force here, was similarly unable to tell how many police officers were still working.
"It's really hard to estimate," Mr. Kelly said. "There is a low attendance on the part of the Haitian police."
On Monday in Port-au-Prince, law enforcement experts from a Justice Department agency will begin training the first 375 candidates for the interim Haitian force. But by late last week, the screening committee had identified only 200 men who qualified, and was rushing to select the rest by the Monday deadline, General Meade said.
The agency, the International Criminal Investigative Training Assistance Program, plans to run nine one-week courses in ethics and human values, with 375 recruits in each class.
Program directors said they needed three weeks to give proper training but had been ordered to condense the curriculum into about six days because of the urgent need to relieve American troops of police duties.
By mid-December, the program hopes to graduate at least 3,000 retrained police officers who can maintain civil order until the new, permanent police force is trained next year.
But some American officials express concern about the interim force's success.
"The official line is that by March they'll have a pretty strong interim force with international monitors, but my personal opinion is that this could be difficult to execute," said a top aide to Mr. Kelly, who is in charge of 1,100 police monitors from 27 countries who will accompany the interim police officers on the beat to guard against human rights abuses.
Creating a credible, effective Haitian police force will be an uphill struggle because uncertainty has prompted many members of the military to disappear, said Robert S. Gelbard, Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters, who oversees the interim police operation.
But Mr. Gelbard, a chief advocate of the plan, and other Administration officials insist that they can eventually lure Haitian security forces out of hiding with guaranteed, salaried jobs, a coveted treasure in Haiti's devastated economy.
In addition to the former Haitian police and military, American officials have recruited and trained about 1,200 refugees from the camps at Guantanamo. The recruits, who will be unarmed "public safety trainees," received several days of training in ethics, Haitian criminal law and basic procedures. They will serve as clerks or traffic police.
In Cap-Haitien, about 25 of the trained refugees and 18 interim police officers have divided into five-man teams who began a week ago to conduct two-hour patrols throughout the city of 65,000. They work under the watchful eye of 20 Argentine police trainers, who wear distinctive yellow baseball caps.
In Port-au-Prince, a sprawling city of about a million, 27 two-man Haitian teams began patrols this week with monitors from Bolivia, Argentina, Israel and St. Vincent.
The patrols, made up of trained refugees and members of the existing police and military who stayed at their posts, increased their shifts last week to three eight-hour stints from one six-hour tour. But American soldiers still provide the main firepower to quell any serious disturbances.
Another hopeful sign, Colonel Sullivan said, was an incident several days ago in which the Haitian police led American soldiers to the biggest hidden arms cache they have found so far, a huge pile of heavy weapons hidden behind a false wall in the home of a former supporter of the military regime which was looted by crowds after he fled.
Graduates from the Justice Department training program will be assigned to beats in Port-au-Prince, Cap-Haitien and other cities and towns. One indication of how few officers there are now is that while 1,100 police monitors are committed and 600 are actually in Haiti, only 75 were working this week.
"How do you get new people in and train them properly?" General Downing said. "Let's face it, you're not going to train them in a week or 10 days. It's probably going to take six months."
Outside Haiti's two largest cities, General Downing said, the Haitian security forces have a mixed record. In some towns, the police and military have disappeared, leaving Special Forces troops to keep order. But in other communities, the general said, "respected" members of the security forces have operated well-run towns.
What Administration officials and American commanders in Haiti fear most is the possibility that the police program may falter and United States troops may end up keeping order for several months. While the Haitian people cheer American soldiers now, commanders worry that an extended presence could breed resentment, as it did in Somalia.
"There is a window," General Downing said. "There is a time when the good will will start to melt. We're conscious of it, and we're trying to play that card hard. We don't want to be there after that window closes."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE WHITE HOUSE;
Rejecting Republican Assertions, Clinton Says Fiscal Memo Is Not Policy Plan

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
President Clinton struggled today to distance himself from a memorandum, sent to him by his own budget director and leaked to the press, in which a bevy of new taxes and cuts in Medicare and Social Security were listed as "illustrative options" for future economic policy.
The disclosure -- barely two weeks before midterm elections -- stirred glee among Republicans, who immediately asserted that Mr. Clinton was plotting to skirt promises to leave Social Security and Medicare benefits alone. 
 The White House first defended itself with a statement from Mr. Clinton's chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, insisting that the memorandum was but a "catalogue" of proposals from elsewhere, and not a policy document. But tonight in Seattle, the President paused during a weekend of campaigning to offer his personal explanation.
"I do not support cuts in Social Security, and I believe any savings we achieve in the Medicare program should be used in health care," Mr. Clinton said. "That has always been my position. There is nothing in that memo and nothing in the record which should indicate that I have changed my position on these two fundamental issues."
The President said the memorandum arose from internal talks about an imminent report by a Presidential commission headed by Senators Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, and John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri. The panel studied entitlement spending and the Republicans' "Contract with America," a political tract that commits the party to cut taxes while balancing the Federal budget.
The denials did not wash with Republicans, who were given the memorandum by an anonymous Federal worker late last week.
"Hypocrisy is the word that comes to mind, as it occasionally does with this Administration," said William Kristol, who heads a research group called the Project for the Republican Future. Mr. Kristol, an adviser to former Vice President Dan Quayle, said he had given a copy of the memorandum to The Washington Post, which reported on it today.
The Oct. 3 document, from Alice M. Rivlin, the budget director, and entitled "Big Choices," bears the earmarks of a political working paper. Marked "draft" and "for handout and retrieval in meeting," it is written on unmarked white paper.
In it, Ms. Rivlin stated that the decisions made in the 1996 budget preparations that begin this week will be crucial to Mr. Clinton's re-election. And she suggested that officials make difficult decisions soon if they hope either to control the Federal deficit, which is projected to begin rising again in 1996, or to free up additional money for the President's domestic agenda.
The paper outlines an "illustrative range of packages" for the future economic course. They range from continuing present policies and allowing the deficit to rise again, to making a commitment to erase the Federal deficit by the year 2000 -- which, over five years, would require $689 billion in new taxes or spending cuts, or both.
Ms. Rivlin made no recommendations in the memorandum, except to note that two developments this summer had made the need to chart a clear course more urgent.
First, she wrote, the demise of health care legislation leaves the White House without a clear strategy to rein in the deficit. Second, she said, the Republican contract, however hollow and filled with "empty promises" it may appear to the White House, offers voters "attractive-sounding tax cuts" as an alternative to Democratic policies.
"Our attacks on the Republicans for evasiveness about how they would pay for their 'contract' have been effective, but they make it imperative that we continue our established policy of explicit and paid-for proposals," she wrote.
Whether the White House wants to reduce the deficit, finance new initiatives, or both, Ms. Rivlin wrote, budget writers have but three places to find money, none of them attractive.
The first is from new cuts in discretionary spending -- that is, programs like highway building and education aid that, unlike welfare and Medicare, are not mandated by law. "Congressional resistance is strong," she wrote, and a new Congress may decide to cut the discretionary programs that Mr. Clinton prizes most, like the new national service corps.
The second source of money is new taxes. "The anti-government mood probably precludes any general-purpose tax increase," Ms. Rivlin wrote, but some taxes tied to specific purposes -- like a tobacco tax tied to health care changes -- might win support.
The third source, she wrote, is cuts in entitlement programs like Federal retirement benefits, Social Security, Medicare and farm subsidies.
The choices for Medicare, Social Security and other benefit programs, labeled "illustrative entitlement options," are diverse. One is to freeze or reduce annual cost-of-living adjustments, saving $109 billion over five years. Another would save $270 billion by capping most benefit spending except for the cost of new recipients and inflation.
The memorandum ended by stating that the options, from doing nothing to balancing the budget, are "illustrative packages that may serve to start our discussion." Senior officials said they were nothing more.

HEADLINE: Lessons in Rebounds From G.M. and I.B.M.

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR with JAMES BENNET 

 BODY:
It seemed like two of the world's most troubled companies had finally gotten it right. In hard-won turnarounds, General Motors and I.B.M. were bouncing back from disastrous losses and just about everybody, from customers to investors, was cheering.
But last week, the cheering turned to frightened silence at G.M., when it reported a worrisome loss in its crucial auto business in North America despite soaring sales. Though the company reported an overall profit, the disappointing loss in North America, G.M.'s first in nine months, prompted a panicky stock selloff on Wall Street and doubts throughout corporate America and in dozens of G.M. factory towns whether the renaissance of the world's largest industrial company was in fact on track. 
 Only minutes before the G.M. report, the International Business Machines Corporation announced its financial results, painting a much brighter picture: profit and sales were surprisingly strong and Wall Street was pleased.
The comeback of both companies has been scrutinized around the world not only because of their economic reach -- they directly employ more than 880,000 people in scores of cities and towns -- but also because for generations they have been centers of American ingenuity and industrial might. I.B.M. is the leading patent holder in the world; G.M. leads an industry that accounts for one in eight jobs in the United States.
G.M.'s setback last week suggested a divergence of fates for the two companies. But experts say that G.M.'s problems may actually serve as a cautionary lesson for I.B.M. It also illustrates the travails of reshaping a giant company after years of mismanagement in an economy where the direction has been difficult to predict.
"Six months or nine months from now, I.B.M. could be facing the same kind of hiccup that G.M. is today," said Noel Tichy, a professor at the University of Michigan business school. "Trying to transform these big corporations, really making a fundamental change in the way they do things, is very difficult."
Both I.B.M. and G.M., despite its slippage last week, seem to be making steady progress in their recovery drives, experts say. But both have benefited from a pickup in the economy, and both must hurry to get into shape before their markets turn sour.
For G.M., the timing is more closely linked to the general level of economic activity, and the next downturn in the auto business is expected in 1996. I.B.M., for its part, must rush to find new growth as its traditional business in big mainframe computers erodes.
"The jury is still out on both I.B.M. and G.M.," said Michael Hammer, a management consultant in Cambridge, Mass.
To design, make and market Chevrolets and computers are very different undertakings. But there have been some striking similarities in the fundamental changes at both companies.
Both G.M. and I.B.M. squeezed out their chief executives. The new men are tackling issues of cost-cutting, business strategy and corporate culture. At I.B.M. headquarters in Armonk, N.Y., top executives hope to avoid missteps, but they sound prepared for a lengthy, sometimes bumpy road to recovery.
"We've got a long way to go to get this company ticking again," Jerome B. York, the chief financial officer of I.B.M., said in an interview on Friday. "We understand that."
Mr. York has first-hand experience with difficult turnaround efforts. He joined I.B.M. in May 1993, after rising to become the chief financial officer at the Chrysler Corporation.
"I figure we're about three innings -- a third of the way -- into our turnaround," Mr. York said.
At G.M., executives clearly recognize that they have much hard work ahead, especially after last quarter's setback.
"Sometimes you take two steps forward and take one step back," G. Richard Wagoner Jr., president of G.M.'s North American operations, said Friday. In the early going, he said, the No. 1 auto maker benefited from some "quicker hit" savings. Now, as G.M. addresses structural problems in the way it develops cars and trucks, the savings might not be apparent for years. "You don't see the results from one day to the next," Mr. Wagoner said.
 
Starting Fresh With New Chiefs
 In November 1992, G.M. selected John F. Smith Jr., a 30-year company executive, as its president and chief executive after ousting Robert C. Stempel for failing to brake its slide. Though an insider, Mr. Smith, 56, has a reputation within G.M. as a well-traveled general manager. He was an insider more in pedigree than in mentality.
I.B.M. went further afield when it chose Louis V. Gerstner Jr., who was chairman of RJR Nabisco, to take over the troubled computer giant in April 1993. In Mr. Gerstner, 52, the I.B.M. board chose a classic general manager.
Both new chiefs cut costs with abandon. At I.B.M., payroll cuts had been made gradually since 1986, when the company's worldwide employment peaked at 406,000. At the end of 1992, the payroll was down 25 percent to 302,000 workers, with stated plans to trim an additional 25,000 or so. But Mr. Gerstner, working with Mr. York, went much further, trimming more workers and shedding plants and equipment. By the end of this year, the company's payroll is expected to be down to roughly 215,000, about half its high.
The current I.B.M. cost-cutting goal is to reduce annual expenses by about $8 billion by 1996. Last week, Mr. York said I.B.M. had already achieved savings of $5.5 billion a year.
Management experts are skeptical of the long-term benefits of just getting rid of people and plants. Instead, they say, the real benefit comes from making people work more efficiently.
"The heart of changing any big company like I.B.M. and G.M. is transforming the inbred culture -- that is where you get the fundamental improvements and the lasting savings," Mr. Hammer, the consultant, said.
Mr. York said he tried to begin that cultural change when drafting his expense-reduction plans. "You've got to get people looking outside the company at customers and competitors," he said.
So he spent his first three months at I.B.M. setting up eight cost-cutting task forces, involving hundreds of people. Their task was to set targets based on the costs of their most efficient competitors, or "benchmarks."
One result: speeding up the turnover of its computer inventory. In 1993, I.B.M.'s $10 billion inventory of computers turned over, or sold, 2.8 times a year. This year, the inventory is turning over at an annual rate of 3.5 times. "The improvement means roughly $2 billion in savings of cash not tied up financing inventory," Mr. York explained.
 
Trying Hard But Still Behind
 At G.M., Mr. Smith also cut costs by shrinking employment in North America by 74,000, or 23 percent, since 1991. Like I.B.M., the auto company has used the benchmark technique extensively to get some hidebound longtime employees to focus on matching the likes of Toyota in production costs and speed of developing a new model.
G.M. has made some impressive strides. In 1991, the company lost $10.7 billion, before interest and taxes. Last year, by contrast, it made a $362 million profit -- a swing that Fortune magazine hailed a few weeks ago as "GM's $11 Billion Turnaround."
From 1991 to the beginning of 1994, G.M. eliminated $2,800 in costs, before taxes, from every vehicle it manufactured, Harbour & Associates, a Troy, Mich., research firm, estimated.
The bad news for G.M. is that it is still far less efficient than the industry's cost leaders. That explains why Chrysler made an average of $1,000 on every vehicle it sold in the third quarter of this year, while G.M. lost $296.
That quarter is traditionally a soft time for the car makers because it includes summer shutdowns of factories for maintenance and vacations. But with the economy strong, Chrysler reported a $651 million profit, and the Ford Motor Company is expected to announce a profit of up to $1 billion on Wednesday,
The gap between G.M. and its rivals is what worries Wall Street analysts. "If you're not making money when times are good, how are you going to make money when times are bad?" asked Jack V. Kirnan, an analyst for Salomon Brothers.
Quickening the speed of product development and matching product offerings with market demand are also vital goals for recovery at both G.M. and I.B.M. Again, both companies have improved their records, but still have a way to go.
To save time and money in designing and manufacturing cars, G.M. is switching from 12 basic car platforms, or wheelbases, to 5. At the same time, Mr. Smith pushed G.M.'s designers and engineers to create cars that would be easier and less costly to make. The new Chevrolet Cavalier and Pontiac Sunfire -- two subcompacts that share the same platform -- are early examples of the change. The new cars take 20.5 hours to assemble, or 40 percent less than the models they replace. G.M. also cut the number of parts used by 29 percent and trimmed the number of suppliers by 40 percent.
Yet G.M. still takes longer to make a Cavalier than Ford takes to make cars at its most efficient plants. And while it is working to close the gap, G.M. still takes about 48 months from initial design to start-up production of a new model. That compares with 36 months for Toyota. At Chrysler, the popular Neon subcompact took 37 months to go from design to production.
And for all the progress at cutting parts and assembly time for the Cavalier, the new model is two years late. It was supposed to be introduced in 1992, but it was delayed because G.M. was short of cash.
The real problem now is that G.M. cannot get the cars produced and out of its Lordstown, Ohio, factory. Like other auto companies, G.M. is trying to equip its factories with more flexible manufacturing systems capable of switching rapidly to produce new models. Unfortunately, it still cannot make such changes smoothly. Last year, the Honda Motor Company began making a new model in three days.
But as the market for small cars surged this summer, G.M. made no Cavaliers or Sunfires for almost two months. Quality problems have continued to slow production. "A couple of times we've turned off the line when we've found something that we didn't like," said Mr. Wagoner, the head of North American operations.
 
Matching Output To Demand
 I.B.M. has had its own design and manufacturing problems -- not with quality but with keeping models and production runs in tune with demand. The problem has been most pronounced in I.B.M.'s personal computer business. Last year, for example, I.B.M. was overly aggressive in forecasting demand for its Value Point line and was saddled with some $700 million in unsold inventory.
This year, it has the opposite problem with a new multimedia personal computer, the Aptiva line, which it introduced to the home market earlier this month. Just as G.M. dealers are clamoring for Cavaliers, computer retailers and consumers cannot get their hands on I.B.M.'s new models.
"I.B.M.'s bureaucracy can't tell the difference between a hot product and a dud," said Seymour Merrin, a consultant in Palo Alto, Calif. Like G.M.'s production bottlenecks with popular cars and trucks, I.B.M. "is going to lose market share," he said.
 
Using Size To Advantage
 Both G.M.'s Mr. Smith and I.B.M.'s Mr. Gerstner have made the strategic decision to stay with the businesses they have and simply run them more efficiently. In Mr. Smith's case, the issue seems to have been more straightforward.
Some analysts have long said that G.M. was simply trying to support too many lookalike brands. Without eliminating a few, like Oldsmobile and Saturn, the company was too cumbersome to be efficient. Mr. Smith has apparently dismissed that argument. Instead, he has concluded that the efficiencies will come mainly in car development and manufacturing.
Mr. Gerstner, too, believes that big companies can be made to work, and that size can be an advantage for I.B.M. Against the advice of some industry consultants, he has kept the company together as an integrated supplier of hardware, software and services.
Many analysts say I.B.M. is still trying to do too many different things. "I.B.M. could just muddle through, but to really thrive it has to set a new standard either in hardware or services," said David Yoffie, a professor at the Harvard Business School. "That's the fundamental dilemma it hasn't really come to terms with yet."
