HEADLINE: U.S. Diplomatic Mission on 5-Nation Africa Tour

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MZUZU, Malawi, Oct. 23

 BODY:
With concern growing over possible violence in neighboring Mozambique, a senior American delegation visited this newly democratic country today as part of a five-nation African tour intended to improve peacekeeping on a continent scarred by civil wars and refugee crises.
Officials said the mission, led by Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, was a departure for American diplomacy in Africa, where Washington has decided to increase military cooperation with the growing number of countries that have switched to multiparty democracy after decades of dictatorships. 
 The effort, which centers on providing training, logistical, financial and intelligence aid to the newly democratic countries, is intended to encourage their efforts to contain conflicts in neighboring states. Officials say such conflicts threaten peace and economic development throughout the continent.
"There is no shortage of African countries willing to take part in peacekeeping efforts," Mr. Talbott said in an interview. "But they also come forward to us and say, 'We are developing countries, we have the World Bank and I.M.F. looking over our shoulders, and we don't have the capacity to do it by ourselves.' "
Mr. Talbott said that after civil wars in Somalia and Rwanda, where the United Nations sponsored peacekeeping and the United States provided airlift and other logistical support, Washington was studying the idea of providing C-137 transport planes to a regional organization of southern African countries to help them respond rapidly to crises.
In addition to talks with political leaders in Zimbabwe and Malawi, Mr. Talbott has addressed groups of soldiers and officers, telling them that "as a result of the U.N.'s being overburdened, the international community is in danger of not being able to respond quickly enough to new crises when they occur."
After visiting Malawi, Mr. Talbott's delegation will stop briefly in Zaire before going to Ghana and Ivory Coast.
Ghana, which is head of the West African Economic Community, has played a lead role in mediation efforts in Liberia. Zimbabwe and Malawi have been among the most active African countries in peacekeeping efforts on the continent, playing significant roles in Somalia and Rwanda.
In addition to Rwanda, and neighboring Burundi, where clashes have sent refugees streaming into Zaire, officials in Zimbabwe and Malawi expressed concern over the long civil wars in Liberia and Angola, and worsening political conditions in Africa's most populous country, Nigeria.
But their deepest immediate concern is over the potential for renewed strife in Mozambique, where national elections to be held on Thursday and Friday may seal the end of 20 years of civil war. The conflict has created costly refugee crises and disrupted overland transportation throughout the region.
Efforts to build a national army from the two warring sides have stalled badly, and diplomats have expressed concern over recent statements by Afonso Dhlakama, the former rebel leader, in which he has said that the only way his party can lose is if there is fraud.
International observers, who believe that the governing Frelimo party is the strong favorite in the vote, say Mr. Dhlakama's statements are ominously reminiscent of Angola's rebel leaders, who resumed their civil war after they lost that country's first national elections.
A further element of worry comes from the Association of Demobilized Soldiers, which represents 75,000 fighters from both the rebel and Government armies, and has warned of unrest if its members are not guaranteed jobs by "the politicians."
"We cannot talk about peacekeeping until we have talked about the urgent situation on the ground in Mozambique," said Malawi's Foreign Minister, Edward Bwanali, shortly after meeting here with Mr. Talbott. "After the elections there is the chance that everything will turn out all right. That is our hope, but we fear there could also be a new tragedy."

HEADLINE: At the U.N., a Drive for Diversity

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 21

 BODY:
In this parliament of 184 nations, there are few who disagree that it is time to make the Security Council, the Western-dominated power center of the United Nations system, look more like the diverse world it serves.
"It is ironic that in the midst of the rapid spread of democracy in recent years and the expanding membership of the United Nations, the Security Council remains unrepresentative in its size and the geographic distribution of its membership, and undemocratic in its decision-making and working methods," Roberto R. Romulo, Foreign Secretary of the Philippines, told the General Assembly recently. 
 Richard Butler, Australia's representative, said in an interview: "It is absolutely clear that the Security Council we have today is yesterday's Security Council. It cannot do the job we need done today and will certainly need in the future."
But how to democratize the Security Council -- whose permanent, veto-wielding members are the United States, Britain, France, Russia and China -- is the hard part. Any expansion would mean intense competition for permanent seats, and many seasoned officials here are doubtful that reform could come quickly.
Japan and Germany, the defeated nations of World War II, are the leading candidates for permanent membership in a body dominated for half a century by the war's victors. But large or increasingly rich developing nations also demand representation, saying that the world has changed too much since 1945 to justify reserving the most powerful seats for the industrialized countries of the global north.
Razali Ismail, Malaysia's chief delegate, said there was a growing estrangement between a few nations that make the big decisions and the others who are often called on to carry them out.
"There are other countries that are, willy-nilly, involved in things the Security Council does, and they want a say," said Mr. Razali, who is a member of a committee studying United Nations reform.
"The major powers are not prepared to put out the adequate number of soldiers for peacekeeping, for example, so they count on us. Malaysia has 2,700 soldiers on various fronts. We are in Somalia, in Angola, in Bosnia. Politically, it is no longer tenable for all of us to supply troops -- to pull the trigger, as it were, for the U.N. -- without having the right to say something about the process of decision making and what peacekeeping is all about."
The feeling of being manipulated by the United States, Britain and France, which have dominated the Security Council's business since the collapse of the Soviet Union, has sharpened recently around the issues of Haiti and Bosnia.
On Haiti, the Clinton Administration pressed and cajoled members to back a July 31 resolution authorizing an American invasion, although several nations had concerns about establishing a precedent for armed intervention to restore democracy. Then, barely two months later and without informing the United Nations, Washington cut a deal with the Haitian military.
In Bosnia and Herzegovina, the pace and level of United Nations operations have been largely dictated by Britain and France, which some Islamic countries believe are hostile to the Muslim-led Bosnian Government and unwilling to deal harshly with the Serbs who hold nearly three-quarters of the country.
Despite the efforts of Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate, to meet regularly with representatives of smaller nations, Mr. Razali said that "more and more people are concerned about the Security Council acting within its own context and sense of momentum."
The General Assembly, active if ideologically driven in the cold war years -- when it was generally considered a nuisance by Washington -- has been sidelined.
"As the General Assembly has been marginalized in the last two, three years, the developing nations of the south feels their input at the United Nations is almost irrelevant," said Clovis Maksoud, the Arab League's former observer at the United Nations who now heads the Center for the Global South at American University in Washington.
Questions about how to change the Security Council -- how big to make it, who should join it and how broad its functions should be -- are difficult to answer. Almost any significant change in the 15-member body, with the 5 permanent seats held by the United States, Russia, China, Britain and France, and 10 rotating seats representing major regions of the world, would provoke intense competition.
The permanent members are likely fight to keep their powerful positions, especially Britain and France, whose credentials are most frequently challenged by developing nations and former colonies. At the same time, there may be no less of a tussle among the nations of the next rank that would battle each other for the privilege of joining the club.
Jamsheed K. A. Marker, Pakistan's chief delegate, said any reform would have to avoid the appearance of establishing a new set of regional superpowers. In Pakistan's case, that means neighboring India. In other regions there would be similar rivalries.
Diplomats say a reconstituted Council should have no more than 20 to 25 members, perhaps in three rather than the present two categories, with a new group given permanent seats but perhaps no veto power. Discussions are in very early stages.
"At the end of the day we're not sure what will be required to put together a compromise," said Douglas J. Bennet, the Clinton Administration's Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs. He said that President Clinton, while still a candidate, "got the ball rolling" by proposing to add Germany and Japan to the permanent members.
Both countries, already large contributors to the United Nations, could be expected to bear a larger share of the organization's costs, which now fall heavily on the United States. Japan is openly campaigning for a seat, while Germany has been more circumspect though no less interested.
Among the developing nations, Nigeria, South Africa, Egypt, India, Indonesia, Mexico and Brazil are considered candidates.
"To have this come out right, one has to come to a conclusion that everybody regards as legitimate," Mr. Bennet told reporters recently. "It takes time to do that. At this point I don't think we've reached that."
But he added: "I am told by old U.N. hands that issues ripen here, and sometimes they ripen very quickly. Who knows, this could be one."
Washington's opinion is critical to the pace of the discussion because the United States has unequaled power to effect or block change. A reorganization of the Council would require amending the United Nations Charter, a decision that would need the backing of not only the General Assembly but also the Security Council itself. The change would also require ratification by national parliaments.
Mr. Butler, the Australian delegate, chairman of the committee organizing the 50th anniversary celebrations of the United Nations and a leader in the campaign to remodel the world forum, has been drawing possible organizational charts to prod some of his colleagues into more concrete discussions. He said the Security Council needed to be considered in a broader reform of the United Nations system "to make it fit for the challenges that we now face in this new period of world politics -- and more than politics, of world development, or lack of development."
"Today's world is beset by economic and social problems that are simply enormous," Mr. Butler said. "Because of interdependence, if they're not addressed, they could spread far beyond the countries where those problems are being experienced in their sharpest form."
"If you want to amend the Charter, you have to have a two-thirds majority in the General Assembly and ratification in national parliaments," he said. "I don't think there would be a two-thirds majority just for adding Germany and Japan. Some of those other big countries from the developing world would successfully argue that it's the wrong response for the quest for making a modern Council simply to add two more countries of the north, industrial giants."
Mr. Razali, the Malaysian delegate, concurs.
"If we get it right, then the Security Council that we will have in the future will be quite different from the one that was put together in 1945," he said. "At that time it was an elite group, the victorious powers as custodians of peace. Now, with all that has taken place, obviously that has to change."

HEADLINE: Rwandans to Receive Loan

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 21

 BODY:
To help ease a financial crisis at Rwanda's diplomatic missions in the United States, the relief group AmeriCares is planning to announce on Monday that it will lend the Rwandans $200,000 free of interest for six months.
The loan will be given "to the people of Rwanda" to be used in any way the Government chooses, said Stephen M. Johnson, the president of AmeriCares, based in New Canaan, Conn. 
 Joseph Mutaboba, Rwanda's charge d'affaires in Washington, said he hoped that this novel approach to relief would become more widely used and added:
"We need the kind of money to buy a computer, a fax, a printer, some paper. You see the kind of needs we have. If we lose our mission electricity and have no fax working, I cannot even contact my Government. We need the kind of help that will get the machinery going."
The plight of Rwandan diplomats in the United States first came to light on Tuesday when the police in New York announced that Rwanda's Acting Foreign Minister, Vianney Jean-Marie Ndagijimana, was missing, along with $187,000 in cash he was supposed to have given to Rwandan diplomats here and in Washington to pay the country's bills. Mr. Ndagijimana appears to have gone to France, but he has not been seen and there has been no news of the money.
Since the Rwandan crisis erupted in April, AmeriCares has flown about 500,000 pounds of mostly medical supplies worth over $11 million for use in refugee camps in Zaire and Tanzania and centers for displaced people in Rwanda. AmeriCares, a nonprofit organization, solicits donations to aid disaster areas.

HEADLINE: Report Says Advocacy Group Let H.I.V. Go Unchecked in Blood Products for Hemophiliacs

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Executives of the National Hemophilia Foundation understood as early as 1982 that the source of AIDS was probably a blood-borne virus that pharmaceutical companies could eliminate from the blood-clotting medicine routinely given to hemophiliacs, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported today.
But for years, the foundation publicly described the spread of AIDS through such products as unavoidable because of an early lack of knowledge about the spread of the disease, the newspaper reported. 
 Half of America's 20,000 hemophiliacs have been infected with the AIDS virus by tainted clotting factor, a concentrate of blood that stems the uncontrolled bleeding symptomatic of hemophilia, a hereditary condition. About 3,000 hemophiliacs infected in this way have died.
In reaching its conclusions about the foundation, the newspaper cited sworn testimony and documents from a class-action lawsuit that patients and their families filed last year in Federal District Court in Chicago against the foundation, which is based in New York, and four drug companies.
In July 1982, the Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta reported the first cases among hemophiliacs of what later became known as AIDS.
A doctor with the agency, Bruce Evatt, wrote that month to Louis Aledort, then the foundation's medical co-director, saying the disease was possibly caused by a virus and transmitted through blood.
"Hemophiliacs would be prime candidates to develop this syndrome," Dr. Evatt wrote.
In December 1982, Mr. Aledort asked an advisory committee of the Federal Food and Drug Administration not to require drug firms to neutralize viruses in clotting products by using processes available at the time, the newspaper said. Mr. Aledort said it would make the medicine unaffordable, and the committee did not require the neutralizing steps.
By early 1983, officials in the blood industry were questioning prospective donors of the clotting factor to try to screen out people susceptible to AIDS. A diagnostic test for the disease was not available until nearly two years later.
But in July 1983, Mr. Aledort told the drug agency that "this was not the time for recall" of unscreened clotting products, even though the foundation's board supported such an order. The board recommended monitoring, and the F.D.A. did not order a recall.
In a December 1983 memo, the foundation's executive director, Alan P. Brownstein, expressed concern about the economic harm that a recall would have on the drug industry.
And when hemophiliacs began dying of AIDS, foundation officials publicly opposed filing suits against the drug companies and even testified against patients who did, the newspaper said.
The lawsuit in Chicago asserts that the defendants continued to sell and promote the products even though they knew some blood donors posed a high risk of H.I.V. infection, said David Shrager of Philadelphia, the main lawyer for the plaintiffs.
The companies named in the suit are Rhone-Poulenc Rorer of Collegeville and its subsidiary, the Armour Pharmaceutical Company; Miles Inc. of Pittsburgh; the Baxter Healthcare Corporation of Deerfield, Ill., and the Alpha Therapeutic Corporation of Los Angeles.
Representatives of drug companies said last week that they had responded to the AIDS crisis as quickly as possible at a time when little was known about the disease and how it was spread.
"Because of the great deal of emotion and because of the enormous tragedy, there's a great deal of revisionist history," said Beth Leahy, a spokeswoman for Rhone-Poulenc Rorer. "What may seem clear now was not known then."
Drug companies have won all but 1 of 14 jury trials of lawsuits filed by hemophilia patients or survivors, she said. The 14th case has been appealed.
In the Chicago case, Judge John F. Grady of Federal District Court ruled on Aug. 5 that the issue of negligence could be tried as a class action. A week later, plaintiffs rejected a $160 million settlement offer from Rhone-Poulenc Rorer and from Baxter, the newspaper said.

HEADLINE: Social Health Is Improving, A Study Says

 BODY:
After three consecutive years of decline, the nation's social health is improving again, social scientists at Fordham University are announcing today in an annual report.
But the researchers report that the social well-being of the nation is still at one of its lowest points in 23 years. 
 The report, titled "The Index of Social Health," seeks to measure the nation's progress in addressing major social problems by analyzing 16 social issues including infant mortality and out-of-pocket health costs for the elderly.
Researchers used a computer model and data gleaned from various Federal agencies, including the Census Bureau, to reduce the nation's social health to a single figure ranging from 0 to 100, which they call the social health index.
The first report, published in 1986, measured social health retrospectively for the year 1970 and gave it a ranking of 73.8. As of 1992, the latest year for which data were available, Fordham's index stood at 40.6.
While that is 45 percent lower than the 1970 figure, it represents an improvement over the 1990 and 1991 rankings, which were 39.4 and 38.8, respectively.
"It's too early to tell if we're on an upswing, but an increase is certainly better than a decline," said Dr. Marc L. Miringoff, the author of the study and the director of the Fordham Institute for Innovation in Social Policy in Tarrytown, N.Y. "Now the question is, will it continue?"
The latest report was the first since 1987 to find 7 of the 16 individual indicator problems improving in a single year: infant mortality, teen-age suicide, high school dropout rates, drug abuse, homicide, food stamp coverage and access to affordable housing.
The problems that worsened were child abuse, unemployment, health insurance coverage, average weekly earnings, poverty among the elderly, health costs for the elderly and the gap between the rich and the poor.
Two problems remained the same: traffic deaths and the number of children being raised in poverty.
Dr. Miringoff offered two explanations for the improved index. For the first time since 1970, three teen-age social problems -- high school dropout rates, suicide and drug abuse -- all improved.
In addition, he said, the social index often rises during Presidential election years.
"We've only had an upswing eight times, and five were in election years," Dr. Miringoff said. "In an election year there is an increase in funding, which seems to confirm the fact that spending does make a difference."
This year the report included a special section that took a closer look at poverty trends among children and the elderly.
Poverty among children has worsened significantly since 1970, with 21 percent of the nation's children living under the poverty line in 1992, the highest level in nine years.
Among the elderly, the trend is more encouraging, with 13 percent of those over the age of 65 living in poverty, a drop of nearly 50 percent since 1970, when the rate was 25 percent.
Dr. Miringoff said the report was the social equivalent to economic indicators like the Consumer Price Index.
"We have nothing like that on the social sphere," he said. "In other words, bells don't go off when the children living below the poverty level goes above 20 percent, which it is. But we really pay a lot of attention when housing starts increase 1 percent."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
In Legislative Elections, Choices Are Hard to Find

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
POLITICIANS worry about survival (their own), and ruminate obsessively about the public mood (sour). They blame the economy, or the media, or immigration, or whatever else they can come up with to explain away why so many voters seem to be fed up.
It is not all that complicated. As Cassius might have advised had Shakespeare illumined the 20th century instead of the 16th, try a little introspection. 
 Consider this year's legislative elections. Yes, this is an election year for New York's State Senate and Assembly, but one would hardly know it, given the paucity of captivating races. Challenging incumbents is just too daunting.
"More people die in office than are voted out of office," said Conrad M. Foa, a Democrat and insurance company executive who is making a second try at unseating State Senator Roy M. Goodman, the Manhattan Republican.
Mr. Foa, though frustrated with the lack of what he considers adequate press coverage, remains stubbornly optimistic. But he does not argue with the obvious -- that legislators benefit immeasurably from what Kevin Sack, the Albany bureau chief for The New York Times, once described as "a virtually impenetrable quilt of self-entrenchment."
The Legislature's self-protection system works. Two year ago, 92 percent of legislators seeking re-election won; in 1990, the re-election rate was 98.9 percent. This year, though incumbents are in trouble nationwide, the results will no doubt be similar. And probably not because voters have warm and fuzzy feelings for their state representatives.

 IT'S because the voters have little choice. Most potential challengers don't bother to run, and those who do tend to be outmatched by the advantages of incumbency. The greatest is in fund-raising, since special-interest groups, with their deep pockets, favor incumbents who can thank them with helpful votes. Public campaign financing would weaken that cozy relationship, so most lawmakers oppose it.
Other advantages legislators give to themselves. They see to it that taxpayers pay for self-promoting "newsletters" that contain little news. They hire expert lawyers to redraw district lines after each census -- lines that invariably protect incumbents. And they bring home the pork, which they prefer to call "member items." But pork it is -- grants of money for local groups, from Carnegie Hall to the celebrated Museum of Cheese in Rome, N.Y.
As a recent series of articles in The Syracuse Herald-American reminded readers, legislators routinely spend public dollars on politics, be it paying the salary of a staff photographer or financing those three television studios that churn out self-serving videos of legislators for home consumption.
So well known and amply documented is Albany's incumbency protection program that legislative leaders discuss it without much apology. The 11-part series in The Herald-American barely elicited a defensive shrug from them. Sheldon Silver, the Democratic Speaker of the Assembly, notes that he has made some changes to penetrate the veil of secrecy that cloaks political spending in the Assembly. The Senate's leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Republican, has made a few even more modest concessions. But with the exception of a few mavericks, lawmakers resist the only thing that can break Albany's cozy habits -- a top-to-bottom overhaul.
Legislatures tend to be that way, especially in New York, which used to have plenty of money to throw around; legislators made sure they threw some at each other. Times have changed and the voters clearly know it. Why don't politicians?
Unless maybe they really do, but prefer to keep themselves comfortable as long as they can.
POLITICAL POSTSCRIPT: Speaking of voter disaffection, isn't it interesting how elected officials sometimes provide candid insights into themselves when they are not running for office? Maybe this annoys the public, too.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, for example, was on his best behavior when running for re-election in 1992. But in this, a non-election year for him, he created a crude scene at last weekend's ground-breaking for New York City's Holocaust memorial because he didn't like his seat. And just last week he advised the Republican candidate for lieutenant governor how to seek Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's support: "You'll make him an offer he can't refuse," he told Elizabeth P. McCaughey.
He ultimately apologized -- after first indignantly denying he ever said any such thing.
Such behavior is familiar to those who have dealt with Mr. D'Amato. There are few political reporters or rival politicians in the state who have not been the target of his undeleted expletives. And more than one woman who has crossed his path has had reason to comment on his lack of, uh, politesse. Now the voters have got a closer look.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: CALIFORNIA;
Media-Wise Governor Runs A Smooth Race in California

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SANTA CLARA. Calif., Oct. 20

 BODY:
If he had stumbled, it could have been an awkward moment for Gov. Pete Wilson's re-election campaign, but you would never have guessed it. California cool, sound-stage smooth, he gives nothing away; you can no more read his emotions in his face than see through a mirror.
His big issue is illegal immigration. He has dramatized his promises to do something about it by endorsing Proposition 187, a ballot initiative that would require the state's schools, hospitals and other institutions to deny services to illegal immigrants, who come mainly from Mexico. As the proposition has gained strength, so has he, and together they have pulled well ahead in the polls. 
 But Mr. Wilson has always had a lot of trouble with his party's right wing, and this week two leading Republican conservatives, Jack F. Kemp and William J. Bennett, both members of George Bush's Cabinet, denounced the ballot measure, describing it as "fundamentally flawed and constitutionally questionable."
Reporters caught up with the Governor in an aircraft-assembly hangar in Long Beach. Nobody had to tell him it was time to play the Beltway card.
"Those are two guys who have been in Washington too long," he said with his tight, mirthless smile. "Nice guys, but when you spend too much time in an ivory tower, you lose touch with reality. They ought to come out to California and look at the real world."
Sound bite. Next question.
"In a state as large as this," the Governor of the nation's largest state said later on board a private jet, heading north, "people don't have time for a lot of fine points. You have to be crystal clear. We think people are most deeply moved in three areas: crime and immigration -- a real sense of rage about those -- and jobs, which is their broadest, most long-lasting concern. So that's what we hit on, morning, noon and night."
Running a tightly focused, politically adept campaign has helped Mr. Wilson overtake his Democratic rival, Kathleen Brown, the state treasurer, who is the daughter and sister of former governors. So has Ms. Brown's late-starting effort, which has somehow failed to capitalize on this year's anti-incumbent mood, even though she is running against a man who has held public office without a break since he was elected to the Assembly in 1966, a man right up there in Edward M. Kennedy's and Mario M. Cuomo's and Thomas S. Foley's class when it comes to incumbency.
Mr. Wilson's own analysis was dismissive if not condescending.
"In terms of energy and polish, she's fine," the Governor said of his opponent. "But from the voter's standpoint, she's saying the wrong things."
Perhaps. Like President Clinton and other leading Democrats, Ms. Brown is opposed to Proposition 187.
But that would not have mattered much without this year's upturn in the California economy, which for Mr. Wilson could not have come at a better moment. The rising economic tide may not be lifting President Clinton's boat much, but it has floated Mr. Wilson's skiff off the rocks in the last few months.
Four years ago, having won a third solid statewide victory in eight years, Mr. Wilson left the Senate and moved to Sacramento. California's politicians, accustomed by the successes of Richard M. Nixon and Ronald Reagan to setting their sights high, began talking about him as a probable Presidential candidate.
But then came a sharp, sudden economic downturn, driven by trouble in aerospace and real estate. It quickly produced a $14 billion state budget shortfall, to which the Governor responded with a $7 billion tax increase and $5 billion in spending cuts. His approval ratings plunged, and he cut state spending further, admitting that it had been a policy as well as a political error, and a bad one, to raise taxes at a time when the California economy was in the dumps.
By the beginning of this year, the 61-year-old Mr. Wilson's prospects for a second term, let alone a race for national office, seemed close to nil.
That all seems a long time ago now. Then, he felt cornered, and it showed in his defensive explanations. Now, he feels freed, and that shows, too, as he feeds his audiences, stop by stop, day by day, little bits of evidence that California has touched bottom and is on the way back. He sounds like a chamber of commerce news release come to life.
In Anaheim, he tells them that Inc. magazine says, "Twice as many of the 500 fastest-growing entrepreneurial companies are in California as in any other state." In Santa Clara, in the heart of Silicon Valley, he quotes a bank's prediction, quoted in that morning's Wall Street Journal, that the state will grow by about 4.8 percent next year. In Chatsworth, not far from the epicenter of the Los Angeles earthquake, he talks about how many Fortune 500 companies have moved their headquarters here.
At every stop, he praises the people of California, whom he calls "the most innovative and entrepreneurial people the good Lord has ever created."
But he also praises Pete Wilson. What turned things around, he says, is his work in making California a better place to do business. He cites reform of the state's "onerous" workers' compensation laws and the efforts of his bureaucracy-fighting "Red Teams," the expansion of state export-loan guarantees and the enactment of a law allowing a 6 percent tax credit on manufacturing equipment.
Not exactly crowd-rousing items, those, but then he is not exactly speaking to crowds. There is not much glad-handing or other retail campaigning.
This is California, the media state par excellence, and like other candidates here Mr. Wilson usually appears not at rallies but at carefully scripted political mini-events, one-act plays intended to make a single point and planned with an eye to picture possibilities ("Don't get in the shot, don't get in the shot," the advance men cry at every stop when some unruly worker or onlooker strays into the camera's range).
Show business is never far away in California, and the Governor's trip this week was described, on the yellow and black cover of an explanatory document, as "Pete Wilson's Greatest Hits Jobs Tour."
Thus, Tuesday's Chatsworth visit was meant to show, as the Governor likes to say, that "California can compete with South Carolina or Singapore" when it comes to high-tech industry, and indeed the ADC Fibermux plant, which makes circuit boards for computer networks, starred in its assigned role. It looked as spotlessly clean and felt as over air-conditioned as Singapore, and it was staffed largely by Asian-Americans.
At almost every stop, someone stepped up to give Pete Wilson credit for making California government friendlier to business, a partner instead of an adversary. In Long Beach, for example, Dr. Carl Chen, the founder of Advanced Aerodynamics and Structures Inc., the first new American builder of airplanes in decades, said his company had been courted by many states and by countries from South Korea to South Africa, because of its potential for creating jobs.
"Because of Governor Wilson and his reforms, we decided to stay in California," Dr. Chen declared.
Sometimes the little shows are convincing, sometimes less so. In Santa Clara, the occasion was the announcement by Intel, the computer chip maker, that it planned to enlarge its plant here, a project that will cost $500 million and create 300 jobs. Mr. Wilson said this demonstrated once again the company's commitment to California and his Administration's success at cutting red tape.
In fact, Intel has also promised in the last 18 months to build factories costing more than $1 billion in Arizona and New Mexico, choosing those states in part because they offered better tax breaks and lower regulatory hurdles.
The details have nagged a bit at Mr. Wilson on the immigration question, too. Experts on the subject trace part of California's problem to a bill in 1986 that allows illegal immigrants to come here as agricultural workers. Mr. Wilson, then a Senator, had a hand in drafting the measure, but he insists that his version would have forced the illegals to return home after the harvest. That safeguard, he says, was dropped in the bargaining on the bill.
Looking a little like a prep-school teacher in his tweedy clothes, the Governor plows diligently through his arguments: Services to illegal aliens eat up 10 percent of the state's budget; that means fewer computers for schoolrooms and fewer new hospital beds; that is unfair to the people of California, and the Federal Government ought either to seal the border or foot the bill. Whatever else it is, this is a campaign about real issues, unlike many others this year.
On crime, Mr. Wilson takes the high road ("I am privileged to be the first Governor in the nation to sign a three-strikes-and-you're-out bill into law," he said in an Eastman Kodak warehouse in Hollywood) as well as the low. No matter what Ms. Brown says to suggest that she, too, is tough on crime, he tars her with her father's and her brother's aversion to the death penalty and their tolerance of what he terms "our absurdly lenient laws on repeat offenders."
Many of those around him, including contributors, old friends and staff members, fully expect to hear lines like that from the candidate Wilson in the 1996 Presidential campaign. California now casts nearly 10 percent of the votes in the electoral college (and a similar percentage of those at party conventions). Its primary will be early in 1996, not late, making it far more important. A victory for Mr. Wilson would place him in a distinctly strategic position.
But he insists that he will not run. Is that an irrevocable no, a Shermanesque no, a not-even-a-draft no? "It's a no," he said, adding that he was looking forward to serving out a second full four-year term in Sacramento.
He may not mean it, though he reminds people that Mr. Cuomo said, no, and made it stick. If he does shun a White House bid, one reason may be a quirk in California law. Candidates for governor and lieutenant governor run separately, and the clear front-runner for the No. 2 job this time is Gray Davis, a very liberal Democrat who served as chief of staff to Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr.
It is quite possible, Mr. Wilson allowed drily, that the voters would resent a Governor who was elected after a campaign in which he indulged in Brown-bashing only to spend a year or so traipsing around the country, leaving a Brown acolyte in charge back home.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN TRAIL;
Case of the Disappearing Running Mate

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:
Poor Stan Lundine. Even after eight years as Lieutenant Governor, sometimes it seems that nobody remembers who Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's running mate is.
A brochure promoting Mr. Cuomo's record on women's issues urges New Yorkers to "vote Cuomo/ Burstein," a reference to the Democratic candidate for Attorney General, Karen S. Burstein, who, unlike Mr. Lundine, is a woman. The signs waved at the rally where Mr. Cuomo was endorsed by the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson on Thursday read: "Cuomo/McCall," a reference to the Democratic candidate for State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, who, unlike Mr. Lundine, is black. 
 Apparently, Mr. Lundine's demographics -- he is of Swedish descent and from Jamestown, in the southwestern corner of the state -- do not rate the same attention.
 
Tax-Cutter's Defense
 After criticizing State Senator George E. Pataki for failing to provide complete details about his tax-cutting plans, Mr. Cuomo continues to withhold information about his own. Never caught without a rationale, Mr. Cuomo is providing two alternate defenses for his decision.
The first is the "I'll show you mine when he shows you his" defense, based perhaps on the belief that voters want followers, not leaders. "He's not arguing with me," Mr. Cuomo told reporters last week when asked when more details would be forthcoming. "Why do I have to show any more numbers?"
The Governor's second defense is the "I've done it" defense. He argues that the fact that he and the Legislature enacted an income-tax cut in 1987 is all the proof that should be needed that he can do it again.
"I said I would do it and we did it," he said in Buffalo earlier this month. "You want more details? What's better than that?"
Mr. Cuomo acknowledges that the final phase of the 1987 tax cut has been repeatedly canceled, but says he warned the Legislature at the time that the cut was too deep. He signed the bill, he says, because he was confident his veto would have been overridden.
 
Dueling Endorsements
 Governor Cuomo won the editorial endorsement of Newsday yesterday, gaining a trophy to match the one Mr. Pataki gathered last week from The Daily News.
Newsday said Mr. Cuomo had "never lived up to the high promise of his soaring rhetoric and breathtaking intellect," but it credited him with guiding the state through "the worst economic slump since the Great Depression."
It said it was easy to understand why, after 12 years, many New Yorkers feel it is time for a change. But the paper also praised Mr. Cuomo's "unquestioned integrity, tenacious energy and a burning commitment to do good."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Circulation Losses Go On at New York Papers

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
The daily circulation of New York City newspapers is continuing a slide that began more than a year ago, according to new data supplied by the publishers of the four big metropolitan area papers.
In the six-month period that ended Sept. 30, Newsday, The New York Times and The Daily News all saw their average weekday circulations decline from the corresponding period last year. Newsday saw particularly sharp declines in Long Island as well as New York City, with the daily circulation of its New York City edition shrinking by 37,425, or 13 percent, to 230,150. 
 The New York Post, which was in chaos a year ago, recorded a modest increase in daily circulation to 405,300, up from 394,431 in the corresponding period in 1993, reflecting a return to a measure of stability.
The Sunday News showed a circulation gain of 4 percent, to 964,030, the only sign of significant growth among the four papers during the period. Newsday and The Times, meanwhile, lost Sunday circulation; The Post does not have a Sunday edition.
But even with the indications of new stability at The News and The Post, each of the four large New York City area newspapers has a smaller circulation now than it did two years ago, the information from the publishers shows. The combined average Monday-to-Friday circulation of the four papers has slipped more than 150,000, or 4.9 percent, since 1992.
Taken together, the numbers show that newspaper circulation in the country's biggest media market is shrinking again, after it had appeared to be leveling off several years ago.
In interviews, newspaper publishers attributed the falling circulation to lack of consumer confidence, reader resistance to higher newspaper prices and increasing competition from cable television, on-line computer services and other electronic information sources. Even the baseball strike and the lack of riveting news events like the Presidential election were cited as possible explanations.
Whatever the cause, some industry watchers say they worry about signs that newspaper circulation nationally, which was stable in the 1980's, may have begun a new plunge.
"I think it is part of a 50-year trend that has made the newspaper less important in the life of the American family," said Everette E. Dennis, executive director of the Freedom Forum Media Studies Center at Columbia University.
The data from the four New York newspapers provided an advance look at statistics to be released early next month by the Audit Bureau of Circulations, an independent organization that issues circulation reports for the nation's newspapers every six months.
The group's new report is being awaited with special anticipation because the last report, for the six months that ended March 31, showed unexpectedly sharp declines at most large newspapers across the country from the comparable period a year earlier. According to Media Industry Newsletter, a trade publication, 38 of the 60 biggest newspapers in the country, or nearly two-thirds, lost daily circulation.
Some newspaper executives said last year's harsh winter contributed to the broad circulation declines for the six months that ended March 31. But some industry analysts say that even if the speed of the circulation decline slows, there are indications that circulation may be shrinking over the long term.
The rate of circulation decline at The New York Times has slowed from 3.4 percent in the period that ended March 31 to 2.3 percent in the latest period, when the paper's average daily circulation was 1,114,900. The rate of decline of The Times's Sunday circulation of 1,724,700 has also slowed, from 2.4 percent to 1.8 percent.
William L. Pollak, a Times executive vice president, said the newspaper was fighting the circulation declines, though he said The Times's advertising sales force was focusing on such factors as the high income levels and the educational backgrounds of the paper's readers. Mr. Pollak said some of the circulation declines might be related to recent price increases for both home delivery and newsstand purchases.
Still, Mr. Pollak said, The Times's executives see the paper's declining circulation as "bad news" and are hoping that the rate of decline will continue to slow, both locally and nationally.
The publisher of Newsday, Robert M. Johnson, acknowledged that his paper had seen a sharp drop in circulation, affecting even its base on Long Island. The paper's total circulation fell 7.3 percent in the latest six-month period, to 693,556. Newsday's total Sunday circulation fell 5.5 percent, to 779,629, the first time it has been under 800,000 in recent years.
Though a majority of Newsday's losses were inside the New York City limits, Mr. Johnson said the circulation figures did not indicate any weakening in the paper's commitment to build a competitive New York City newspaper.
Mr. Johnson cited three reasons for the circulation declines. He said the paper had intentionally reduced sales at some low-volume newsstands because it was too costly to service those outlets. He said the paper had also been increasing the price paid by readers in an effort to get more revenue from circulation sales, which may have driven away some newspaper buyers.
And Mr. Johnson said unsettled labor relations were a third cause of declining circulation. He said a demand by management that the paper's unions work to lower the paper's labor costs had led to some unhappiness among some of the paper's production workers. The result, he said, is that the newspaper often arrives late to newsstands, reducing sales.
At The Daily News, Fred Drasner, the co-publisher, said the increase in Sunday circulation reflected the returning vitality of his paper. He also noted that the Sunday paper, which costs $1, was the least expensive Sunday paper in the city. The News has also promoted its Sunday paper heavily and added new features, including a full-color television guide.
As for the loss in daily circulation, Mr. Drasner said he believed that consumers were still uncertain of the economy, slowing the number of publications they buy regularly at newsstands. And, he said, there were some signs that the baseball strike had cut into The News's circulation.
At The Post, Martin Singerman, the publisher, said the circulation gain of 10,869 a day in the latest six-month period showed that the newspaper was returning to health, although he said it was still losing money. "In a climate when newspaper circulations are going down," he said, "it speaks for itself."
Mr. Singerman did acknowledge, however, that about 4,000 of that added circulation had been gained on Staten Island, where The Post has increased circulation by cutting its price in half, to 25 cents, in an experiment to attract readers.
The Post's current circulation of 405,300 is still well below its circulation of 437,918 in the corresponding period in 1992, before Rupert Murdoch swooped in to save the paper from extinction.
